Vertical Midco GmbH, a Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung organized under the laws of Germany (the “EUR SSN Issuer”), is offering €750,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of its
% Senior Secured Notes due 2027 (the “SSN EUR Fixed Notes”) and €1,000,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of its Floating Rate Senior Secured Notes due 2027 (the “SSN EUR FRN
Notes” and, together with the SSN EUR Fixed Notes, the “SSN EUR Notes”). Vertical U.S. Newco Inc., a corporation organized under the laws of Delaware (the “USD SSN Issuer” and, together
with the EUR SSN Issuer, the “SSN Issuers”), is offering €1,250,000,000 (USD equivalent) in aggregate principal amount of its % Senior Secured Notes due 2027 (the “SSN USD Notes”
and, together with the SSN Secured EUR Notes, the “Senior Secured Notes”). Vertical Holdco GmbH, a Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung organized under the laws of Germany (the “SUN
Issuer” and, together with the SSN Issuers, the “Issuers”), is offering €400,000,000 (USD equivalent) in aggregate principal amount of its % Senior Notes due 2028 (the “SUN USD Notes”
and, together with the SSN USD Notes, the “USD Notes”) and €650,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of its % Senior Notes due 2028 (the “SUN EUR Notes” and, together with the
SUN USD Notes, the “Senior Notes”). The Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes are collectively referred to herein as the “Notes.” The proceeds of the offering of the Notes (the “Offering”)
will be used in connection with the financing for the proposed acquisition (the “Acquisition”) of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG (the “Target”) by Vertical Bidco GmbH (“Bidco”), an affiliate of the
Issuers.
The SSN EUR Fixed Notes will bear interest at a rate of % per annum, the SSN EUR FRN Notes will bear interest at a rate equal to EURIBOR (with a 0% floor) plus % per
annum, reset quarterly, and the SSN USD Notes will bear interest at a rate of % per annum. The SUN USD Notes will bear interest at a rate of % per annum and the SUN EUR
Notes will bear interest at a rate of % per annum. The Senior Secured Notes will mature on, 2027. The Senior Notes will mature on, 2028. The Issuers will pay
interest on the SSN EUR Fixed Notes, the SSN USD Notes and the Senior Notes (collectively, the “Fixed Rate Notes”), as applicable, semi-annually in arrears on each of and
, commencing on, 2021. The EUR SSN Issuer will pay interest on the SSN EUR FRN Notes quarterly in arrears on each of,, and
, commencing on, 2020.
Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, the Initial Purchasers (as defined herein) will deposit the gross proceeds of the Notes into segregated escrow accounts (the “Escrow
Accounts”) in the names of the Issuers but controlled by the Escrow Agent (as defined herein) pending consummation of the Acquisition, and pledged on a first-ranking basis in favor of the
Trustee (as defined herein) on behalf of the holders of the relevant series of Notes. The release of the escrow proceeds will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that
the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within two business days). The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to the
satisfaction of certain conditions, including, among others, certain regulatory approvals and the performance of certain closing actions. If the conditions to the release of the escrow
proceeds have not been satisfied on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date (as defined herein) or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory
redemption. The special mandatory redemption price of the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts,
if any, to, but excluding such special mandatory redemption date.
All or a portion of the Fixed Rate Notes may be redeemed at any time prior to, 2023, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the relevant series of Notes
redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date plus a “make-whole” premium, as described in this offering memorandum.
Prior to, 2023, the Issuers may in each calendar year redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of the Fixed Rate Notes (including any additional Fixed
Rate Notes of the same series) at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the
redemption date. At any time prior to, 2023, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of Fixed Rate Notes may be redeemed with the net proceeds of one or
more specified equity offerings at a redemption price equal to %, %, % and % in respect of the SSN EUR Fixed Notes, SSN USD Notes, SUN USD Notes and SUN
EUR Notes, respectively, in each case, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, provided that at least 50% of the aggregate
principal amount of such series of Fixed Rate Notes remains outstanding after the redemption (unless all Fixed Rate Notes of such series are redeemed substantially concurrently). The
Fixed Rate Notes may be redeemed at any time on or after, 2023, at the redemption prices set forth in this offering memorandum.
All or a portion of the SSN EUR FRN Notes may be redeemed at any time prior to, 2021, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the SSN EUR FRN
Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date plus a “make-whole” premium, as described in this offering
memorandum. The SSN EUR FRN Notes may be redeemed at any time on or after, 2021, at the redemption prices set forth in this offering memorandum.
Upon the occurrence of certain defined events constituting a change of control or upon certain asset sales, each holder of Notes of any series may require the relevant Issuer, as applicable, to
repurchase all or a portion of the Notes of such series at a price equal to 101% of their principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the
redemption date. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if, pro forma for such change of control, a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in
connection with such event. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, each Issuer may elect to redeem all, but not less than all, of the relevant series of Notes.
On the Issue Date and subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will be guaranteed by the Issue Date
Guarantors (as defined herein) on a senior basis and senior subordinated basis, respectively. Within 150 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date (as defined herein), subject
to the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein) and substantially simultaneously with the guarantees granted in favor of obligations under the Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured
Notes and the Senior Notes will be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors (as defined herein) on a senior basis and senior subordinated basis, respectively.
On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes, and the relevant Note Guarantees (as defined herein) will be secured by (i) a first-ranking pledge over the relevant Escrow Accounts and (ii) subject to
the Agreed Security Principles, on a first-priority basis by security interests in the SSN Issue Date Collateral (as defined herein). Within 150 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing
Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with the obligations under the Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured by the SSN Post-Closing
Collateral (as defined herein, and together with the SSN Issue Date Collateral, the “SSN Collateral”). The SSN Collateral will also secure the Senior Facilities on a first-priority basis. On the Issue
Date, the Senior Notes and the relevant Note Guarantees will be secured by (i) a first-ranking pledge over the relevant Escrow Accounts and (ii) subject to the Agreed Security Principles, by
security interests in the SUN Collateral (as defined herein). The SUN Collateral will also secure the Private Senior Notes (as defined herein). The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees
and the security and the liability of each Guarantor (as defined herein) and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on
_the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The security interests in favor of the Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances._

**European Economic Area and the UK**

**_Prohibition of Sales to EEA or UK Retail Investors_**

The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or
otherwise made available to any retail investor in the EEA or the United Kingdom. For these purposes, a retail
investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of
MiFID II; or (ii) a customer within the meaning of Directive (EU) 2016/97 (as amended or superseded, the
“Insurance Distribution Directive”), where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in
point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II. Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU)
No 1286/2014 (as amended, the “PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them
available to retail investors in the EEA or the United Kingdom has been prepared and therefore offering or
selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA or the United Kingdom
may be unlawful under the PRIIPs Regulation.

This offering memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of Notes in any Member State of the
EEA or the United Kingdom that is subject to Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 of the European Parliament and of the
Council of 14 June 2017 (as amended, the “Prospectus Regulation”) will be made pursuant to an exemption
under the Prospectus Regulation from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of the Notes.

Notwithstanding the United Kingdom’s departure from the European Union, any references in this offering
memorandum to European Union law should be treated as references to such law as applies in England and
Wales from time to time including as retained, amended, extended, re-enacted or otherwise given effect on or
after 11:00 pm on January 31, 2020.

**_MiFID II Product Governance_**

Solely for the purposes of the manufacturer’s product approval process, the target market assessment in respect
of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is eligible counterparties and
professional clients only, each as defined in MiFID II; and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to
eligible counterparties and professional clients are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or
recommending the Notes (a “distributor”) should take into consideration the manufacturers’ target market
assessment; however, a distributor subject to MiFID II is responsible for undertaking its own target market
assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining the manufacturers’ target market assessment)

**PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL INFORMATION**

**The Issuers**

The SUN Issuer and the EUR SSN Issuer were each incorporated on February 11, 2020, and the USD SSN Issuer
was incorporated on April 14, 2020, in each case to facilitate the Transactions. As of the date of this offering
memorandum, the Issuers have no material assets or liabilities, do not have any revenue-generating activities of
their own and have not engaged in activities other than those related to their incorporation and in preparation of
the Transactions. As a result, no historical financial information of the Issuers is included in this offering
memorandum.

**Elevator Technology Business**

The Elevator Technology Business did not exist as a separate group prior to December 31, 2019. It formed part
of a larger group of companies controlled by thyssenkrupp AG and was reported as a segment within the
consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG. In order to facilitate the Acquisition, all companies and
operating activities that are part of the Elevator Technology Business were transferred, directly or indirectly, to
the Target in a corporate reorganization that was completed on December 31, 2019 (the “Reorganization”).

All historical financial information presented in this offering memorandum is that of the Elevator Technology
Business. When referring to the “Elevator Technology Business,” “we,” “us,” “our” or the “Group” in respect of
such financial information, we mean (i) prior to the completion of the Reorganization on December 31, 2019, the
“Elevator Technology Business” as defined in our Audited Combined Financial Statements (as defined below)
and (ii) after the Reorganization, the “thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Group” as defined in our Unaudited
Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (as defined below) or the business carried out by the “thyssenkrupp
Elevator Technology Group,” as the context requires. The financial information as of and for the six months
ended March 31, 2019 and 2020 gives effect to the Reorganization as if it had occurred at the beginning of the
periods presented.

There are important differences between the Elevator Technology Business as presented in the Audited
Combined Financials as of and for the financial years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019 and the
business carried out by the Target and its subsidiaries as presented in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated
Financial Statements as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020. See “—Basis of Preparation”
and our Financial Statements included elsewhere herein.

**Historical Financial Information**

As the Elevator Technology Business did not exist as a separate group and since all companies and operating
activities within the Elevator Technology Business were under the common control of thyssenkrupp AG, in each
case, prior to the Reorganization, the financial information presented as of and for the financial years ended
September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019 has been prepared on a combined basis. Effective with the Reorganization,
the Elevator Technology Business came into existence as a separate group and therefore, the financial
information presented for the Target and its consolidated subsidiaries as of and for the six months ended March
31, 2019 and 2020 was prepared on a consolidated basis. As a result, this offering memorandum presents the
following financial information of the Group (the “Financial Statements”):

- The unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of the Target and its consolidated subsidiaries as of
and for the six months ended March 31, 2020, including comparative information for the six months ended
March 31, 2019 (the “Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements”), which were prepared in
accordance with International Accounting Standard 34, Interim Financial Reporting; and

- The audited combined financial statements of the Elevator Technology Business as of and for the financial
years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019 (the “Audited Combined Financial Statements”), which
were prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards, as adopted by the EU
(“IFRS”), have been audited in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (“ISA”) by
PricewaterhouseCoopers GmbH Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft, Friedrich-List-Straße 20, 45128 Essen,
Federal Republic of Germany (“PwC”), independent auditors, who issued an independent auditor’s report
thereon.

The independent auditor’s report on the Audited Combined Financial Statements is qualified due to issues
regarding local book keeping and financial reporting processes, which led to qualified, adverse or disclaimer of
opinions on the financial information of certain entities of the Elevator Technology Business’s Operating Unit
Spanish Latin America (as defined in the Financial Statements). Due to these issues, PwC was unable to obtain
sufficient information and evidence required to assess the existence, completeness, valuation and cut-off of the

xvii


-----

assets and liabilities as well as the income and expense of these subsidiaries and, as a result, was unable to
determine whether any adjustments might have been necessary in respect of the combined financial position as of
September 30, 2018 and 2017 and the combined statements of profit and loss, comprehensive income and
changes in equity or net cash flows as reported in the combined statement of cash flows for the financial years
ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017 (see Note 1 of the Audited Combined Financial Statements). The
auditor’s qualification does not pertain to the combined statement of financial position as of September 30, 2019
included in the Audited Combined Financial Statements. The independent auditor’s report also contains an
emphasis of matter paragraph that the Elevator Technology Business has not operated as a separate stand-alone
group of entities and that the Audited Combined Financial Statements are, therefore, not necessarily indicative of
the results that would have occurred if the Elevator Technology Business had operated as a separate standalone
group of entities during the years presented or for any future period.

In the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements, the issues relating to the Elevator Technology
Business’s Operating Unit Spanish Latin America described above still remained for the six-month period ended
March 31, 2019 (see Note 1 of the other explanatory notes of the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial
Statements).

For the purposes of this offering memorandum, we refer to the financial year ended September 30, 2017 as the
“2016/2017 Financial Year,” the financial year ended September 30, 2018, as the “2017/2018 Financial Year”
and the financial year ended September 30, 2019, as the “2018/2019 Financial Year.”

After the completion of the Transaction, we expect to report our financial results and condition at the level of
thyssenkrupp Elevator until September 30, 2021, and Vertical Topco III thereafter. The Financial Statements in
this offering memorandum have not been adjusted to reflect the impact of any changes that might occur as a
result of purchase price allocation effects to be applied as a result of the Transactions. However, Vertical
Topco III will account for the Acquisition using the acquisition method in accordance with IFRS 3 “Business
_Combinations” and will apply purchase price allocation effects in connection with the Transactions to their_
financial statements for accounting periods subsequent to the Acquisition Closing Date. The application of
purchase accounting could result in different carrying values for existing assets and assets we may add to our
balance sheet, which may include intangible assets, such as goodwill, leasehold rights and software, and different
amortization and depreciation expenses. Due to these and other potential adjustments, our future financial
statements could be materially different once the adjustments are made and may not be comparable to the
Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Financial data in this offering memorandum as of and for the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial
Years, and for the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020, (i) if presented as “audited,” is taken from the
Audited Combined Financial Statements and (ii) if presented as “unaudited,” is taken or derived from the
Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements, thyssenkrupp Elevator’s accounting records or its internal
management reporting systems or derived from the Audited Combined Financial Statements.

In making an investment decision, investors must rely upon their own examination of our business, the terms of
the Offering and the financial information presented in this offering memorandum.

**Basis of Preparation**

The preparation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements in conformity with IFRS, and the preparation of
the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements in conformity with IAS 34, require the use of certain
critical accounting estimates. These standards also require management to exercise its judgment in the process of
applying accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas where
assumptions and estimates are significant, are disclosed in the financial statements. IFRS differs in various
respects from generally accepted accounting principles in the United States (“U.S. GAAP”). The Group has not
prepared a reconciliation of its financial information to U.S. GAAP or a summary of significant differences in the
accounting and valuation methods of IFRS and U.S. GAAP and does not intend to do so in the future. Potential
investors should therefore consult their own professional advisors for an understanding of the differences
between IFRS and U.S. GAAP.

**_The Audited Combined Financial Statements_**

As IFRS does not provide guidelines for the preparation of combined financial statements, the preparation of the
Audited Combined Financial Statements was subject to IAS 8 “Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting
_Estimates and Errors,” particularly IAS 8.12, which required management of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG to_
consider recent pronouncements of other standard-setting bodies, other financial reporting requirements and

xviii


-----

recognized industry practices in connection with the preparation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements.
Accordingly, in preparing the Audited Combined Financial Statements, thyssenkrupp Elevator applied the
predecessor accounting approach in accordance with recognized industry practices and rules on business
combinations under common control. In general, thyssenkrupp Elevator used the same accounting policies and
measurement principles in preparing the Audited Combined Financial Statements as were used in preparing the
IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG (the “extraction method”). This approach has been
adjusted with respect to transactions with thyssenkrupp Group companies and to ensure compliance with IFRS.
Transactions between the Elevator Technology Business and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group were recognized
in accordance with IFRS and classified as related party transactions as defined in IAS 24 “Related Party
_Disclosures.”_

New IFRS accounting standards were applied in the Audited Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator
Technology Business in fiscal years from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2019, as follows:

- IFRS 9 (Financial instruments) was adopted in the 2018/2019 Financial Year by opting to apply the
standard prospectively (i.e., from the beginning of the 2018/2019 Financial Year) and accordingly, no
adjusted comparative information was disclosed.

- IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) was adopted in 2018/2019 Financial Year by applying
the full retrospective approach to initial application. Due to the financial statements of that fiscal year for
thyssenkrupp AG only presenting one comparative period, the cumulative transition effects were included
directly in retained earnings at the start of the comparative period on October 1, 2017. In contrast, for the
Audited Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business, due to the additional
comparative period from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2017 presented, according to the full
retrospective approach, IFRS 15 has been applied from the beginning of the 2016/2017 Financial Year for
the Audited Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business (i.e. the cumulative
transition effects were included directly in invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp AG at the start of
the comparative period on October 1, 2016).

- IFRS 16 (Leases) was adopted in the 2019/2020 Financial Year by thyssenkrupp AG by opting to apply the
simplified approach of using the modified retrospective method (i.e., the cumulative transition effects are
included directly in equity on October 1, 2019 and the standard is applied from the beginning of the
2019/2020 Financial Year) and no adjusted comparative information was accordingly disclosed.

Additional information on the scope and basis of preparation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements and
the application of significant accounting policies is presented in Note 1 “Basis of preparation” and Note 2
“Summary of significant accounting policies” to the Audited Combined Financial Statements.

As a result, the Audited Combined Financial Statements included in this offering memorandum may not reflect
what the results of operations, financial position and cash flows would have been had the Group operated as a
separate, stand-alone business without the shared resources of thyssenkrupp AG for the periods presented, and
may not be indicative of our future results of operations, financial position and cash flows. The fact that the
companies and operating activities comprising the Elevator Technology Business did not historically exist as a
separate group limits the validity of the combined financial information.

**IFRS 16 (Leases)**

The Financial Statements are prepared and presented in accordance with IFRS. On January 13, 2016, the IASB
published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 on November 9, 2017. IFRS 16 replaced
IAS 17 and the related IFRIC and SIC interpretations, and resulted in almost all leases being recognized on the
balance sheet, as the distinction between operating and finance leases was eliminated. Under the new standard,
the lessee recognizes an asset (the right-to-use the leased asset) and a financial liability to pay lease payments.
The only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases should a company elect to apply an available practical
expedient in order to reduce the transition effort. IFRS 16 became effective for fiscal years commencing on or
after January 1, 2019.

The Group adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) on October 1, 2019, by opting to apply the simplified approach of using the
modified retrospective method, which means that the cumulative transition effects are included directly in equity
on October 1, 2019, and the standard is applied from the beginning of the 2019/2020 Financial Year.
Accordingly, no adjusted comparative information was disclosed.

Unless otherwise indicated, operating and financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020,
represents the mathematical calculation of adding the financial information for the six months ended March 31,
2020 (as derived from the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements) to the difference between the
financial information for the year ended September 30, 2019 (as derived from the Audited Combined Financial
Statements), and the six months ended March 31, 2019 (as derived from the Unaudited Interim Consolidated
Financial Statements), without accounting for differences in the application of accounting measures. The
financial information of the Group as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 includes the six month
period ended March 31, 2020, in which IFRS 16 was adopted for the first-time and also includes the calculated
six month period from April 1, 2019 to September 30, 2019, for which leases were accounted for in accordance
with IAS 17 and the related IFRIC and SIC interpretations, as described above. The first-time adoption of
IFRS 16 had significant impact on certain balance sheet and income statement items, as described above and also
in Note 1 in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements. For that reason, the financial information
as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, is limited in its meaningfulness.

The transition to IFRS 16 on October 1, 2019, gave rise to changes to our assets and liabilities. As a result,
figures as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2020, may not be comparable to the results presented for
prior periods. As of March 31, 2020, our right-of-use assets amounted to €397 million and lease liabilities
amounted to €330 million. The depreciation of right-of-use assets for the six months ended March 31, 2020,
amounted to €49 million and the interest expense from lease liabilities amounted to €8 million.

For an analysis of the impact of the first-time application of IFRS 16 (Leases) from October 1, 2019, see
“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Position and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting
_Comparability of Our Financial Statements—Changes to Accounting Standards—IFRS 16” and the Notes to the_
Audited Combined Financial Statements.

**Non-GAAP Financial Measures**

**_General_**

In this offering memorandum, we present certain financial measures that are not recognized by IFRS or any other
generally accepted accounting principles and that may not be permitted to appear on the face of the Financial
Statements or footnotes thereto. The primary non-GAAP financial measures used in this offering memorandum
include Adjusted EBIT, Adjusted EBIT margin, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, business cash

xxi


-----

flow (post-restructuring), business cash flow (pre-restructuring), capital expenditures, cash conversion, EBIT,
EBIT margin, EBITDA, EBITDA margin, free cash flow, Lease Adjusted EBITDA, operating net working
capital, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other figures for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 (our
“Non-GAAP Measures”). Each of the EBITDA-based and net income-based measures presented in this offering
memorandum is defined and calculated differently from the definition of “Consolidated Net Income” and
“Consolidated EBITDA” presented in the Indentures.

Our primary Non-GAAP Measures are defined as follows:

- “Adjusted EBIT” is defined as EBIT as adjusted for certain special items, including restructuring expenses,
impairment charges/reversals and other non-operating expenses and income;

- “Adjusted EBIT margin” is defined as Adjusted EBIT divided by sales;

- “Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as Adjusted EBIT as adjusted further by adding back depreciation and
amortization expense;

- “Adjusted EBITDA margin” is defined as Adjusted EBITDA divided by sales;

- “business cash flow (post-restructuring)” is defined as business cash flow (pre-restructuring) after
restructuring payments;

- “business cash flow (pre-restructuring)” is defined as free cash flow before restructuring payments, major
M&A transaction payments, payments for the “thyssenkrupp” brand, income taxes paid, payments made to
the remaining thyssenkrupp Group under tax group arrangements and net of interest received/paid;

- “capital expenditures” is defined as the sum of purchase of investments accounted for using the equity
method and non-current financial assets, expenditures for acquisitions of consolidated companies net of cash
acquired, capital expenditures for property, plant and equipment (inclusive of advance payments),
expenditures for acquisitions of shares in the Group from thyssenkrupp Group, cash advances and loans
classified as investing activities and capital expenditures for intangible assets (inclusive of advance
payments);

- “cash conversion” is defined as business cash flow (pre-restructuring) divided by Adjusted EBIT;

- “EBIT” is defined as income/(loss) before tax, finance income, finance expense and “thyssenkrupp” brand
charges but including certain finance expenses and finance income assigned to EBIT based on the economic
classification;

- “EBIT margin” is defined as EBIT divided by sales;

- “EBITDA” is defined as EBIT before depreciation and amortization expense;

- “EBITDA margin” is defined as EBITDA divided by sales;

- “free cash flow” is defined as operating cash flows less cash flows from investing activities;

- “Lease Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as Adjusted EBITDA as adjusted further for the estimated effect of
our adoption of IFRS 16 as if it had been adopted at the beginning of each period presented. While
calculating the Lease Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, in a first step we
excluded the rental expenses resulting from operating leases in accordance with IAS17 for the six month
period between April 1, 2019 to September 30, 2019. In a second step we doubled the values for lease
expense that were recorded in connection with short-term leases, leases for low value assets and expenses
for variable payments for the six month period from October 1, 2019 to March 31, 2020, which were
recognized in accordance with IFRS16;

- “operating net working capital” is defined as total assets less total non-current assets less current financial
and non-financial assets less current income taxes less cash and cash equivalents plus advance payments to
suppliers of inventories and to other current non-financial assets less trade accounts payable and contract
liabilities; and

- “Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as Lease Adjusted EBITDA adjusted further for certain cost
savings adjustments.

These measures are presented in this offering memorandum because they are measures our management used to
assess operating performance, and we believe that they and similar measures are widely used in our industry as a
means of evaluating a company’s operating performance and financing structure, and because we believe they
present helpful comparisons of financial performance between periods by excluding the distorting effect of
certain non-recurring items.

xxii


-----

Our Non-GAAP Measures and ratios are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS, U.S.
GAAP, German GAAP or any other generally accepted accounting principles and should not be considered as
alternatives to performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS, U.S. GAAP, German GAAP or any other
generally accepted accounting principles. Our Non-GAAP Measures may not be comparable to other similarly
titled measures of other companies and have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in
isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. Some of the limitations of
Non-GAAP Measures are that:

- they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital investments or contractual
commitments;

- they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

- they do not reflect the significant interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or
principal payments on our debt;

- they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay;

- they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our consolidated income
statement;

- they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider not to be
indicative of our ongoing operations;

- assets are depreciated or amortized over differing estimated useful lives and often have to be replaced in the
future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements; and

- other companies in our industry and analysts may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting
their usefulness as comparative measures.

Because of these limitations, our Non-GAAP Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary
cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to
meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on the Financial
Statements and using these Non-GAAP Measures only to supplement evaluation of our performance.

and amounts reflecting changes over time periods relating to financial and other data set forth in “Management’s

not using the numerical data in the narrative description thereof.

In respect of financial data set forth in the main body of this offering memorandum, a dash (“—”) signifies that

rounded to zero. By contrast, no such differentiation has been made in respect of the financial data set forth in the
financial information section of this offering memorandum beginning on page F-1. In the financial information
section, zero (“0”) is used to signify both unavailable figures and figures which are either exactly zero or have
been rounded to zero.

**Overview**

We are one of the world’s leading providers of elevator and escalator technology, with top market positions in
the Americas, Europe and Africa and a strong platform to capture growth opportunities in the Asia Pacific region.
We design, manufacture, install, service and modernize state-of-the-art passenger and freight elevators,
escalators, moving walkways, passenger boarding bridges and chair and platform lifts, covering the entire
product life cycle from new installation to service and modernization. Building on our German engineering
heritage, we are an innovation leader in the digital age, leveraging Internet of Things technologies to collect data
and make recommendations for repairs in real time to better serve rapidly urbanizing societies with a focus on
product safety and efficiency. Operating from approximately 1,000 locations worldwide and serving customers in
more than 100 countries, our business is characterized by a global sales and service network to ensure optimum
proximity to clients. High-profile infrastructure projects such as One World Trade Center in New York, the
tallest building in the Americas, the Beijing International Airport T3 Terminal and the Federation Tower in
Russia have all featured our elevator and escalator products, illustrating our strengths and global reach. For the
twelve months ended March 31, 2020, our sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA were €8,048 million and
€1,323 million, respectively.

Our operations comprise three business lines:

- _New Installation:_ Our New Installation business covers the design, manufacture and installation of
elevators, escalators and moving walks for all major markets and industries, including for both commercial
and residential projects, and includes low-rise, mid-rise and high-rise solutions offered at different
customization levels. Our New Installation business contributed 45% of sales in the twelve months ended
March 31, 2020.

- _Service:_ Our Service business offers a broad range of maintenance services both for our own and thirdparty equipment, with a view to ensuring the continued safety, performance and efficiency of elevators,
escalators and moving walkways throughout their usable lives. Depending on the scope agreed in our
service contracts, our services range from basic oil and grease maintenance to bespoke full-service packages
that include the sale and installation of replacement parts. As of March 31, 2020, we had approximately
1.4 million units under maintenance. Our Service business contributed 43% of sales in the twelve months
ended March 31, 2020.

- _Modernization:_ Our Modernization business offers comprehensive solutions ranging from partial
modernization to complete replacement of existing elevator and escalator systems and other solutions, both
for our own and for third-party systems. Our Modernization business contributed 12% of sales in the twelve
months ended March 31, 2020.

Our life-cycle business model is built on our New Installation business, which serves as the entry to our Service
business. On average, we convert 70% to 80% of new elevator and escalator installations into ongoing Service
contracts. This provides a source of stable and recurring sales as we also succeeded in retaining more than 90%
of our Service customers in each of our last three financial years. In addition, we win Service and Modernization
contracts from third parties where another manufacturer undertook the New Installation. The Service and
Modernization businesses, which together accounted for 54% of sales and around 70% of gross profit in the
2018/2019 Financial Year, are a source of stable, recurring sales and high profit margins for the Group, which
provides visibility on future earnings. Driven by our high conversion rate and high retention rates, we have been
able to maintain longstanding customer relationships. Given our global reach and high level of diversification,
our top ten customers in aggregate typically account for less than 3% of our annual revenue.

We have two core divisions and four operating segments, which are part of our reporting segments in accordance
with IFRS 8: Americas, Europe/Africa, Asia/Pacific and Access Solutions (together, our “Operating Segments”)
through which we conduct our customer-facing business activities. Our first core division is the new installation,
service and modernization of elevators, escalators and moving walks (the “Elevator and Escalator division”). Our
second core division is the new installation, service and modernization of access solutions for airports and homes
(the “Access Solutions division”).

The Elevator and Escalator division is divided into three Operating Segments based on geography, which enables
each to tailor its products to the specific customer needs and legal and regulatory requirements in its local markets:

- _Americas:_ Our Americas segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in the Americas
and is sub-divided into two further regional units, including North America, covering the United States and
Canada, and Latin America, covering Brazil as the main Latin American sales area and Spanish Latin
America. Our Americas segment contributed €3,306 million, or 41%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales
and €489 million, or 51%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year.

- _Europe/Africa:_ Our Europe/Africa segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in
Europe and Africa and operates within a widely diverse set of geographical areas through five operational
units: “DACH,” comprising Germany, Austria and Switzerland, “RET,” comprising Russia, Eastern Europe
and Turkey, “FRANCE,” comprising France and Monaco, “BBNI,” comprising the Benelux countries,
Britain, the Nordics and Italy and “IBA,” comprising Spain, Portugal, Angola and Morocco and, through
distributors, certain African countries. Our Europe/Africa segment contributed €2,149 million, or 26%, of
the Operating Segments’ total sales and €227 million, or 24%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT
in the 2018/2019 Financial Year.

- _Asia/Pacific:_ Our Asia/Pacific segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in the Asia/
Pacific region and is organized in six operational units: China, South Korea, India, Australia/New Zealand,
Southeast Asia and the Middle East. Our Asia/Pacific segment contributed €2,307 million, or 28%, of the
Operating Segments’ total sales and €178 million, or 19%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in
the 2018/2019 Financial Year.

Our Access Solutions division operates across all geographies and constitutes our fourth Operating Segment. It
employs a number of different sales strategies and distribution channels, catering to both the business-to-business
and business-to-consumer markets. The Access Solutions division accounted for 5% of the Operating Segments’
total sales and 6% of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year.

**Our Competitive Strengths**

**_Well-established player with a leading global position_**

We hold the top four market position in the global elevator and escalator market (excluding Japan) based on
revenues in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. Our Elevator and Escalator division is divided into three geographical
segments, the Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific, which comprise the majority of elevator and escalator
markets worldwide. Based on revenue in the 2017/2018 Financial Year, we hold the number two position in the
Americas, our most profitable elevator and escalator region, the number four position in Europe/Africa, which
has the largest service business by value globally, and the number five position in Asia/Pacific, the world’s
largest new installations market. As of March 31, 2020, we had 1.4 million units under maintenance across the
globe.

The following graph shows our market position in the elevator and escalator market (excluding Japan) based on
sales in the 2017/2018 Financial Year:

We believe that our status as a global leader in the elevator and escalator industry is attributable to our
particularly strong and far-reaching service network, our track record of high profile infrastructure projects, and
our offering of products and services across the life cycle of elevators and escalators, from new installation to
service to modernization. In addition, we believe that our expertise in the manufacturing and provision of spare
parts, along with our network of specialists and a strong and globally recognized German engineering heritage,
have resulted in a particularly high ranking among our peers with regards to competency of our field force, which
in conjunction with our innovation technology, are what we believe to be the primary purchasing criteria for
customers and puts us in a position of strength relative to our peers. Our strong market position is also driven by
our offering of some of the most innovative and cutting-edge elevator solutions in the world, such as our MAX
technology (“MAX”), our cloud-based maintenance tool, which utilizes Internet of Things (“IoT”) technologies
to collect data on installed units and make recommendations for repairs in real time, making it immensely
valuable to our Service business. In addition, we are in the process of developing the innovative MULTI elevator
system (“MULTI”), a rope-less elevator able to move both vertically and horizontally.

**_Highly resilient business model across cycles through service focused-business and balanced global footprint_**

We have developed a business model that we believe is stable, balanced and resilient through economic cycles,
and therefore, well-positioned for sustainable, long-term value generation, as demonstrated by our strong longterm historical growth. We have delivered resilient sales and Adjusted EBIT margins since the 2007/2008
Financial Year. Despite negative currency effects in recent financial years, our sales have increased from
€7,674 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €8,048 million in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020,
highlighting the stability of our business and our ability to maintain our sales and profitability over the economic
cycle despite external pressures.

The main driver of the resilience and stability of our overall business is the life cycle of our business model. Our
New Installation business is a key driver of our growing installed base and units under maintenance and therefore


3


-----

is the entry gate to our Service and Modernization business. The Service business generates revenue streams that
include fees for regular maintenance and income from repairs and spare parts. The strong profitability and the
asset-light character of our Service business contribute to our high cash generation. For the 2016/2017,
2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years, 70% to 80% of our New Installation units converted into Service
units. In each of the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years, the Service business maintained a
global retention rate of over 90%. Many of our Service business customers eventually become customers of our
Modernization business, which offers us the opportunity to generate revenue from retrofitting or replacing entire
systems of elevators and escalators while continuing the customer relationship. In addition, we attract many
Service customers whose elevator and escalator systems were manufactured and installed by third parties, adding
to our steady Service and Modernization revenue streams.

The high resilience of our business is also driven by a diversified customer base with long-term contracts and
high customer retention rates and a balanced global footprint, minimizing both customer and geographic
concentration risks. Our top ten customers accounted for less than 3% of sales in each of the 2016/2017,
2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years. Geographically, our elevator and escalator operations (including
manufacturing facilities, service centers and employees) are divided across three Operating Segments: the
Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific, which accounted for 41%, 26% and 28% of our Operating Segment’s
total sales, respectively, in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. Our fourth Operating Segment, the Access
Solutions division, operates globally and generated 5% of our Operating Segments’ total sales for the same
period.

The resilience of our business model is demonstrated by our financial performance during periods of worldwide
economic distress. For example, during the global financial crisis, our total Adjusted EBIT margin and sales
remained stable between the 2008/2009 Financial Year and the 2009/2010 Financial Year. Most recently, we
have been able to successfully manage and limit the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business by
having immediately implemented contingency measures, which we believe further proves the resilience of our
business model through the economic cycles. See “Recent Developments—Coronavirus (COVID-19).”

**_Highly attractive industry with structural growth drivers_**

We operate in the global elevator and escalator market, which generated sales of €55.8 billion in 2019 worldwide
(excluding Japan). The global elevator and escalator market grew at a CAGR of 1.7% between 2014 and 2019,
and prior to taking into account the impact of COVID-19, was expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.3% between
2019 and 2024, above expected real GDP growth. Specifically, between 2019 and 2024, the new installation,
service and modernization businesses were expected to grow at a CAGR of 1.7%, 3.9% and 6.9%, respectively.
This growth is underpinned by structural factors and megatrends, including increasing urbanization, an aging
population, a supportive regulatory environment and sustainability and digitalization trends.

Increasing urbanization is one of the primary drivers for the need for more urban spaces worldwide, which
increases demand for elevators and escalators, as they are an inherent component of the residential and
commercial multi-story buildings that characterize urban environments. By 2050, the number of urban
inhabitants is expected to increase by 55%, from approximately four billion today to nearly seven billion. In
particular, the urban population is expected to increase in emerging markets, including from approximately 60%
in 2018 to 80% in 2050 in China. This trend positively affects the growth of the elevator and escalator market, as
urban residents increasingly demand the access and convenience provided by elevators and escalators,
particularly in cities in the developed world where large-scale urban living and infrastructure projects (such as
hospitals, shopping malls and train stations) are increasingly required to offer fast and efficient urban mobility
solutions.

Growth in the elevator and escalator market is also driven by an increasingly aging population. The ratio of
people over the age of 65 years to those under the age of five years is expected to rise from approximately 1:1 in
2019 to 2:1 in 2050. This trend is likely to support demand for elevator and escalator solutions as well as home
access solutions for stairs, as the growing aging population will need or prefer the mobility afforded by elevators,
escalators and home access solutions.

In addition, growth in the elevator and escalator market is driven by a supportive regulatory environment, which
requires the owners of elevator and escalator systems to invest in basic maintenance services to ensure their
systems are consistently operating safely. Currently, over 50% of elevators in North America and Europe are
over 20 years old. As the installed base of elevators and escalators grows and ages, property owners are
increasingly in need of modernizing their elevators and escalators to ensure they comply with applicable


4


-----

regulatory requirements and continue to operate safely. In Asia/Pacific, including China and South Korea, we
believe that there is a particularly strong opportunity to grow our Service and Modernization businesses driven
by the aging of the installed base in those markets and stricter safety regulations requiring regular maintenance
and upgrades.

We believe that long-term growth in the elevator and escalator market will also be positively impacted by a
continued focus on digitalization, connectivity and sustainability, as customers increasingly value features such
as improved energy efficiency and enhanced safety and maintenance monitoring. According to the Market Size/
_Growth Analysis, the market for buildings with digitally automated operations or “smart buildings” is expected to_
grow at 5% per annum through 2024. We believe that our current innovative smart mobility solutions and our
strong research and development capabilities position us to benefit from this demand. For example, our TWIN
elevator system (“TWIN”), which combines two independent cars in one shaft, can already reduce energy costs
by up to 25% and increase usable floor space by up to 25%. In addition we estimate that our MULTI system,
which we are in the process of developing and will be the world’s first rope-free elevator, will allow for space
reductions of up to a further 30% to 50% compared to our TWIN system. We aim to consistently increase
product efficiency and provide additional value-add to our customers across our portfolio of new and existing
products and services.

**_A leader in technology and innovation in the elevator and escalator market_**

We believe that we are a leading innovator in the elevator and escalator market, offering disruptive innovation
and transformative digital solutions. We have been able to successfully monetize IoT and digital opportunities, as
demonstrated by our recently developed MAX technology and our proprietary IT system, VIEW. MAX is a
cloud-based maintenance tool which utilizes IoT technologies to collect data relating to customer elevator units
and make diagnostic recommendations, such as when repairs need to be undertaken or which critical parts need
to be replaced. VIEW is an operational business steering tool, which, among other things, automatically
dispatches qualified technicians to resolve the problems identified by MAX, often even before any visible
operational issues occur. Leveraging our expertise in IoT and other digital tools enables us to improve customer
satisfaction by increasing service quality and efficiency, thereby increasing our customer retention rates and
decreasing cancellation rates.

In addition, we believe that we have created some of the most innovative elevator concepts currently in operation
in the market. We are the only supplier in the industry to have an offering similar to our TWIN elevator system,
which combines two independent cars in one shaft. We are also currently in the process of developing the
MULTI system, which would be the world’s first rope-free elevator, allowing for space reductions of up to a
further 30% to 50% compared to our TWIN system. These systems offer customers greater space efficiency and
architectural flexibility than conventional designs, making us an attractive choice for a customer base that is
increasingly demanding more innovative elevator and escalator products.

**_Strong financial profile with significant operational improvement opportunity._**

We have a track record of long-term stable sales growth, high cash flow generation and high earnings visibility
on recurring future earnings driven by a ten- to 20-year elevator life cycle with a retention rate of over 90%. Our
Elevator and Escalator division has grown consistently over the years, with our Adjusted EBIT margin generally
increasing since the 2011/2012 Financial Year until the 2016/2017 Financial Year. While facing some
headwinds, especially from material price developments and trade tariffs implemented in recent years, we believe
that, following the Transactions, there will be greater opportunity to increase our Adjusted EBIT margin.

Our business benefits from high revenue visibility given the recurring and stable nature of our Service and
Modernization business model. Our New Installation business represents the key enabler for growth of Service
and Modernization by growing our units under maintenance and offering high visibility of future business
performance due to long order-to-fulfilment times. Most of our New Installation units are converted into
maintenance units, which propels our Service business. Our Service contracts on average have a gross profit
margin of approximately 40%, which progressively increases over the elevator’s lifetime due to increased spare
parts sales. Many of our Service business customers eventually become customers of our Modernization
business, driven by an aging installed base with the need to upgrade and extend the life cycle of the elevators and
escalators. The Service and Modernization businesses, which together accounted for 54% of sales and around
70% of gross profit for the 2018/2019 Financial Year, are a source of stable, recurring sales and high profit
margins for the Group. Our Service contracts have an average length between one to five years. Our full life

relationships, enables high visibility on recurring future earnings.

**Our Strategies**

We aim to deliver strong growth in our business, including significant margin expansion, through our three key
strategies, Base, Core, and Core+, as further discussed below.

**_Base Strategy: Continue to capitalize on our market position and structural growth_**

Our Base strategy consists of leveraging the structural factors that drive growth in the market in which we
operate, together with our leading position in those markets, to grow our business and increase our profitability.

As one of the world’s leading elevator and escalator companies, we aim to manufacture and install a substantial
portion of the new elevators and escalators expected to be installed worldwide in the coming years. As a result of
our global scale and strong brand recognition in the market, we believe there is significant sales potential for our
New Installation business and continued growth opportunities for increasing our units under maintenance,
resulting in further revenue and profit generation in our key markets.

In addition, we target continued growth in all our business segments by leveraging structural factors such as an
aging population, global urbanization and stricter safety requirements driving demand for maintenance and
modernization services. In particular, we believe that our Service and Modernization businesses are positioned
for growth as the installed base of elevators and escalators grows and ages.

In the Americas, we target growth in our New Installation business, driven by expected growth in the US
construction sector and our strength in meeting customer demands for efficient execution and technical
excellence, such as our expertise in the hydraulic segment. We target growth in our Service business due to
customer demand for high quality services with short lead times, and through reducing cancellation rates and
winning service contracts for third-party installations. We also target growth in both our Service and
Modernization businesses driven by increases in the average age of the installed base of elevators and escalators
in the region and a strict regulatory environment.

In Europe/Africa, we expect that the large, aging installed base of elevators and escalators, supported by a strict
regulatory environment and high customer retention and conversion rates, will generate attractive service and


7


-----

modernization opportunities. We further expect that strong construction output, particularly from the residential
segment and a slight recovery in Southern Europe as well as a more competitive product offering due to our
manufacturing optimization initiatives in Spain and Germany, will drive our New Installation business and,
consequently, growth in our Service and Modernization businesses.

In Asia/Pacific, we aim to benefit from the anticipated growth of the new installations market, targeting robust
expansion of our New Installation business, including in India and other markets. We believe that growing
customer demand for high quality services and an expanding installed base will also contribute to growth in our
Service and Modernization businesses. We expect that an expanding installed base of elevators and escalators
and the growing importance of IoT solutions, particularly in South Korea, will lead to strong growth
opportunities in our Service and Modernization businesses. We expect China, the largest elevator and escalator
market in Asia, will continue to generate our highest New Installation growth globally, and that conversion of
many of these newly installed units to Service contracts will continue to drive growth in the Service business. We
believe that there is a particularly strong opportunity to grow our Service and Modernization businesses in China
and other developing markets, driven by the growth and the aging of the installed base in those markets and
stricter safety regulations requiring regular maintenance and upgrades, which many emerging market countries
are adopting as their regulatory systems mature.

**_Core Strategy: Realize structural profitability upside_**

Our Core strategy consists of realizing structural profitability upside by focusing on (i) standardization within our
New Installation business, (ii) manufacturing optimization, (iii) service and modernization growth and
digitalization, (iv) selling, general and administrative (“SG&A”) cost reduction and (v) procurement
optimization. In addition, following the Acquisition, we expect to realize additional cost savings as part of the
Sponsors’ Transformation Program.

_Standardization of Our New Installation Business_

We plan to continue to drive the standardization of our New Installation business by simplifying the amount and
types of products and components we offer our customers.

Historically, in part due to our strategy of growing through acquisitions, we provided customers with a large
share of customized product solutions. This resulted in a highly diverse but overlapping product portfolio and
limited price competitiveness due to the high costs of designing and producing such a wide range of
individualized products. In order to optimize our structure, we are in the process of simplifying our regional
product portfolio and standardizing certain components. For example, the number of product platforms in the
Group has been reduced by more than half in the last decade as part of a process of implementing a simplified
portfolio structure with further improvements planned going forward. In Europe, we have streamlined our major
platforms down to two, which cover 80% of our products. This has resulted in synergies and a strong evolution of
order intake in the first half of 2019/2020 while not impacting customers’ perception of our product offering or
quantity of sales. We believe this will lead us to benefit from economies of scales, focusing our resource
allocation more efficiently and allowing us to provide a more cost-competitive offering without compromising on
customer service.

In addition, we have also standardized and harmonized components across products to allow specific modular
components, such as traction machines, controllers/inverters and doors, to be used across multiple product
platforms, which we expect will result in lower costs due to the use of fewer parts, a leaner set-up, less
complexity, higher agility and easier external sourcing. These initiatives are aimed at focusing our sales teams on
value-based selling by presenting customers with a harmonized product portfolio of key high quality, high
margin products.

We plan to adapt our manufacturing to focus on products that provide our customers with one of three
customization levels for low-rise buildings (less than 45 meters), mid-rise buildings (between 45 and 100 meters)
and high-rise buildings (above 100 meters). These customization levels comprise: (i) Value for Money “100,”
which is our lower priced option with no customization; (ii) Performance “200,” which is our moderately priced
option with medium customization; and (iii) Customization “300,” which is our high priced option with full
customization. This value proposition model offers customers flexible and transparent pricing, which we expect
will make our products especially compelling to customers in high-volume and growth markets, such as large
property developers in Asia/Pacific. Our processes, in turn, will be optimized by focusing on a leaner offering
and steering our salesforces and engineers toward a focus on sales efforts based on product margin potentials and
the conversion of New Installation units into Service contracts and later into Modernization sales.


8


-----

_Manufacturing Optimization_

We are engaged in an ongoing effort to optimize our manufacturing operations. These measures have included
closing and, where possible, consolidating manufacturing sites, increasing outsourcing of standardized products
and developing factories with improved technology for greater automation. For example, in Asia/Pacific, we
have established leaner manufacturing operations, with a newly established plant in India and advances in
automation at our plants in China and South Korea. In the Americas, we have consolidated all North America
manufacturing at our Middleton facility to enhance efficiency and reduce costs. In Europe/Africa, we have
shifted our factories away from a regional focus (in which a particular factory only serves specific countries) to a
model where all factories can deliver to the entire Europe/Africa region, with each factory having a dedicated
product focus. As part of this shift, we have restructured our Móstoles plant in Spain and we are currently
restructuring our operations in Germany to reduce costs and simplify production.

In the long term, we aim to move away from a classic factory model, where the focus is on major production and shipping
of complete elevator systems and requires high personnel expenses, towards a model where we produce only key, mission
critical components and outsource commoditized parts, resulting in lower fixed costs and higher productivity.

_Service and Modernization Growth and Digitalization_

We aim to deliver service growth through leveraging our attractive business model and IoT innovation
technology.

Our business model contributes to the growth of our Service and Modernization business as, on average, 70% to
80% of New Installation contracts convert into Service contracts, and many of those Service business customers
eventually become customers of the Modernization business. We aim to grow our Service business, which is a
source of stable and recurring sales and high margins, by pursuing multiple initiatives aimed at increasing
revenues per unit while decreasing costs. In particular, we believe that our use of digital and IoT technologies,
including the recently developed MAX and VIEW systems, will enable us to improve customer satisfaction by
increasing service quality and efficiency, and thereby increase customer retention rates and decrease cancellation
rates. Particularly, in North America, our Service business growth is driven by the reduction of cancellation rates.
We have already improved our cancellation rates and we aim to reduce our cancellation rates further through
strict management focus and tools like the MAX and VIEW.

We expect the growth of our Service business will contribute to new Modernization customers as the installed
base grows and ages, generating an additional stream of stable and recurring revenues. We also believe that we
can leverage the scale and efficiency gains achieved by MAX and VIEW to reduce the costs per unit of providing
services, such as technician travel time and spare parts. In addition, we intend to increase our rate of winning
customers away from competitor service providers by enhancing the efficiency of our spare parts organization,
increasing our service training and leveraging the superior quality of our Service business and our capability to
refurbish multi-brand spare parts through our ITS unit.

_SG&A costs optimization_

We aim to reduce SG&A costs by centralizing administrative functions, adopting a range of organizational
efficiency measures and improving our IT systems. Specifically, we are engaged in an ongoing effort to combine
a wide array of administrative processes that historically have been performed locally, such as billing, payroll
and purchasing, into shared service centers. For example, in the United States, we are in the process of
consolidating these functions, previously spread over 18 locations, into one shared service center at the US
headquarters in Atlanta, and we intend to roll out a similar strategy in Europe and Asia. We are also in the
process of harmonizing our IT processes by rolling out VIEW globally, continuing to transition to cloud-based
services, adopting global templates and standards, “delayering,” or flattening, management levels to simplify our
organization and reduce overhead costs and adopting other efficiency enhancements. These measures have
resulted in more than €80 million in total cost savings over the last three financial years.

_Procurement Optimization_

Finally, throughout our Core strategy, we aim to reduce our procurement costs by optimizing our supply chains
through commercial measures, such as, for example, supplier days, clustering managed spend, and engaging in
e-auctions, continuing from measures implemented historically. For example, between the 2011/2012 Financial
Year and the 2018/2019 Financial Year, our purchasing savings increased by 300%, outpacing our procurement
spend which increased by 50%.


9


-----

_Transformation Program_

Following the Acquisition, we expect to realize €240 million in potential cost savings within 15 to 18 months after
July 1, 2020 through the Sponsors’ Transformation Program, assuming various things, including that the program
will be implemented beginning on July 1, 2020 and driven by key management, including the Chief Executive
Officer of the Group. The Transformation Program focuses on cost savings opportunities related to (i) commercial
operations, (ii) service operations, (iii) procurement costs, (iv) G&A costs and (v) other operational costs. Some of
these initiatives will be continued through the efficiency measures, which we are already in the process of
implementing, as described above.

As part of our commercial operations initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our
organizational efficiency by restructuring and centralizing our sales supports team, including by shifting
employees to low cost countries. In addition, we seek to increase our sales force productivity through various
measures, including improving our administrative processes and completing faster technical sales. This is
facilitated by our offering of fewer customization options resulting from the optimization of our product and
service portfolios. We also intend to increase our focus on sales efforts based on product margin potentials and
the conversion of New Installation units into Service contracts and later into Modernization sales. We expect to
realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €7 million related to our commercial operations initiatives.

As part of our service operations initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our
organizational efficiency by rationalizing the number of our application engineers, reducing the number of
platforms in our offering, standardizing our service offering and reducing the number of our service centers,
particularly in the U.S. We intend to implement other measures under these initiatives as well, including improving
process, technology and performance management in order to increase the productivity of our service technicians.
We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €15 million related to our service operations initiatives.

As part of our procurement initiatives under the Transformation Program, we intend to implement multiple
measures to reduce costs relating to our procurement activities. For the 2018/2019 Financial Year, we believe
that our estimated addressable cost base for procurement activities comprised €2.1 billion of direct costs and €0.5
billion of indirect costs. To reduce these costs, we intend to establish group-wide supply agreements with global
suppliers for key categories of direct materials, such as motors, cables and doors, including through leveraging
change-of-control provisions under our existing supplier agreements with local or regional suppliers. We also
expect to increase our focus on supplier driven innovation in connection with, among other things, tendering
processes. To pursue improvements in specification management, we seek to standardize purchases for complex
parts and establish business unit sourcing boards, which will act as advisory panels in key end markets to
promote best practices and streamline procurement processes. Furthermore, we continue to shift our relationships
with local suppliers to regional suppliers in order to both increase the number of sites served by our suppliers and
decrease the number of our total suppliers, resulting in increased efficiencies. We also continue to streamline the
amount and variety of individually supplied components in order to purchase bundles of different products and
higher volumes of specific products, resulting in improved purchasing ability. Moreover, where appropriate, we
target shifting to agreements with suppliers in low cost countries or otherwise shifting purchases from our
suppliers of local products to products sourced from low cost countries. In addition, we are working to utilize
both centralized regional lead-buyers to streamline demand-management processes and defined sourcing hubs to
allow for best value and benchmark sourcing through increased spend, price and margin transparency.
Furthermore, we expect to realize cost savings from our commercial operations initiatives that result in the
rationalization of our product offering and standardization of our SKUs. We expect to realize cost savings in an
aggregate amount of €132 million in connection with our procurement initiatives.

As part of our G&A cost savings initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our
organizational efficiency and generate attrition savings through a leaner operating model, the shifting of
employees to low cost countries and increased automation, including within our shared service centers. We
expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €36 million related to our G&A cost savings initiatives.

As part of our other operational initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to reduce direct and
indirect personnel expenses and scrappage costs by decreasing the portion of poor quality production. We target
replicating the cost of poor quality levels that we have achieved at our Korean plant (where such costs are
estimated to be 0.6% of internal sales) at our other plants, particularly our Middleton plant. We also intend to
outsource parts and components and streamline production overhead and assembly processes to reduce costs. We
expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €50 million related to our other operational initiatives.

initiatives, mainly as a result of (i) voluntary redundancy, early retirement and other severance costs, (ii) staff
training costs, (iii) investments in IT to digitize, automate and streamline processes, (iv) investments in the
existing shared service centers in Europe, Brazil and the U.S., as well as potentially operating new, regional
centers in Eastern Europe and Asia and (v) consulting, financial and legal advisory fees in connection with

**_Core+ Strategy: Deliver additional value through innovation, digitalization and bolt-on acquisitions_**

Our Core+ strategy aims to deliver additional value by (i) focusing on disruptive innovation, (ii) monetizing IoT
opportunities, (iii) seeking opportunistic mergers and acquisitions and (iv) continuing the measures defined under
our Core strategy.

We have a long-standing German engineering heritage and a history of innovative digital solutions with the
potential to transform the Elevator and Escalator division. We are a leading innovator in the elevator and
escalator market and strive to address what we believe are fundamental technological challenges to better serve a
rapidly urbanizing society. For example, we estimate that up to 40% of usable space in buildings is utilized for
elevator shafts. Our TWIN elevator system combines two independent cars in one shaft in order to increase
efficiency and creates more usable area by using up to 25% less usable space than an ordinary elevator. The
TWIN elevator system’s unique value-add has made it a top choice for premier buildings around the world,
including the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany, and the CMA Tower in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. We
believe that our MULTI elevator system, which is currently in the developing phase, has the potential to be even
more compelling to the market. MULTI is a rope-less elevator able to move both vertically and horizontally,
which will allow new architectural designs and unlimited building height and, we estimate, will use up to 30% to
50% less usable space than an ordinary elevator. We believe that our New Installation customers place a high
value on innovative solutions like TWIN and MULTI, which both have the potential to significantly increase the
usable area in buildings that is available for sale or rent.

We also aim to continue to monetize our IoT technologies more effectively in the future to create sustainable
business value and cash flow. By the 2021/2022 Financial Year, we aim to charge connection and monthly fees
to customers for using MAX, which already supported the servicing of over 129,000 units as of March 31, 2020.
Other innovations currently in the pipeline include our asset performance management solution as well as our
Intelligent Gate Management System, part of our Access Solutions division. We plan to follow the MAX
blueprint for these and other new products by clearly demonstrating the value of the product after launch,
bringing the technology to maturity and then developing a pricing and sales model that accurately reflects our
value to customers.

In addition, we have a track record of successful mergers and acquisitions, including most recently our
acquisitions of Nashville Machine’s elevator division and O’Keefe Elevator Company, Inc. in the 2018/2019
Financial Year. We plan to further develop our profit potential by opportunistically seeking future M&A targets,
which we believe can be value accretive to the Group.
