**_Escrow Accounts_**

Pending the consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from the
Offering of the Notes into the Escrow Accounts in the names of the Issuers. The Escrow Accounts will be
controlled by the Escrow Agent and will be pledged on a first-priority basis in favor of the Trustee on behalf of
the holders of the respective series of the Notes. See “Summary—The Offering—Collateral.”

The release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts is subject to the satisfaction of certain
conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly
(and in any event within two business days). See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds;
_Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory_
_Redemption.” If these conditions are not satisfied on or before the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the occurrence_
of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory
redemption price for the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and
unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption.
See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,”
“Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Risk Factors—
_Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not_
_satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds_
_to cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.”_

In the event of a special mandatory redemption, the SUN Issuer, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes, and
Vertical Topco III, in the case of the Senior Notes, will be required to fund the relevant Issuer in such aggregate
amounts as are required in order to enable the Issuers to pay any funding shortfall, including Escrow Account fees,
negative interest on the Escrow Accounts’ balances and costs and accrued and unpaid interest and additional
amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes on such special mandatory redemption date (the “Escrow Equity
Commitment”), pursuant to the Equity Commitment Letter. The holders of the Notes will not have any direct right
to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must rely on the Issuers’ respective rights to enforcement under the
Escrow Equity Commitment. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special
_Mandatory Redemption,” “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption”_
and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed
_Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have_
_sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.”_

**The Sponsors**

**_Advent_**

Founded in 1984, Advent is one of the largest and most experienced global private equity investors. With offices
on four continents, Advent has established a globally integrated team of over 220 investment professionals
focused on buyouts and growth equity investments in five core sectors. Since initiating its private equity strategy
in 1989, Advent has invested $40 billion in over 350 private equity investments across 42 countries, and as of
December 31, 2019, managed $56.8 billion in assets. Today, as Advent did more than 30 years ago, it seeks to
invest in well-positioned companies and partner with management teams to create value through sustained
revenue and earnings growth.

**_Cinven_**

Cinven is a leading international private equity firm with offices in London, Frankfurt, Guernsey, Hong Kong,
Luxembourg, Madrid, Milan, New York and Paris. Since 1988, the Cinven Funds have invested in over
130 companies and led transactions totaling more than €100 billion. The firm’s investment focus is on six key
sectors: healthcare, business services, consumer, financial services, industrials, and technology, media and
telecommunications. Cinven’s investment strategy targets companies that are well positioned in their respective
markets and require an equity investment of €200 million or more. Using its long-standing experience and
proven economic growth strategies (such as buy and build), Cinven works closely with management teams to
facilitate growth and help its portfolio companies reach their full potential.

**_ADIA_**

Established in 1976, ADIA is an independent, globally diversified investment institution whose sole mission is to
invest funds on behalf of the Government of the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, to make available the necessary financial
resources to secure and maintain the future welfare of the Emirate. ADIA manages a diversified global
investment portfolio, across more than two-dozen asset classes and sub-categories, including quoted equities,
fixed income, real estate, private equity, alternatives and infrastructure. In private equity specifically, ADIA,
through its subsidiaries, is a leading and long-established global investor acting both as a limited partner in
reputable private equity funds world-wide, and as a shareholder supporting companies and management teams to
achieve long-term growth and value creation.

**_AUBA_**

Auba is a nominated investment vehicle of GIC Special Investments Pte Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of GIC.

GIC is a leading global investment firm established in 1981 to manage Singapore’s foreign reserves. A
disciplined long-term value investor, GIC is uniquely positioned for investments across a wide range of asset
classes, including equities, fixed income, private equity, real estate and infrastructure. In private equity, GIC
invests through funds as well as directly in companies, partnering with its fund managers and management teams
to help world class businesses achieve their objectives. GIC has over US$100 billion in assets in over
40 countries and has been investing in emerging markets for more than two decades. Headquartered in
Singapore, GIC employs over 1,500 people across 10 offices in key financial cities worldwide.

**_RAG-Stiftung_**

The RAG-Stiftung’s business model aims to ensure the financing of perpetual obligations of RAG’s coal mining
activities with the proceeds from the sale of shares in Evonik Industries AG and their reinvestment, with
dividends from Evonik Industries AG and other income from investments, as well as with revenue generated
from its diverse financial assets. In accordance with this business model, the primary objective is to finance the
cash outflow for the sustainable financing of perpetual obligations from investment income and financial assets.
A further purpose of the RAG-Stiftung is the promotion of education, science and culture in connection with
German coal mining in the mining regions of North Rhine-Westphalia and Saarland.

**Recent Developments**

**_Coronavirus (COVID-19)_**

Since January 2020, there has been a progressive global spread of the COVID-19 pandemic, resulting in various
actions, including lockdowns, by governments across the world in order to contain and control the virus.
COVID-19 has impacted markets and facilities in multiple ways, depending on the local exposure to the virus
and the measures taken by local governments.

Our Asia/Pacific, Americas and Europe/Africa segments, which comprise our Elevator and Escalator division,
have been affected in varying degrees. The effect of COVID-19 was felt in all regions, leading to complete
lockdowns in some regions and milder restrictions in others. In the Asia/Pacific region, temporary restrictions
were mainly observed in China after a full lockdown of manufacturing sites in February 2020 due to government
restrictions, but with recovery to almost normal operations in March 2020. India has also been affected by
government restrictions and our facility in Pune is currently ramping up its operations. In the Americas, some
reductions were observed in Brazil, while production in the United States remained mainly at normal levels, with
only temporary restrictions on construction sites and service operations. In the Europe/Africa segment, Spain,
France, Italy and Germany were the most impacted countries, with some site restrictions and temporary
reductions or lockdowns in productions facilities.

The Access Solutions division has been affected in each of its home solutions and airport solutions offerings.
Activities for home solutions have been operating at a lower level with partial temporary shutdowns of
production facilities, but are recovering constantly. The partial or complete shutdown of most airports has led to
a decrease of New Installation and Service operations due to postponements and suspensions of some projects.

We have implemented a contingency plan headed by a steering committee consisting of members of our
Management Board. Our contingency plan focuses on the health and safety of our workforce, cash flexibility,
workforce flexibility, business continuity, sales push and communication. Cash management measures revolve
around personnel savings, tight working capital management and a capital expenditure freeze. Around 15,000
employees are currently affected by these contingency measures, which include funded and non-funded
furloughs and overtime reduction.

Despite the negative global macroeconomic outlook as a result of COVID-19, we believe that in the medium to
long term, the outbreak will not have a material adverse effect on our overall business and results of operations,
due to the underlying resilience of our business and immediate implementation of contingency measures. Our
New Installation business was temporarily impacted in countries with lockdown measures, as discussed above.
However, all our manufacturing plants are currently operational. Our Service business has performed largely as
expected, given applicable safety and regulatory requirements.

However, the COVID-19 pandemic has been evolving rapidly and we are unable to predict how the outbreak may
affect our business in the future. We continue to monitor the situation to ensure the safety of our employees, react
to any operational developments, logistics disruptions and macroeconomic fluctuations and assess the ongoing
impact of developments on our financial condition, results of operations, cash flows and liquidity.

_One Month Ended April 30, 2020_

Based on thyssenkrupp AG’s preliminary management accounts, including certain segmental information derived
therefrom, we estimate that our sales for the one-month period ending April 30, 2020, was approximately
€617 million compared to sales of approximately €671 million in the corresponding period in 2019, representing
a decrease of 8%.

We estimate that our Adjusted EBIT was approximately €53 million for the one-month period ending April 30,
2020, compared to approximately €70 million in the corresponding period in 2019 after giving effect to estimated
additional standalone corporate costs in the 2019/2020 Financial Year of €30 million per annum distributed

compared to approximately €648 million in the corresponding period in 2019, representing a decrease of 0.5%.

We estimate that our business cash flow (pre-restructuring) was approximately €166 million for the one-month
period ending April 30, 2020, compared to approximately €101 million in the corresponding period in 2019 after
giving effect to estimated additional standalone corporate costs in the 2019/2020 Financial Year of €30 million
per annum distributed equally across each one-month period in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The change in
business cash flow (pre-restructuring) represents an increase of 65%.

Our results for the one-month period ending April 30, 2020, were mainly driven by the impact of the COVID-19
pandemic, together with strong development in business cash flow showing positive development in all
Operating Segments.

_One Month Ended May 31, 2020_

Based on thyssenkrupp AG’s preliminary management accounts, including certain segmental information derived
therefrom, we estimate that our sales for the one-month period ended May 31, 2020, was approximately
€634 million compared to sales of approximately €689 million in the corresponding period in 2019, representing
a decrease of 8%.

We estimate that our Adjusted EBIT was approximately €70 million for the one-month period ended May 31,
2020, compared to approximately €74 million in the corresponding period in 2019 after giving effect to estimated
additional standalone corporate costs in the 2019/2020 Financial Year of €30 million per annum distributed
equally across each one-month period in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The change in Adjusted EBIT represents
a decrease of 6%.

We estimate that our Adjusted EBIT margin was approximately 11.0% for the one-month period ended May 31,
2020, compared to approximately 10.8% in the corresponding period in 2019, representing an increase of 0.2%.


17


-----

We estimate that our order intake was approximately €631 million for the one-month period ended May 31, 2020,
compared to approximately €679 million in the corresponding period in 2019, representing a decrease of 7%.

We estimate that our business cash flow (pre-restructuring) was approximately €104 million for the one-month
period ended May 31, 2020, compared to approximately €71 million in the corresponding period in 2019 after
giving effect to estimated additional standalone corporate costs in the 2019/2020 Financial Year of €30 million
per annum distributed equally across each one-month period in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The change in
business cash flow (pre-restructuring) represents an increase of 46%.

Our results for the one-month period ended May 31, 2020 were impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, while
sales and Adjusted EBIT were showing notable recovery compared to the one-month period ended April 30,
2020 together with a continued strong development in business cash flow.

equity interest each of these companies holds in its subsidiaries and, with respect to the Issuers only, as of the Issue Date, the Escrowed
Property pending consummation of the Acquisition. Prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, the restrictive covenants in the Indentures will
only apply to the Issuers and the Issue Date Guarantors. Bidco will not obtain control of the Target until the Acquisition Closing Date.

(6) In connection with the Transactions, the SFA Borrowers are expected to enter into the Senior Facilities Agreement, which will provide
for committed facilities of €7,550.0 million (equivalent) in the form of (i) Senior Term Facilities in an amount of €5,550.0 million
(equivalent); (ii) the Revolving Credit Facility in an amount of €1,000 million (equivalent); and (iii) the Guarantee Facility in an amount
of €1,000 million (equivalent). On the Issue Date, all of the Issue Date Guarantors will guarantee the Senior Facilities on a senior basis,
pari passu with the Note Guarantees of the Senior Secured Notes and senior to the Note Guarantees of the Senior Notes. Within 150 days
from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Facilities will be guaranteed by
the Post-Closing Guarantors on a senior basis, pari passu with the Note Guarantees of the Senior Secured Notes and senior to the Note
Guarantees of the Senior Notes. On the Issue Date, the Senior Facilities will be secured by the SSN Issue Date Collateral. Within
150 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date and subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Facilities will be
secured by the SSN Post-Closing Collateral. The SSN Collateral will also secure the Senior Secured Notes.

(7) On the Issue Date and subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, (i) the SSN EUR Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by
the USD SSN Issuer, Newco and Bidco, (ii) the SSN USD Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the EUR SSN Issuer, Newco
and Bidco and (iii) the Senior Notes will be guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by the SSN Issuers, Newco and Bidco. On the
Issue Date, the Notes and the Issue Date Guarantee will be secured by the Escrow Charges. Upon the definitive release of the Escrowed
Property, the first-priority security interests over the Escrowed Property will be released. On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes
and the Senior Notes will also be secured by the SSN Issue Date Collateral and the SUN Collateral, respectively. The SUN Collateral
will also secure the Private Senior Notes. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the security and the liability of each
Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on
_the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The security interests in favor of the Notes and the Note_
Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances.

(8) The EUR SSN Issuer is offering €750 million in aggregate principal amount of its SSN EUR Fixed Notes and €1,000 million in
aggregate principal amount of its SSN EUR FRN Notes. The Senior Secured Notes will be senior obligations of the SSN Issuers and will
(i) rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the SSN Issuers’ existing and future senior indebtedness, including the Senior
Facilities, (ii) rank senior in right of payment to all of the SSN Issuers’ existing and future indebtedness that is expressly subordinated in
right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including its obligations in respect of the Senior Notes, (iii) be effectively subordinated to
all of the SSN Issuers’ existing and future indebtedness that is secured by liens that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes, to the extent
of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness and (iv) be structurally subordinated to any existing or future
indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the SSN Issuers that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes, including their obligations to trade
creditors.

(9) On the Acquisition Closing Date, the Issuers intend to use the proceeds from the Senior Term Facilities, the Notes, the Private Senior
Notes and the Equity Contribution to (i) fund the consideration payable for the Acquisition and (ii) pay the fees and expenses incurred in
connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.”

(10) Within 150 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially
simultaneously with the guarantees granted in favor of obligations under the Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior
Notes will be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors on a senior basis and senior subordinated basis, respectively. Within 150 days
from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with the
obligations under the Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured by the SSN Post-Closing Collateral. The SSN Collateral
will also secure the Senior Facilities on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes. The validity and enforceability of the Note
Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain
_Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The_
security interests in favor of the Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. For the twelve months
ended March 31, 2020, on a consolidated basis and excluding statistical corporate cost allocations, the Post-Closing Guarantors generated
62.8% of the Group’s consolidated EBITDA and 44.5% of the Group’s consolidated sales. As of March 31, 2020, on a consolidated basis
and excluding the value of the “thyssenkrupp” brand (the license for which will automatically terminate 18 months after the Acquisition
Closing Date), the Post-Closing Guarantors accounted for 36.4% of the Group’s consolidated assets.

**Change of Control . . . . . . . . . . . .** Upon the occurrence of certain defined events constituting a change of

the Notes of such series at a price equal to 101% of their principal amount
plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but
excluding, the redemption date. However, a change of control will not be
deemed to have occurred if, pro forma for such change of control, a
specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection
with such event. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Change of
_Control” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Change of Control.”_

**Escrow Proceeds; Special**
**Mandatory Redemption . . . . .** Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, and pending consummation
of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of
the Offering into the Escrow Accounts, held in the name of the relevant
Issuer. The Escrow Accounts will be controlled by the Escrow Agent, and
pledged on a first-priority basis in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the
holders of the respective series of Notes. The release of the proceeds
deposited in the Escrow Accounts will be subject to the satisfaction of
certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration
for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within two
business days). Upon delivery to the Trustee and the Escrow Agent of an
officer’s certificate stating that the conditions to the release of the proceeds
from escrow are satisfied, the Escrowed Property will be released to the
Issuers and utilized as described in “Use of Proceeds,” “Description of the


28


-----

_Senior_ _Secured_ _Notes—Escrow_ _of_ _Proceeds;_ _Special_ _Mandatory_
_Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds;_
_Special Mandatory Redemption.” If the conditions to the release of the_
Escrowed Property have not been satisfied on or prior to the business day
immediately following the Escrow Longstop Date, or upon the occurrence
of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory
redemption.

The special mandatory redemption price of the Notes will be equal to 100%
of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest
and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, such special mandatory
redemption date.

In the event of a special mandatory redemption, the SUN Issuer, in the case
of the Senior Secured Notes, and Vertical Topco III, in the case of the
Senior Notes, will be required to fund the relevant Issuer in such aggregate
amounts as are required in order to enable the Issuers to pay any funding
shortfall, including Escrow Account fees, negative interest on the Escrow
Accounts’ balances and costs and accrued and unpaid interest and
additional amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes on such
special mandatory redemption date (the “Escrow Equity Commitment”),
pursuant to the Equity Commitment Letter. The holders of the Notes will
not have any direct right to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and
must rely on the Issuers’ respective rights to enforcement under the Escrow
Equity Commitment.

In addition, the conditions applicable to the special mandatory redemption
may be waived by holders of the Notes representing a majority in aggregate
principal amount of the Notes outstanding.

See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds;
_Special Mandatory Redemption,” “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow_
_of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,” and “Risk Factors—Risks_
_Relating to the Transactions—If the conditions precedent to the release of_
_the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to_
_redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds to_
_cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.”_

(1) We define EBIT as income/(loss) before tax, finance income, finance expense and “thyssenkrupp” brand charges, but including certain
finance expenses and finance income assigned to EBIT based on economic classification. We define Adjusted EBIT as EBIT, as adjusted
for special items as described below. We define Adjusted EBITDA as Adjusted EBIT, as adjusted further by adding back depreciation
and amortization expense. We define Lease Adjusted EBITDA as Adjusted EBITDA, as adjusted further for the estimated effect of our
adoption of IFRS 16 as if it had been adopted at the beginning of each period presented. See “Presentation of Financial Information—
_Non-GAAP Financial Measures—General” for further information on how Lease Adjusted EBITDA is calculated. We define Pro Forma_
Adjusted EBITDA as Lease Adjusted EBITDA, as adjusted further for certain cost savings adjustments as set forth in the tables below.
EBIT, Adjusted EBIT, Adjusted EBITDA, Lease Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA are collectively referred to herein
as our “EBITDA-based measures.”

We believe that our EBITDA-based measures are useful to investors in evaluating our operating performance and our ability to incur and
service our indebtedness. We believe that Adjusted EBITDA is useful to investors because it is adjusted for certain items that we believe
are not indicative of our underlying operating performance. We believe that Lease Adjusted EBITDA is useful to investors because it
gives pro forma effect to the application of IFRS 16 as if it had been adopted at the beginning of the relevant period. See “Presentation of
_Financial Information—Non-GAAP Financial Measures—General” for further information on how Lease Adjusted EBITDA is_
calculated. We believe that Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA is useful to investors because it gives effect to cost saving initiatives we expect
to implement after the Transactions.

Our EBITDA-based measures and ratios are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS and should not be considered
as alternatives to performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. Our
EBITDA-based measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and have limitations as analytical
tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. Pro Forma
Adjusted EBITDA and the other EBITDA-based measures presented herein differ from Consolidated EBITDA as defined in the
Indentures governing the Notes. Because of these limitations, our EBITDA-based measures should not be considered as measures of
discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to service our
indebtedness. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our Financial Statements included elsewhere herein
and using these non-GAAP measures only to supplement evaluation of our performance. See “Presentation of Financial Information—
_Non-GAAP Financial Measures.”_

(A) Represents non-recurring expenses in relation to our use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand. In the periods up to September 30, 2019, the
Elevator Technology Business was using the “thyssenkrupp” brand under an operating licensing model for which it incurred license
fees recognized in profit or loss in other expenses. As of September 30, 2019, the operating licensing model was terminated and
thus the license fees we incurred in prior periods are non-recurring and have been added back to EBIT. On September 30, 2019, the
Elevator Technology Business entered into a new license agreement with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group for the right to use the
“thyssenkrupp” brand for certain classified classes relevant for the Elevator Technology Business in exchange for a one-time fee
and with no other recurring expenses after September 30, 2019. In connection with the Acquisition, the License Agreement was
amended in March 2020, resulting in the intangible asset representing the right of use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand to be classified as
held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5 in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements. The re-classification resulted
in a non-recurring, non-cash impairment charge against the intangible asset, which we have added back to EBIT. See “Certain
_Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Relationships with the thyssenkrupp Group in the Past—License Agreement” and_
Note 1 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements and to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements.

(B) Represents restructuring expenses and net impairment losses plus certain other non-operating income and expense items if such
items individually exceed a de minimis threshold of €0.5 million. In the periods presented, the majority of our restructuring costs
relate to cost savings programs and operational improvement measures implemented at our European factories, our French, Spanish
and German operations and our US operations. The large majority of our net impairment losses in Financial Year 2017 was due to
the impairment of trade accounts receivable following a restructuring program in the Middle East, which had been initiated in 2016.
Other special items include mainly (i) non-recurring costs related to project re-evaluations following the restructuring program in
the Middle East in Financial Year 2016/2017, (ii) restructuring costs in Europe/Africa; legal fees, penalties and remediation costs
following inspections in Ontario, Canada and impairments of receivables and inventories in the Middle East in the 2017/2018
Financial Year and (iii) restructuring related costs in Europe/Africa and an unclaimed properties provision (€24 million) already
partially recorded previously by thyssenkrupp and then allocated to the Elevator Technology Business in the Financial Year
2018/2019.

(D) Our Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, has been negatively impacted by corporate cost
allocations from thyssenkrupp AG that we do not consider to be representative of our standalone costs going forward because they
were allocated retrospectively in accordance with carve-out accounting principles. These cost allocations were calculated as a
proportion of thyssenkrupp AG’s overall corporate costs, based on allocation metrics such as revenue contribution of the Elevator
Technology Business rather than a systematic review of the organization, FTEs and infrastructure that would be required to perform
the relevant functions as a stand-alone business, and negatively impacted our Adjusted EBITDA by €98 million, €71 million,
€73 million, €30 million and €16 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year, 2017/2018 Financial Year, 2018/2019 Financial Year,
the six months ended March 31, 2019 and the three months ended December 31, 2019, respectively. We incurred actual standalone
costs of €10 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020, which included some ramp-up costs that we do not expect to
continue, and thus estimate that our actual standalone costs will amount to approximately €30 million per annum going forward. We
have therefore taken (i) the €69 million of our combined corporate cost allocations and actual standalone costs during the twelve
months ended March 31, 2020 less (ii) our €30 million estimate of actual standalone costs per annum going forward, and added the
difference back to Adjusted EBITDA. While we build up additional governance and other functions, the relevant corporate services
that comprise part of these standalone costs will be provided to by thyssenkrupp AG via a combination of direct service agreements
and the New TSAs, which may impact our estimate of these costs in the short term. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of
_Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—Corporate cost allocations.”_

(E) In connection with the Acquisition, Advent and Cinven commissioned a third-party due diligence report from a global consulting
firm to analyze the financial condition and operations of the Elevator Technology Business and its potential for achieving cost
savings. This report has identified €240 million in potential cost savings, which we expect to realize through our Transformation
Program within 15 to 18 months after July 1, 2020. We give effect to these cost saving initiatives in calculating Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA as if the underlying cost savings had been realized on April 1, 2019. We expect to incur one-off costs amounting to
between €240 and €294 million in connection with these initiatives, mainly as a result of (i) voluntary redundancy, early retirement
and other severance costs, (ii) staff training costs, (iii) investments in IT to digitize, automate and streamline processes,
(iv) investments in existing shared service centers in Europe, Brazil and the U.S., as well as potentially operating new, regional
centers in Eastern Europe and Asia and (v) consulting, financial and legal advisory fees in connection with implementing these
initiatives. The cost savings adjustments set forth in the following table are based on various assumptions and estimates by external
