**RISK FACTORS**

_An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. Prospective investors in the Notes should carefully_
_consider the risks described below and the other information contained in this offering memorandum before_
_making a decision to invest in the Notes. Any of the following risks, individually or together, could adversely_
_affect our business, financial position, results of operations and prospects, and accordingly the value of the_
_Notes. This section describes the risks and uncertainties that we believe are material, but these risks and_
_uncertainties may not be the only ones that we face. Additional risks and uncertainties, including those of which_
_we are currently unaware or those which we currently deem immaterial, may also result in decreased sales,_
_assets and cash inflows, increased expenses, liabilities or cash outflows or other events that could result in a_
_decline in the value of the Notes, or which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial_
_position, results of operations and prospects. The order in which the risks are presented does not necessarily_
_reflect the likelihood of their occurrence or the magnitude of their potential impact on our business, financial_
_position, results of operations and prospects or on the trading price of the Notes._

_This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our_
_actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in those forward-looking statements as a result of_
_various factors, including the risks described below and included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. For_
_more information, see “Forward-Looking Statements.”_

**Risks Relating to Our Business**

**_We operate in a highly competitive industry and are subject to pricing pressure._**

The elevator technology business is a highly competitive sector in a mature industry with a relatively small
number of large, established market participants in each of the New Installation, Service and Modernization
businesses.

In the New Installation business, we mostly compete to sell and install the elevator technology unit, but in some
instances, we also compete with market participants that sell elevators, escalators or components to third-party
distributors who undertake the installation themselves. Our competitors for the New Installation business are
generally consolidated in most of the markets in which we operate, but in certain countries, such as China, there
is more fragmentation. Competitors in this business include global elevator manufacturers, such as KONE, Otis
and Schindler; elevator technology units of large technology multinationals, such as Hitachi and Mitsubishi, both
of which are particularly, but not exclusively, competitive in the Asian markets; and a number of other global,
regional and local manufacturers. Key factors affecting competition in the New Installation business include
initial product price, brand reputation and image, lead time for delivery, cost of ownership, warranty terms,
product safety, technology and innovation, design, quality and performance.

In the Service and Modernization businesses, we compete to provide maintenance and modernization services to
customers irrespective of which company manufactured and installed the original equipment. The postinstallation maintenance services market is very competitive in its own right. Our customers in our New
Installation business are not obliged to engage us for providing post-installation services. Further, most of our
service agreements have a duration of one through five years. Therefore, there is potential for substantial churn in
our customers, among various service providers in the market. Competitors in these businesses include many of
our competitors in the New Installation business who also offer post-installation maintenance and modernization
services, as well as companies focused on providing these services exclusively. This is particularly true in China,
which has a large number of such service-only companies and, as a result, an especially competitive and
fragmented elevator services market. Other areas, such as Europe and North America, have more consolidated
service markets, but nonetheless, with high levels of competition. Key factors affecting competition in the
Service and Modernization businesses include the quality and scope, pricing and other terms of maintenance and
repair services, modernization service and technological support as well as overall customer satisfaction.
Technology has become an increasingly important differentiator, as it enables service providers to plan, execute
and anticipate maintenance and repair needs more precisely. In addition, our Service business and, to a certain
extent, our Modernization business, are dependent on the New Installation business for a material portion of their
new customers and serviced units. This is because most customers or units from the New Installation business
enter into service agreements or convert into service units, as applicable, with us, and may eventually become
customers of the Modernization business. As a result, a decline in customers and installed units in the New
Installation business due to increasing competition would most likely have an adverse impact on the number of
new customers and serviced units for the Service and Modernization businesses.

42


-----

Revenue generated by our Service business exceeded 40% of our total revenue in each of the years ended
September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019. Loss of customers due to any of the foregoing risks could have a material
adverse effect on our overall results of operation and financial condition.

In all of our businesses, key competitive risks include falling prices due to competition, and a consequent decline
in margins, loss of customers and market share. Some of our competitors may have greater financial, marketing
and operating resources than us, positioning them to potentially maintain or increase their market shares to our
detriment. Companies with larger pools of service and maintenance customers than us benefit from their
incumbent status with those customers and the recurring revenue generated by their service contracts. Our
competitors could adapt more quickly to changes in customer requirements, technological developments and
market trends than we do, differentiate themselves more effectively, for example by using technological
innovation to develop a disruptive elevator model, or improve the functionality or performance of their products
and services more quickly or in a more cost-effective manner. Some of the smaller service companies with which
our Service and Modernization businesses compete may be more agile and price-competitive in their local
markets and may as a result, undercut our ability to win new customers and retain the existing ones.

If we are not able to compete effectively, our market share may reduce, there may be further pressure on our
prices and our sales and margins may decline, all of which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operations, financial position and prospects.

**_Our future business success depends on our ability to respond to evolving market trends with innovative_**
**_products and services on competitive terms._**

The elevator technology market is characterized by a degree of technological change, as well as by product
enhancements and developments, especially in the service and modernization markets. Our future success is
therefore dependent on our ability to anticipate customer needs, develop and market new products and services
and differentiate our product and service offerings from those of our competitors on a timely basis and on
commercially attractive terms. Changes in customer requirements and preferences, new substitute technologies or
evolving industry standards and practices could render our existing products obsolete or less attractive.

In particular, the elevator technology market is currently subject to a number of market trends and technical
developments to which we are required to respond. The trend towards digitalization and other advances has led to
a growth in potential new applications across the elevator and escalator markets, such as so-called smart
elevators and escalators and smart buildings, which use digital technology to enhance efficiency and
performance, leading in turn to higher customer expectations. For example, customers are increasingly
demanding that their elevators deliver reduced travel and waiting time, more customized and convenient travel,
higher safety and quality standards and increased energy efficiency. In order to develop suitable solutions for
such changing customer expectations, we have made in the past, and we expect we will continue to make in the
future, substantial investments into research and development. There can be no assurance, however, that these
efforts will be successful or that potential customers will not prefer solutions offered by our competitors.

Moreover, developing new products and product lines is complex, time-consuming and costly, and involves a
high degree of risk. Our ability to bring new products to the market may require both significant external funding
and reinvestment of profit, including to acquire additional equipment and production capacity. Delays may occur
irrespective of these efforts, resulting in forgone sales revenue and reputational damage. Moreover, market
developments are difficult to predict and our products and technologies may not gain as wide an acceptance as
we expected at the time of our investment. For example, we have recently launched products such as “MAX,”
our cloud- based maintenance tool, and have products in the development pipeline, such as our MULTI elevator
system, in which we have invested considerable time and money. It is not yet clear whether these products will
win widespread customer acceptance or meet our financial expectations in a timely manner, if at all.
Furthermore, the development and marketing of new products can lead to cost overruns in case of inaccurate
planning and budgeting.

If we fail to adapt to prevailing trends and customer requirements in a timely manner or if our products and
services do not gain market acceptance or experience significant cost overruns, our investments in research and
development may not yield expected returns, our market share could reduce and our reputation may be impacted.
Any or all of these could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition
and prospects.

43


-----

**_The outbreak of COVID-19 and its global economic impact may materially affect our business and results of_**
**_operations._**

Our business could be adversely affected by the outbreak of contagious diseases, including the recent outbreak of
COVID-19. COVID-19 was first announced in December 2019 in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China and since then
has spread to most regions of the world including Europe, Asia, North America and South America. Following
the outbreak of COVID-19 in other countries, the World Health Organization declared COVID-19 to constitute a
global pandemic. COVID-19 has resulted in lockdowns and various levels of restrictions of movement being
imposed globally, including most countries in which we sell our products and services. The restrictions include
curtailing travel, closure of schools, prohibitions of mass gatherings, mandatory remote working, and in some
countries, the ability to access construction sites and office buildings.

Specifically to our business, all the regions in which we operate our Elevator and Escalator division were
affected by varying degrees. The Access Solutions division has been affected in each of its home solutions and
airport solutions offerings. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Coronavirus (COVID-19).”

Measures and restrictions by governments have caused and may continue to cause the overall macroeconomic
conditions in the regions in which we operate and the end-markets in which we sell our products and services to
deteriorate. Were a recession to occur, we cannot predict the length of such recession or the short- and long-term
impact it may have on the global economy or our business specifically. Any or all such consequences may have
an adverse impact on our business and results of operations.

The extent of the impact of COVID-19 on our operational and financial performance will depend on future
developments, including the duration and spread of the outbreak and related travel advisories and restrictions and
the impact of COVID-19 on the overall economy and pace of its overall recovery, all of which are highly
uncertain and cannot be predicted. In addition, COVID-19 may delay or diminish the global trend of increasing
urbanization, which could reduce global demand for new construction and therefore impact our business.
According to IHS, global residential construction spending is expected to decline by 1.5% in 2020, as opposed to
pre-COVID-19 estimates of a growth of 1.9%. Further, global non-residential construction is expected to decline
by 1.7% in 2020, as opposed to pre-COVID-19 estimates of a growth of 1.5%. There are no comparable recent
events that provide us with guidance, and so we cannot assure you that COVID-19 and its consequent economic
effects, or any future outbreak of another virus or other contagious diseases, will not have a material adverse
effect on our business and results of operations. To the extent COVID-19 continues to adversely affect our
business, operations, financial condition and operating results, it may also have the effect of heightening other
risks described in this section, such as those related to indebtedness, our need to generate sufficient cash flows to
service our high level of indebtedness, and our ability to comply with the covenants contained in the agreements
that govern our indebtedness.

**_We may not be able to adjust our personnel and production capacity in line with demand for our products and_**
**_services._**

Demand for our products and services is a function of a wide range of factors, including market cyclicality and
other dynamics, and can be difficult to predict. In particular, the New Installation business is closely linked with
the construction sector and is therefore exposed to significant fluctuations in construction activity levels.
Economic uncertainty, particularly economic downturns, may make it difficult for us to estimate the optimal
level of production capacity, to match our workforce size with conditions in the affected markets and to predict
our future working capital requirements.

From time to time we have experienced, and we may experience in the future, under-utilization of our production
and installation personnel capacity at several of our production facilities as a result of overestimating demand for
our products and services. Capacity under-utilization may result in lower returns on the capital invested in
building such capacity, write-offs on fixed assets and lower product prices, as well as personnel and other costs
associated with maintaining an unnecessarily large workforce, each of which can result in reduced profit
margins. We use measures such as flexible work hours, outsourcing of certain tasks, temporary workers and
production network configuration to calibrate production and personnel capacity. However, these measures may
be inadequate if the decline in demand for our products and services is greater than expected. In addition, we may
not be able to adjust production capacity or personnel in response to economic or market downturns as planned
for political, regulatory or legal reasons, such as employment laws and collective agreements that limit our ability
to adjust the size of our workforce in certain jurisdictions, including in member states of the European Union.
Restructuring measures in connection with capacity adjustments, such as those we have undertaken in our
Middleton, Neuhausen and other manufacturing facilities, could also lead to significant one-off costs.

44


-----

Conversely, if we underestimate demand and have inadequate capacity to meet customer requirements, we may
be compelled to turn away business or miss shipping and project deadlines, resulting in contractual penalties, loss
of customers and market share, loss of revenue and damage to our reputation.

Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial
condition and prospects.

**_Products that do not meet customer specifications or that contain defects or errors could result in significant_**
**_costs for us, including from warranty and product liability claims._**

We are subject to the risk of product defects and defective installation, maintenance or modernization services.
Our New Installation products typically include a contractual one to three year warranty period, but may be
subject to a warranty period of up to according to statutory building laws, depending on the applicable
legislation. The risks are especially present when products are first introduced or when new versions or
enhancements of existing products are released. When the potential for systemic product defects is higher, such a
defect may impact an entire class of products. Product defects or negligence in the provision of services, or
allegations of such, can give rise to contractual warranty, product liability, negligence and other claims. This can
be the case even if the product defect in question is caused by a faulty component or equipment provided by a
third-party supplier. Moreover, we are often contractually required to indemnify customers for damages or losses
resulting from defective products or negligently performed services. Product defects may also necessitate costly
product recalls.

In addition, defects in our products could have severe consequences on end-users and third parties, including
injury and loss of life. In the event of an accident involving our products or services, we could be subject to
claims for negligence, claims in relation to fatal accidents, personal injury, physical damage, product liability and
other lawsuits. Such lawsuits and other similar proceedings can be expensive to defend and may divert the
attention of management and other personnel, regardless of the ultimate outcome. While we have a third-party
product liability insurance program, there can be no assurances that such insurance will provide coverage against
all potential liabilities or that we will be able to maintain such insurance on commercially reasonable terms, if at
all. Similarly, we generally record warranty provisions in our accounts based on past experience and known
claims, but there can be no assurance that such provisions will be adequate for any liability ultimately incurred as
a result of potential product defects or negligence in connection with any of our businesses. In addition, product
defects could require costly product re-designs, recall actions and could damage our reputation, which could in
turn harm our customer relationships and lead to reduced sales. It is also possible that product defects could
result in criminal liability for members of our management regarding their conduct relating to the relevant
product defect, including charges of involuntary homicide or negligent physical injury, which could also damage
our reputation and divert the attention of management from its responsibilities.

Any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations and prospects.

**_Our products and services are subject to a range of different legal and regulatory requirements worldwide,_**
**_compliance with which is costly and burdensome and non-compliance with which may result in significant_**
**_costs and liabilities._**

Our products and services must comply with a broad range of complex legal and regulatory requirements in the
numerous jurisdictions in which we operate. Such laws and regulations include, among others, building codes,
health and safety regulations, industry standards, laws governing public bidding processes, and labor laws
governing local employee and sub-contractor relationships. Such laws and regulations may vary substantially by
jurisdiction, and even within certain jurisdictions. For example, within the United States, each individual state
has adopted a specific building code which references standards for elevators and escalators and which is based,
in most cases, on the International Building Code (“IBC”), in some cases with local variations. Within the EU, an
array of directives and regulations relating to lifts and public safety apply to our business, including technical lift
regulations and safety norms for existing lifts, complemented by laws promulgated by individual member states
such as Germany, France, Italy and Spain. Other key jurisdictions where we do business, including mainland
China, have their own building codes, safety regulations and other laws and regulations which apply to our
products and services. Many jurisdictions regularly revise and update these regulations.

In addition, we are subject to an array of labor laws in the markets where we do business, which are particularly
restrictive in Europe, but can also impact our business in all of our other markets. For example, in South Korea
the government recently passed a directive regulating the degree and conditions under which companies can rely
on local sub-contractors, due to which we will need to employ more service technicians on our rolls to perform

45


-----

services directly and also employ two service technicians for certain services, such as monthly maintenance. The
laws and regulations applicable to our products and services can vary considerably in their content, interpretation
and enforcement from jurisdiction to jurisdiction.

As a result, our cost of compliance with all applicable legal and regulatory requirements is considerable, and
such costs may increase further in the future, given the expected stricter enforcement by regulators globally,
particularly in the areas of safety and energy efficiency. Such laws and regulations are also subject to change on
short notice, imposing an additional compliance burden on us. Any changes to the laws and regulations
governing our products and new product approvals could require modifications to our products as well as our
manufacturing equipment, requiring additional labor and material costs in order to ensure compliance. A
violation by us of applicable laws or regulations or the failure to meet legal or regulatory standards could lead to
the imposition of penalties, fines, damages, recalls, restrictions on or prohibitions of business operations and
other adverse consequences. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, results of operations, reputation and prospects.

**_Demand for our products and services depends on economic conditions globally and in our principal regional_**
**_areas of activity._**

Our results of operations depend significantly on economic conditions globally and in our key jurisdictions of
activity, particularly in Europe/Africa, the Americas and Asia/Pacific. We operate in these key jurisdictions
mainly through our Europe/Africa, Americas and Asia/Pacific segments, which contributed 26%, 41% and 28%,
respectively, of our Operating Segments’ total sales in the 2018/2019 Financial Year, with the outstanding
percentage contributed by our remaining segments for which we do not present geography-based sales splits.

Demand for our products and services, especially in the New Installation business, is driven by activity levels
and capital expenditures within the industries we serve, in particular the residential and commercial construction
industry. These industries are highly cyclical and sensitive to changes in global economic conditions, GDP
growth in the relevant markets, inflation, the interest rate environment and conditions in the credit markets. This
cyclicality may result in significant fluctuations in revenue and profitability from period to period and over the
business cycle. Our New Installation business also serves customers in certain specialized industry segments,
mainly industrial applications and large infrastructure projects (such as subway or metro stations), which are also
sensitive to economic conditions. A weak or uncertain economic environment in one of our key regions or
globally may result in fewer construction, industrial and infrastructure projects and lower business volume for
our customers. This, combined with rising costs of capital and low business and consumer confidence, may cause
customers to delay, cancel, or altogether refrain from New Installation of our products and lower our revenues
from the segment. Even if some customers were to proceed with new installations, the decline in activity levels in
a particular region would likely lead to more competition and pricing pressure on our New Installation business,
which could adversely impact our margins.

This risk may be more pronounced in countries like China, where our New Installation business accounts for a
higher proportion of revenue than in other regions, and where demand for new installations has experienced
downturns in the past due to excessive housing supply and restrictive government policies on new construction in
certain metropolitan cities.

Our Service and Modernization businesses are generally impacted to a lesser extent than New Installations by an
economic downturn as customers in most markets are legally obligated to comply with elevator services and
safety requirements. However, our New Installation business is an important source of new customers for the
Service and Modernization businesses. Therefore, a decline in our New Installation business could therefore
eventually lead to fewer new customers in our Service and Modernization businesses, resulting in lower sales as
well as more competition for services and modernization contracts, putting pressure on the prices we charge for
our services and consequently resulting in lower margins. Poor economic conditions could also encourage
customers to delay modernization initiatives.

Volatility in global financial markets, higher interest rates, unemployment rates, trade policy and conflicts,
consumer confidence, lower corporate earnings, tighter credit conditions and public and private debt levels could
impact economic conditions. Furthermore, geopolitical tensions, terrorism, natural catastrophes, pandemics or
other unforeseen events may prompt unexpected, short-term responses from the markets and declines in demand
for our products, leading to lower sales. For example, Europe, our largest geographic market, is facing sharply
slowing economic growth and a number of structural issues, including lingering debt crises and political
instability in certain EU member states and deteriorating confidence in the institutions of the European Union,
each of which could pose a threat to future European integration and cause prolonged economic uncertainty or an
economic downturn. In addition, economic and financial conditions may continue to be adversely affected by the
United Kingdom’s exit from the European Union.

46


-----

Global economic developments are also currently subject to a high degree of uncertainty with respect to the
stability of the global trade and tariff framework. The trade war between the United States and China, withdrawal
from or renegotiation of bi- and multi-lateral trade agreements by the United States, or any countermeasures by
regional or global trading partners, including the European Union, could have a negative impact on the global
economic environment. These could result in lower investment in residential and commercial construction
projects, as well as industrial and infrastructure projects, and a decline in construction levels generally, leading in
turn to less demand for our products. In China, one our most significant individual sales areas, economic growth
decelerated to the slowest annual rate in decades in 2018, as consumer spending and capital investment declined
amid the country’s trade conflict with the United States. The slowing Chinese economy has reportedly adversely
impacted the credit supply, triggering defaults and other payment problems by several construction companies
and leading to suspensions of certain high-rise projects.

Any economic slowdown, downturn or uncertainty, either globally or locally in our markets, could have a
material adverse effect on demand for our products and services. Such events could put pressure on the prices we
charge, resulting in declines in our sales and margins and have a material adverse effect on our business, overall
financial condition and prospects.

**_Our business could be adversely affected by the imposition of protectionist measures, including tariffs and_**
**_other barriers to trade._**

As an international business with production and sales operations across important trading regions, we face
significant risks from a further escalation of tensions between the United States and its trading partners, as well
as a general increase in protectionist measures affecting global trade. Tariffs and other barriers to trade can
adversely affect us in a variety of ways, including by causing less favorable conditions for the import and export
of parts and components and by increasing our cost of production.

Barriers to trade can increase the cost of raw materials, such as steel and aluminum, increasing the cost of parts
and components used to manufacture our products, as well as of spare parts used in our Service and
Modernization businesses. For example, our US operation imports a significant number of components from
external suppliers in China, such as electronic parts and guiderails, which have become more expensive as a
result of the ongoing trade tensions between the United States and China. Trade barriers can also disrupt our
operations within certain countries or markets by delaying imports and exports or by interrupting international
supply lines upon which we rely. Finally, trade barriers can also adversely affect demand for our products
indirectly through the impact they have on our customers’ business growth and investment activities and their
impact on general economic conditions. See “—Demand for our products and services depends on economic
_conditions globally and in our principal regional areas of activity.”_

Any barriers to trade or other protectionist measures may limit our ability to make use of opportunities from
globalized supply chains and other advantages of the global trading system, increase our cost of production or
our products’ prices and could therefore undermine our competitiveness and have an adverse effect on our
business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

**_We are dependent on third-party suppliers, contractors and distributors._**

We are dependent on third-party suppliers, contractors and sub-contractors and distributors for the timely
delivery of high-quality materials, components and equipment for the manufacture of our products.

_Dependence on suppliers._

If a supplier fails to provide materials, components and equipment as contractually required, or provides materials,
components and equipment that are not of an acceptable quality or which contain defects or errors or which are
delivered on a delayed basis, we may be required to source those supplies or equipment services from alternate
sources. This may result in higher costs, production downtime, inventory backlogs, costly adjustments to or a
re-engineering of our products and delayed completion of project milestones. If we use low quality or defective
components or equipment, we may be exposed to contractual warranty, product liability, negligence and other
claims. Supply and service interruptions can be the result of a number of factors beyond our control, including
product shortages, labor strikes, capacity constraints, regulatory issues or financial distress of the supplier.

The risk of supply interruptions is heightened in instances in which we rely on a small number of suppliers for
the provision of a product or service. In addition to the risk of supply interruptions, the supplier of a key product
or service potentially could exert significant bargaining power over price, quality, warranty or other terms
relating to the product or service. We seek to mitigate such risks through the use of supply agreements containing
provisions designed to avoid such scenarios and aim to have at least two suppliers for important parts and
components. However, such agreements and measures may not always be effective.

47


-----

_Dependence on contractors and sub-contractors._

In addition to external suppliers of goods, we also depend on the services of third-party contractors and
sub-contractors for a significant portion of the work performed, especially in our New Installation business. We
may not always be able to hire qualified contractors and sub-contractors at acceptable prices, especially during
periods of high demand when our competitors may block the installation capacities of our main installation
contractors, rendering them unavailable to us. If we are unable to hire qualified contractors or sub-contractors,
our ability to maintain our customer relationships could be impaired. Moreover, we remain responsible for the
successful completion of our contractors or sub-contractors’ work towards our own contractual partners. As a
result, we may be subject to significant reputational damage, losses or liabilities if contractors or sub-contractors
fail to perform, if serious accidents involving the contractors or sub-contractors occur, or should the contractors
or sub-contractors become insolvent. In addition, a failure by a third-party contractor or sub-contractor or
supplier to comply with applicable laws, rules or regulations could negatively impact our business and reputation
and could result in fines, penalties, suspension or, in the case of government contracts, even debarment, which in
turn could adversely impact our reputation and financial results. Although we seek to shift liability for contractor
or sub-contractor underperformance, contract breach or damages to the specific contractor or sub-contractor via
contract, such provisions may not always be effective, in particular where the contractor or sub-contractor in
question is insolvent or otherwise unable to meet its obligations, or in jurisdictions where such contracts may not
always be reliably enforced by local courts.

Many jurisdictions also have laws regulating the treatment of contractors and sub-contractors, with which we
must comply. See “—We are subject to various laws and regulations relating to the protection of the
_environment, health and safety worldwide, compliance with which can be burdensome and non-compliance with_
_which may result in substantial costs.”_

_Dependence on distributors._

We are also dependent on third-party distributors for our sales in a number of jurisdictions. We have a global
sales and services network covering a majority of the world’s countries. More than 60 countries are covered by
our own field operations, whereas approximately 40 countries, most of which are in emerging markets, are served
via distributors. In some countries, where we have our own field operations, we nonetheless use distributors as an
additional sales channel. Our distributing partners sell our products and services either on an exclusive or
non-exclusive basis. Although we believe that our distributors are properly incentivized to sell our products,
there is no assurance that they will not favor a competitor’s products, particularly where we have a non-exclusive
sales relationship with them, or that they will sell our products as effectively as our competitors sell their
products in those markets, or that our distributors will always succeed in meeting our sales targets and other
expectations. If our distributors fail to effectively sell our products, this could have a material adverse effect on
our New Installations sales, and we could lose market share to our competitors in those markets.

Any of the foregoing risks relating to our dependence on third-party suppliers, contractors and distributors could
have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition or prospects.

**_We may fail to achieve the targeted benefits from restructuring and operational improvement measures._**

Efficiency improvements and cost savings are crucial for us to maintain our competitiveness and improve our
profitability. In recent years, our most significant operating expenses have been on an upward trend, pressuring
our profit margins. Our future success will therefore depend, in part, on our ability to implement operational
improvement measures. Such measures could seek to simplify our product portfolio, increase manufacturing
efficiency through restructuring production and optimize supply chains. They could also seek to reduce our
SG&A expenses by streamlining management, centralizing administrative costs and improving IT systems. In
developing our financial targets relating to sales growth and profitability, we have made certain assumptions
about the financial impact that these operational improvement measures will have on our future financial results.
However, there can be no assurance that these initiatives will yield the targeted benefits, or that they will not
entail higher implementation costs than expected or take longer to implement than expected.

In addition, the adjustments to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA annualizing the impact of certain cost saving
measures and adding back expected synergies from certain operational improvement initiatives presented in this
offering memorandum should be treated with caution when making an investment decision. The assumptions we
have made with respect to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA that we present in this offering memorandum are based
on our current estimates and they involve risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that may cause
actual results, performance or achievements to be materially different from any anticipated future results,
performance or achievements expressed or implied by such adjusted financial information. Our anticipated cost

48


-----

saving and operational run-rate synergies are based upon assumptions about our ability to implement cost saving
measures in a timely fashion and within certain cost parameters. Our ability to achieve planned cost saving and
operational run-rate synergies is dependent upon a significant number of assumptions, some of which may be
beyond our control, including the development of the markets for our products and services, political, legal,
fiscal, market and economic conditions, regulatory developments, and tariff and wage increases. If one or more
of our underlying assumptions regarding these measures proves to have been incorrect, these efforts could lead to
substantially higher costs than planned and we may not be able to realize fully, or realize in the anticipated
timeframe, the expected benefits from our cost saving and operational measures. In addition, cost saving and
operational efficiencies from improved production processes may not be able to be sustained due to changes in
customer needs, changes in regulations, availability and cost of materials or other cost variables.

Our new business initiatives could also result in unintended consequences, such as the loss of key customers and
suppliers and strikes and other industrial actions by our employees, which could undermine the benefits of the
operational improvements by disrupting production and leading to different costs. Operational efficiency
measures generally require a significant amount of management attention and resources, which may disrupt or
otherwise have an adverse effect on our ongoing business operations. These factors may offset the cost savings
we anticipate and which we have included in our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. Consequently, our inability to
realize our anticipated cost savings could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and
results of operation.

**_We are subject to project management and execution risks in connection with our New Installation business._**

Our installation work may require complex project management and execution by our supervisors, employees
and sub-contractors, in particular to ensure completion deadlines are met and costs are managed to ensure
appropriate margins. Costs and contractual completion dates are based on many assumptions which include, in
particular, the cost and availability of labor, equipment and materials, and can be adversely affected by local
weather conditions, delays in the commencement of construction work, strikes or other work stoppages, quality
problems with products and components, the timely performance of suppliers and sub-contractors or other third
parties and unanticipated technical problems, among other events over which we may have no or only limited
control. We have in the past borne time and cost overruns due to unforeseen reasons, including project-delay
costs not chargeable to customers, and re-work issues and in some cases, suffer consequential contractual
penalties. If we are unable to control these factors in our ongoing or future projects, it could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_Our business depends on the price and availability of high-quality raw materials, parts and components._**

We purchase a broad range of components and parts in connection with our manufacturing operations. These
include electric and electronic components like traction machines and printed circuit board assembly, as well as
mechanical components like guiderails, shaft/cabin doors, speed governors and escalator steps, among others.
These components often contain raw materials such as steel, aluminum and rare earths (which are used in
magnets), and therefore their price and availability is impacted by fluctuations in the underlying raw material
costs. The cost of parts and components represents a significant portion of our total costs.

Prices for raw materials, components and parts are susceptible to fluctuations, driven by global or regional
supply/demand dynamics in commodity and end markets, production capacity constraints of suppliers,
availability of certain materials, transportation costs, infrastructure failures, government regulations and tariffs,
geopolitical events, changes in currency exchange rates, the economic climate and other factors. Price increases
attributable to such price fluctuations, along with increasing transportation costs, can create pressure on our profit
margins. If the prices of these parts and components increase in the future, and we are not able to at least partially
pass such increases on to customers in the form of higher prices or otherwise mitigate costs, this could negatively
affect our profitability. We do not hedge our exposure to raw material price increases.

We are also subject to the risk of supply shortages for key raw materials used in our parts and components. A
shortage of these could arise from increases in demand due to strong economic and market conditions, decreases
in extraction and production due to natural disasters, political instability or unrest or production limits imposed in
extracting and producing countries. For example, China, which is currently the predominant producer of rare
earth elements, has limited the export of such elements in the past and is increasingly using other mechanisms,
such as an export licensing system or the imposition of higher raw material duties, which has caused adverse
price movements in the past and could limit access to such materials. Shortages in the availability of key parts
and components due to shortages in the underlying raw materials may result in production shortfalls that could, if
significant, result in the inability to fulfill customer orders and complete projects, and result in a loss of business

49


-----

volume. Any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, results of
operations, financial condition and prospects.

**_Unforeseen business interruptions at production facilities or other operational problems may lead to_**
**_production bottlenecks or project delays._**

Our success depends on the uninterrupted and reliable operation of our manufacturing operations. Unforeseen
disruption of a production facility could be caused by a number of events, including a maintenance outage, power
or equipment failure, fires, floods, earthquakes or other natural disasters, social unrest or terrorist activity, work
stoppages, public health concerns (including pandemics), regulatory measures or other operational problems. For
instance, many of our manufacturing facilities experienced temporary shutdowns due to COVID-19 recently.
Serious construction site accidents, particularly those resulting in fatalities, can lead to production disruptions
and even lengthy work stoppages caused by regulatory or other official interventions.

A prolonged disruption at a manufacturing facility could result in production downtimes or temporary operation
at reduced capacity preventing us from completing production orders in a timely manner, loss of business
volume, and reduced productivity or profitability at a particular production site. Even less severe problems
involving our production facilities, such as missed shipment dates, split shipments, defective software or
materials, or logistics problems, could lead to project delays or other problems in our New Installation business.
It could also result in significant repair costs and, in severe cases, injuries or loss of life that are not or not
completely covered by our insurance coverage.

Any production downtime, stoppage at our facilities or project sites, serious accidents or other operational
problems and delays, if significant, could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, results of
operations, financial condition and prospects.

**_We are subject to risks relating to public sector contracts and non-compliance with regulations on public_**
**_procurement._**

We derive a material portion of our revenues from governmental entities, quasi-governmental organizations and
state-owned businesses. Projects involving governments or governmental agencies carry various risks inherent in
the government contracting process. For example, business generated from public or quasi-public entities may be
affected by political and administrative decisions concerning levels of public spending or changes in
governments and their economic policies. Decisions to decrease public spending or changes in priorities or other
unforeseen issues may result in the termination or downscaling of public sector contracts, which could result in a
loss of revenue and limit our recovery of incurred costs, reimbursable expenses and profits on work completed
prior to the termination. Contractual non-compliance, failure to comply with procurement regulations and laws
regarding the protection of classified information, violation of non-discrimination rules or environmental, health
and safety regulations and other improper or illegal activities, may result in various civil and criminal penalties
and administrative sanctions, which may include termination of contracts, forfeiture of profits, exclusion from
future tenders, suspension of payments, fines and suspensions or debarment from doing business with the
government. Government contracts are also often subject to more extensive scrutiny and publicity than other
contracts. Any negative publicity related to such contracts, regardless of the accuracy of such publicity, may
adversely affect our business and reputation. The realization of any of these risks could have a material adverse
effect on our reputation, business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_We may fail to successfully identify, enter into or integrate acquisitions and/or successfully execute disposals._**

We have made acquisitions and disposals in the past and we anticipate we will enter into such transactions in the
future. For example, in May 2019, we announced the acquisition of Nashville Machine Elevator Co., Inc.,
followed in July by the announcement that we had acquired O’Keefe Elevator Company Inc., both in the United
States. Corporate acquisitions and disposals are associated with significant risks. We may not be able to identify
suitable acquisition candidates in the future. Even if we do identify a suitable acquisition candidate, we may not
be able to finance such acquisition on favorable terms, if at all. Diligence reviews of acquisition targets may not
identify all of the material issues necessary to accurately estimate the cost or potential loss contingencies with
respect to a particular transaction, including potential exposure to regulatory sanctions resulting from an
acquisition target’s previous activities. We may incur unanticipated costs or expenses in connection with such
transactions, including post-closing asset impairment charges, expenses associated with eliminating duplicate
facilities, litigation and other liabilities, including related to warranties. We may also encounter difficulties in
integrating acquisitions with our operations, applying our internal controls processes to these acquisitions or in
managing strategic investments. Target companies may be located in countries in which the underlying legal,

50


-----

economic, political and cultural conditions do not correspond to those customary in our key areas of activity or
have other national peculiarities with which we are not familiar. Moreover, any planned acquisition may be
subject to review and approval by the competition and other regulatory authorities of a number of jurisdictions,
which may impede a planned transaction.

We may not realize the targets for growth, economies of scale, cost savings, development, production and
distribution targets, or other strategic goals that we seek from the acquisition to the extent or in the timeframe
anticipated, and the attention of management and other personnel may be diverted for long periods of time.
Moreover, the purchase price may prove to have been too high or unforeseen restructuring or integration
expenses may become necessary. Failure to successfully complete our corporate acquisitions or the acquisition of
equity interests in companies could adversely affect our business, results of operations, financial condition and
prospects.

Furthermore, we may make strategic disposals from time to time. Disposals may result in continued financial
involvement in the divested businesses, such as through guarantees or other financial arrangements, following the
completion of the respective transactions. Under these arrangements, non- performance by those divested
businesses could result in financial obligations for us and could affect our future financial results. In addition, we
could be subject to potential liabilities resulting from contractual warranties and indemnities, as well as
regulatory risks of not being able to obtain required approvals.

The materialization of any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of
operations, financial condition and prospects.

**_We are exposed to foreign exchange translation and transaction risks, which may reduce our operating_**
**_results, and our hedging activities may not be effective._**

Our reporting currency is the euro. However, we conduct our business in a large number of countries across the
globe and in several international currencies. In the years ended September 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, 77% of our
net sales were generated by operating subsidiaries with a functional currency (generally the local currency) other
than the euro. In terms of our results of operations, the US dollar, the Chinese renminbi, the Brazilian real, the
Canadian dollar and the South Korean won are the most important foreign currencies. Any change in exchange
rates between foreign currencies and the euro affects our reported results of operations and assets and liabilities
when the results of those subsidiaries are translated into euro for reporting purposes. In preparing combined and
consolidated financial statements, assets and liabilities of subsidiaries are translated into euro at the foreign
exchange rates at the balance sheet date. Income statements of subsidiaries are translated to euro at the average
exchange rates for the period. Accordingly, fluctuations in the value of other currencies against the euro reduce
or increase these subsidiaries’ contribution to, among other things, our net sales and profit and thus also affect
our statement of financial position.

Among the factors that affect foreign exchange rates are trade balances, short-term interest rates, differences in
relative values of similar assets in different currencies, long-term opportunities for investment and capital
appreciation, and other macroeconomic and political developments, including deliberate manipulation by certain
countries of their currencies. The exchange rates between the foreign currencies and the euro have fluctuated
significantly in recent years and may continue to do so in the future. Unfavorable fluctuations in the values of the
currencies in which our international subsidiaries’ financial statements are prepared against the euro could have a
material negative impact on our future consolidated financial statements.

We are also exposed to transactional risk to the extent our subsidiaries and us execute transactions in a currency
other than our functional currency, which arises mainly when we import components from one jurisdiction,
incurring a cost in that jurisdiction’s currency, and invoice for our products and installation in the local currency.
Our transactional risk exposure is less significant than our translation risk exposure, because we produce and
install our products predominantly in our key markets, which generally has the effect of matching the currencies
of our costs with those of our sales. Nonetheless, adverse exchange rate movements can impact the profitability
of our New Installation business and, to a lesser degree, the Modernization business, to the extent key imported
components become more expensive in our local sales areas.

We generally manage our transactional foreign currency risk related to booked transactions through different
foreign exchange hedging strategies, mainly consisting of derivative foreign exchange instruments and split
currency sales contracts. There can be no assurance that we can always enter into such arrangements on
acceptable terms, that such arrangements will be available at all times when we wish to use them, that the
relevant over-the-counter counterparty will always be able to fulfill our contractual obligations or that these
strategies will be sufficient to effectively mitigate the transactional foreign exchange risks described above. In
addition, we do not hedge our foreign currency translation risk exposure.

51


-----

Our exposure to exchange rate volatility, our unsecured translation risks and a failure to adequately hedge
transactional risks could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and
prospects.

**_We are subject to risks related to our international operations._**

We have manufacturing operations, customers, and projects worldwide, including in a number of emerging
markets. As a result, we are subject to various risks inherent in international business operations, including:

- political and economic instability and exposure to potentially undeveloped legal systems;

- unexpected or unfavorable changes in foreign laws, regulatory requirements and related interpretations;

- difficulties in attracting and retaining locally qualified management and employees;

- staffing challenges, including those related to works councils, labor unions and immigration laws;

- exposure to economic sanctions, laws and regulations, trade barriers, local content requirements and import
and export licensing requirements;

- logistical and communications difficulties;

- requirements to expend a portion of funds locally and governmental industrial cooperation requirements,
coups, increased risk of fraud and political corruption, terrorism, or acts of war;

- exposure to local public health issues and the resulting impact on economic conditions;

- the complexity of managing competing and overlapping tax regimes;

- foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations and currency controls;

- greater risk of uncontrollable accounts and longer collection cycles;

- the risk of government-sponsored competition; and

- controls on the repatriation of cash.

In particular, we have significant operations in mainland China and derive a significant portion of our revenues
from Chinese customers. As a consequence, we are increasingly subject to economic and political risks in
mainland China, as well as certain Chinese laws and regulations regarding foreign-invested enterprises, including
foreign currency exchange rules. Moreover, as laws and regulations in mainland China are gradually evolving,
there may be uncertainty in their interpretation and enforcement. The administrative and court authorities in
China have significant discretion in interpreting and implementing statutory terms. Thus, it may be more difficult
for us to evaluate the outcome of administrative and court proceedings in China, should they arise, than in other
systems.

Our overall success as a global business depends to a considerable extent on our ability to anticipate and
effectively manage differing legal, political, social and regulatory requirements and economic conditions and
unforeseeable developments. The materialization of local business risks or our inability to adapt to changing
conditions in markets outside of our core markets could have significant adverse effects on our business, results
of operations and financial condition.

**_We are subject to risks arising from legal disputes and government proceedings._**

We are, and may in the future become involved in or threatened with, legal proceedings in the ordinary course of
our business, including disputes with suppliers, sub-contractors, customers, employees and investors concerning,
among other things, breaches of contract, product defects and liability, intellectual property, labor and
environmental or shareholder rights issues. Furthermore, we may become subject to proceedings by
governmental authorities in connection with our compliance with laws and regulatory requirements, including in
the areas of antitrust, tax, environmental and safety matters. For example, we have in the past been fined a total
of €319.8 million by the European Commission for violation of EU antitrust rules and currently face private
enforcement claims in relation to our participation in elevator cartels in several EU jurisdictions, the current total
value of the claims being approximately €150 million. See “—We are exposed to legal risks regarding antitrust
_regulation and related enforcement actions and damage claims.” In addition, four fatal accidents in South Korea_
resulting in the deaths of five employees from consortium partners of our South Korean subsidiary have led to
criminal and administrative proceedings for alleged violation of various health and safety-related rules, as well as
construction industry and elevator regulations in connection with the use of sub-contractors. The alleged

52


-----

violations of health and safety and construction industry regulations may result in the imposition of monetary
fines and a suspension of the New Installation business license in South Korea for a period of time ranging from
several months to, in a worst case scenario, a much longer period, depending on the final outcome of the
proceedings. The alleged violations of the elevator regulations could result in monetary fines as well as
suspension of our Service business license in South Korea for at least two years. In addition, we could suffer
reputational damage in South Korea as a consequence of the proceedings. Although we do not anticipate lengthy
suspensions of the New Installation or Service business licenses to be a likely outcome of the proceedings, there
is no guarantee that this will prove to be correct. The outcome of pending or potential future legal or regulatory
proceedings is, as a general matter, difficult to predict. If such proceedings are resolved against us, we may be
subject to civil, criminal or other penalties, as well as damages, as described above, which may exceed any
provisions set aside or any available insurance coverage or be required to change our business practices. Even if
we ultimately prevail in legal and regulatory proceedings, defending such actions can be costly and result in the
diversion of management’s attention away from our business.

Any legal or regulatory proceeding pending or threatened against us could have a material adverse effect on our
reputation, business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

**_We are exposed to legal risks regarding antitrust regulation and related enforcement actions and damage_**
**_claims._**

We are subject to antitrust regulation in the European Union and other jurisdictions and therefore face a number
of legal risks in connection with anticompetitive business practices.

A finding of infringement of antitrust regulations can result in: significant fines, based on, among other factors,
the infringing entity’s annual turnover; private enforcement claims by third parties, such as customers and/or
competitors; a requirement to change business practices that may result in reduced revenues and/or margins; and
reputational damage. In addition, antitrust rules and regulations in certain jurisdictions may impose restrictions
on our ability to carry out certain acquisitions, enter into joint ventures, or require forced divestments or the
implementation of other measures.

The elevator technology industry has seen heightened scrutiny by antitrust authorities in recent years and we
have faced, and may in the future face, significant antitrust enforcement actions. In 2007, the European
Commission imposed fines on thyssenkrupp AG, the Target’s holding company, and its affiliates as well as other
global elevator manufacturers for participation in cartels for the installation and maintenance of lifts and
escalators in Germany, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands in violation of EU antitrust rules. The
European Commission decision cited impermissible restrictive business practices, including rigged bids for
procurement contracts, price fixing, allocation of projects among competitors, and the exchange of business
secrets and other confidential information, among other offenses. thyssenkrupp AG and its subsidiaries were
fined €479.7 million in 2007, an amount that was subsequently reduced to €319.8 million. We avoided a fine
from similar investigations by the Austrian Federal Competition Authority by acting as a crown witness. Private
enforcement claims in connection with these matters have been filed both in and out of court against
thyssenkrupp AG and its subsidiaries in a number of jurisdictions, including Belgium, Austria and the
Netherlands. The claimants allege that the cartel led to cartel overcharges and umbrella damages in relation to
sales by third-party competitors not participating in the cartel, the total value of the claims being approximately
€150 million plus interest. Our indemnity under the Share Purchase Agreement for these claims is capped to
€29 million and is only applicable for existing claims. We have set aside provisions for those pending claims
which, in our opinion, will probably lead to cash outflows.

Adverse judgments in these or potential future antitrust matters could result in substantial liability for us, which
could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and reputation.

**_The pricing of cross border transactions is often the subject of negotiation with tax authorities, and any_**
**_adjustments imposed may lead to the greater or double taxation of profits._**

Most national tax authorities follow the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development or United
Nations guidelines when considering the arm’s length nature of cross border pricing of goods and services.
Adjustments made by a national tax authority may not lead to a corresponding adjustment in the other tax
jurisdiction. Also, even where a corresponding tax adjustment is allowed, national tax rates may be different and
may therefore increase our overall burden of taxation. Our cross border trade is increasing and, although we
benchmark our intercompany pricing regularly, the risk of an adverse adjustment will require constant
monitoring, which may require a substantial amount of management resources. Potential discrepancies in the
adjustments made by the tax authorities in certain jurisdictions may result in an increased tax burden on our
Group.

53


-----

**_We may be exposed to transfer price risks in connection with our operating activities._**

We take advantage of our international network and centralize our strategic functions. In particular, we transfer
and provide goods and services among the companies of the Group by adopting a corporate tax transfer frame
model for the billing of intercompany services. There is a risk that tax authorities in individual countries will
assess the relevant transfer prices differently from our tax transfer pricing model and address retroactive tax
claims against one of our companies. While our tax transfer pricing model has been audited by the competent
authorities in certain countries, in others such model is still under discussion with the authorities. A German
Group company had been subject to a tax audit related to transfer pricing issues for the financial years 2010 to
2012. According to the view of the German tax authorities, the transfer prices for supplies of products between
such Group company and foreign Group companies had been determined incorrectly. Consequently, those
transfer prices had been adjusted for the financial years 2010 to 2012. Such adjustment was rolled-over to the
financial years 2013 to 2015. Presumably, such transfer pricing adjustments will also be undertaken in the course
of audits for subsequent financial years. Also in other cases, there can be no assurance that our transfer prices
will be accepted by all the relevant authorities. If they fail to be accepted, this could have a material adverse
effect on our financial condition, results of operations and ability to perform our obligations under the Notes.

**_We are dependent on good relationships with our employees and their trade unions as well as employee_**
**_representative bodies and stakeholders and are party to a number of collective agreements._**

We are dependent on good relationships with our employees, trade unions, employee representative bodies such
as works councils (Betriebsräte) and other stakeholders to successfully operate our business. Personnel expenses
make up a significant portion of our costs and we are obliged to comply with various collective agreements, such
as collective bargaining agreements and works council agreements that are in place with trade unions as well as
works councils and other employee representative bodies. Employees at our German locations and at a number of
foreign subsidiaries have traditionally been heavily unionized and we regularly conduct, or are involved in,
negotiations with the relevant trade unions and employee representative bodies. Any deterioration of these
relationships could adversely impact our business operations.

We have faced strikes and other types of conflicts with trade unions and our employees in the past and may face
them again in the future. In particular, these could come up again when current collective agreements expire or
are to be negotiated. Solidarity strikes at other entities within our Group may also occur. Any such strikes,
conflicts, work stoppages or other industrial actions may disrupt our production and sales activities, damage our
reputation and adversely affect our customer relations, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Many collective agreements impose obligations and restrictions on us that may adversely affect our flexibility to
undertake adjustments to our workforce, restructurings, reorganizations and similar corporate actions.
Approximately 4,751 of our 52,567 employees as of March 31, 2020 enjoy some form of special protection
against dismissal based on contractual commitments which are contained in, inter alia, collective agreements (in
particular, the “Future Elevator” agreement concluded in March 2020), which means that ordinary dismissals of
these employees are in general not possible or, depending on the scope of the additional protection, are subject to
special requirements. These commitments are over and above the requirements under applicable labor laws. For
example, in March 2020, thyssenkrupp Elevator concluded a collective bargaining agreement “Future Elevator”
with German IG Metall in connection with the Acquisition. The “Future Elevator” collective bargaining
agreement excludes forced redundancies (Ausschluss betriebsbedingter Beendigungskündigungen) and site
guarantees (Standortsicherungszusagen) for the German production and essential service sites and is valid until
March 31, 2027. Further, we also have in place a collective agreement including a site guarantee
(Standortsicherungszusage) for the site in Neuhausen (Germany) until September 30, 2022. In addition, we have
in place collective agreements excluding ordinary dismissals (Beschäftigungssicherung) for Neuhausen until
September 30, 2022 and for 390 employees of the German field organization until September 30, 2026, with an
option to terminate the agreement on September 30, 2022.

Any restructuring or reorganizational measures, including the commercial operations cost savings measures that
we succeed in carrying out as part of the Transformation Program, may strain relations with employees and their
representatives. This may make it more difficult for us to subsequently negotiate, renew or extend collective
agreements in a favorable and timely manner. We may also become subject to new collective agreements, which
may increase our operating costs. In addition, our competitors may obtain competitive advantages compared to
us, if they succeed in negotiating collective wage agreements or other collective agreements on more favorable
terms and conditions. Any failure to negotiate wages and other key employment conditions that are reasonable
and fair from our perspective could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations or prospects.

54


-----

**_Our success depends substantially on our ability to attract, hire, train and retain experienced management and_**
**_personnel._**

Our management team has substantial expertise and industry experience and the loss of key members of
management could adversely affect our ability to implement our strategic objectives. Further, we are also
dependent on personnel that are highly skilled and qualified in scientific, mechanical and technical fields. In
some jurisdictions, the technicians servicing our products are required by local regulations to have special
qualifications, limiting the supply of such technicians. In the United States, a shortage in qualified technicians
has already led to hiring constraints and in the Asia/Pacific market, technicians typically need to receive
extensive in-house training before they can start servicing our products.

Our success in attracting and retaining such personnel depends on a variety of factors, including the supply of
qualified candidates in the relevant market, as well as our compensation and benefit programs, work
environment, career development opportunities, commitment to diversity and public image. These factors may
pose greater risks in connection with the Reorganization and the Acquisition. Competition for qualified personnel
is increasing. There can be no assurance that we will be successful in attracting and retaining experienced
management and key technical personnel and any failure to do so could have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

**_The value of goodwill, brand names or other intangible assets reported in our financial statements may need_**
**_to be partially or fully impaired as a result of revaluations._**

As of March 31, 2020, our carrying amount of intangible assets, including goodwill, recorded on our
consolidated statements of financial position was €1,922 million. Under IFRS, we are required to annually test
our recorded goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets and to assess the carrying values of other intangible
assets when impairment indicators exist. Because of such tests, we could be required to recognize impairment
losses in our income statement, if the carrying value is in excess of the fair value or value in use. Factors that
could trigger an impairment of such assets include the underperformance of our business relative to projected
future operating results, negative industry developments or economic trends, including changes in borrowing
rates or weighted average cost of capital, applicable tax rates or changes in working capital. Should we have to
book any impairment losses, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and
financial condition.

**_We have a substantial pension and other similar employee benefits-related obligations and are subject to risks_**
**_related to the development of these obligations and to funding requirements of our pension and other post-_**
**_employment benefit plans._**

We maintain various pension plans providing for company pension and retirement benefits, including defined
benefit pension plans, and have other similar plans providing for long-term employee related benefits, mainly in
our subsidiaries in Germany, the United States, France, South Korea, the United Kingdom and Switzerland. As of
March 31, 2020, our accrued pension obligations amounted to €319 million.

The valuation and development of the defined benefit obligation under these plans depends, among other factors,
upon agreed contributions rates, future asset performance, longevity and the actuarial profile of the plan
participants, level of interest rates used to calculate future liabilities, actuarial assumptions and experience,
effectiveness of amendments made to the benefit plans and government regulations and potential court rulings in
relation to the plan administration and the calculation. Depending on these variables, future cash funding
requirements for our pension plans and other long-term employee related benefit plans could be significantly
higher than the amounts estimated as of March 31, 2020, which could have a material adverse effect on our
results of operations, financial condition or prospects.

If the market value of the plan assets decreases, we may also have to substantially increase our pension
provisions. For example, fluctuations in currency, interest rates, actuarial assumptions and changes in the
valuation of any funding assets may adversely affect the net liabilities for pension plans and similar plans
providing for long-term employee related benefits or, in the case of multi-employer plans like the National
Elevator Industry Pension Plan, the failure of any of the key contributing employers to make adequate
contributions may adversely affect the value of the plan assets. In such event, we may have to cover the shortfall
of funding assets or face significant additional funding obligations, which could have a material adverse effect on
our net assets, financial position and results of operations.

Any significant increase in the present value of our pension and other obligations related to employee benefits
and/or significant decrease in the fair value of the plan assets for a funding of the obligations, could have a
material adverse effect on our net assets, financial position and results of operations.

55
