In accordance with IFRS 8, we report our results of operations in five segments:

- _Americas: Our Americas segment comprises all activities related to the new installation, service and_
modernization of elevators, escalators and moving walks (the “Elevator and Escalator division”) in countries
in North and South America.

- _Europe/Africa: Within our Europe/Africa segment, we report the results of our Elevator and Escalator_
division in countries in Europe and Africa.

- _Asia/Pacific: Within our Asia/Pacific segment, we report the results of our Elevator and Escalator division_
in countries in the Middle East and Asia, Australia and New Zealand.

- _Access Solutions: In addition to our core Elevator and Escalator division, we offer access solutions for_
airports (such as passenger boarding bridges, ground support equipment, visual docking guidance systems,
ancillary equipment products and maintenance services) and homes (such as chairlifts, platform lifts and
home elevators), the results of which are reported in our Access Solutions segment.

- _Corporate Elevator: Within the Corporate Elevator segment, we report the consolidated results of certain_
non-customer facing administrative services that support our operating activities, including services related
to our headquarters, financing, research and development, intellectual property and human resources.

The five reporting segments described above reflect our internal management reporting and are based on the
same accounting principles as the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim
Consolidated Financial Statements. Segment results are reconciled to our Financial Statements taking into
account consolidation effects, which primarily relate to intercompany profits in inventories and the reversal of
intercompany interest income, and retrospective group allocations that represent a proportionate amount of
corporate costs and non-operational effects that were historically recorded at the parent company level without
being recharged to the Elevator Technology Business.

**Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations**

We believe that the factors discussed below have significantly affected our results of operations, financial
condition and cash flow in the historical periods for which financial information is presented in this offering
memorandum, and that these factors will continue to have a material influence on our results of operations,
financial condition and cash flow in the future.

**_Activity levels in the construction industry_**

Demand for our products and services is significantly influenced by activity levels and capital expenditures
within the residential and commercial construction industry, which is highly cyclical and sensitive to changes in
global economic conditions, GDP growth in the relevant markets, inflation, the interest rate environment and
conditions in the credit markets. Our New Installation business, in particular, is influenced by changes in the
global economic conditions, whereas our Service and Modernization businesses are more resilient and have
demonstrated strong and continuous revenue growth during periods of economic distress. Cyclicality in
economic conditions and activity levels in the construction industry may result in significant fluctuations in our
sales and profitability from period to period and over the business cycle, although there tends to be a time lag
between changes in activity levels in the construction industry and the resulting impact on our results of
operations, since elevators and escalators are often among the last items to be installed in new buildings.

A robust economic environment, particularly one marked by low interest rates and borrowing costs, typically
results in strong growth in construction and infrastructure projects, including growth in the construction of new
residential and commercial buildings, which in turn drives demand in our New Installation business and typically

96


-----

has a positive impact on our order intake and sales. Higher activity levels in the construction industry also tend to
lead to increases in the prices that we and our competitors are able to charge customers. Conversely, weaker
economic conditions in our markets tend to lead to lower levels of construction activity and lower demand in our
New Installation business, and therefore generally have a negative impact on our order intake and sales. Due to
economic impact of COVID-19, the global economy is likely entering a period of decline, which will probably
reduce construction activity around the world.

In the periods presented in this offering memorandum, strong construction activity in the Americas during the
2016/2017 and 2017/2018 Financial Years was a key driver of increases in order intake in the Americas segment,
whereas slowing construction activity in the Americas during the 2018/2019 Financial Year resulted in relatively
slower order intake. Overall, our sales declined between 2016/2017 and 2017/2018 but increased between
2017/2018 and 2018/2019, primarily due to the adverse impact of foreign exchange fluctuations.

Over the longer term, we believe that construction activity is more influenced by demographic and population
trends, such as the growth in urbanization, than by short-term economic factors. We believe that urbanization in
particular has been and will continue to be a fundamental long-term driver of demand for multi-story buildings
and large public infrastructure projects, and therefore of elevator and escalator products, notwithstanding shorterterm variations in demand arising from changes to activity levels in the construction industry and economic
developments. See “Industry.”

Our Service and Modernization businesses are impacted by conditions in the construction industry to a lesser
extent than the New Installation business. Services and Modernizations customers tend to enter into multi-year
service contracts and, given that customers in most countries are legally obliged to comply with elevator service
and safety requirements under applicable building codes, our Service business in particular tends to be relatively
stable and less susceptible to fluctuations in construction activity than our New Installation business. However,
construction activity has an indirect effect on our Service and Modernization businesses as the New Installation
business is an important source of new customers for both.

**_Growth of the New Installation business_**

The New Installation business comprises nearly half of our total sales in any given year, contributing 49%, 48%,
46% and 43% of our total sales in the 2016/2017, 2017/2018, 2018/2019 Financial Years (on a combined basis)
and the six months ended March 31, 2020 (on a consolidated basis), respectively. The New Installation
business’s larger importance lies in its significant contribution to growth in new Services and Modernizations
contracts, making it the starting point for our revenue life cycle. Our ability to grow our New Installation
business is therefore crucial to the growth of all three of our business lines. See “—Conversion of New
_Installations units into Services and Modernizations contracts and ability to retain existing, and win new,_
_Services and Modernizations customers.”_

We believe that our ability to consistently manufacture products that are competitive on price, safety, quality and
technology while maintaining an efficient supply chain in order to protect our margins are critical elements of the
growth of our New Installation business. To this end, we are currently in the process of streamlining our product
portfolio and standardizing certain components, as well as implementing a value-selling approach based on
offering customers a flexible pricing model in which pricing is determined by the degree of product
customization. See “—Operational improvement measures.” To a lesser extent, growth in the New Installation
business is also driven by our ability to win high profile mandates, such as prestigious and large-scale high rise
and infrastructure projects, which play a vital role in marketing our lower profile, but higher volume business.

**_Conversion of New Installations units into Services and Modernizations contracts and ability to retain_**
**_existing, and win new, Services and Modernizations customers_**

Our New Installation business is the entry gate to the Service and Modernization businesses, since a high
proportion of newly installed units are subsequently converted into paid Service contracts. The Service and the
Modernization businesses together accounted for 51%, 52%, 54% and 57% of our total sales in the 2016/2017,
2017/2018, 2018/2019 Financial Years (on a combined basis) and six months ended March 31, 2020 (on a
consolidated basis), respectively. Our Service business is a source of stable, recurring sales and high profit
margins for the Group. Service revenues can be categorized into either maintenance or repair sales (including
direct spare parts sales), and vary by segment, typically comprising over half of our sales in Europe/Africa and
the Americas but much less in Asia/Pacific, which is dominated by the New Installation business and Access
Solutions. Profit margins tend to be higher in the Service business than in the New Installation business, mainly
due to the recurring sales model and high customer retention rates. Many Service business’s customers
eventually become customers of the Modernization business, which further extends the customer relationship and
positions us well to provide Services to the modernized units.

97


-----

The key performance indicators for our Service business are the units under maintenance, the conversion rate and
the retention rate:

- _Units under maintenance: Units under maintenance is one of the Service business’s key drivers of sales_
growth. Over the last three financial years, units under maintenance increased at a CAGR of 1.7% to
approximately 1.4 million units as of March 31, 2020.

- _Conversion rate: The conversion rate is calculated as the percentage of New Installation units (excluding_
distributor sales, which do not directly result in access to servicing the relevant units) that have been
converted into paid Service contracts. We estimate that our global conversion rate was between 70% to 80%
in each of the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years. The conversion rate thereby
contributes to the growth of our units under maintenance.

- _Retention rate: The retention rate is a like-for-like metric calculated as units under maintenance at the end of_
the year (excluding new units that were added during the year) divided by units under maintenance at the
beginning of the year. The terms of our service agreements vary by jurisdiction and customer, but most last
from one to five years, with service contracts following an installation often providing for an introductory
period (for example, one to two years) during which the customer is not obligated to pay for services. We
maintained a global average retention rate of above 90% on our service contracts over the last three
financial years.

We believe the key factors driving our conversion and retention rates are the breadth and global reach of our
service network, with approximately 1,000 service branches in our key markets worldwide, the quality of our
Services, our competitive pricing, and our innovative, digitally enhanced maintenance solutions, including
products like MAX and IT solutions such as our operating business steering tool VIEW.

In addition, we provide maintenance and modernization services on elevators and escalators installed by third
parties through our ITS unit. Our ITS unit provides specialized training to our service personnel and focuses on
the efficient refurbishment of spare parts. We believe that our ITS unit is more developed and advanced than that
of our competitors and has enhanced our ability to win Services and Modernizations work from customers of our
competitors.

**_Personnel costs_**

Our results of operations are significantly affected by personnel expenses, which, together with the costs of
materials, represent a significant majority of our operating costs. Personnel costs include wages and salaries,
social security, post-employment and other employee benefit costs. Personnel costs related to production workers
are included in cost of goods sold, whereas personnel costs for non-production workers are included in selling
expenses (for example, for sales force), general and administrative expenses (for example, for human resources
or other administrative functions), and research and development costs (for example, for our research engineers).
Our ability to effectively manage our personnel costs has a significant impact on our gross margin and overall
profitability.

In the periods under review in this offering memorandum, our personnel expenses remained relatively stable at
€3,135 million and €3,078 million in the 2016/2017 and 2017/2018 Financial Years, respectively, and increased
by 5.9% to €3,261 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase in the 2018/2019 Financial Year was
primarily the result of increases in personnel expenses in the Americas and Asia/Pacific segments, reflecting
headcount growth primarily in the Service business as the business grew, as well as higher salaries and wages as
a result of tariff or other salary increases and impacts from translational exchange rate effects, partly offset by
headcount reductions in the Europe/Africa segment. Overall, our workforce remained broadly stable over the
period, with headcount numbers of 52.7 thousand in the 2016/2017 Financial Year, 53.0 thousand in the
2017/2018 Financial Year and 53.1 thousand in the 2018/2019 Financial Year.

We seek to manage personnel expenses mainly through adjusting our staffing levels to match our needs when
necessary, which can result in headcount growth in growing markets and reductions in slowing markets, or as a
result of efficiency measures adopted to offset the impact of personnel cost inflation. Recent examples include
our initiative to consolidate our US administrative functions in a shared service center at our US headquarters in
Atlanta, Georgia, which is expected to result in headcount reductions among back office and other personnel, as
well as our ongoing efforts to reduce complexity and optimize production processes at our manufacturing
facilities in the Americas and Europe. Over the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years, we were
able to offset labor cost inflation by increasing labor efficiency, resulting in a global increase of sales per FTE.

Our ability to implement measures to control our personnel expenses is subject to constraints. In some
jurisdictions, such as the Americas and China, local labor laws and other regulations provide us with a relatively

98


-----

high degree of flexibility in adjusting our employee headcount based on needs, and thereby the attendant
personnel costs. In other jurisdictions, including Germany, our ability to optimize staffing levels and manage
personnel expenses is limited by restrictive labor laws and collective agreements, such as collective bargaining
agreements and works council agreements that are in place with trade unions as well as works councils and other
representative bodies.

**_External procurement spend_**

Our results of operations are significantly affected by our external procurement spend, which, together with
personnel costs, comprises a significant majority of our operating costs. Material cost increases exceeding sales
growth adversely impact our gross margin, and therefore our ability to control material cost is a key lever for
profitability. We manage our global purchasing activities through a Group-wide procurement organization in
order to leverage our purchasing ability and benefit from economies of scale and through implementing
initiatives to offset price inflation.

We purchase components and parts in each of our three business lines, but the largest exposure is in our New
Installation business, which has the highest material costs due to its manufacturing activities. Our purchases
cover a wide range of components, including electric and electronic components such as traction machines and
printed circuit board assemblies, as well as mechanical components such as guiderails, shaft/cabin doors, speed
governors and escalator steps, among others. These components contain raw materials such as steel, aluminum,
and rare earths (which are used in magnets), and therefore prices of these components are impacted by
fluctuations in the underlying raw material cost.

Prices for raw materials, components and parts are susceptible to fluctuations driven by global or regional
supply/demand dynamics in commodity and end markets, production capacity constraints of suppliers,
availability of certain materials, transportation costs, infrastructure failures, government regulations and tariffs,
geopolitical events, changes in currency exchange rates, the economic climate and other factors. For example,
between the 2017/2018 Financial Year and the 2018/2019 Financial Year, material prices increased in the
Americas mainly due to U.S. tariffs, which drove up material import costs. Between the 2016/2017 Financial
Year and the 2017/2018 Financial Year, material prices increased in the Asia/Pacific segment due to adverse
market price developments in China and Korea, which impacted our material costs as a result of the relatively
high proportion of New Installation business in Asia/Pacific. Our operations in China have a high exposure to
material price risk. However, during the 2017/2018 Financial Year when raw materials prices in China increased
significantly compared to the previous year, it only had a limited impact on our Group overall, as the reduction in
Adjusted EBIT in China during that year due to the raw material price increase was less than 5% of our Group’s
total Adjusted EBIT in the same year. In order to reduce this risk, we have, among other things, increased our
sales prices in China and are in regular supplier re-negotiations to reflect the material price movements.

In order to manage our exposure to fluctuations in the prices of components, we try to source our goods on a
Group-wide level to leverage purchasing ability and economies of scale. We also aim to have at least two
suppliers for each component in different geographic regions and regularly review changes in material prices
based on published information. Nevertheless, market prices of parts and components are subject to increases as
a result of the fluctuation dynamics described above. Such price increases, along with increasing transportation
costs, have created some pressure on our profit margins. We seek to pass on cost increases to our customers
where possible; however, due to competition in the elevator and escalator industry, we have not always been able
to pass such increases on to customers in full. During the period under review, we partially offset cost increases
by optimizing our supply chains through commercial measures, such as holding supplier days, clustering
managed spend, and engaging in e-auctions, and technical efficiency measures, such as streamlining our product
platforms and standardizing components. In the 2018/2019 Financial Year, we achieved significant purchasing
savings compared to the prior year through these measures. See “—Operational improvement measures.”

**_Operational improvement measures_**

We operate in an industry where efficiency improvements and cost savings are crucial in order to maintain or
improve competitiveness and profitability. Our operational improvement measures focus broadly on four areas:
(i) simplification of our product portfolio and harmonizing of components in our New Installation business;
(ii) optimizing manufacturing efficiency and supply chains; (iii) increasing profitability by growing our Service
business and enhancing Service quality and efficiency via digital innovations, among other measures; and
(iv) reducing SG&A expenses. We have incurred substantial restructuring costs in connection with our
operational improvement measures, amounting to €106 million, €35 million and €56 million in the 2016/2017,
2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years (on a combined basis), respectively and €13 million in the six months
ended March 31, 2020 (on a consolidated basis). Restructuring costs in 2016/2017 were primarily driven by

99


-----

restructurings in Germany and France, whereas restructuring costs in 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 related to
restructurings in Europe and the Americas.

Following the Acquisition, we expect to realize €240 million in potential cost savings within 15 to 18 months
after July 1, 2020 through the Sponsors’ Transformation Program, assuming, among other things, that the
program will be implemented beginning on July 1, 2020 and driven by key management, including the Chief
Executive Officer of the Group. The Transformation Program focuses on cost savings opportunities related to
(i) commercial operations, (ii) service operations, (iii) procurement costs, (iv) G&A costs and (v) other
operational costs. We expect to incur one-off costs amounting to between €240 and €294 million in connection
with these initiatives, mainly as a result of (i) voluntary redundancy, early retirement and other severance costs,
(ii) staff training costs, (iii) investments in IT to digitize, automate and streamline processes, (iv) investments in
the existing shared service centers in Europe, Brazil and the U.S., as well as potentially operating new, regional
centers in Eastern Europe and Asia and (v) consulting, financial and legal advisory fees in connection with
implementing these initiatives.

_New Installations standardization_

Historically, in part due to our strategy of growing through acquisitions, we provided customers with a large
share of customized product solutions. This resulted in a highly diverse but overlapping product portfolio and
limited price competitiveness due to the high costs of designing and producing such a wide range of
individualized products. In order to drive cost efficiency by eliminating unnecessary duplication across the
portfolio, the number of product platforms in the Group has been reduced by more than half in the last decade as
part of a process of implementing a simplified portfolio structure, with further improvements planned going
forward. The revised structure is divided into building type (i.e. low-, mid- or high-rise) and degree of
customization and focuses on the most competitive platforms, which can be scaled across segments within each
market.

Where possible, we have also standardized and harmonized components across products. Historically, different
products tended to require their own unique components, leading to higher costs than necessary. We have already
streamlined our product designs to permit specific modular components, such as traction machines, controllers/
inverters and doors, to be shared across multiple product platforms and have targeted a number of additional
widely used components for future harmonization. This has resulted in less complexity and easier external
sourcing of components, among other benefits.

These efforts, which are ongoing, have allowed and will continue to allow us to leverage economies of scale and
allocate our resources more efficiently across the entire business.

_Manufacturing optimization_

We are engaged in an ongoing effort to optimize our manufacturing operations and supply chains. These
measures have included closing and consolidating manufacturing sites to improve our utilization rates,
restructuring factories to increase our focus on the most promising products and platforms, increasing
outsourcing of standardized components, and developing state-of-the-art factories that are highly automated and
equipped with improved technology, advancing from a classic factory to a fulfillment and engineering center.
Specifically, we have established lean manufacturing operations in Asia/Pacific, with a newly established plant in
India and advances in automation at our plants in China and Korea. In the Americas, we have in recent years
consolidated all manufacturing facilities in North America at our Middleton facility, which we believe will
further enhance efficiency and reduce costs. In Europe, we have restructured our Móstoles plant in Spain and are
currently restructuring our operations in Germany to reduce costs and simplify production. In Europe/Africa, we
have also shifted our factories away from a regional focus (in which a particular factory only serves specific
countries) to a model where all factories can deliver to the entire Europe/Africa region, with each factory having
a dedicated product focus.

In the long term, we aim to move away from a classic factory model, where the focus is on major production and
shipping of complete elevator systems and requires high personnel expenses, towards a model where we produce
only key, mission critical components and outsource commoditized parts, resulting in lower fixed costs and
higher productivity.

_Service and digitalization growth_

We aim to increase our profitability by growing our Service business, which is a source of stable, recurring sales
and high margins, through multiple initiatives. We intend to increase our conversion rate, particularly in regions
like China where conversion levels are currently lower than our global average, our global retention rate, and our

100


-----

rate of winning customers away from competitors by continuing to enhance the efficiency of our spare parts
organization and increasing our service training, as well as by leveraging the superior quality and improving field
performance of our Services and our capability to refurbish multi-brand spare parts. We believe that our
innovative use of digital technology, including the recently developed MAX system, improved and faster supply
chains for spare parts, as well as improved back office and IT functions such as our proprietary IT system VIEW,
will enable us to improve customer satisfaction by increasing service quality and efficiency, and thereby increase
customer retention rates and attract new customers while also leveraging efficiency gains. We target substantial
sales growth and efficiency gains in our Service and Modernization businesses in all regions between the
2019/2020 and 2021/2022 financial years.

_SG&A expense optimization_

We are committed to reducing SG&A and other expenses by centralizing administrative functions, harmonizing
our IT systems and adopting a range of organizational efficiency measures as part of our “SG&A Excellence”
program. Specifically, we are engaged in an ongoing effort to combine a wide array of administrative processes
that historically have been performed locally, such as billing, payroll and purchasing, into shared service centers.
This process is well advanced in the Americas, where for example in the United States these functions will be
consolidated into one shared service center at the U.S. headquarters in Atlanta, and we intend to roll it out in
other regions. We have in addition reduced the number of operating units within the Europe/Africa and the
Americas segments. We are also in the process of harmonizing our IT processes by rolling out VIEW globally,
continuing to transition to cloud-based services, and adopting global templates and standards, and driving
efficiency throughout the global organization by “delayering,” or flattening, management levels and adopting
other efficiency enhancements. These measures have resulted in more than €80 million in total SG&A savings
over the last three financial years. These savings, together with lower negative non-recurring items and positive
exchange rate effects, contributed to the decline in SG&A costs from €1,419 million in the 2016/2017 Financial
Year to €1,301 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year, despite general salary increases. SG&A costs increased
to €1,349 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year due to negative effects from exchange rates as well as sales
volume and general salary increases which more than offset operational improvement measures across the
Group.

_Procurement Optimization_

In addition, we aim to reduce our procurement costs by optimizing our supply chains through commercial
measures, such as, for example, supplier days, clustering managed spend, and engaging in e-auctions. For
example, between the 2011/2012 Financial Year and the 2018/2019 Financial Year, our purchasing savings
increased by 300%, outpacing our procurement spend which increased by 50%.

_Transformation Program_

As part of our commercial operations initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our
organizational efficiency by restructuring and centralizing our sales supports team, including by shifting
employees to low cost countries. In addition, we seek to increase our sales force productivity through various
measures, including improving our administrative processes and completing faster technical sales. This is
facilitated by our offering of fewer customization options resulting from the optimization of our product and
service portfolios. We also intend to increase our focus on sales efforts based on product margin potentials and
the conversion of New Installation units into Service contracts and later into Modernization sales. We expect to
realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €7 million related to our commercial operations initiatives.

As part of our service operations initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our
organizational efficiency by rationalizing the number of our application engineers, reducing the number of
platforms in our offering, standardizing our service offering and reducing the number of our service centers,
particularly in the U.S. We intend to implement other measures under these initiatives as well, including
improving process, technology and performance management in order to increase the productivity of our service
technicians. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €15 million related to our service
operations initiatives.

As part of our procurement initiatives under the Transformation Program, we intend to implement multiple
measures to reduce costs relating to our procurement activities. For the 2018/2019 Financial Year, we believe
that our estimated addressable cost base for procurement activities comprised €2.1 billion of direct costs and
€0.5 billion of indirect costs. To reduce these costs, we intend to establish group-wide supply agreements with
global suppliers for key categories of direct materials, such as motors, cables and doors, including through
leveraging change-of-control provisions under our existing supplier agreements with local or regional suppliers.
We also expect to increase our focus on supplier driven innovation in connection with, among other things,

101


-----

tendering processes. To pursue improvements in specification management, we seek to standardize purchases for
complex parts and establish business unit sourcing boards, which will act as advisory panels in key end markets
to promote best practices and streamline procurement processes. Furthermore, we continue to shift our
relationships with local suppliers to regional suppliers in order to both increase the number of sites served by our
suppliers and decrease the number of our total suppliers, resulting in increased efficiencies. We also continue to
streamline the amount and variety of individually supplied components in order to purchase bundles of different
products and higher volumes of specific products, resulting in improved purchasing ability. Moreover, where
appropriate, we target shifting to agreements with suppliers in low cost countries or otherwise shifting purchases
from our suppliers of local products to products sourced from low cost countries. In addition, we are working to
utilize both centralized regional lead-buyers to streamline demand-management processes and defined sourcing
hubs to allow for best value and benchmark sourcing through increased spend, price and margin transparency.
Furthermore, we expect to realize cost savings from our commercial operations initiatives that result in the
rationalization of our product offering and standardization of our SKUs. We expect to realize cost savings in an
aggregate amount of €132 million in connection with our procurement initiatives.

As part of our G&A cost savings initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our
organizational efficiency and generate attrition savings through a leaner operating model, the shifting of
employees to low cost countries and increased automation, including within our shared service centers. We
expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €36 million related to our G&A cost savings initiatives.

As part of our other operational initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to reduce direct and
indirect personnel expenses and scrappage costs by decreasing the portion of poor quality production. We target
replicating the cost of poor quality levels that we have achieved at our Korean plant (where such costs are
estimated to be 0.6% of internal sales) at our other plants, particularly our Middleton plant. We also intend to
outsource parts and components and streamline production overhead and assembly processes to reduce costs. We
expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €50 million related to our other operational initiatives.

See also “Summary Financial and Other Data—Other Financial, Operating and Pro Forma Information—Other
_Pro Forma Information.”_

**_Corporate cost allocations_**

Our combined statements of profit or loss for the last three financial years include corporate cost allocations from
thyssenkrupp AG, which were retrospectively allocated to us in accordance with carve-out accounting principles
and represent a proportionate amount of corporate costs and non-operational effects that were historically
recorded at the parent company level without being recharged to the Elevator Technology Business. Our
corporate costs allocations (in regards to our EBIT) amounted to €98 million, €71 million and €66 million in the
2016/2017 Financial Year, 2017/2018 Financial Year and 2018/2019 Financial Year, respectively. Corporate cost
allocations within EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year included corporate costs of €73 million and a partially
offsetting reversal of a provision with regard to unclaimed properties in the US in the amount of €7 million,
which qualified as a special item for Adjusted EBIT calculation. We do not consider these costs to be
representative of our additional standalone corporate costs going forward. The relevant functions will be
provided in the future by the Group itself. We estimate that additional standalone costs will amount to
approximately €30 million per annum going forward, resulting in generally lower general and administrative
costs than the amounts allocated to us in the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

We are exposed to translation and transactional foreign exchange risks. Due to the broad scope of our
international operations, a substantial portion of our assets, liabilities, sales and expenses are denominated in
currencies other than the euro. Our predominant exposures are the U.S. dollar and the Chinese renminbi. Further
main foreign exchange exposures relate to the Brazilian real, the Canadian dollar and the South Korean won.

Changes in the exchange rates between these currencies can affect our operations and financial position as a
result of translational exchange rate effects. These effects arise because the financial results of thyssenkrupp
Elevator’s subsidiaries are measured in the currency of the primary economic environment in which the
subsidiary operates (our functional currency). The results of operations and assets and liabilities of a number of
thyssenkrupp Elevator’s global subsidiaries are, therefore, measured in currencies other than the euro and are
then translated into euro for presentation of our financial results, assets and liabilities in our financial statements.
Consequently, fluctuations in the applicable foreign currency exchange rates may increase or decrease the euro
value of our non-euro assets, liabilities, sales, costs and order intake, even if their value has not changed in the
local functional currency.

102


-----

We are also exposed to transactional risk to the extent our subsidiaries and we execute transactions in a currency
other than their functional currency, which arises mainly when we import components from one jurisdiction,
incurring a cost in that jurisdiction’s currency, and invoice for our products and installation in the local currency.
Our transactional risk exposure is less significant than our translation risk exposure, because we produce and
install our products predominantly in our key markets, which generally has the effect of matching the currencies
of our costs with those of our sales. Nonetheless, adverse exchange rate movements can impact the profitability
of our New Installation business and, to a lesser degree, the Modernization business, to the extent key imported
components become more expensive in our local sales areas.

The exchange rates between the functional currencies of our global subsidiaries and the euro have fluctuated
significantly in recent years and may continue to do so in the future. Our sales, for example, decreased by 1.2%
between the 2016/2017 Financial Year and the 2017/2018 Financial Year on an absolute basis, largely driven by
negative foreign exchange rate movements in the U.S. dollar, the Chinese renminbi, the Brazilian real and the
South Korean won, whereas in constant currency terms sales increased over the period. Sales increased by 5.0%
between the 2017/2018 Financial Year and the 2018/2019 Financial Year on an absolute basis but increased less
on a constant currency basis. Through their impact on sales and costs, foreign exchange movements also impact
our reported profitability.

**_Regulatory requirements_**

In all jurisdictions where we operate, our products and services are subject to laws, rules, regulations and
technical standards at international, supranational, national, state and municipal levels. In particular, this
regulatory framework governs the design, manufacture, installation, operation and product safety of our products
and services, and is mainly outlined in applicable building laws, building codes, specific safety codes for
elevators and escalators and other product safety laws, as well as laws governing airport ground equipment and
airport buildings. In addition, we are subject to regulatory requirements concerning product standards for energy
efficiency and sustainability.

These and other applicable laws are amended and revised from time to time, typically in ways that increase the
technical and safety standards applicable to elevators installed after their effective date. Such amendments and
revisions may require us to update our product designs and installation procedures to ensure our Products qualify
for the necessary operating licenses and otherwise comply with the new requirements. The cost of compliance
with these laws can be significant, impacting our operating and compliance costs and thereby our results of
operations.

At the same time, the laws described above are a key driver of sales in our Service and Modernization businesses,
as both new and existing customers (typically the owner of the building where work is carried out or in some
cases the property manager) are required to ensure their elevators and escalators are compliant with the
prevailing standards. Our Service business therefore offers a broad range of Services, from basic oil and grease
maintenance to bespoke full-service packages, to ensure, among other things, optimal safety and compliance with
the applicable laws in each jurisdiction where it installs and services elevators, escalators, and moving walks. In
addition, with the average age of buildings and of the installed base of elevators, escalators and moving walks
steadily growing in many countries, property owners increasingly need to invest in modernizing their elevators,
escalators and moving walks. We therefore offer comprehensive elevator and escalator modernization to enable
our customers to comply with applicable legal requirements and continue to operate safely. When governments
and regulators amend the laws or otherwise introduce new requirements, our New Installation business benefits
by marketing our products to construction companies and developers as compliant with such new requirements.
See “Regulation.”

**Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements**

**_Stand-Alone Business_**

The Elevator Technology Business did not exist as a separate group prior to December 31, 2019. It formed part
of a larger group of companies controlled by thyssenkrupp AG and was reported as a segment within the
consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG. In order to facilitate the Acquisition, all companies and
operating activities that are part of the Elevator Technology Business were transferred, directly or indirectly, to
the Target in a corporate reorganization that was completed on December 31, 2019.

As the Elevator Technology Business did not exist as a separate group and since all companies and operating
activities within the Elevator Technology Business were under the common control of thyssenkrupp AG, in each
case, prior to the Reorganization, the financial information presented as of and for the financial years ended

103


-----

September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019 has been prepared on a combined basis. Effective with the Reorganization,
the Elevator Technology Business came into existence as a separate group and therefore, the financial
information presented for the Target and its consolidated subsidiaries as of and for the six months ended March
31, 2019 and 2020 was prepared on a consolidated basis.

There are important differences between the Elevator Technology Business as presented in the Audited
Combined Financials as of and for the financial years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019 and the
business carried out by the Target and its subsidiaries as presented in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated
Financial Statements as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020. See “Presentation of
_Financial Information—Basis of Preparation” and our Financial Statements included elsewhere herein._

_The Audited Combined Financial Statements_

As IFRS does not provide guidelines for the preparation of combined financial statements, the preparation of the
Audited Combined Financial Statements was subject to IAS 8 “Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting
_Estimates and Errors,” particularly IAS 8.12, which required management of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG to_
consider recent pronouncements of other standard-setting bodies, other financial reporting requirements and
recognized industry practices in connection with the preparation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements.
Accordingly, in preparing the Audited Combined Financial Statements, thyssenkrupp Elevator applied the
predecessor accounting approach in accordance with recognized industry practices and rules on business
combinations under common control. In general, thyssenkrupp Elevator used the same accounting policies and
measurement principles in preparing the Audited Combined Financial Statements as were used in preparing the
IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG (the “extraction method”). This approach has been
adjusted with respect to transactions with thyssenkrupp Group companies and to ensure compliance with IFRS.
Transactions between the Elevator Technology Business and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group were recognized
in accordance with IFRS and classified as related party transactions as defined in IAS 24 “Related Party
_Disclosures.”_

New IFRS accounting standards were applied in the Audited Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator
Technology Business in fiscal years from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2019, as follows:

- IFRS 9 (Financial instruments) was adopted in the 2018/2019 Financial Year by opting to apply the
standard prospectively (i.e., from the beginning of the 2018/2019 Financial Year) and accordingly, no
adjusted comparative information was disclosed.

- IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) was adopted in 2018/2019 Financial Year by applying
the full retrospective approach to initial application. Due to the financial statements of that fiscal year for
thyssenkrupp AG only presenting one comparative period, the cumulative transition effects were included
directly in retained earnings at the start of the comparative period on October 1, 2017. In contrast, for the
Audited Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business, due to the additional
comparative period from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2017 presented, according to the full
retrospective approach, IFRS 15 has been applied from the beginning of the 2016/2017 Financial Year for
the Audited Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business (i.e. the cumulative
transition effects were included directly in invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp AG at the start of
the comparative period on October 1, 2016).

- IFRS 16 (Leases) was adopted in the 2019/2020 Financial Year by thyssenkrupp AG by opting to apply the
simplified approach of using the modified retrospective method (i.e., the cumulative transition effects are
included directly in equity on October 1, 2019 and the standard is applied from the beginning of the
2019/2020 Financial Year) and no adjusted comparative information was accordingly disclosed.

Additional information on the scope and basis of preparation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements and
the application of significant accounting policies is presented in Note 1 “Basis of preparation” and Note 2
“Summary of significant accounting policies” to the Audited Combined Financial Statements.

As a result, the Audited Combined Financial Statements included in this offering memorandum may not reflect
what the results of operations, financial position and cash flows would have been had the Group operated as a
separate, stand-alone business without the shared resources of thyssenkrupp AG for the periods presented, and
may not be indicative of our future results of operations, financial position and cash flows. The fact that the
companies and operating activities comprising the Elevator Technology Business did not historically exist as a
separate group limits the validity of the combined financial information.

**_Changes to Accounting Standards—IFRS 16 (Leases)_**

The Financial Statements are prepared and presented in accordance with IFRS. On January 13, 2016, the IASB
published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 on November 9, 2017. IFRS 16 replaced
IAS 17 and the related IFRIC and SIC interpretations, and resulted in almost all leases being recognized on the
balance sheet, as the distinction between operating and finance leases was eliminated. Under the new standard,
the lessee recognizes an asset (the right-to-use the leased asset) and a financial liability to pay lease payments.
The only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases should a company elect to apply an available practical

105


-----

expedient in order to reduce the transition effort. IFRS 16 became effective for fiscal years commencing on or
after January 1, 2019.

The Group adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) on October 1, 2019, by opting to apply the simplified approach of using the
modified retrospective method, which means that the cumulative transition effects are included directly in equity
on October 1, 2019 and the standard is applied from the beginning of the 2019/2020 Financial Year.
Accordingly, no adjusted comparative information was disclosed.

The first-time adoption of IFRS 16 had significant impact on certain balance sheet and income statement items,
as described above and also in Note 3 in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements.

The transition to IFRS 16 on October 1, 2019, gave rise to changes to our assets and liabilities. As a result,
figures as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2020, may not be comparable to the results presented for
prior periods. As of March 31, 2020, our right-of-use assets amounted to €397 million and lease liabilities
amounted to €330 million. The depreciation of right-of-use assets for the six months ended March 31, 2020,
amounted to €49 million and the interest expense from lease liabilities amounted to €8 million.

See Note 2 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements and Note 3 to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated
Financial Statements for more information about our application of IFRS 16.

**_Impact of COVID-19_**

The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted both our Elevator and Escalator division and our Access Solutions
division across all regions to varying degrees. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Coronavirus (COVID_19).”_

We believe that in the medium to long term, the outbreak of COVID-19 will not have a material adverse effect on
our overall business and results of operations, due to the underlying resilience of our business and immediate
implementation of contingency measures. Our New Installation business was temporarily impacted in countries
with lockdown measures, as discussed above. However, all our manufacturing plants are currently operational.
Our Service business has performed largely as expected, given applicable safety and regulatory requirements.

In our Financial Statements, COVID-19 is considered as a trigger event for an impairment test of goodwill as of
March 31, 2020. Therefore, the operational planning of the Elevator Technology Business was tested for validity
against the background of the COVID-19 pandemic and, in effect, the recoverability of goodwill of the Elevator
Technology Business was not classified as critical. Furthermore, other intangible assets and property, plant and
equipment were also tested for impairment per March 31, 2020, which did not result in any impairment losses for
the Elevator Technology Business.

The effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business and the industry will ultimately depend on a number of
factors, including, but not limited to, the duration and severity of the outbreak and the length of time it takes for
demand and return and for normal economic and operating conditions to resume. Accordingly, our financial
condition and results of operations will differ in respect of the current year and for future periods, when
compared to the historical financial condition and results of operations presented in this discussion.

**Key Line Items in Our Statements of Profit or Loss and Other Comprehensive Income**

Set forth below is a description of the key line items presented in our Financial Statements. Our key line items
are reported on the basis of uniform accounting policies that are implemented at each entity within our scope of
consolidation.

**_Sales_**

Sales primarily includes revenue generated from contracts with customers related to the New Installation
business, the Service business and the Modernization business in the respective business units.

**_Cost of sales_**

Cost of sales includes the production and purchase costs incurred to generate the sales. In addition to direct
material costs, non-staff overheads and personnel costs, which represent the majority of cost of sales, production
costs also include production-related indirect costs, including depreciation of production facilities and warranty
costs.

**_Gross margin_**

Gross margin is the difference between sales and cost of sales.

**_Research and development cost_**

Research and development cost includes expenses in connection with research and development activities not
eligible for capitalization and other costs related to the functional area of research and development.

**_Selling expenses_**

Selling expenses include personnel costs related to distribution and costs for distributing products, including
marketing and transportation and other costs related to the functional area of distribution.

**_General and administrative expenses_**

General and administrative expenses include costs incurred in operating and administering the business, and
consist primarily of expenses for salaries of non-production workers and headquarters expenses and other costs
related to the functional area of general administration.

**_Other income_**

Other income includes all operating income that is not included in or attributable to sales.

**_Other expenses_**

Other expenses includes all operating expenses that are not included in or attributable to the functional categories
mentioned above.

**_Other gains/(losses), net_**

Other gains/(losses), net includes results from disposals of non-current assets such as property, plant and
equipment or intangible assets.

**_Income/(loss) from operations_**

Income/(loss) from operations is the sum of gross margin, research and development cost, selling expenses,
general and administrative expenses, other income, other expenses and other gains/(losses), net.

**_Income from companies accounted for using the equity method_**

Income from companies accounted for using the equity method relates to the result from investments in
associates and joint ventures, which are initially (at acquisition) measured at cost in the statement of financial
position, and our share of net income/loss of the investee generated after acquisition is recognized in the
statement of profit or loss.

107


-----

**_Finance income_**

Finance income consists of interest income from financial receivables, income from valuation of interest
derivatives, other interest and similar income.

**_Finance expense_**

Finance expense consist of net interest on the net defined benefit liability, interest expenses on financial debt,
interest costs included in lease payments and other interest and similar expenses.

**_Financial income/(expense), net_**

Financial income/(expense), net is the sum of the income from companies accounted for using the equity method,
interest income and interest expense.

**_Income/(loss) before tax_**

Income/(loss) before tax is the sum of income/(loss) from operations and financial income/(expense), net.

**_Income tax (expense)/income_**

Income tax (expense)/income includes net current income tax and net deferred tax.

**_Net income/(loss)_**

Net income/(loss) is the sum of income/(loss) before tax and income tax (expense)/income.

_Sales_

Our sales increased by €87 million, or 2.3% from €3,795 million in the six months ended March 31, 2019 to
€3,882 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily driven by increased sales in
our Americas segment. In the United States, sales increased across all business lines and were particularly strong
within the Service business. This was partly offset by lower sales in our Europe/Africa segment as a result of
lower sales from the manufacturing entities to other business units, as well as COVID-19 related decline,
especially in the second quarter in the Asia/Pacific segment.

Our sales for the Europe/Africa segment decreased from €1,064 million or 2.9% in the six months ended
March 31, 2019 to €1,033 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The decrease was primarily driven by
lower sales due to less supply for major projects to other Operating Segments.

Our sales for the Americas segment increased by €92 million, or 5.8%, from €1,597 million in the six months
ended March 31, 2019 to €1,689 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily
driven by an increase in sales across all business lines in the United States, positive exchange rate effects from
USD and additional sales from companies acquired in the second half of the previous Financial Year. The
positive effects were partly offset by lower sales in South America, mainly due adverse exchange rate effects
from BRL.

Our sales for the Asia/Pacific segment decreased by €19 million, or 1.8%, from €1,047 million in the six months
ended March 31, 2019 to €1,028 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The decrease was primarily
driven by lower New Installation sales in the Middle East due to less major infrastructure projects, as well as
COVID-19 related sales decline in China in the second quarter.

Our sales for the Access Solutions segment increased by €3 million, or 1.6%, from €188 million in the six
months ended March 31, 2019 to €191 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was
primarily driven by higher New Installation and Service sales in our airport solutions in the United States, partly
offset by a decline in the home solutions sales, mainly due to COVID-19, with the main impact in China and to a
lesser extent, in Europe.

_Cost of sales_

Our cost of sales increased by €70 million, or 2.5%, from €2,767 million in the six months ended March 31, 2019
to €2,837 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily driven by a higher sales
volume in the Americas segment.

_Research and development cost_

Our research and development cost increased by €5 million, or 16.1%, from €31 million in the six months ended
March 31, 2019 to €36 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily driven by
higher amortization related to capitalized global R&D project costs.

_Selling expenses_

Our selling expenses increased by €8 million, or 3.2%, from €250 million in the six months ended March 31,
2019 to €258 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily driven by an increase
of allowances for financial assets in the Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific segments.

_General and administrative expenses_

Our general and administrative expenses decreased by €35 million, or 8.3%, from €421 million in the six months
ended March 31, 2019 to €386 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The decrease was primarily
driven by lower personnel expenses as a result of operational improvement measures mainly in the Americas
segment, particularly in the United States and the Europe/Africa segment, especially in manufacturing in Spain
and Italy and Corporate Elevator segments. Furthermore, lower restructuring related costs in the Americas
segment (mainly in the United States) and Europe/Africa (mainly manufacturing and British Islands), as well as
lower travel expenses across all segments positively impacted the cost development.

_Other income_

Our other income decreased by €6 million, or 17.6%, from €34 million in the six months ended March 31, 2019
to €28 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The decrease was primarily driven by lower
miscellaneous income gains.

_Other expenses_

Our other expenses increased by €12 million or 11.7% from €103 million in the six months ended March 31,
2019 to €115 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily driven by higher
expenses relating to the license agreement with thyssenkrupp AG in connection with the use of the
“thyssenkrupp” brand, partly offset by reduced miscellaneous other expenses.

_Financial income/(expense), net_

Our financial income/(expense), net decreased by €37 million from an income of €13 million in the six months
ended March 31, 2019 to an expense of €(24) million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. This effect was
primarily driven by financial interest paid for thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financial accounts in the current
reporting period versus financial income received for thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financial accounts in the
previous reporting period.

_Income tax (expense)/income_

Our income tax (expense)/income decreased by €8 million, or 8.3%, from €(96) million in the six months ended
March 31, 2019 to €(88) million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The decrease was primarily driven by
lower pre-tax results.

profits in the Americas segment, namely in the United States where profitable Service growth and favorable
exchange rate effects contributed to the positive result, the Asia/Pacific segment due to operational improvement

COVID-19 pandemic.

improvements in the DACH region.

Our Americas segment’s Adjusted EBIT increased by €15 million, or 6.6%, from €227 million in the six months
ended March 31, 2019 to €242 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily
driven by a higher sales volume in the United States, especially within the profitable Service business and by
positive exchange rate effects.

Our Asia/Pacific segment’s Adjusted EBIT increased by €7 million, or 11.5%, from €61 million in the six
months ended March 31, 2019 to €68 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was
primarily driven by a higher share of Service profits as well as a solid development of the New Installation
business in China, partially offset by negative impact from the COVID-19 pandemic in the second quarter.

_Sales_

Our sales increased by €382 million, or 5.0%, from €7,579 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to
€7,961 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by strong growth in the
Americas segment as a result of robust increases in both New Installations and Services due to higher repair sales
in the United States, moderate growth in the Europe/Africa segment due to growth in Service sales in Germany
and Spain and New Installations growth in the Access Solutions segment, partially offset by a decline in the Asia/
Pacific segment due to weaker market development in New Installations in South Korea. The increase in sales
was supported by broadly positive currency effects.

moderate growth in Service sales in Germany and Spain, supported by continued strong conversion and retention

111


-----

Our sales in the Americas segment increased by €323 million, or 10.8%, from €2,983 million in the 2017/2018
Financial Year to €3,306 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by robust
increases in both New Installations as well as Services due to strong growth in repair sales in the United States.
Positive currency effects from the U.S. dollar also contributed to the increase.

Our sales in the Asia/Pacific segment decreased by €30 million, or 1.3%, from €2,337 million in the 2017/2018
Financial Year to €2,307 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by weaker
market development in New Installations in South Korea, partly offset by Service growth due to robust
conversions of units from the New Installation business in China as a result of continued high New Installations
sales volumes and positive exchange rate effects mainly relating to the Chinese renminbi.

Our sales in the Access Solutions segment increased by €13 million, or 3.5%, from €372 million in the
2017/2018 Financial Year to €385 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by
New Installations growth in the Home Solutions business.

_Cost of sales_

Our cost of sales increased by €274 million, or 4.9%, from €5,552 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to
€5,826 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. Such increase mirrored the percentage increase in sales for the
period, with cost of sales as a percentage of sales remaining constant at 73% for both Financial Years. Personnel
costs increased due to labor cost inflation in all segments and due to adverse currency effects particularly in the
Americas segment, but were partly offset by increased labor efficiency and structural improvements resulting
from our operational improvement measures. Material costs increased in the United States due to volume
increases in both the New Installation business and the Service business and due to the impact of U.S. tariffs, for
which the positive effects from purchasing volume savings programs could only partly compensate. Operational
issues at the Middleton manufacturing facility also had a negative impact on cost of sales in the Americas. In the
Asia/Pacific segment, lower sales volumes in South Korea and material cost-reduction measures in China
contributed to lower cost of sales.

_Research and development cost_

Our research and development cost increased by €4 million, or 5.9%, from €68 million in the 2017/2018
Financial Year to €72 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by higher costs
for regular product maintenance activities in the Europe/Africa segment, which is required and conducted in
order to keep our product portfolio up-to-date and to ensure that our products comply with all codes and
standards.

_Selling expenses_

Our selling expenses increased by €35 million, or 7.4%, from €476 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to
€511 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by higher sales volumes and
foreign exchange rate effects mainly in the Americas segment as well as general salary increases, partially offset
by efficiency gains from operational improvement measures.

_General and administrative expenses_

Our general and administrative expenses increased by €13 million, or 1.6%, from €825 million in the 2017/2018
Financial Year to €838 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. These were primarily due to general inflationary
cost increases and adverse impact from foreign exchange fluctuations, partly offset by the effect of operational
improvement measures focused on reducing global SG&A costs.

_Other income_

Our other income increased by €9 million, or 17.6%, from €51 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to
€60 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year due to miscellaneous income gains.

_Other expenses_

Our other expenses increased by €21 million, or 11.4%, from €185 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to
€206 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by a provision taken in
connection with a lawsuit.

112


-----

_Financial income/(expense), net_

Our financial income/(expense), net decreased by €7 million, or 30.4%, from €23 million in the 2017/2018
Financial Year to €16 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by a
€23 million increase in financial expense over the period mainly due to higher interest expenses owed on
thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financial accounts, offset by a €15 million increase in financial income due to
higher interest income earned on thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financial accounts.

_Income tax (expense)/income_

Our income tax (expense)/income increased by €97 million, or 76.4%, from €(127) million in the 2017/2018
Financial Year to €(224) million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by the
absence of one-time effects from the US tax reform which had occurred in the previous year.

Our Adjusted EBIT increased by €56 million, or 7.3%, from €763 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to
€819 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by increased profit contribution
from all our Operating Segments.

Our Americas segment’s Adjusted EBIT increased from €476 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to
€489 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year, driven by growth in the Service business supported by increased
repair sales, positive impacts from efficiency gains and purchasing volume savings programs and positive
exchange rate effects mainly relating to the US dollar, offsetting the negative developments in the New
Installation business relating mainly to adverse material price effects resulting from US tariffs and operational
inefficiencies at the Middleton manufacturing facility.

Our Europe/Africa segment’s Adjusted EBIT increased from €212 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to
€227 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year, primarily driven by growth in the Service Business, especially in
Germany, as well as efficiency gains and structural improvements from operational improvement measures.

Our Asia/Pacific segment’s Adjusted EBIT increased from €148 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to
€178 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year, primarily driven by higher profits from the New Installation
business due to improved market pricing and material cost reduction measures in China as well as growth in the
Service business due to robust conversion from New Installation business units in China. These effects were
partly offset by negative developments resulting from the market decline of the New Installation business in
South Korea.

Our Access Solutions division’s Adjusted EBIT increased from €58 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to
€62 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by reductions of corporate costs.

_Sales_

Our sales decreased by €95 million, or 1.2%, from €7,674 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to
€7,579 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily due to adverse currency effects,
particularly with respect to the U.S. dollar and the Brazilian real, which negatively impacted sales in the
Americas segment, as well as adverse currency effects with respect to the Chinese renminbi and the South
Korean won, which negatively impacted sales in the Asia/Pacific segment. As a consequence, sales in the
Americas segment declined by 4.4% between the 2016/2017 Financial Year and the 2017/2018 Financial Year,
while sales in the Asia/Pacific segment increased by 1.7%. Excluding currency effects, sales increased in the
Americas due to strong levels of construction activity, which drove New Installations, and increased at a higher
rate in Asia/Pacific due to growth in Services. Sales in the Europe/Africa segment increased by 2.6% over the
period, partially offsetting the decrease resulting from the sales decline in the Americas segment.

Our sales in the Europe/Africa segment increased by €54 million, or 2.6%, from €2,063 million in the 2016/2017
Financial Year to €2,117 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by higher
sales in the New Installation business as a result of major infrastructure projects delivered by the Europe/Africa
segment to our Middle East region. There was marginal sales growth in the Service and Modernization

114


-----

businesses, mainly driven by operations in the DACH operating unit (comprising Germany, Austria and
Switzerland), supported by strong conversion and retention rates. These increases were partly offset by negative
currency effects with respect to the Turkish lira and the Russian ruble.

Our sales in the Americas segment decreased by €136 million, or 4.4%, from €3,119 million in the 2016/2017
Financial Year to €2,983 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by negative
currency effects in the U.S. dollar and Brazil real, which mainly impacted the New Installation business, partially
mitigated by strong levels of construction activity and growth in the Service businesses as a result of
management’s focus on increasing repair sales and increased growth in Modernizations contracts in the United
States.

Our sales in the Asia/Pacific segment increased by €39 million, or 1.7%, from €2,298 million in the 2016/2017
Financial Year to €2,337 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. Strong conversion rates in China and South
Korea resulted in significant Services growth, which was partly offset mainly by negative currency effects with
respect to the Chinese renminbi and the South Korean won. Sales in the New Installation business Unit suffered
mainly due to a weaker market in South Korea.

Our sales in the Access Solutions segment increased by €4 million, or 1.1%, from €368 million in the 2016/2017
Financial Year to €372 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by growth in
New Installations as a result of major airport projects in Turkey and the United States, partially offset by declines
in Services and Modernizations sales as a result of the expiry of certain Service agreements and the completion
of several Modernizations projects.

_Cost of sales_

Our cost of sales remained relatively constant at €5,561 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year and
€5,552 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. Cost of sales increased slightly as a percentage of sales from
72.5% in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to 73.3% in the 2017/2018 Financial Year due to material costs increases
in the Asia/Pacific segment as a result of negative price developments in China and South Korea, which mainly
impacted New Installation, the largest business in that region. These increases were offset by decreases in the
Americas segment as a result of favorable currency effects with respect to the U.S. dollar and Brazilian real,
although material prices in the Americas were also adversely impacted by U.S. tariffs, mainly on steel imports
from China, over the period. Material price increases were also partly offset by positive impacts from purchasing
volume savings programs.

Personnel costs were broadly stable over the period, as labor cost inflation effects were offset by increased labor
efficiency measures and favorable currency effects.

_Research and development cost_

Our research and development cost decreased by €19 million, or 21.8%, from €87 million in the 2016/2017
Financial Year to €68 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by the
capitalization, in accordance with IAS 38, of certain research and development expenses in the 2017/2018
Financial Year (including global projects such as MULTI and other mature and professionalized global research
and development projects).

_Selling expenses_

Our selling expenses decreased by €76 million, or 13.8%, from €552 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to
€476 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by a decline in allowances for
financial assets, mainly due to allowances in connection with a restructuring program in the Middle East which
were recorded in the 2016/17 Financial Year. Further decreases resulted from SG&A improvement measures
globally, particularly in Asia/Pacific where we made progress centralizing administrative costs and carrying out
other cost savings initiatives in China, and favorable exchange rates with respect to the U.S. dollar.

_General and administrative expenses_

Our general and administrative expenses decreased by €42 million, or 4.8%, from €867 million in the 2016/2017
Financial Year to €825 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by reduced
corporate cost allocations from thyssenkrupp AG, operational improvements and a positive impact from
exchange rates mainly in relation to the U.S. dollar.

115


-----

_Other income_

Our other income increased by €10 million, or 24.4%, from €41 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to
€51 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year, primarily due to a one-time legal settlement.

_Other expenses_

Our other expenses increased by €49 million, or 36.0%, from €136 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to
€185 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by increased expenses relating
to license fee payments to thyssenkrupp AG in connection with our use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand.

_Financial income/(expense), net_

Our financial income/(expense), net decreased by €4 million, or 14.8%, from €27 million in the 2016/2017
Financial Year to €23 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by a
€27 million decrease in finance income over the period mainly due to lower interest income earned on
thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financial accounts which was offset by a €23 million decrease in finance expense
as a result of lower interest expenses owed on thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financial accounts.

_Income tax (expense)/income_

Our income tax (expense)/income decreased by €151 million, or 54.3%, from €(278) million in the 2016/2017
Financial Year to €(127) million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by the US
tax reform, which resulted in a devaluation of deferred tax liabilities in the United States as well as a lower
applicable tax rate on US profits in the 2017/18 financial year.
