Our Adjusted EBIT decreased by €49 million, or 6%, from €812 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to
€763 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by reduced profit contribution
from the New Installation business in the Asia/Pacific and Europe/Africa segments and negative exchange rate
developments mainly related to the US dollar, as offset by the growth of the Service business in the Americas
segment.

Our Adjusted EBIT in the Europe/Africa segment decreased from €223 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year
to €212 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by lower profitability in the
New Installation business due to performance issues in both project execution in Turkey and France as well as in
the Group’s European manufacturing operations, which was only partly offset by Service business growth and
positive impacts from restructuring and efficiency measures in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and France.

Our Adjusted EBIT in the Americas segment decreased from €509 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to
€476 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by lower profitability in the
New Installation business due to adverse currency effects with respect to the US dollar and Brazilian real, as well
as increased costs arising from US tariffs, in particular for steel imports from China, only partly offset by positive
effects from Service growth and efficiency measures.

Our Adjusted EBIT in the Asia/Pacific segment decreased from €203 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to
€148 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by decreased profitability in
the New Installation business as a result of negative material cost developments in China and South Korea. These

116


-----

effects were partially offset by profit gains from efficiency measures in China in the form of centralization and
other cost savings initiatives as well as Service business growth due to conversion of units from the New
Installation business.

Our Adjusted EBIT in the Access Solutions division increased from €55 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year
to €58 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by higher sales volumes, in
particular two major airport projects in Turkey and the United States, and operational improvements as a result of
SG&A cost reductions.

**Liquidity and Capital resources**

**_Overview_**

Following the completion of the Transactions, we expect that our principal sources of liquidity will be cash flows
from operations and drawings under our Revolving Credit Facility. The availability of our Revolving Credit
Facility will be subject to certain conditions.

We aim to manage capital to ensure that all companies within the Elevator Technology Business can continue to
operate as a going concern. Our ability to generate cash flow from operations depends on our future operating
performance, which is in turn dependent on general economic, financial, competitive, market and other factors,
many of which are beyond our control. In addition, we anticipate that we will be highly leveraged for the
foreseeable future and our ability to generate future financing cash flows will be limited by the Indentures and
the Senior Facilities, which may have important negative consequences for you. See “Risk Factors,”
“Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness,” “Description of the
_Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness” and “Description of Certain Financing_
_Arrangements.” Any additional indebtedness that we do incur could reduce the amount of our cash flow available_
to make payments on our then existing indebtedness, including under the Notes offered hereby, and increase our
leverage.

The proceeds from the Offering will be used as set forth under “Use of Proceeds.”

_Operating cash flows_

Our operating cash flows on a consolidated basis increased by €113 million, or 146.8%, from €77 million in the
six months ended March 31, 2019 to €190 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was
primarily driven by the increased net income (before non-cash items like depreciation, amortization and deferred
taxes) partially offset by an overall increase in net working capital.

Our operating cash flows on a combined basis increased by €200 million, or 72.5%, from €276 million in the
2017/2018 Financial Year to €476 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by
declines in working capital, including positive cash flow effects from development of inventories, trade accounts
receivable and contract assets, partially offset by net negative cash flow effects from net development of contract
liabilities and provisions. The increase was also due to minor effects resulting from an increase in net income
before non-cash items, mainly comprising deferred tax effects.

117


-----

Our operating cash flows on a combined basis decreased by €217 million, or 44.0%, from €493 million in the
2016/2017 Financial Year to €276 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year, despite an increase in net income
before changes in working capital. The decrease was primarily driven by the significant overall increase in net
working capital, including negative cash flow effects from development of trade accounts receivable, contract
assets, provisions and trade payables, partially offset by positive cash flow effects from development of contract
liabilities. The decrease was also due to effects resulting from increased net income before non-cash items,
including depreciation, amortization and deferred taxes.

_Cash flows from investing activities_

Our cash outflows on a consolidated basis from investing activities strongly increased by €3,228 million from
€58 million in the six months ended March 31, 2019 to €3,286 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020.
The increase was primarily driven by acquisitions of shares in the Group companies from thyssenkrupp Group
during the six months ended March 31, 2020 as part of the legal reorganization of the Group finalized as of
December 31, 2019.

Our cash outflows on a combined basis from investing activities increased by €1,267 million from €116 million
in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to €1,383 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. This increase was primarily
driven by the one-time €1,080 million fee paid in connection with the Licensing Agreement for the use of the
“thyssenkrupp” brand (see “Business—Intellectual Property”), increased expansions and major project
expenditure, specifically the acquisitions of Nashville Machine Elevator and O’Keefe Elevator Company Inc. and
advance payments in connection with thyssenkrupp Group internal asset transfers, including €74 million of real
estate assets, in preparation for the operational carve-out of the elevator technology business.

Our cash outflows on a combined basis from investing activities decreased by €29 million, or 20.0%, from
€145 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €116 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was
primarily driven by a decrease in cash outflow for capital expenditures mainly with respect to property, plant and
equipment following the finalization of several major investments in the Asia/Pacific segment.

_Cash flows from financing activities_

Our cash flows on a consolidated basis from financing activities strongly increased by €3,052 million from an
outflow of €32 million in the six months ended March 31, 2019 to an inflow of €3,020 million in the six months
ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily driven by a significant increase in amounts received from
thyssenkrupp Group due to the existing integration of the Group into the cash pooling of thyssenkrupp Group and
due to capital increases. These increased cash inflows were mainly associated with the already mentioned legal
reorganization of the Group.

Our cash flows on a combined basis from financing activities increased by €1,156 million, or 583.8%, from an
outflow of €198 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to an inflow of €958 million in the 2018/2019 Financial
Year. The increase was primarily driven by an increase in amounts received pursuant to thyssenkrupp Group
intragroup financing arrangements.

Our cash outflow on a combined basis from financing activities decreased by €151 million, or 43.3%, from
outflows of €349 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to outflows of €198 million in the 2017/2018 Financial
Year. The decrease in cash outflows was primarily driven by a net decrease in amounts paid pursuant to
thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financing arrangements.

**_Capital Expenditures_**

Our capital expenditures primarily relate to expansion and major products, such as acquisitions and the
operational expansion of manufacturing facilities, and maintenance, such as information technology and research
and development expenditures, as well as investments in regular business activities. Our capital expenditures as a
percentage of sales was equal to 1.9%, 1.6%, and 17.4% in the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial
Years (on a combined basis), respectively, and 1.6% and 88.8% in the six months ended March 31, 2019 and
2020 (on a consolidated basis), respectively.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management**

We are exposed to financial risks in the form of credit risk (default risk), market risk (foreign currency and
interest rate risk) and liquidity risk during the course of our ordinary business activities. Market risk is the risk
that fair values or future cash flows of non-derivative or derivative financial instruments will fluctuate due to
changes in risk factors. Among market risks relevant to our business are foreign currency and interest rate risks.
Associated with these risks are fluctuations in income, equity and cash flow.

The analyses and amounts discussed below that are determined by means of sensitivity analyses represent
hypothetical, future-oriented data that can differ from actual outcomes because of unforeseeable developments in
financial markets. Moreover, non-financial or non-quantifiable risks, such as business risks, are not considered
here. Credit risk, market risk and liquidity risk are described below and in more detail in Note 21 to the Audited
Combined Financial Statements.

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk (default risk) is the risk of the Group incurring financial losses due to the non-fulfilment or partial
fulfilment of existing debt obligations. Credit risk management is governed by corporate guidelines. Companies
and business operating activities of the Group are required to implement credit risk management in accordance
with these guidelines.

In order to minimize default risks (credit risks) from the use of financial instruments, we only conclude such
transactions with counterparties that meet our internal minimum requirements. We currently conclude our
financial instruments with thyssenkrupp AG or with financial institutions. After the Acquisition Closing Date, we
expect to conclude new financial instruments with financial institutions only.

We generally manage default risks by requiring suitable advance as well as progress payments. In rare cases
where a credit risk analysis suggests a potentially higher default risk, letters of credit and payment guarantees
from banks, insurance companies and management companies are requested. In order to minimize default risks
from operating activities, our corporate guidelines provide for the assessment of default risk based on the risk
profile of the business partner using suitable internal and, where available, external information, such as ratings
and credit reports, in conjunction with the corresponding estimation of financial risk exposure regarding the
respective business transaction from our perspective. We make a credit decision for each transaction with each
business partner using the aforementioned approach. Considering the individual characteristics of our customer
structures and business models, we lay down clear process rules for determining which measures are to be taken
in the event of a payment default in order to mitigate the maximum default risk as far as possible. Transactions
the value of which exceeds specified materiality thresholds, especially in the area of major sales contracts, also
require prior approval at different management levels within the Group. Among other things, the amount and
hedging of default risks are assessed.

**_Foreign Currency Risk Exposure_**

We are exposed to translation and transactional foreign exchange risks. Translational risk arises when we
translate the financial statements of our subsidiaries which have a functional currency other than our functional
reporting currency, the euro. Transactional risk arises when our subsidiaries execute transactions in a currency
other than their functional currency. In the years ended September 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, 77% of our net sales
were generated by operating subsidiaries with a functional currency (generally the local currency) other than the
euro. In terms of our results of operations, the US dollar, the Chinese renminbi, the Brazilian real, the Canadian
dollar and the South Korean won are the most important foreign currencies, though for the purposes of sensitivity
analysis under IFRS 7, the US dollar is the only relevant risk variable.

Our policy is to continuously monitor such risks through our risk management system. There have been no
significant risk concentrations in the past financial year, as less than 5% of net sales require derivative foreign
currency hedging as of the financial year ended September 30, 2019, of which approximately 75% is linked to
the euro and U.S. dollar. Of our sales for the 2018/2019 Financial Year, 55% were either in euro or U.S. dollar.
Foreign currency hedging is used to fix prices on the basis of hedging rates as protection against any unfavorable
exchange rate fluctuations in the future. Hedging periods are generally based on the maturities of underlying
transactions. Foreign currency derivative contracts usually have maturities of twelve months or less, but can also
be up to six years in exceptional cases.

The U.S. dollar is the only relevant risk variable for sensitivity analyses under IFRS 7, as the vast majority of
foreign currency cash flows occur in U.S. dollars. As hedging transactions are generally used to hedge underlying
transactions, opposite effects in underlying and hedging transactions are almost entirely offset over the total

122


-----

period. Thus, the transactional currency risk exposure results from hedging relationships with off-balance sheet
underlying transactions, i.e., hedges of firm commitments and forecasted sales.

Both the proceeds from the offering of, and the liabilities incurred under, the SSN USD Notes, the SUN USD
Notes and the USD TLB Facility will be denominated in U.S. dollar. We may consider entering into certain
derivative agreements for hedging all or a portion of our exposure to fluctuations in the euro-value of these
liabilities. We have not yet completed our analysis and procedures to determine the accounting treatment of such
potential derivative agreements.

For more information on our foreign currency risk exposure, including a sensitivity analysis, see Note 21 to the
Audited Combined Financial Statements.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Interest rate instruments can result in cash flow risks, opportunity effects, as well as interest rate risks affecting
the statement of financial position and earnings. Refinancing and variable-rate financial instruments are subject
to cash flow risk which expresses the uncertainty of future interest payments. We measure cash flow risk by
means of cash flow sensitivity. Opportunity effects arise from non-derivatives, as these are measured at
amortized costs rather than fair value, in contrast to interest derivatives. The difference, the so-called opportunity
effect, affects neither our statement of financial position nor the statement of profit or loss. Opportunity effects
and interest rate risks affecting the statement of financial position and earnings are determined by calculating fair
value sensitivity analyses and changes.

Borrowings under the Senior Facilities, the SSN EUR FRN Notes and the Private Senior Notes will be variable
rate debt. We may consider entering into certain derivative agreements, for hedging all or a portion of our
exposure to fluctuations in the interest rate of these liabilities. We have not yet completed our analysis and
procedures to determine the accounting treatment of such potential derivative agreements.

For more information on our interest rate risk exposure, including a sensitivity analysis, see Note 21 to the
Audited Combined Financial Statements.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that we are unable to meet our existing or future obligations associated with financial
liabilities due to insufficient availability of cash or cash equivalents.

To counter this risk, cash inflows and outflows and due dates are continuously monitored and managed. Cash
requirements are primarily met by cash generated from operations and until the Acquisition Closing Date, will
also be met with borrowings from thyssenkrupp AG and cash in connection with cash management and cash
pooling services performed by thyssenkrupp AG. As of March 31, 2020, on a consolidated basis, we had cash
and cash equivalents of €220 million. Further, we had cash and cash equivalents of €307 million, €256 million
and €313 million, respectively, September 30, 2017, September 30, 2018 and September 30, 2019 on a combined
basis, respectively. As a result, there were no material concentrations of liquidity risk in the period under review.

Following the Transactions, we will mitigate our liquidity risks by rolling liquidity planning, maintaining
adequate liquidity reserves in the form of cash, and by drawing the Revolving Credit Facility. For more
information on our liquidity risk, including future undiscounted cash outflows, see Note 21 to the Audited
Combined Financial Statements.

**Critical Accounting Policies**

The combined financial information presented in our Audited Combined Financial Statements does not
necessarily reflect the net assets, financial position, results of operations and capital structure that would have
occurred if we had existed as a separate, standalone group in the reporting periods under consideration. The fact
that we did not historically exist therefore limits the validity of the combined financial information. It also means
that the combined financial information cannot be used to forecast the future development of the operations that
have been combined to form the Group.

In preparing the Audited Combined Financial Statements, our management made additional assumptions and
estimates, particularly in connection with operating activities to be transferred and allocable expenses for
administrative services provided by remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies. These assumptions and estimates
affect the amounts and the reporting of recognized assets and liabilities, income and expenses and contingent
liabilities. The actual amounts may vary from these estimates.

We apply estimates and judgments by management especially in the following accounting policies.

123


-----

**_Business Combinations_**

As a result of acquisitions, we recognized goodwill in our statement of financial position. In a business
combination, all identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities acquired are recorded at the date of
acquisition at their respective fair value. One of the most significant estimates relates to the determination of the
fair value of these asset and liabilities. Land, buildings and equipment are usually independently appraised while
marketable securities are valued at market price. If any intangible assets are identified, depending on the type of
intangible asset and the complexity of determining our fair value, we either consult with an independent external
valuation expert or develop the fair value internally, using an appropriate valuation technique which is generally
based on a forecast of the total expected future net cash flows. These evaluations are linked closely to the
assumptions made by management regarding the future performance of the assets concerned and any changes in
the discount rate applied.

**_Recoverability of Goodwill_**

We test annually, and also when any indicators exist, whether goodwill has suffered an impairment loss. If there
is an indication, the recoverable amount of the cash-generating unit has to be estimated, which is the greater of
the fair value less costs to sell and the value in use. The determination of the value in use involves making
assumptions and estimates related to the projection and discounting of future cash flows. See Note 4 to the
Audited Combined Financial Statements. Although management believes the assumptions used to calculate
recoverable amounts are appropriate, any unforeseen changes in these assumptions could result in impairment
charges to goodwill, which could adversely affect the future financial position and operating results.

**_Recoverability of Assets_**

At each balance sheet date, we assess whether there is any indication that the carrying amounts of our property,
plant and equipment, investment property or intangible assets may be impaired. If any such indication exists, we
estimate the recoverable amount of the asset. The recoverable amount is the greater of the fair value less costs to
sell and the value in use. In assessing the value in use, we have to determine discounted future cash flows from
the related assets. Estimating the discounted future cash flows involves significant assumptions, including
particularly those regarding future sale prices and sale volumes, costs and discount rates. See Notes 4 and 5 to the
Audited Combined Financial Statements. Although management believes that our estimates of the relevant
expected useful lives, our assumptions concerning the economic environment and developments in the industries
in which we operate and our estimations of the discounted future cash flows are appropriate, changes in the
assumptions or circumstances could require changes in the analysis. This could lead to additional impairment
charges in the future or to reversal of impairments if the trends identified by management reverse or the
assumptions or estimates prove incorrect.

**_Other Provisions_**

The recognition and measurement of other provisions are based on the estimation of the probability of a future
outflow of resources as well as empirical values and the circumstances known at the reporting date. This means
that the actual later outflow of resources may differ from the other provisions. See Note 15 to the Audited
Combined Financial Statements.

**_Revenue Recognition from Contracts with Customers_**

Certain entities of the Group report some of their business transactions as construction contracts, in which sales
are recognized over time using the percentage-of-completion method. This method requires accurate estimates of
the extent of progress towards completion. Depending on the methodology to determine contract progress, the
significant estimates include total contract costs, remaining costs to completion, total contract sales, contract
risks and other judgments. The managements of the operating companies continually review all estimates
involved in such contraction contracts and adjust them as necessary.

The expected variable consideration amount is estimated at the inception of a contract with a customer. The
estimate is made using either the probability-weighted expected value or the most likely amount. The estimation
method giving the better forecast for the respective contract is always used. The variable consideration amount
estimated at contract inception is reviewed at each reporting date and adjusted as necessary.

In the case of contracts with customers which have distinct performance obligations, the required allocation of
the transaction price to the distinct performance obligations is carried out by reference to the relative standalone
selling prices. The relative standalone selling prices used generally correspond to directly observable market

124


-----

prices at which we separately sell the performance obligations to other customers. If the standalone selling price
is not directly observable, we make a best estimate of the standalone selling price. In these cases, we use an
adjusted market assessment approach, an expected cost plus a margin approach, or a residual approach.

**_Income Taxes_**

The recognition and measurement of current and deferred tax receivables and liabilities depend on management
estimates of tax uncertainties and future business performance. These include both the interpretation of existing
tax regulations and the testing of deferred tax assets for impairment. We adjust these estimates when there is
sufficient evidence of the need for such adjustment.

**_Employee Benefits_**

We account for pension and other post-retirement benefits in accordance with actuarial valuations. These
valuations rely on statistical and other factors in order to anticipate future events. These factors include key
actuarial assumptions including the discount rate, expected salary increases, mortality rates and health care cost
trend rates. These actuarial assumptions may differ materially from actual developments due to changing market
and economic conditions and therefore may result in a significant change in post-retirement employee benefit
obligations, of equity and the related future expense. See Note 14 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements
for further information.

**_Legal Contingencies_**

Various entities within the Group are party to litigations related to a number of matters as described in greater
detail in “Business—Legal Proceedings.” The outcome of these matters may have a material effect on the
financial position, results of operations or cash flows. Management regularly analyzes current information about
these matters and provides provisions for probable contingent losses including the estimate of legal expense to
resolve the matters. For the assessments, internal and external lawyers are used. In making the decision regarding
the need for loss provisions, management considers the degree of probability of an unfavorable outcome and the
ability to make a sufficiently reliable estimate of the amount of loss. The filing of a suit or formal assertion of a
claim against any of these entities within the Group or the disclosure of any such suit or assertions, does not
automatically indicate that a provision of a loss may be appropriate. See Note 20 to the Audited Combined
Financial Statements for further information.

**Overview of the Elevator and Escalator Market**

We are primarily active in the elevator and escalator market (referred to as “E&E”). The E&E market is worth
approximately €56 billion (excluding Japan) according to the Market Size/Growth Analysis, and there are
approximately 16 million elevators and escalators installed globally, with more than 900,000 new units installed
each year. The E&E market encompasses (i) elevators for office buildings, apartment buildings, shopping
centers, hotels, hospitals, train and metro stations, airports and other similar applications and (ii) escalators and
moving walks with the ability to handle heavy traffic and frequent use utilized in a broad range of applications. A
mixture of global, pure play elevator and escalator manufacturers, industrial conglomerates with elevator and
escalator divisions and smaller regional and local companies make up the competitive landscape of the elevator
and escalator market. For buyers of elevator and escalator products, key purchasing criteria include price (in
particular for new installation tenders), customer relationships, brand reputation, operational scale, cost of
ownership, terms of maintenance and repair services, efficiency and innovative product offerings. With a
relatively fragmented, localized customer base and a diverse regulatory environment, local expertise is important
to obtain both new installation and recurring service contracts.

Elevators are typically divided into high-, mid- and low-rise categories, with varying regulatory and technical
requirements. High-rise units generally serve commercial applications above 100 meters. Mid-rise units usually
serve commercial or public projects with a height of 45-100 meters. Low-rise units mostly serve residential
projects under 45 meters. Due to regional differences in product demand and regulation, elevator and escalator
products from a manufacturer may also differ depending on the location of the intended customer.

Within the elevator and escalator market, there are generally three discrete lines of business driven by the product
lifecycle and customer relationship: New Installation, Services and Modernizations. After their initial
manufacture and installation, elevators and escalators require continuous maintenance throughout their lifespan
before requiring varying levels of modernization. The graphic below illustrates the typical sales lifecycle for an
original equipment manufacturer (OEM) alongside the customer relationship for an elevator or escalator:

**_New Installation_**

The New Installation business encompasses the sale of new equipment and the associated manufacturing,
delivery and installation at the desired site. The market for new installations of elevator and escalator projects is
driven by demand from the broader construction industry. It is therefore largely project-based and often subject

126


-----

to a competitive tender process, and selection by developers or contractors will depend on a number of factors,
including budget, technical specifications and service offerings post-installation. In connection with the new
installation tender process, OEMs also seek to secure longer-term, recurring service contracts for installed units.
OEMs term this the conversion process, and often measure their performance in part based on their conversion
rate of New Installations units to Service contracts. New Installation business is therefore an important driver for
growth of the Service business. OEMs also consistently work to increase the efficiency of their manufacturing
supply chain. Components may be sourced from third-party suppliers or produced in-house depending on the
level of complexity and customization required. Whereas in the past a large share of the components were often
manufactured in-house by the OEM itself, there has been a trend in the industry to outsource a larger range of
components, such as elevator doors, to third-party suppliers. This has reduced the complexity of the production
process for OEMs as their factory sites increasingly shift from deep manufacturing to component configuration.

Once manufactured, elevators are typically shipped in pieces and assembled on site, whereas escalators are
typically assembled in the factory and shipped as a complete product. Installation may be completed by an
OEM’s own employees or outsourced to sub-contractors.

Additionally, producers attract business through technology and innovation that reduces product downtime and
fulfills other buyer requirements. For instance, energy-saving technologies can help buyers reach sustainability
goals for their projects and advanced destination controls can increase the number of passengers able to be
dispatched per hour. Furthermore, recent developments in IoT technology, such as real-time diagnosis and
reporting of events by the elevator itself to an OEM’s service center, present an attractive proposition to New
Installations buyers with the prospect of more efficient service during the lifetime of the elevator or escalator and
enhanced contract retention for OEMs.

**_Service_**


The Service business involves the full range of steps required to properly maintain an elevator or escalator
throughout its usable life and is mission-critical in nature. For business owners, regular service of elevators and
escalators is essential to maintain consistent uptime and safety of users in their facilities. Furthermore, elevators
and escalators are subject to broad and sometimes diverse sets of regulations and safety standards across
jurisdictions which typically require maintenance on elevators and escalators by licensed service professionals in
certain intervals. In addition, Service customers are often property owners who are able to pass through
maintenance costs to tenants, making them somewhat less price sensitive when choosing a Service provider.

Based on long-term customer relationships through service contracts, the Service business can provide recurring
and reliable sales streams to Service providers at higher margins than the New Installation business. Service
providers as a result are able to achieve a higher degree of visibility into resilient and recurring future earnings
through the elevator or escalator lifecycle, as illustrated by the graphic below:

Service agreements tend to fall into one of three categories based on service scope: full maintenance, partial
maintenance and oil & grease. Terms of service agreements may vary by jurisdiction and customer, but often last
one to five years. Depending on the scope of the service agreement, the Service provider may charge a flat fee for
regular maintenance and on an individual invoice basis for additional repairs and spare parts. Usually, the OEM
of the elevator or escalator product has an advantage in winning a service contract for its own products.
Participants in the elevator and escalator market however also have the ability to service the products of third
parties, provided they have the required technical expertise internally available. This can be a further valuable
revenue stream for Service providers at various points throughout a product’s lifecycle as contracts come up for
renewal.

127


-----

While the elevator and escalator Service business is primarily local in its operation, Service providers benefit
from greater scale as they are able to maintain more competitive cost structures, network density and
technological leadership. Having a dense network of service branches with technicians trained on all types of
elevator and escalator units enables providers to increase their market coverage and further solidify their brand
reputation. Greater scale also allows for operational efficiencies such as faster sourcing of spare parts.

Moreover, recent technological advancements, such as those in the IoT landscape, allow Service providers with
global reach to further benefit from their scale as they are able to develop efficient service solutions based on
their deep experience in the field across regions. IoT solutions include real-time diagnosis and reporting of events
by the elevator itself to a Service provider’s service center, which can reduce product downtime, add value for
the Service customer and make service technicians more efficient. The advantages of IoT-powered maintenance
solutions have the potential to not only improve an OEM’s conversion rate from New Installations units to
recurring service contracts, they also help ensure customer retention over the long-term.

**_Modernization_**

As an elevator or escalator ages, it requires increasing amounts of maintenance to operate efficiently and
maintain compliance with local regulations. Maintenance expenses for older systems also tend to increase as
spare parts become outdated and therefore less common. Modernization helps solve these issues by providing
customers with a range of options to prolong the usable life of an elevator or escalator system and postpone a
more capital-intensive full replacement. With the age of the installed base of escalators and elevators generally
increasing across regions, Modernizations represent a further source of recurring revenue alongside the New
Installation and Service businesses.

Modernizations can range from the replacement or upgrade of a single component (such as a traction machine) to
the exchange of an entire system within a building (with a result akin to a New Installations project). OEMs seek
to win modernization work from both existing Service customers and from new customers. Many modernization
providers have the ability to modernize third-party elevator or escalator systems in addition to their own systems,
representing opportunities to expand their installed base.

The large and aging global installed base means that OEMs have the potential to derive significant recurring
revenues from modernization customers. Moreover, OEMs have the potential to convert the modernized units
into service contracts, increasing their number of units under maintenance.

There are approximately 16 million elevators and escalators currently installed globally, and over 900,000 new
elevators and escalators are being installed each year, supported by an estimated increase in growth in China and
ongoing growth in construction activity driving New Installations.

Today, the global population, and in particular the urban population, continues to grow. More than 200,000
people move to cities each day (Source: United Nations, 2018). By 2050, the number of urban inhabitants is
expected to increase by 55%, from approximately 4 billion today to nearly 7 billion (Source: United Nations,
2018). Within cities there is an increasing demand for better access and convenience, renovation activity of
existing infrastructure, new large-scale infrastructure and urban living projects and demand for innovative
products. As elevators and escalators are an inherent component of the residential and commercial multi-story
buildings that characterize urban environments, this will drive structural growth for the elevator and escalator
market. The elevator and escalator New Installations market is forecast to grow at a 1.7% CAGR between 2019
and 2024, driven in part by solid global macroeconomic output and construction output (source: Market Size/
Growth Analysis). Based on forecasts incorporating the COVID-19 impact, global residential construction
spending is expected to decline by 1.5% in 2020 (compared to +1.9% growth expected pre-COVID-19 outbreak)
and global non-residential construction is expected to decline by 1.7% (compared to +1.5% growth expected
pre-COVID-19 outbreak) (source: IHS). The medium term outlook remains positive with global residential
spending projected to grow at a 1.7% CAGR 19-24E and non-residential structures spending projected to
increase at a 1.6% CAGR 19-24E (source: IHS).

The elevator and escalator Service market is also forecast to outpace the greater global market with a 3.9%
CAGR between 2019 and 2024, driven by increasing regulatory requirements and customer demands for safety
and convenience as well as appreciation of service quality. This is particularly relevant in highly regulated and
developed markets such as North America and Europe, with an ageing installed base. The elevator and escalator
market is subject to a variety of laws and regulations which require the owners of elevator and escalator systems
to invest in maintenance to ensure their systems are operating safely. The need for maintenance of a growing
installed base is expected to fuel Service growth. In addition, the elevator and escalator modernization market is
forecast to grow at a 6.9% CAGR between 2019 and 2024. As the installed base of elevators and escalators ages,
property owners increasingly need to invest in modernization of their elevators and escalators to further ensure
they comply with applicable regulatory requirements and continue to operate safely and efficiently.

The trend towards sophisticated IoT solutions and general digitalization of transportation technologies is also
estimated to support growth in the elevator and escalator Service market, as customers across regions demand
increasing levels of service quality and uptime from their products. The availability of big data from elevators
and escalators in real time allows OEMs to improve their Service offerings and increase the retention of their
customers. Furthermore, new concepts in urbanization and architecture require innovative new elevator and
escalator products that can increase usable space, passenger capacity and safety. Rope-less, multidirectional
elevators (such as our MULTI elevator) are presenting architects and urban planners with new opportunities for
building and infrastructure design.

**Geographic Dynamics of the Elevator and Escalator Market**

Due to factors including market maturity, regulatory variations and macroeconomic trends, the elevator and
escalator market differs in important ways across regions.

**_Americas_**

Within the Americas, North America is a large and stable region, with an elevator and escalator market estimated
at €11 billion as of September 30, 2019 (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis). As a service-driven market,
North America is characterized by its globally leading margins driven by the high value per unit under
maintenance, which we estimate to be approximately five times that of China based on our order intake in the
years ended September 30, 2018 and September 30, 2019. The United States represents the most important area
within the Americas. The share of elevators in commercial operation (as opposed to residential) within the
United States is expected to be 61% by 2021 (Source: Freedonia). Latin America represents a young market with
significant upside potential. According to our estimates, we occupy a number two position in the Americas.
Specific market dynamics include:

- In New Installation, market value in North America was estimated at €3.9 billion and in Latin America was
estimated at €0.8 billion as of 2019 (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis). In the US, the market demands
fast execution, a high level of cost efficiency and a quick turnover of finished products to drive growth.
Furthermore, the market in North America has some of the highest technical requirements (for instance,
regulatory requirements for more complex elevator brakes) in the industry, resulting in higher pricing
compared to other regions. In addition, building code regulations in the United States mandating wheelchair
accessibility drive growth for elevator and escalator products and service. The New Installations market in
Latin America is expected to grow in terms of value at a CAGR of 3.1% for the five-year period from 2019
to 2024 due to a favorable macroeconomic outlook and changing trends from single-family to multi-family
housing. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis)

131


-----

- In the Service business, market value (including service and repair sales) in North America was estimated at
€5.1 billion as of 2019. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) North America is a mature market with a
relatively high number of installed units translating into a high Service share. Growth is expected to be
driven by customer demand for high quality services and a willingness to pay for such service to ensure
product uptime. Strict regulatory requirements for inspection and maintenance are also expected to
contribute to growth.

- In the Modernization business, market value in North America was estimated at €2.0 billion as of 2019.
(Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) There is an increasing potential for growth, as the average age of
the installed base in North America increases and regulations remain strict. Over 50% of the installed base
in the United States is more than 20 years old (Source: Third Party and Company Industry Analysis),
driving a continuing need for further Modernizations.

**_Europe/Africa_**

Europe/Africa represents the world’s largest Service market based in part on an estimated six million units under
maintenance as of 2019. The overall Europe/Africa elevator and escalator market is forecast to grow at a CAGR
of 2.8% from 2019 to 2024. According to our estimates, we occupy a number four position in Europe/Africa.
Specific market dynamics include:

- In the New Installation business, market value in Europe/Africa was estimated at €5.3 billion as of 2019.
Market volume in units is expected to grow at a CAGR of 2.2% for the five-year period from 2019 to 2024,
driven by strong construction output, particularly from the residential segment and a slight recovery in
Southern Europe (e.g., Spain).

- In the Service business, market value (including service and repair sales) in Europe/Africa was estimated at
€8.8 billion as of 2019. Europe is characterized by attractive conversion rates above the global average. The
Service market in terms of sales in Europe is expected to grow at a CAGR of 2.7% for the five-year period
from 2019 to 2024. Growth is expected to be driven by a number of factors, including customer demand for
high quality and regulatory requirements.

 - In the Modernization business, market value in Europe/Africa was estimated at €2.5 billion as of 2019.
(Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) The large and aging installed base in Europe is expected to spur
growth. Moreover, beneficial changes in EU regulations regarding modernization are expected to lead to
further opportunities.

**_Asia/Pacific_**

The Asia/Pacific region (excluding Japan) is the world’s largest New Installations market, with an approximately
700,000 new units estimated installed in 2019. In terms of market value within Asia/Pacific, in China, the market
contracted at an estimated -1.4% CAGR from 2014 to 2019, in part due to government restrictions on
construction in top-tier cities to counteract housing oversupply. A rebound is however expected in China with
substantial growth expected from 2019 to 2024, supported by increasing opportunities for new installations.
Significant growth is expected in the Asia/Pacific region more broadly as well, with an estimated CAGR of 4.2%
from 2019 to 2024, mainly driven by the region’s increasing demand for Services and Modernizations and a
turnaround in new installations in China. The market in Asia/Pacific is fragmented, with more than 50% of
market share currently going to service companies smaller than the top providers in the region. This represents an
opportunity for market share gain. According to our estimates, we occupy a number five position in Asia/Pacific,
as well as a leading position in South Korea. Specific market dynamics include:

- In New Installation, market value in Asia/Pacific was estimated at €16.2 billion as of 2019. (Source: Market
Size/Growth Analysis) The absolute quantity of new units installed in 2019 was approximately 540,000 in
China and approximately 160,000 in the rest of Asia/Pacific (India being the second largest New Installations
market by volume), compared to approximately 220,000 units in the Americas and Europe/Africa regions
combined. New Installations in China represent approximately 43% of the value of newly installed units per
annum globally. The New Installations market in terms of value is expected to grow by a CAGR of 1.6%
between 2019 and 2024. Robust growth is expected in China, India and other Asia/Pacific countries.

- In the Service business, market value (including service and repair sales) in Asia/Pacific was estimated at
€7.8 billion as of 2019. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) Units under maintenance in 2019 were
estimated at approximately eight million, having surpassed the European market in 2016. The share of the
Service business in the overall elevator and escalator market has increased by 8.8 percentage points during
the five-year period from 2013/2014 to 2018/2019, supported by increasing regulation governing

maintenance and repairs. The Service market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.4% for the five-year
period from 2019 to 2024. Drivers include an expanding installed base, especially in China, growing
customer demand for high quality services and increasing regulation of the sector. The relatively mature
South Korean market in particular is expected to place increasing importance on successful IoT service
solutions.

- In the Modernization business, market value in Asia/Pacific was estimated at €1.6 billion as of 2019.

**The Access Solutions Market**

We are also active in the market for airport and home solutions. Airport solutions include passenger boarding
bridges and related group support equipment, as well as intelligent gate systems. Home solutions include
chairlifts, platform lifts and home elevators that enable customers to move independently and comfortably in
their homes and other buildings. The business-to-consumer nature of the home solutions business leads to a
scattered customer landscape. The market for airport and home solutions is somewhat analogous to the elevator
and escalator market in that the product characteristics are similar, there is crossover in parts of the customer
base and it is generally organized around the same lines of business: New Installations, Services and
Modernizations. Depending on individual product lines within the market, the competitive landscape can range
from quite fragmented (platform lifts and home elevators) to more concentrated (passenger boarding bridges and
chairlifts). Overall the market is characterized by a variety of opportunities for OEMs, with strong growth drivers
and attractive margins.

The home solutions business represents a structural growth market driven by an aging population globally. The
world’s population is expected to age across all regions, with the ratio of people over the age of 65 years to those
under the age of five years expected to rise from approximately 1:1 in 2019 to 2:1 in 2050 (Source: United
Nations, 2019). The global market for home mobility accessibility solutions was an estimated €2.3 billion in
2019, and the market is expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 5% for the five-year period from 2019 to
2024. According to our estimates, it occupies a number three global position for home solutions.

The airport solutions business also represents a growth market, driven by an increasing number of air travel
passengers worldwide together with rising infrastructure investments. Customer demand for high quality service
and digital solutions are also expected to drive further growth. The global market for airport solutions was an
estimated €1.0 billion in 2019, and the market is expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 4% for the fiveyear period from 2019 to 2024. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis). According to our estimates, our airport
solutions business occupies the number one position globally.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are one of the world’s leading providers of elevator and escalator technology, with top market positions in
the Americas, Europe and Africa and a strong platform to capture growth opportunities in the Asia Pacific region.
We design, manufacture, install, service and modernize state-of-the-art passenger and freight elevators,
escalators, moving walkways, passenger boarding bridges and chair and platform lifts, covering the entire
product life cycle from new installation to service and modernization. Building on our German engineering
heritage, we are an innovation leader in the digital age, leveraging Internet of Things technologies to collect data
and make recommendations for repairs in real time to better serve rapidly urbanizing societies with a focus on
product safety and efficiency. Operating from approximately 1,000 locations worldwide and serving customers in
more than 100 countries, our business is characterized by a global sales and service network to ensure optimum
proximity to clients. High-profile infrastructure projects such as One World Trade Center in New York, the
tallest building in the Americas, the Beijing International Airport T3 Terminal and the Federation Tower in
Russia have all featured our elevator and escalator products, illustrating our strengths and global reach. For the
twelve months ended March 31, 2020, our sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA were €8,048 million and
€1,323 million, respectively.

Our operations comprise three business lines:

- _New Installation:_ Our New Installation business covers the design, manufacture and installation of
elevators, escalators and moving walks for all major markets and industries, including for both commercial
and residential projects, and includes low-rise, mid-rise and high-rise solutions offered at different
customization levels. Our New Installation business contributed 45% of sales in the twelve months ended
March 31, 2020.

- _Service:_ Our Service business offers a broad range of maintenance services both for our own and thirdparty equipment, with a view to ensuring the continued safety, performance and efficiency of elevators,
escalators and moving walkways throughout their usable lives. Depending on the scope agreed in our
service contracts, our services range from basic oil and grease maintenance to bespoke full-service packages
that include the sale and installation of replacement parts. As of March 31, 2020, we had approximately
1.4 million units under maintenance. Our Service business contributed 43% of sales in the twelve months
ended March 31, 2020.

- _Modernization:_ Our Modernization business offers comprehensive solutions ranging from partial
modernization to complete replacement of existing elevator and escalator systems and other solutions, both
for our own and for third-party systems. Our Modernization business contributed 12% of sales in the twelve
months ended March 31, 2020.

Our life-cycle business model is built on our New Installation business, which serves as the entry to our Service
business. On average, we convert 70% to 80% of new elevator and escalator installations into ongoing Service
contracts. This provides a source of stable and recurring sales as we also succeeded in retaining more than 90%
of our Service customers in each of our last three financial years. In addition, we win Service and Modernization
contracts from third parties where another manufacturer undertook the New Installation. The Service and
Modernization businesses, which together accounted for 54% of sales and around 70% of gross profit in the
2018/2019 Financial Year, are a source of stable, recurring sales and high profit margins for the Group, which
provides visibility on future earnings. Driven by our high conversion rate and high retention rates, we have been
able to maintain longstanding customer relationships. Given our global reach and high level of diversification,
our top ten customers in aggregate typically account for less than 3% of our annual revenue.

We have two core divisions and four operating segments, which are part of our reporting segments in accordance
with IFRS 8: Americas, Europe/Africa, Asia/Pacific and Access Solutions (together, our “Operating Segments”)
through which we conduct our customer-facing business activities. Our first core division is the new installation,
service and modernization of elevators, escalators and moving walks (the “Elevator and Escalator division”). Our
second core division is the new installation, service and modernization of access solutions for airports and homes
(the “Access Solutions division”).

The Elevator and Escalator division is divided into three Operating Segments based on geography, which enables
each to tailor its products to the specific customer needs and legal and regulatory requirements in its local markets:

- _Americas:_ Our Americas segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in the Americas
and is sub-divided into two further regional units, including North America, covering the United States and
Canada, and Latin America, covering Brazil as the main Latin American sales area and Spanish Latin
America. Our Americas segment contributed €3,306 million, or 41%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales
and €489 million, or 51%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year.

- _Europe/Africa:_ Our Europe/Africa segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in
Europe and Africa and operates within a widely diverse set of geographical areas through five operational
units: “DACH,” comprising Germany, Austria and Switzerland, “RET,” comprising Russia, Eastern Europe
and Turkey, “FRANCE,” comprising France and Monaco, “BBNI,” comprising the Benelux countries,
Britain, the Nordics and Italy and “IBA,” comprising Spain, Portugal, Angola and Morocco and, through
distributors, certain African countries. Our Europe/Africa segment contributed €2,149 million, or 26%, of
the Operating Segments’ total sales and €227 million, or 24%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT
in the 2018/2019 Financial Year.

- _Asia/Pacific:_ Our Asia/Pacific segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in the Asia/
Pacific region and is organized in six operational units: China, South Korea, India, Australia/New Zealand,
Southeast Asia and the Middle East. Our Asia/Pacific segment contributed €2,307 million, or 28%, of the
Operating Segments’ total sales and €178 million, or 19%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in
the 2018/2019 Financial Year.

Our Access Solutions division operates across all geographies and constitutes our fourth Operating Segment. It
employs a number of different sales strategies and distribution channels, catering to both the business-to-business
and business-to-consumer markets. The Access Solutions division accounted for 5% of the Operating Segments’
total sales and 6% of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year.

**Our Competitive Strengths**

**_Well-established player with a leading global position_**

We hold the top four market position in the global elevator and escalator market (excluding Japan) based on
revenues in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. Our Elevator and Escalator division is divided into three geographical
segments, the Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific, which comprise the majority of elevator and escalator
markets worldwide. Based on revenue in the 2017/2018 Financial Year, we hold the number two position in the
Americas, our most profitable elevator and escalator region, the number four position in Europe/Africa, which
has the largest service business by value globally, and the number five position in Asia/Pacific, the world’s
largest new installations market. As of March 31, 2020, we had 1.4 million units under maintenance across the
globe.

We believe that our status as a global leader in the elevator and escalator industry is attributable to our
particularly strong and far-reaching service network, our track record of high profile infrastructure projects, and
our offering of products and services across the life cycle of elevators and escalators, from new installation to
service to modernization. In addition, we believe that our expertise in the manufacturing and provision of spare
parts, along with our network of specialists and a strong and globally recognized German engineering heritage,
have resulted in a particularly high ranking among our peers with regards to competency of our field force, which
in conjunction with our innovation technology, are what we believe to be the primary purchasing criteria for
customers and puts us in a position of strength relative to our peers. Our strong market position is also driven by
our offering of some of the most innovative and cutting-edge elevator solutions in the world, such as our MAX
technology (“MAX”), our cloud-based maintenance tool, which utilizes Internet of Things (“IoT”) technologies
to collect data on installed units and make recommendations for repairs in real time, making it immensely
valuable to our Service business. In addition, we are in the process of developing the innovative MULTI elevator
system (“MULTI”), a rope-less elevator able to move both vertically and horizontally.

**_Highly resilient business model across cycles through service focused-business and balanced global footprint_**

We have developed a business model that we believe is stable, balanced and resilient through economic cycles,
and therefore, well-positioned for sustainable, long-term value generation, as demonstrated by our strong longterm historical growth. We have delivered resilient sales and Adjusted EBIT margins since the 2007/2008
Financial Year. Despite negative currency effects in recent financial years, our sales have increased from
€7,674 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €8,048 million in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020,
highlighting the stability of our business and our ability to maintain our sales and profitability over the economic
cycle despite external pressures.

The main driver of the resilience and stability of our overall business is the life cycle of our business model. Our
New Installation business is a key driver of our growing installed base and units under maintenance and therefore
is the entry gate to our Service and Modernization business. The Service business generates revenue streams that
include fees for regular maintenance and income from repairs and spare parts. The strong profitability and the

136


-----

asset-light character of our Service business contribute to our high cash generation. For the 2016/2017,
2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years, 70% to 80% of our New Installation units converted into Service
units. In each of the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years, the Service business maintained a
global retention rate of over 90%. Many of our Service business customers eventually become customers of our
Modernization business, which offers us the opportunity to generate revenue from retrofitting or replacing entire
systems of elevators and escalators while continuing the customer relationship. In addition, we attract many
Service customers whose elevator and escalator systems were manufactured and installed by third parties, adding
to our steady Service and Modernization revenue streams.

The high resilience of our business is also driven by a diversified customer base with long-term contracts and
high customer retention rates and a balanced global footprint, minimizing both customer and geographic
concentration risks. Our top ten customers accounted for less than 3% of sales in each of the 2016/2017,
2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years. Geographically, our elevator and escalator operations (including
manufacturing facilities, service centers and employees) are divided across three Operating Segments: the
Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific, which accounted for 41%, 26% and 28% of our Operating Segment’s
total sales, respectively, in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. Our fourth Operating Segment, the Access
Solutions division, operates globally and generated 5% of our Operating Segments’ total sales for the same
period.

The resilience of our business model is demonstrated by our financial performance during periods of worldwide
economic distress. For example, during the global financial crisis, our total Adjusted EBIT margin and sales
remained stable between the 2008/2009 Financial Year and the 2009/2010 Financial Year. Most recently, we
have been able to successfully manage and limit the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business by
having immediately implemented contingency measures, which we believe further proves the resilience of our
business model through the economic cycles. See “Recent Developments—Coronavirus (COVID-19).”

**_Highly attractive industry with structural growth drivers_**

We operate in the global elevator and escalator market, which generated sales of €55.8 billion in 2019 worldwide
(excluding Japan). The global elevator and escalator market grew at a CAGR of 1.7% between 2014 and 2019,
and prior to taking into account the impact of COVID-19, was expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.3% between
2019 and 2024, above expected real GDP growth. Specifically, between 2019 and 2024, the new installation,
service and modernization businesses were expected to grow at a CAGR of 1.7%, 3.9% and 6.9%, respectively.
This growth is underpinned by structural factors and megatrends, including increasing urbanization, an aging
population, a supportive regulatory environment and sustainability and digitalization trends.

Increasing urbanization is one of the primary drivers for the need for more urban spaces worldwide, which
increases demand for elevators and escalators, as they are an inherent component of the residential and
commercial multi-story buildings that characterize urban environments. By 2050, the number of urban
inhabitants is expected to increase by 55%, from approximately four billion today to nearly seven billion. In
particular, the urban population is expected to increase in emerging markets, including from approximately 60%
in 2018 to 80% in 2050 in China. This trend positively affects the growth of the elevator and escalator market, as
urban residents increasingly demand the access and convenience provided by elevators and escalators,
particularly in cities in the developed world where large-scale urban living and infrastructure projects (such as
hospitals, shopping malls and train stations) are increasingly required to offer fast and efficient urban mobility
solutions.

Growth in the elevator and escalator market is also driven by an increasingly aging population. The ratio of
people over the age of 65 years to those under the age of five years is expected to rise from approximately 1:1 in
2019 to 2:1 in 2050. This trend is likely to support demand for elevator and escalator solutions as well as home
access solutions for stairs, as the growing aging population will need or prefer the mobility afforded by elevators,
escalators and home access solutions.

In addition, growth in the elevator and escalator market is driven by a supportive regulatory environment, which
requires the owners of elevator and escalator systems to invest in basic maintenance services to ensure their
systems are consistently operating safely. Currently, over 50% of elevators in North America and Europe are
over 20 years old. As the installed base of elevators and escalators grows and ages, property owners are
increasingly in need of modernizing their elevators and escalators to ensure they comply with applicable
regulatory requirements and continue to operate safely. In Asia/Pacific, including China and South Korea, we
believe that there is a particularly strong opportunity to grow our Service and Modernization businesses driven
by the aging of the installed base in those markets and stricter safety regulations requiring regular maintenance
and upgrades.

137


-----

We believe that long-term growth in the elevator and escalator market will also be positively impacted by a
continued focus on digitalization, connectivity and sustainability, as customers increasingly value features such
as improved energy efficiency and enhanced safety and maintenance monitoring. According to the Market Size/
_Growth Analysis, the market for buildings with digitally automated operations or “smart buildings” is expected to_
grow at 5% per annum through 2024. We believe that our current innovative smart mobility solutions and our
strong research and development capabilities position us to benefit from this demand. For example, our TWIN
elevator system (“TWIN”), which combines two independent cars in one shaft, can already reduce energy costs
by up to 25% and increase usable floor space by up to 25%. In addition we estimate that our MULTI system,
which we are in the process of developing and will be the world’s first rope-free elevator, will allow for space
reductions of up to a further 30% to 50% compared to our TWIN system. We aim to consistently increase
product efficiency and provide additional value-add to our customers across our portfolio of new and existing
products and services.

**_A leader in technology and innovation in the elevator and escalator market_**

We believe that we are a leading innovator in the elevator and escalator market, offering disruptive innovation
and transformative digital solutions. We have been able to successfully monetize IoT and digital opportunities, as
demonstrated by our recently developed MAX technology and our proprietary IT system, VIEW. MAX is a
cloud-based maintenance tool which utilizes IoT technologies to collect data relating to customer elevator units
and make diagnostic recommendations, such as when repairs need to be undertaken or which critical parts need
to be replaced. VIEW is an operational business steering tool, which, among other things, automatically
dispatches qualified technicians to resolve the problems identified by MAX, often even before any visible
operational issues occur. Leveraging our expertise in IoT and other digital tools enables us to improve customer
satisfaction by increasing service quality and efficiency, thereby increasing our customer retention rates and
decreasing cancellation rates.

In addition, we believe that we have created some of the most innovative elevator concepts currently in operation
in the market. We are the only supplier in the industry to have an offering similar to our TWIN elevator system,
which combines two independent cars in one shaft. We are also currently in the process of developing the
MULTI system, which would be the world’s first rope-free elevator, allowing for space reductions of up to a
further 30% to 50% compared to our TWIN system. These systems offer customers greater space efficiency and
architectural flexibility than conventional designs, making us an attractive choice for a customer base that is
increasingly demanding more innovative elevator and escalator products.

**_Strong financial profile with significant operational improvement opportunity._**

We have a track record of long-term stable sales growth, high cash flow generation and high earnings visibility
on recurring future earnings driven by a ten- to 20-year elevator life cycle with a retention rate of over 90%. Our
Elevator and Escalator division has grown consistently over the years, with our Adjusted EBIT margin generally
increasing since the 2011/2012 Financial Year until the 2016/2017 Financial Year. While facing some
headwinds, especially from material price developments and trade tariffs implemented in recent years, we believe
that, following the Transactions, there will be greater opportunity to increase our Adjusted EBIT margin.

Our business benefits from high revenue visibility given the recurring and stable nature of our Service and
Modernization business model. Our New Installation business represents the key enabler for growth of Service
and Modernization by growing our units under maintenance and offering high visibility of future business
performance due to long order-to-fulfilment times. Most of our New Installation units are converted into
maintenance units, which propels our Service business. Our Service contracts on average have a gross profit
margin of approximately 40%, which progressively increases over the elevator’s lifetime due to increased spare
parts sales. Many of our Service business customers eventually become customers of our Modernization
business, driven by an aging installed base with the need to upgrade and extend the life cycle of the elevators and
escalators. The Service and Modernization businesses, which together accounted for 54% of sales and around
70% of gross profit for the 2018/2019 Financial Year, are a source of stable, recurring sales and high profit
margins for the Group. Our Service contracts have an average length between one to five years. Our full life
cycle business model, with our high conversion and retention rates across businesses and long-term customer
relationships, enables high visibility on recurring future earnings.

**_Highly experienced and execution focused management team_**
