**Our Strategies**

We aim to deliver strong growth in our business, including significant margin expansion, through our three key
strategies, Base, Core, and Core+, as further discussed below.

**_Base Strategy: Continue to capitalize on our market position and structural growth_**

Our Base strategy consists of leveraging the structural factors that drive growth in the market in which we
operate, together with our leading position in those markets, to grow our business and increase our profitability.

As one of the world’s leading elevator and escalator companies, we aim to manufacture and install a substantial
portion of the new elevators and escalators expected to be installed worldwide in the coming years. As a result of
our global scale and strong brand recognition in the market, we believe there is significant sales potential for our
New Installation business and continued growth opportunities for increasing our units under maintenance,
resulting in further revenue and profit generation in our key markets.

In addition, we target continued growth in all our business segments by leveraging structural factors such as an
aging population, global urbanization and stricter safety requirements driving demand for maintenance and
modernization services. In particular, we believe that our Service and Modernization businesses are positioned
for growth as the installed base of elevators and escalators grows and ages.

In the Americas, we target growth in our New Installation business, driven by expected growth in the US
construction sector and our strength in meeting customer demands for efficient execution and technical
excellence, such as our expertise in the hydraulic segment. We target growth in our Service business due to
customer demand for high quality services with short lead times, and through reducing cancellation rates and
winning service contracts for third-party installations. We also target growth in both our Service and
Modernization businesses driven by increases in the average age of the installed base of elevators and escalators
in the region and a strict regulatory environment.

In Europe/Africa, we expect that the large, aging installed base of elevators and escalators, supported by a strict
regulatory environment and high customer retention and conversion rates, will generate attractive service and
modernization opportunities. We further expect that strong construction output, particularly from the residential
segment and a slight recovery in Southern Europe as well as a more competitive product offering due to our
manufacturing optimization initiatives in Spain and Germany, will drive our New Installation business and,
consequently, growth in our Service and Modernization businesses.

140


-----

In Asia/Pacific, we aim to benefit from the anticipated growth of the new installations market, targeting robust
expansion of our New Installation business, including in India and other markets. We believe that growing
customer demand for high quality services and an expanding installed base will also contribute to growth in our
Service and Modernization businesses. We expect that an expanding installed base of elevators and escalators
and the growing importance of IoT solutions, particularly in South Korea, will lead to strong growth
opportunities in our Service and Modernization businesses. We expect China, the largest elevator and escalator
market in Asia, will continue to generate our highest New Installation growth globally, and that conversion of
many of these newly installed units to Service contracts will continue to drive growth in the Service business. We
believe that there is a particularly strong opportunity to grow our Service and Modernization businesses in China
and other developing markets, driven by the growth and the aging of the installed base in those markets and
stricter safety regulations requiring regular maintenance and upgrades, which many emerging market countries
are adopting as their regulatory systems mature.

**_Core Strategy: Realize structural profitability upside_**

Our Core strategy consists of realizing structural profitability upside by focusing on (i) standardization within our
New Installation business, (ii) manufacturing optimization, (iii) service and modernization growth and
digitalization, (iv) selling, general and administrative (“SG&A”) cost reduction and (v) procurement
optimization. In addition, following the Acquisition, we expect to realize additional cost savings as part of the
Sponsors’ Transformation Program.

_Standardization of Our New Installation Business_

We plan to continue to drive the standardization of our New Installation business by simplifying the amount and
types of products and components we offer our customers.

Historically, in part due to our strategy of growing through acquisitions, we provided customers with a large
share of customized product solutions. This resulted in a highly diverse but overlapping product portfolio and
limited price competitiveness due to the high costs of designing and producing such a wide range of
individualized products. In order to optimize our structure, we are in the process of simplifying our regional
product portfolio and standardizing certain components. For example, the number of product platforms in the
Group has been reduced by more than half in the last decade as part of a process of implementing a simplified
portfolio structure with further improvements planned going forward. In Europe, we have streamlined our major
platforms down to two, which cover 80% of our products. This has resulted in synergies and a strong evolution of
order intake in the first half of 2019/2020 while not impacting customers’ perception of our product offering or
quantity of sales. We believe this will lead us to benefit from economies of scales, focusing our resource
allocation more efficiently and allowing us to provide a more cost-competitive offering without compromising on
customer service.

In addition, we have also standardized and harmonized components across products to allow specific modular
components, such as traction machines, controllers/inverters and doors, to be used across multiple product
platforms, which we expect will result in lower costs due to the use of fewer parts, a leaner set-up, less
complexity, higher agility and easier external sourcing. These initiatives are aimed at focusing our sales teams on
value-based selling by presenting customers with a harmonized product portfolio of key high quality, high
margin products.

We plan to adapt our manufacturing to focus on products that provide our customers with one of three
customization levels for low-rise buildings (less than 45 meters), mid-rise buildings (between 45 and 100 meters)
and high-rise buildings (above 100 meters). These customization levels comprise: (i) Value for Money “100,”
which is our lower priced option with no customization; (ii) Performance “200,” which is our moderately priced
option with medium customization; and (iii) Customization “300,” which is our high priced option with full
customization. This value proposition model offers customers flexible and transparent pricing, which we expect
will make our products especially compelling to customers in high-volume and growth markets, such as large
property developers in Asia/Pacific. Our processes, in turn, will be optimized by focusing on a leaner offering
and steering our salesforces and engineers toward a focus on sales efforts based on product margin potentials and
the conversion of New Installation units into Service contracts and later into Modernization sales.

_Manufacturing Optimization_

We are engaged in an ongoing effort to optimize our manufacturing operations. These measures have included
closing and, where possible, consolidating manufacturing sites, increasing outsourcing of standardized products
and developing factories with improved technology for greater automation. For example, in Asia/Pacific, we

141


-----

have established leaner manufacturing operations, with a newly established plant in India and advances in
automation at our plants in China and South Korea. In the Americas, we have consolidated all North America
manufacturing at our Middleton facility to enhance efficiency and reduce costs. In Europe/Africa, we have
shifted our factories away from a regional focus (in which a particular factory only serves specific countries) to a
model where all factories can deliver to the entire Europe/Africa region, with each factory having a dedicated
product focus. As part of this shift, we have restructured our Móstoles plant in Spain and we are currently
restructuring our operations in Germany to reduce costs and simplify production.

In the long term, we aim to move away from a classic factory model, where the focus is on major production and shipping
of complete elevator systems and requires high personnel expenses, towards a model where we produce only key, mission
critical components and outsource commoditized parts, resulting in lower fixed costs and higher productivity.

_Service and Modernization Growth and Digitalization_

We aim to deliver service growth through leveraging our attractive business model and IoT innovation
technology.

Our business model contributes to the growth of our Service and Modernization business as, on average, 70% to
80% of New Installation contracts convert into Service contracts, and many of those Service business customers
eventually become customers of the Modernization business. We aim to grow our Service business, which is a
source of stable and recurring sales and high margins, by pursuing multiple initiatives aimed at increasing
revenues per unit while decreasing costs. In particular, we believe that our use of digital and IoT technologies,
including the recently developed MAX and VIEW systems, will enable us to improve customer satisfaction by
increasing service quality and efficiency, and thereby increase customer retention rates and decrease cancellation
rates. Particularly, in North America, our Service business growth is driven by the reduction of cancellation rates.
We have already improved our cancellation rates and we aim to reduce our cancellation rates further through
strict management focus and tools like the MAX and VIEW.

We expect the growth of our Service business will contribute to new Modernization customers as the installed
base grows and ages, generating an additional stream of stable and recurring revenues. We also believe that we
can leverage the scale and efficiency gains achieved by MAX and VIEW to reduce the costs per unit of providing
services, such as technician travel time and spare parts. In addition, we intend to increase our rate of winning
customers away from competitor service providers by enhancing the efficiency of our spare parts organization,
increasing our service training and leveraging the superior quality of our Service business and our capability to
refurbish multi-brand spare parts through our ITS unit.

_SG&A costs optimization_

We aim to reduce SG&A costs by centralizing administrative functions, adopting a range of organizational
efficiency measures and improving our IT systems. Specifically, we are engaged in an ongoing effort to combine
a wide array of administrative processes that historically have been performed locally, such as billing, payroll
and purchasing, into shared service centers. For example, in the United States, we are in the process of
consolidating these functions, previously spread over 18 locations, into one shared service center at the US
headquarters in Atlanta, and we intend to roll out a similar strategy in Europe and Asia. We are also in the
process of harmonizing our IT processes by rolling out VIEW globally, continuing to transition to cloud-based
services, adopting global templates and standards, “delayering,” or flattening, management levels to simplify our
organization and reduce overhead costs and adopting other efficiency enhancements. These measures have
resulted in more than €80 million in total cost savings over the last three financial years.

_Procurement Optimization_

Finally, throughout our Core strategy, we aim to reduce our procurement costs by optimizing our supply chains
through commercial measures, such as, for example, supplier days, clustering managed spend, and engaging in
e-auctions, continuing from measures implemented historically. For example, between the 2011/2012 Financial
Year and the 2018/2019 Financial Year, our purchasing savings increased by 300%, outpacing our procurement
spend which increased by 50%.

_Transformation Program_

Following the Acquisition, we expect to realize €240 million in potential cost savings by September 30, 2021
through the Sponsors’ Transformation Program, assuming the program will be implemented beginning on July 1,
2020 and driven by key management, including the Chief Executive Officer of the Group. The Transformation
Program focuses on cost savings opportunities related to (i) commercial operations, (ii) service operations,
(iii) procurement costs, (iv) G&A costs and (v) other operational costs. Some of these initiatives will be continued
through the efficiency measures, which we are already in the process of implementing, as described above.

142


-----

As part of our commercial operations initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our
organizational efficiency by restructuring and centralizing our sales supports team, including by shifting
employees to low cost countries. In addition, we seek to increase our sales force productivity through various
measures, including improving our administrative processes and completing faster technical sales. This is
facilitated by our offering of fewer customization options resulting from the optimization of our product and
service portfolios. We also intend to increase our focus on sales efforts based on product margin potentials and
the conversion of New Installation units into Service contracts and later into Modernization sales. We expect to
realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €7 million related to our commercial operations initiatives.

As part of our service operations initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our
organizational efficiency by rationalizing the number of our application engineers, reducing the number of
platforms in our offering, standardizing our service offering and reducing the number of our service centers,
particularly in the U.S. We intend to implement other measures under these initiatives as well, including improving
process, technology and performance management in order to increase the productivity of our service technicians.
We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €15 million related to our service operations initiatives.

As part of our procurement initiatives under the Transformation Program, we intend to implement multiple
measures to reduce costs relating to our procurement activities. For the 2018/2019 Financial Year, we believe
that our estimated addressable cost base for procurement activities comprised €2.1 billion of direct costs and
€0.5 billion of indirect costs. To reduce these costs, we intend to establish group-wide supply agreements with
global suppliers for key categories of direct materials, such as motors, cables and doors, including through
leveraging change-of-control provisions under our existing supplier agreements with local or regional suppliers.
We also expect to increase our focus on supplier driven innovation in connection with, among other things,
tendering processes. To pursue improvements in specification management, we seek to standardize purchases for
complex parts and establish business unit sourcing boards, which will act as advisory panels in key end markets
to promote best practices and streamline procurement processes. Furthermore, we continue to shift our
relationships with local suppliers to regional suppliers in order to both increase the number of sites served by our
suppliers and decrease the number of our total suppliers, resulting in increased efficiencies. We also continue to
streamline the amount and variety of individually supplied components in order to purchase bundles of different
products and higher volumes of specific products, resulting in improved purchasing ability. Moreover, where
appropriate, we target shifting to agreements with suppliers in low cost countries or otherwise shifting purchases
from our suppliers of local products to products sourced from low cost countries. In addition, we are working to
utilize both centralized regional lead-buyers to streamline demand-management processes and defined sourcing
hubs to allow for best value and benchmark sourcing through increased spend, price and margin transparency.
Furthermore, we expect to realize cost savings from our commercial operations initiatives that result in the
rationalization of our product offering and standardization of our SKUs. We expect to realize cost savings in an
aggregate amount of €132 million in connection with our procurement initiatives.

As part of our G&A cost savings initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our
organizational efficiency and generate attrition savings through a leaner operating model, the shifting of
employees to low cost countries and increased automation, including within our shared service centers. We
expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €36 million related to our G&A cost savings initiatives.

As part of our other operational initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to reduce direct and
indirect personnel expenses and scrappage costs by decreasing the portion of poor quality production. We target
replicating the cost of poor quality levels that we have achieved at our Korean plant (where such costs are
estimated to be 0.6% of internal sales) at our other plants, particularly our Middleton plant. We also intend to
outsource parts and components and streamline production overhead and assembly processes to reduce costs. We
expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €50 million related to our other operational initiatives.

We expect to incur one-off costs amounting to between €240 and €294 million in connection with these
initiatives, mainly as a result of (i) voluntary redundancy, early retirement and other severance costs, (ii) staff
training costs, (iii) investments in IT to digitize, automate and streamline processes, (iv) investments in the
existing shared service centers in Europe, Brazil and the U.S., as well as potentially operating new, regional
centers in Eastern Europe and Asia and (v) consulting, financial and legal advisory fees in connection with
implementing these initiatives.

**_Core+ Strategy: Deliver additional value through innovation, digitalization and bolt-on acquisitions_**

Our Core+ strategy aims to deliver additional value by (i) focusing on disruptive innovation, (ii) monetizing IoT
opportunities, (iii) seeking opportunistic mergers and acquisitions and (iv) continuing the measures defined under
our Core strategy.

We have a long-standing German engineering heritage and a history of innovative digital solutions with the
potential to transform the Elevator and Escalator division. We are a leading innovator in the elevator and
escalator market and strive to address what we believe are fundamental technological challenges to better serve a
rapidly urbanizing society. For example, we estimate that up to 40% of usable space in buildings is utilized for
elevator shafts. Our TWIN elevator system combines two independent cars in one shaft in order to increase
efficiency and creates more usable area by using up to 25% less usable space than an ordinary elevator. The
TWIN elevator system’s unique value-add has made it a top choice for premier buildings around the world,
including the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany, and the CMA Tower in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. We
believe that our MULTI elevator system, which is currently in the developing phase, has the potential to be even
more compelling to the market. MULTI is a rope-less elevator able to move both vertically and horizontally,
which will allow new architectural designs and unlimited building height and, we estimate, will use up to 30% to
50% less usable space than an ordinary elevator. We believe that our New Installation customers place a high
value on innovative solutions like TWIN and MULTI, which both have the potential to significantly increase the
usable area in buildings that is available for sale or rent.

We also aim to continue to monetize our IoT technologies more effectively in the future to create sustainable
business value and cash flow. By the 2021/2022 Financial Year, we aim to charge connection and monthly fees
to customers for using MAX, which already supported the servicing of over 129,000 units as of March 31, 2020.
Other innovations currently in the pipeline include our asset performance management solution as well as our
Intelligent Gate Management System, part of our Access Solutions division. We plan to follow the MAX
blueprint for these and other new products by clearly demonstrating the value of the product after launch,
bringing the technology to maturity and then developing a pricing and sales model that accurately reflects our
value to customers.

In addition, we have a track record of successful mergers and acquisitions, including most recently our
acquisitions of Nashville Machine’s elevator division and O’Keefe Elevator Company, Inc. in the 2018/2019
Financial Year. We plan to further develop our profit potential by opportunistically seeking future M&A targets,
which we believe can be value accretive to the Group.

**History**

The heritage of thyssenkrupp dates back to 1811, when Friedrich Krupp founded a cast steel factory in his
hometown of Essen, Germany, and 1871, when August Thyssen established Thyssen & Co. Both companies
separately evolved into major industrial conglomerates until they were combined into thyssenkrupp through a
merger in 1999.

While the Elevator Technology Business was historically integrated with thyssenkrupp’s operations,
thyssenkrupp began a separation process to facilitate the Acquisition in 2019. On December 31, 2019, all assets
and liabilities that form part of the Elevator Technology Business were transferred to thyssenkrupp Elevator
Holding GmbH, which was subsequently converted to an Aktiengesellschaft and renamed as thyssenkrupp
Elevator AG (the “Target”). thyssenkrupp Elevator AG is the top holding company of the Elevator Technology
Business, the sole shareholder of thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding and a
wholly-owned indirect subsidiary of thyssenkrupp AG.

The Elevator Technology Business was incepted in the second half of the 20th century, when the industrial
conglomerate that is now thyssenkrupp acquired several elevator manufacturers in Germany and Western
Europe, including Rheinstahl AG, a specialist in the construction and installation of transportation equipment,
elevators, escalators and jet bridges. Leveraging this new industry experience and its German engineering
heritage, the Elevator Technology Business flourished and soon delivered major advances in elevator and
escalator technology. Building on its early success in Europe, thyssenkrupp continued to broaden its footprint in
the global elevator and escalator market through further acquisitions in Germany, Canada, the Netherlands and
the United States in the 1980s and 1990s, which also expanded its service scope into home solutions such as
chairlifts. Having constructed a dedicated elevator factory in Neuhausen, near Stuttgart, Germany in the 1970s,
thyssenkrupp further expanded its production capacities as the Elevator Technology Business continued to grow,
adding an escalator factory in Spain in 1991 and an elevator and escalator factory in Zhongshan, China in 1995,
which also marked the business’s entry into the Asia/Pacific region. After the turn of the century, thyssenkrupp
made targeted acquisitions to further build up its market position, primarily including the purchase of KONE

**Our Business Lines**

Our operations comprise three business lines:

- _New Installation: Our New Installation business covers the design, manufacture and installation of_
elevators, escalators and moving walks for all major markets and industries, including for both commercial
and residential projects and includes low-rise, mid-rise and high-rise solutions offered at different
customization levels. We are a global leader in the new installations and believe we are renowned for our
global reach, innovation capability (including the development of digital solutions) and ability to execute
the most advanced elevator projects, having been involved in some of the most prominent architectural
projects in recent years. Our New Installation business contributed 49%, 48% and 46% in sales in the
Financial Years 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019, respectively.

- _Service: Our Service business offers a broad range of maintenance services both for our own and third-party_
equipment, with a view to ensuring the continued safety, performance and efficiency of elevators,
escalators, moving walks and access solutions throughout their usable lives. Depending on the scope agreed
in our service contracts, our services range from basic oil and grease maintenance to bespoke full-service
packages that include the sale and installation of replacement parts. Our Service business had approximately
1,000 service branches servicing approximately 1.4 million units under maintenance (including 60,000 units
from the Access Solutions division) worldwide as of March 31, 2020. Since services have to be provided
regularly to keep elevators and our other solutions in operation, our Service business creates a recurring and
stable revenue stream. Our Service business contributed 41%, 42% and 42% in sales for the Financial Years
2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019, respectively.

- _Modernization: Our Modernization business offers comprehensive solutions ranging from partial_
modernization to complete replacement of an existing elevator and escalator systems and other solutions,
both for our own and for third-party systems. Our Modernization business contributed 10%, 11% and 12%
in sales for the Financial Years 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 respectively.

**Products, Services and Modernizations**

**_Products of the Elevator and Escalator division_**

_Elevator Products_

We are a leading elevator and escalator company in terms of global reach and innovation (including the
development of digital solutions) and have the ability to execute the most prestigious elevator projects in our
industry. We cover the entire design and installation of elevator systems for all major markets and industry types.
Some of our recent credentials include the Hudson Yards development and the One World Trade Center, New
York, the Beijing International Airport T3 Terminal and the Federation Tower, Russia.

We provide elevator solutions for office buildings, apartment buildings, shopping centers, hotels, hospitals, train
and metro stations, airports and other similar applications. This includes the design, manufacture and installation
of traction drive elevators (driven by electric motor and cable), with or without a machine room, and hydraulic
drive elevators (driven by hydraulic cylinder). In North America, hydraulic drive elevators are more commonly
used, compared to the rest of the world, where traction drive elevators are more common. We cover all classes
and applications, from economical residential to more demanding commercial projects. These include low-rise,
mid- rise and high-rise solutions; as well as several innovative high-end elevator technologies. Our offerings are
driven by demand in the relevant markets, as well as applicable legal and regulatory requirements. Where
possible, we strive to utilize the same components (such as doors, controllers and traction machines) across
product types and models. However, since each elevator must be tailored to the specific building and the
regulatory requirements of the jurisdiction where it is installed, there can be significant differences between
individual elevators from the same product line.

We aim to categorize our product lines into three platforms, including solutions for low-rise, mid-rise and highrise buildings. Each product platform generally offers three primary options with regards to their performance,
durability and customization level: “Value for Money” (no customization), “Performance” (medium
customization) and “Customization” (full customization).

We offer four core elevator product lines, which may be marketed under different brands in certain regions. A
product line forms the basis for each individual elevator’s design, which we develop in accordance with each
customer’s specific customization needs and the applicable local technical and regulatory requirements.
Accordingly, elevators from the same product line can have different technical specifications when installed in
different regions of the world. We also offer additional elevator products to provide greater client-driven
optionality. Our four core elevator product lines are described below:

- _evolution / meta—Our Americas and Europe/Africa segments market the evolution elevator product line in_
the Americas, Europe and Africa. Our Asia/Pacific segment offers a product that is similar to the
“evolution” elevator product line under the meta brand.

- _momentum / zeta—Our Americas and Europe/Africa segments also offer the momentum elevator product_
line across the Americas, Europe and Africa. Our Asia/Pacific segment offers a similar product under the
_zeta brand._

- _synergy / enta—The Europe/Africa segment offers the synergy product line, which is primarily meant for_
low-rise constructions. Our Asia/Pacific segment offers a similar product under the enta brand.

- _endura—The Americas segment also sells the endura product line, which is a hydraulic model in_
accordance with the technological preference in North America.

In addition to our core product lines described above, we also sell freight elevators and other specialized
elevators tailored to serve specific transportation purposes, as well as our innovative products and solutions.
These include the following:

- _TWIN—The TWIN elevator system has two separate cars which are arranged on top of one another within_
the same single elevator shaft and operate independently of one another. The TWIN allows one elevator
shaft to handle up to 40% more passengers and to save labor and material expenses since only one elevator
shaft is needed for two cars. This increases leasable and otherwise usable space in buildings by up to 25%.
The TWIN has made it a top choice for premier buildings throughout the world, including the European
Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany and the CMA Tower in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

- _MULTI—The MULTI elevator system is expected to be the world’s first rope-less, linear motor driven_
elevator system. It is designed to operate with multiple cars existing within one shaft, and also to move
seamlessly between horizontal and vertical shafts within a building. In a practical sense, this reduces
passenger wait times, significantly increases potential passenger capacity and reduces elevator weight and
mass for energy reduction and increased usable space in building design. While TWIN saves up to 25% of
usable space in buildings, the MULTI increases those savings up to approximately 30-50% in high-rise
buildings. Beyond these practical benefits, the MULTI’s unique design also opens up a significant range of
new possibilities for architects in the design of modern buildings by removing the building height and
breadth restrictions presented by traditional elevator systems. The MULTI system is currently in prototype
design stage with a test version running in our test tower in Rottweil, Germany.

In addition, we also manufacture solutions to enhance the efficiency of existing elevator systems. For instance,
our AGILE solution, which is a digital user interface and building management system, based on the IoT
technology, allows building managers to intelligently group and assign passengers to elevators and facilitate
rapid movement of people to their destination. AGILE comes with four core elements, which revolve around
destination control, enhanced security, a design center featuring a touch screen interface and an elevator
management center.


_Escalator and Moving Walk Products_

Our escalators and moving walk product lines provide state-of-the-art technology and have the ability to handle
heavy traffic and frequent use. Similar to our capabilities in the elevator market, we are able to develop,


148


-----

manufacture and install top-quality escalators and moving walks for the most demanding projects. Our escalator
and moving walk offerings include products for all applications, including train stations, airports and office
buildings, and are designed to meet the highest operational and safety standards.

Escalators and moving walks traditionally consist of a robust drive unit/electric motor, steps, handrail/balustrade,
step chain, truss, coverings of various materials and a central control unit. We customize these elements in close
cooperation with each particular customer for any of our product lines. Many of the world’s largest recent
infrastructure and commercial building projects have featured our escalators, including the Lester B. Pearson
International Airport, Toronto, the Indira Gandhi International Airport, New Delhi, the One World Trade Center,
New York, as well as the Amsterdam and Shenzhen metro networks.

We offer three types of escalators, with minor regional variations, each helping to move passengers safely,
efficiently and comfortably:

- _velino: the velino commercial-duty escalator is designed to preserve the architectural integrity of buildings,_
and, with our compact dimensions, is ideal for shopping malls. The dual CPU controllers and the optional
variable voltage variable frequency (“VVVF”) drive technology, save energy and help keep operating costs
low.

- _tugela: the tugela heavy-duty escalator is designed for high-rise applications and locations with heavy_
traffic. Featuring larger motors and chains than the velino, combined with reinforced handrail drives, it is
well-suited for convention centers, stadiums, smaller airports or other places where large numbers of people
need to be transported.

- _victoria: the victoria transit-duty escalator represents our most rugged escalator, ideal for non-stop_
applications for transport hubs, such as the busiest and most technically challenging metro and train stations,
as well as larger airports. It is our most powerful escalator, featuring a specially reinforced drive system
capable of delivering nonstop maximum performance throughout the day even when operating at full load
capacity.

We manufacture three core types of moving walks, which transport passengers safely and quickly to their
destination in metro and train stations, airports or other buildings:

- _orinoco: the orinoco moving walks offer indoor and outdoor transportation solutions, allowing the_
transportation of large volumes of passengers carrying luggage and allowing sufficient space to pass
standing passengers safely.

- _iwalk: the iwalk moving walks offer indoor and outdoor transportation solutions, allowing pit or pit-less_
installation. To address building settings that offer minimal or no clearance for drive mechanisms directly
underneath the moving walk, our iwalk is a modular solution that opens up opportunities for architects and
developers. The modular nature of the product means that it can be easily customized, and pieces can be
removed for repair or replacement with simply a forklift, requiring minimal or no modification work to the
existing structure.

- _ACCEL: the ACCEL is our innovative, high-speed moving walk product, which is currently being_
introduced to the market. Building on linear motor technology that thyssenkrupp first developed for its work
on the Transrapid magnetic train project, the new ACCEL moving walk provides an initial speed of 0.65 m/s
and then accelerates to 2.0 m/s using a cutting-edge overlapping pallet system and synchronized handrail
system. ACCEL is able to transport passengers up to three times faster than a conventional moving walk. In
airport terminals, this can reduce connection times between gates by up to 70%, as shown by operations at
the Toronto Pearson Airport.

_New Installations of Elevators, Escalators and Moving Walks_

New Installations of elevators, escalators and moving walks refer to installations of these products in a new site.
Elevators are typically shipped as components and are assembled on site, whereas escalators are assembled in the
factory and subsequently shipped as a complete product. The installation work is either carried out by us directly
or outsourced to sub-contractors.

**_Products of the Access Solutions division_**

_Airport Solutions_

An airport is often a traveler’s first and last impression of a city or country. Passenger numbers at airports are
expected to double until 2037 (Source: The International Air Transport Association, market size (OI) based on

149


-----

_the Target’s internal estimations, public domain data and statistical calculations). We are focused on improving_
a traveler’s critical impressions while also providing intelligent solutions that elevate airport performance and
drive industry innovation. Our Airport Solutions, consisting of passenger boarding bridges, related ground
support equipment, visual docking guiding systems (VDGS) and intelligent gate management systems (IGMS),
serve airports across the world. We are a global player, outfitting some of the largest airport projects. We offer
comprehensive and flexible passenger boarding bridge options, which consider customers’ requirements and
allow them to select optimal configurations to suit their specific needs.

_Passenger boarding bridges_

Noseloader bridges are specifically designed to enable precise docking in areas with restricted aircraft size and/or
parking constraints, since they use a telescopic tunnel which extends from the terminal to connect with the
aircraft. A hydraulic elevation system ensures smooth operation while automated systems, such as
pre-positioning, reduce human error.

An apron drive bridge has more free movement by using telescopic, elevation and rotation axes to deliver
maximum docking flexibility while taking up minimal space. Our two and three-tunnel models feature
customizable steel, glazed glass or steel-and-glass walls.

For those terminals that do not provide a direct boarding bridge connection or that present design challenges such
as steep inclines, our Bridge Link (the “Bridge Link”) solution provides easy connectivity. These adaptable
“fixed tunnels” link the boarding bridge to the building. They are also customized to match the boarding bridge’s
look, feel and dimensions for a seamless passenger arrival and departure experience.

Our passenger boarding bridges can serve all commercial passenger aircraft, up to the largest in operation, the
Airbus A380, and our global footprint allows it to fulfill some of the world’s largest customer orders. Istanbul’s
new airport (IST), which opened in April 2019, is outfitted with 143 passenger boarding bridges, all provided by
us—our largest single passenger boarding bridge contract to date. We have the most comprehensive passenger
boarding bridges in the industry and are able to service our customers along the entire value chain, from New
Installations to Services and Modernizations. We have the largest global installation base of passenger boarding
bridges, with a market share of approximately 33%.

_Ground support equipment_

To support airports in their need to respond to growing air traffic worldwide, we provide ground support
equipment such as preconditioned airflow system (PCA) or ground power (400Hz) and potable water units,
which are essential to improve aircraft service operations and to avoid tarmac delays. We typically sub-contract
this equipment for manufacturing and offer these along with our passenger boarding bridges.

_Intelligent gate systems_

Our intelligent gate systems are innovative solutions that help major airports around the world avoid costly
ground operation incidents by increasing their gates’ efficiency. Solutions like our integrated management airport
system (IMAS) and atlantis (formerly FMT Atlantis) enable monitoring of integrated equipment at the gate,
including ground power units (400Hz), visual docking guidance systems, preconditioned air, surveillance
cameras and automatic doors. We have a comprehensive offering of digital solutions, which enable real time
monitoring of asset operations, automate operations and enable efficient maintenance. We believe that our APIS
(formerly FMT APIS) system is the only visual docking guidance systems that delivers 100% accurate aircraft
identification, resulting in increased gate safety, decreased turnaround times and reduced environmental impact.
We believe that these intelligent solutions simplify formerly time and labor-consuming tasks, reduce human error
and deliver a smoother passenger experience, in addition to improving aircraft turnaround times at the gate. Our
key strength is to provide the right software for the hardware, which enables a one-stop solution for ensuring that
all components work together and ensures safety, reliability and overall quality of our products and services.

_Home Solutions_

Our Home Solutions address mobility issues for aging segments of the world’s population as well as those with
disabilities by offering products that are robust and reliable. From chairlifts and platform lifts to home elevators,
we enable people to move independently and comfortably in their homes and other buildings.

_Chairlifts_

Chairlifts eliminate the barrier posed by stairs by providing a seat attached to a track which runs along the
staircase. In many cases, chairlifts are retrofitted onto an existing structure, which can make each installation

150


-----

complex and unique. Our chairlifts strive to balance design and functionality, offering optimal accessibility,
while meeting ergonomic requirements. We believe that our patented advanced swiveling and leveling (ASL)
technologies make our chairlifts among the industry’s best. Both elderly customers and government institutions
use our chairlift solutions.

We believe we are a technology leader for chairlifts. Our HoloLinc[®] application, of which more than 100 units
are already being used in the field, is the world’s first mixed reality chairlift solution, which employs a new headmounted, mixed-reality HoloLinc device from Microsoft to allows our customers and employees to more quickly
and accurately measure the space in which a chairlift is to be installed, which we believe reduces overall lead
time, helping to reduce customer stress and to lower costs.

_Platform lifts_

Our platform lifts provide people in wheelchairs with independent access to areas with inclines or vertical rises,
improving access to indoor and outdoor public spaces, such as government buildings, tourist sites and public
transportation systems, as well as to private areas. The platform lifts come equipped with ergonomic design
elements, including joystick control and safety features.

_Home elevators_

Drawing on our decades of experience in commercial elevators, we have developed a line of customized lifts for
private homes or standardized lifts for housing construction projects. They can be designed with or without a
shaft and can be integrated easily into existing or new homes.

**_Service Offering of the Service Business_**

We consider the Service business, a source of stable, recurring sales and high margins for us, as our most
important product and the heart of our business model. We service approximately 1.4 million units under
maintenance as of March 31, 2020. We offer a broad range of Services, from basic oil and grease maintenance to
bespoke full-service packages, to ensure highest safety, performance and efficiency of elevators, escalators and
moving walks. We also have an ITS Unit, a part of our Elevators and Escalators division, which reverse
engineers elevator and escalator products manufactured by third parties to develop capability of providing
services for such equipment. Since our products have to be serviced regularly throughout their entire life span,
the Service business typically creates a recurring and stable revenue stream for us.

Our net sales in the Service business are driven by the conversion of New Installations units into service
contracts. This is evidenced by our average conversion rate of approximately 70% to 80% globally (the
conversion rate being calculated as the percentage of New Installations units (excluding distributor sales, which
do not directly result in access to servicing the relevant units) that have been converted into Service contracts).
We also have an average retention rate globally of above 90% for our Service customers (calculated as units
under maintenance at the end of the year divided by units under maintenance at the beginning of the year,
adjusted for new units under maintenance at the end of that financial year). As of September 30, 2019, our units
under maintenance were served by approximately 1,000 branches, of which 300 branches were in the Americas
segment, 300 branches in the Europe/Africa segment and 400 branches were in the Asia/Pacific segment. We
have also recently begun implementing shared service centers, designed to enhance efficiency by centralizing a
number of administrative processes across regions.

Our Services are provided based on service contracts with the customers. The service contracts set out the scope
of the service package for the customers and range from basic packages, including inspection and testing, to full
maintenance packages which may include services such as preventative maintenance, repair, parts repair and
replacement, quality assurance, annual safety testing, after hours emergency service, quality assurance or release
of passengers trapped in cabins. Pricing for our Services depends upon the type of contract. In a full service
contract, the main costs are those of labor and components. In an oil & grease service contract, the main cost is
labor. The majority of our service contracts have a term of one to five years but may also go up to ten years in
some regions. Typically, we include the first one or two years of maintenance for a newly installed elevator or
escalator in the New Installations price, depending on the region.

MAX, our cloud-based digitally enhanced maintenance solution, is designed to increase service quality by
reducing downtime by up to 50% through creating information transparency for the customer. As of March 31,
2020, more than 129,000 MAX units had been installed globally. We collaborated with Microsoft on MAX to
develop an IoT based end-to-end solution to digitally transform service operations and create new customer
solutions. MAX is supported by VIEW, our operational business steering tool which automatically dispatches
qualified technicians to resolve the problems identified by MAX.

151


-----

MAX enables machine data from elevators and escalators to be collected globally in real-time using a proprietary
IoT device. This and additional internal data is then transmitted to the cloud through highly secure channels and
analyzed using VIEW to generate actionable insights for our technicians, improve reliability and availability of
the elevator or escalator units and create transparency for our customers. This real-time diagnosis draws the
technician’s attention to necessary action not only when shutdowns happen but even before the defect occurs.
The cloud-based modular and extendable nature of the MAX platform sets us apart from our competitors’
offerings, which are extensions of traditional systems.

We also use real-time troubleshooting with online diagnostic and customer service tools, as well as remote
monitoring to service our approximately 1.4 million units under maintenance as of March 31, 2020.

Changes in the legal and regulatory environment applicable to the products are a key factor that influences the
services provided by our Service business. The different legal and regulatory regimes also determine the scope of
service provided by us within the Operating Segments.

**_Services of the Modernization Business_**

With the average age of buildings steadily growing in many countries, property owners increasingly need to
invest in modernizing their people transportation systems. We therefore offer comprehensive elevator and
escalator modernization to enable our customers to comply with applicable legal requirements and to prolong
their elevator and escalator system’s lifespan safely and cost efficiently. Our Modernization business addresses
challenges relating to the customers’ need to comply with constantly evolving standards and regulations,
age-related wear and tear, efficiency and capacity optimization. Modernization benefits may include lower
operating costs, greater energy efficiency and increased tenant satisfaction, as well as an increase in the
building’s value.

Our partial Modernization solutions for elevators include safety and regulatory retrofits (e.g. fire control
systems), the replacement of individual components to match existing ones (e.g., door drives and operating
panels), a new look for the cabin and entrance, retrofits for increased comfort (e.g., door zone monitoring
systems), more functionality (e.g. access control) and optimizing energy consumption (e.g., LED lighting that
switches off when the cabin is standing still). We offer modernization solutions not only for elevator systems
which we have manufactured and installed, but also for elevators manufactured and installed by third-party
companies. Our solutions can be adapted to all existing installations, regardless of the component type and its
manufacturer. We utilize widely used and tested technologies, plus flexibility in parts supplied for such
modernization projects.

We also offer a wide range of tailored replacement solutions for existing elevator systems (with or without a
machine room). These solutions go beyond simple modernization upgrades to encompass the complete
replacement of an existing elevator system. Our replacement solutions seek to make use of the existing shaft and
avoid additional masonry, structural modification and painting. This not only limits costs, but also reduces the
amount of dust and noise produced by the modernization process. Our replacement solutions range from very
small lift systems to our high-end TWIN system, depending on the particular customer’s needs and the available
infrastructure, which offers the potential to expand transport capacity within the same shaft footprint.

In addition, we offer modernization solutions not only for elevators, but also for escalators, moving walks and
airport solution systems. For escalators and moving walks, the modernization solutions include the replacement
of individual components such as steps and handrails or, if necessary, the entire system. We offer retrofitting
measures to increase the system’s energy efficiency, such as energy efficiency controller (EEC), LED lighting or
skirt brushes.

**Manufacturing**

**_Manufacturing process_**

Our manufacturing processes begin with the order intake for a new elevator, escalator or our other products and
culminate with installing and assembling the system at our customer’s site. The manufacturing process is not
only a key element for the New Installation business, but also for the Modernization business, if significant
system upgrades are required. The main steps of the manufacturing process include the configuration of the
system, as well as the production of components by us or the procurement of components from third-party
suppliers. Whether a segment purchases components for its products from third-party suppliers in accordance
with our procurement strategy (for more details on our procurement process, see “Procurement and Supply
_Management”) or whether it produces them itself depends on a variety of factors. Standardized and commodity_
components are often sourced from third parties whereas technically complex and bespoke components are

152


-----

typically produced by us. Our manufacturing operations are steered centrally from our headquarters, but have
their organizational structures within each Operating Segment to accommodate the particularities of the markets
in which such segment operates.

**_Manufacturing facilities_**

In Europe, the main manufacturing facilities for the Elevator and Escalator divisions are located in Neuhausen
and Hamburg in Germany and Móstoles (Madrid), Andoain and Norte (Mieres) in Spain. The facilities in
Hamburg and Mieres are focused on escalators and moving walks, manufacturing high-end products for high-end
markets, including escalators for metro and train stations. The elevator factory in Neuhausen serves the high-rise
business, but also the mid-rise business, including the evolution line, for the European market, but also for export
of components such as traction drives to other regions. The factory in Móstoles (Madrid) manufactures the
synergy line, mainly for the European markets, and, to a lesser extent, for export to other regions. It is supported
by Andoain, which is mainly assembling electrical controllers. The facility in Mieres, Spain is focused on
escalators for the European and Latin American markets.

In North America, the factory is located in Middleton, Tennessee, United States, and the order management
organization is located in Germantown, Tennessee, United States, one hour away from the factory, serving not
only the manufacturing process of the New Installation business, but also providing the configuration services
and components for the Modernization business in the United States. The factory in Guaiba, Porto Alegre, Brazil,
manufactures elevators for the Latin American market, including Mexico.

In the Asia/Pacific region, the main manufacturing facilities for the Elevator and Escalator divisions are located
in: Songjiang, China; Shanghai, China; Zhongshan, China; Cheonan City, South Korea; and Pune, India.
Songjiang is the headquarter for Asia manufacturing and includes a production facility for traction machines,
doors and controllers. Shanghai serves the value for money market in China and is a manufacturing facility only,
as all production processes are outsourced, and components are bought in the market. Zhongshan comprises two
separate manufacturing facilities for high-rise elevators, including a test tower, and escalators. Cheonan in South
Korea is one of the manufacturing facilities with the best operational KPIs within the Group (such as sales per
employee) and is strategically important to serve the South Korean market. The facility in Pune is our newest and
was built to serve the Indian market, which is otherwise difficult to access due to high import taxes, specific code
requirements and a heavily localized supply chain.

The main manufacturing facilities for the Access Solutions division are located in: Fort Worth (Texas), United
States; Krimpen aan den Ijssel, the Netherlands; Pisa, Italy; Mieres, Spain; and Shanghai, China. Our Access
Solutions division’s key manufacturing facilities are strategically located in close proximity to our end-markets
and customers. The division has five manufacturing facilities: three with respect to Home Solutions (located in
the Netherlands, Italy and China), and two with respect to Airport Solutions (located in the United States and
Spain). Our Access Solutions division operates 14 service stations focused on Airport Solutions and ten field
locations focused on Home Solutions. The unit is headquartered in Essen, Germany.

**Procurement and Supply Management**

In order to install, manufacture and service our products, we rely on sourcing a wide range of components,
technical goods and raw materials, as well as services, such as elevator installation services, IT services and
marketing.

**_Organizational structure_**

We manage our global purchasing activities through a group-wide procurement organization, in order to leverage
the demand and benefit from economies of scale in our procurement of doors, controllers, traction machines,
guiderails and transmission means. Our material field strategies are based on an extensive knowledge of
customer needs and business requirements, global supply markets, and supplier capabilities. Under the material
field strategies, spending is actively steered towards selected suppliers. However, due to diverging regional
regulatory requirements and customer demands, procurement decisions are still made at the local level, subject to
compliance with the global procurement framework. In particular, differences exist between demands driven by
code requirements for North America and other markets where we operate. Therefore, a major portion of our
procurement staff works at the operational level.

**_Procurement strategy_**

We aim to generate the highest possible added value and sustainable reduction of material costs while ensuring
high levels of material availability and quality, and evaluate whether components should be sourced from supply

153


-----

markets or manufactured in-house. This decision is mainly driven by the competitiveness of the supply chains for
specific components. Specialized components on the other hand are usually manufactured in-house in order to
safeguard the technological features of such components.

In order to avoid dependencies on individual suppliers, we aim to have at least two suppliers for each of its
components in different geographic regions, and, ideally, five or six, to be able to auction our demands and
award the contract to the most competitive offer. Typically, supply contracts include no volume commitments,
ensuring high flexibility for us.

**Real Property**

We operate numerous manufacturing facilities worldwide and use land with office buildings, warehouses,
research and development facilities, and other facilities in a large number of countries as either owner or lessee.
Our lease contracts are currently centrally managed by thyssenkrupp Real Estate GmbH and are in the process of
being transferred to thyssenkrupp Elevator on a decentralized approach, to take effect from the Acquisition
Closing Date. We lease some of our premises, including our current headquarters in Essen, from thyssenkrupp
AG. We are currently proposing to move our headquarters to a standalone location in 2021, but are likely to
continue leasing several other premises from thyssenkrupp AG, after the Acquisition Closing Date.

Lease payments and service fees payable under the relevant lease agreement are on an arm’s length basis.
Operational expenditure and external costs incurred by thyssenkrupp group-companies in connection with a
specific lease agreement are either included in the monthly lease payable under the lease agreement, or passedthrough to the relevant user of the space according to a pre-determined contractual distribution key or according
to the space occupied by a relevant user on a pro rata basis.

**Customers**

We have different types of customers from both the public and the private sector. In the New Installation and
Modernization businesses, we typically enter into contracts with construction companies, developers or directly
with the owners of a building. In some cases, contracts are entered into with dealers or resellers who then sell our
products to the end-customers. Home Solutions is our only business where we sell to consumers directly as well
as through our dealer network.

In the Service business, our contracting partner is typically the owner of the building where maintenance work is
carried out. In some regions, the services are contracted by a property or facility manager.

Since the New Installation business is project-driven, the customer base is very fragmented. The Service business
on the other hand is shaped by long-term customer relationships, but equally has a highly diversified customer
base. Our Services contracts have tenors of varying periods. Full service contracts could go up to five years,
whereas oil & grease service contracts generally have a one-year tenor, often with an automatic renewal clause.

Generally, our top 10 customers change every year and typically account for less than 3% of revenues in a given
financial year, leading to a highly diversified customer base.

We aim to build long lasting customer relationships where the New Installation business leads to Service
business and ultimately to Modernization business. For competitors to maintain our service equipment installed
by us would require investment into the diagnostic, tooling, training, operational systems and inventories that we
continually develop. We believe that our customers generally rationalize the value of our support structure and
our consistent service delivery, even if it comes at a slight premium. Our retention rate has been more than 90%
for each of the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years and the six months ended March 31, 2020.
Ideally, customers become long-term customers of all three businesses.

**Sales Network and Marketing**

We have an extensive sales and services network around the globe covering the majority of the world’s countries.
As of March 31, 2020, more than 60 countries are covered by our own field operations, whereas approximately
40 countries are being served via distributors. Distributors are our strategic partners that sell our products and
services either exclusively or non-exclusively. In the 2018/2019 Financial Year, approximately 17% of our sales
were generated through third party intermediaries, such as our distributors. Our sales intermediaries’ landscape is
highly fragmented and we are not materially dependent on any specific intermediary to conduct our business. The
sales network follows our sales process named “EAGLE”. EAGLE sets out guidelines to provide a harmonized
sales process throughout the Operating Segments, to increase efficiency and transparency and to focus on
customer interaction by implementing a common sales vision that aims to ensure that the same customer

154


-----

approach is followed across our branches. It is supported by three bespoke training modules that the respective
sales representatives, sales managers and branch managers, as well as sales support personnel, call center
personnel and technicians have to undergo to ensure that the objectives set by EAGLE are adequately fulfilled.
The sales process is tracked through clearly defined performance indicators throughout the Group. We endeavor
to base business relationships on our own terms and conditions to the extent possible and have a process of
internal review in case a customer proposes different terms. The EAGLE methodology does not apply to our
third party distributors, but our distributors’ performance control is generally oriented towards this methodology
to ensure comparability our direct and indirect sales channels.

**Research and Development**

We believe we are recognized as a technology leader in our industry due to our continuous investment in our research
and development (“R&D”) capabilities. We have 16 research and development centers spread across countries in the
Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific. We are the only supplier in the industry to have an offering similar to our
TWIN elevator system, which combines two independent cars in one shaft. We are also currently in the process of
developing the MULTI system, which would be the world’s first rope-free elevator. Our R&D work is focused on what
we consider to be the fundamental technological challenges to better serve a growing, aging and rapidly urbanizing
society. Central among these are the digital transformation of industry, climate change and energy transition. At the
same time, customer demand for high quality applications, increased functionality, design flexibility and lower cost
manufacturing processes are also driving our research and development efforts. We believe that taking a leading
position in the development of sustainable products manufactured in a sustainable way will ultimately strengthen our
position and help to distinguish us from our competitors. Throughout our research and development process, the core
principle guiding innovation is product safety.

To execute these plans, we manage the entire life cycle of our products beginning with the development of an
idea and ending with the decision on whether to launch a product.

Our research and development costs and capitalized development costs related to internally developed
innovations amounted to €106 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. We employed approximately 800 fulltime employees in research and development- related activities as of March 31, 2020.

**_Research and development strategy_**

Strategically, our focus is to perpetuate the innovation for which we and our brand are known. On the product
side, the emphasis is on steadily improving the existing products and trying to design products that will meet
customers’ design expectations while satisfying their practical needs. These include features such as ‘INSIGHT’,
which can monitor, control and schedule elevators and escalators and air-purification and anti-bacterial
ultraviolet light and face & voice recognition features, which help improve safety of elevators during the
COVID-19 crisis. With regards to the Services and Modernization, the goal is to continuously use state-of-the-art
digitalization and technology in conjunction with big data to progress the market further into the digital age,
enhancing efficiency, safety, and effectiveness, leading to greater customer satisfaction and providing
recognizable daily improvements. We are constantly on the hunt for the next new, industry-disruptive
technology, starting from incremental improvements of our existing products to entirely new product categories
and functionalities.

While we are always aiming at improving product efficiency, our research and development focus depends on
customers’ needs and interests within a particular geographic region (e.g. cost is a key driver within the Asia/
Pacific region, whereas value-add is generally more important in Europe and North America). Through research
and development, we aim to consistently provide new value-add to our customers across new and existing
products and services offered, decrease customer costs and increase product efficiency.

We believe that certain market trends and challenges will determine the main areas of our research and
development efforts in the near future. These factors include urbanization, as well as the emphasis on the safe
and efficient flow of people within cities. We also believe that opportunities exist in certain areas which
complement our broader strategy of growing our business. We will continue to deploy research and development
resources to capitalize on these perceived selective opportunities.

**_Organizational structure_**

Group-wide research and development work is driven by the Corporate Functions “Product Life Cycle
Management” (“PLM”) and R&D. These functions are established in the Operating Segments and regions where
we are active. PLM and R&D formulate and coordinate joint procedures for research and development and
secure patent and trademark protection for our innovations. Whereas PLM monitors market demands and defines
what R&D should achieve, R&D executes the research and development work to meet the goals that PLM sets.

155


-----

_PLM_

PLM has product managers for the different product segments. Product managers analyze trends, customer needs,
market potentials, competitive technologies and products under technical and commercial aspects; and translate
these trends into future products.

Pre-product development, PLM defines the product requirements, develops the business case and indicates
differentiation aspects and unique selling points. PLM aligns the product development with the segment strategy
and plans the market introduction, following which it tracks and prioritizes the product development pipeline.

Subsequently, we work to ensure the seamless integration and real-time availability of all information generated
over the lifetime of a product. The product manager defines and evaluates KPIs to measure product market
performance. The PLM process includes not only innovation and portfolio management, but also our engineering
and manufacturing through to the end of the product life cycle when we take a product off the market.

We require PLM for all our products, ensuring a process which enables us to harmonize and manage all stages of
a product life cycle, while also giving our individual segments the ability to tailor the requirements to their
specific markets. We are therefore able to provide customers with products customized exactly to their
requirements.

_Core research and development_

After PLM has set out the requirements for our products, R&D is in charge of finding solutions which satisfy the
market needs reflected in PLM’s product roadmap. The pillars of our R&D structure are the “Research and
Innovation” and “Product Design”, as well as “Test and Qualification”.

Research and Innovation is responsible for technology discovery and scouting, overseeing feasibility studies, the
coordination and initiation of research networks and the setup and management of research cooperation with
universities and industry associations.

Product Design designs all standardized products which are introduced to the markets. They are responsible for
ensuring that the designs meet the applicable standards and specifications and they define the product concept
and the details of the design.

Test and Qualification processes ensure that designs comply with regional national (safety) codes, standards and
product specifications via verification and validation procedures. Tests are planned and conceptualized for
normal and severe operations under specific lifetime and maintenance perspectives at in-house Test and
Qualification centers and our test towers. All Test and Qualification processes are documented in a standardized
way.

Our research and development approach combines a pragmatic mix of globalized and regional goals and
management, with regional teams across our Operating Segments who are positioned close to the local markets
and products. Over recent years, we have worked to further globalize what has historically been regionally
segmented teams across different Operating Segments. Through the introduction of global platforms, teams
across the Operating Segments employ common tools, work on common products and utilize shared resources to
affect our research and development shared goals. Simultaneously, these teams across the Operating Segment
maintain a distinct advantage of specialized knowledge due to their proximity to the specific local products and
market mechanics. This dual track approach allows globalized management to follow product footprints, yet
localized autonomy to leverage regional know-how.

**_Cooperation with third parties_**

We collaborate with external scientific and academic institutions. These collaborations are mainly based in the
United States and Europe. Majority of our research projects are often pursued in cooperation with globally
recognized universities or research institutes, such as Georgia Tech University, Universidad de Oviedo, the
University of Stuttgart and the University of Northampton. These critical partnerships accomplish two goals:
firstly, they assist us in accomplishing our specific research and development projects, and secondly, they
provide access to a pool of top talent from which we may hire new team members. We also participate in
industry associations and other organizations such as the European Lift Association (ELA) and the LEED
(Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) certification program of the US Green Building Council
(USGBC). Our innovation capability is supported by collaborations with customers or other industry sectors,
typically regarding the implementation of specific technologies in an effort to realize a specific product.

**_Trade Unions and Collective Bargaining_**

Many companies in our Group are members of local employers’ associations (Arbeitgeberverbände) of the
elevator and escalator industry and/or the metal and electronics industry. Since these industries tend to be highly
unionized, many of our employees are organized in country-specific union organizations. In Germany, as an
example, many of the employees are organized in the German Industrial Union of Metalworkers (IG Metall).
Several German companies of the Group are subject to various relevant industry-wide collective bargaining
agreements (Flächentarifverträge) for the metal and electronics industry and/or apply collective bargaining
agreements which have been concluded specifically for one or several Group companies. For example, in March
2020, thyssenkrupp Elevator concluded a collective bargaining agreement “Future Elevator” with German IG
Metall in connection with the Acquisition. The “Future Elevator” collective bargaining agreement excludes
forced redundancies (“Ausschluss betriebsbedingter Beendigungskündigungen”) and provides for site guarantees
(“Standortsicherungszusagen”) for the German production and essential service sites and is valid until March 31,
2027. In many other countries in which we operate, we are bound by collective bargaining agreements with trade
unions in France, Spain, the United States, Canada and Brazil as amended from time to time.

In several countries including Germany, France, Spain, Belgium and Italy, employee representative bodies have
been established. These employee representative bodies enjoy numerous information and consultation rights
relating to personnel, social and economic matters, especially with regard to dismissals, compensation and
benefits and in case of restructurings or redundancies.

Collective agreements which are in place in various countries provide for additional protection and benefits (e.g.
severance entitlements) of employees, as well as enhanced information and consultation rights of employee
representatives in connection with lay-offs, restructurings, reorganizations and other corporate actions. In some
countries, collective agreements have been entered into with local employee representative bodies covering a
broad range of topics, in particular remuneration and working time.

A minority of our employees enjoy some form of special protection against dismissal, not only due to explicit
commitments in collective agreements, but also for other reasons, in particular statutory or contractual provisions
regarding, among other things, maternity and sick leave or works council and/or union membership.

Since 2016, we have from time to time experienced strikes at sites in France and Spain, though these have not
caused material disruptions. Good relationships with our employees are especially important to us, and we
believe that we generally have good and constructive relationships with our employees, their trade unions and
representative bodies.

**_Pension plans and retirement_**

Depending on the situation in the specific countries, we grant current and former employees and their dependents
pension and (early) retirement benefits. The pension benefits are based on various pension plans in the form of
defined benefit or defined contribution pension plans in various countries. Our obligations under these plans
vary, depending on legal, tax and economic circumstances in the various countries in which we operate, and, in
most of the countries, they generally depend on the length of service and remuneration of the employee
concerned.
