**Intellectual Property**

Our global intellectual property (“IP”) strategy aims to protect and enhance our competitive position in the
various geographic regions in which we operate. This is achieved by effective management of our IP rights,
including patents, designs and trademarks. The Group gives high priority to protecting our innovations and the
actual and future business value that we can derive therefrom. IP rights are currently centrally managed and
coordinated by thyssenkrupp Intellectual Property Services GmbH based in Essen, Germany, which provides this
service to us, with support and assistance from in-house IP professionals in key countries such as the United
States and China. After the Acquisition Closing Date, we will be managing our intellectual property with our
own in-house IP professionals and external counsel.

As of March 31, 2020, we owned approximately 900 granted patents, 570 patent families, 550 registered
trademarks and 160 trademark families and had applied for approximately 800 patents and 90 trademarks. We
also owned approximately 117 designs and applied for registration of approximately 26 designs, as of March 31,
2020.

While IP is an essential part of our business and IP assets are, in the aggregate, of material importance to our
business, we believe that no single IP asset is material to our business as a whole. On September 25, 2019,
thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation entered into a licensing agreement with thyssenkrupp AG (the “Licensing
Agreement”), allowing us to indefinitely use certain trademarks, including the trademark “thyssenkrupp” in
carrying out the business of the Group against payment of a one- time fee. Under the terms of the Share Purchase
Agreement, the Licensing Agreement will be terminated prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, with effect as on a
date falling 18 months after the Acquisition Closing Date. We are required to use our commercially reasonable
best efforts to introduce a new brand for our business within a period of six months from the Acquisition Closing
Date.

As part of the thyssenkrupp-wide IP policy, approximately 20 of our companies have concluded IP trust
agreements with thyssenkrupp AG in 2013 pursuant to which certain IP assets are co-owned by (i) the respective
company of the Group and (ii) thyssenkrupp AG as trustee for the respective company of the Group. The IP trust
agreements cover patents, trademarks and design rights, in each case as registered or acquired after the date of
the IP trust agreements. All IP trust agreements have been terminated. The process of de-registering
thyssenkrupp AG as co-owner from the IP registers will continue until all IP assets previously covered by the IP
trust agreements are registered in the sole name of the relevant entity of the Group. This applies to approximately
800 IP rights that the Group created or acquired during the relevant period.

**Legal Proceedings**

From time to time, in the ordinary course of business, the Elevator Technology Business is subject to litigation.
Except as set forth in this offering memorandum, there were no governmental, regulatory, administrative, civil,
labor or other proceedings ongoing, pending or to our knowledge, threatened, that would have a material adverse
impact on the Elevator Technology Business as a whole.

**_Antitrust proceedings and private follow-on litigation_**

Starting in January 2004, the European Commission conducted raids on elevator and escalator manufacturers in
Belgium, Germany, Luxembourg and the Netherlands. Following these inspections, the European Commission
opened an investigation into Otis, KONE, Schindler and the thyssenkrupp Group. According to the European
Commission, between 1995 and 2004, cartel members rigged bids for procurement contracts, fixed prices and
allocated projects to each other, shared markets and exchanged competitively sensitive information. The
thyssenkrupp Group was fined a total of €479.7 million in February 2007 for its involvement in this cartel. The
thyssenkrupp Group appealed the decision which resulted in a reduced fine of €319.8 million. This decision has
become final and binding and the fine has been paid. Similar proceedings, including several raids on elevator and
escalator manufacturers, were launched by the Austrian Federal Competition Authority, but thyssenkrupp Group
applied for leniency under the applicable Austrian leniency program and received full immunity from fines in
Austria.

As a result of the European Commission’s decision of February 2007 and the investigation by the Austrian
Federal Competition Authority, thyssenkrupp AG and some of its subsidiaries were subject to private follow-on
litigation. Although final judgments have been issued or settlements have been entered into in the majority of the
cases, we remain exposed to possible joint and several liabilities arising from ongoing claims up to the amount of
€150 million in total in Belgium, the Netherlands and Austria. The Group has made appropriate provisioning for
the sums we may be liable to pay, as well as the costs of the proceedings. We also have an indemnity under the
Share Purchase Agreement of up to €29 million from these claims.

158


-----

_Civil cartel claims Belgium_

The European Commission is suing the Group jointly and severally with competitors for damages of €6.1 million
plus interest for cartel overcharges of our products in the EU buildings in Belgium. The case was originally
dismissed by the Brussels Commercial Court in 2014 and is currently pending at the court of appeals. We have
made a provision of €2.6 million to cover the risk of this litigation, which is equivalent to 75% of the claimed
amount relating to projects involving thyssenkrupp Elevator, plus potential interest as of September 30, 2019.

_Civil cartel claims the Netherlands_

In 2011, a foundation, Stichting Elevator Cartel Claim (representing, among others, H&M, C&A and NH
Hotels), brought action against us as well as our competitor KONE, for a declaration of liability, alleging cartelrelated damages following the European Commission’s decision of 2007 and claiming damages of €22.3 million
plus interest. The case is currently pending before the District Court of Rotterdam. We have made a provision of
€3.3 million to cover the risk of this litigation, which is equivalent to 50% of the claimed amount relating to
projects involving thyssenkrupp Elevator, plus potential interest as of September 30, 2019.

_Civil cartel claims Austria_

Eight lawsuits by public institutions or corporations and companies (including the City of Vienna, the City of
Linz, the SPAR corporate group and various real estate companies) against the Group jointly and severally with
the other participants of the cartel are currently pending. The total value of the claims is approximately
€117.3 million plus interest, of which claims related to thyssenkrupp Elevator’s projects are approximately
€14.7 million plus potential umbrella claims of €5.1 million. The claimants allege that the cartel in Austria led to
cartel overcharges and umbrella damages in relation to sales by third-party competitors who did not participate in
the cartel. Ultimately, we do not expect to be fully liable for the total amount based on the number of our
products involved but rather for a fraction, if at all, of the value in dispute based on our products involved. We
have made a provision of €20.8 million as of September 30, 2019 to cover the risk of this litigation.

**_Ciacorp International Corporation vs. thyssenkrupp Elevadores, S.A._**

Ciacorp International Corporation sued thyssenkrupp Elevadores, S.A. over an alleged debt of BRL 207 million
(approximately €48 million) owed to some business partners of the former principal shareholder of Sur,
Mr. Aumonde. thyssenkrupp Elevadores S.A. acquired Sur from Aumonde in 1999, and Aumonde’s former
partners in an otherwise unrelated business venture in Uruguay claim that the structure of the Sur acquisition
enabled Aumonde to avoid having liquidity in Brazil, thereby allowing him to escape payment of his debts.
Aumonde’s former partners have brought thyssenkrupp Elevadores, S.A. into the suit by claiming that the
transfer of control of Sur should be found null and void as a fraudulent conveyance, thus returning control of the
company to Aumonde or his holding company, whereby the former partners could then access Aumonde’s
Brazilian assets to cover Aumonde’s debt to them. thyssenkrupp Elevadores, S.A. already won in the local and
regional court. The judgment on the third appeal is pending.

The appeal was allocated to one of the Panel Courts at the Superior Court of Justice in Brasilia.

**_Criminal and administrative proceedings against thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea Ltd._**

Four fatal accidents resulting in five deceased employees of consortium partners (installation companies) of
thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea Ltd. (“thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea”) on four different sites in South Korea in the
years 2018 and 2019 have led to the initiation of criminal and administrative proceedings, inter alia, against
thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea, mainly for indicted non- performance of certain safety measures as the owner of
the business. Three of these proceedings are currently in initial criminal and administrative proceedings in lower
courts, and a fourth has been appealed by the prosecution and by thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea.

In March 2019, the Korean environment and labor committee (“ELC”) of the national assembly began to
investigate these incidents. The ELC ordered (i) a two-week special investigation, which concluded on
November 5, 2019 against the safety management at sites and the legality of certain related contracts and (ii) all
relevant government ministries to audit the four major elevator companies in South Korea for any violations
against certain statutory laws. On November 7, 2019, the ELC conducted an audit where thyssenkrupp Elevator
Korea and the relevant government ministries were present for questioning.

These ongoing administrative proceedings may eventually result in the imposition of administrative sanctions
against thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea for violations of health and safety-related rules as well as construction
industry and elevator regulations governing sub-contracting, specifically on the following grounds:

159


-----

(i) responsibility of thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea as a ‘business owner’ for the infringement of safety-related
rules; and (ii) violation of the 50% rule on subcontracting under the Elevator Act, forbidding the outsourcing of
more than 50% to third parties in connection with maintenance services. The potential sanctions for violation of
the health and safety provisions range from a fine of €0.2 million to suspension of the New Installation business
in South Korea for a period of three to eleven months. The potential sanctions for violation of the provisions of
the Elevator Act range from monetary fine of €0.9 million to a suspension of the Service business in South Korea
for at least two years. thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea, however believes that the relevant authority is considering
limiting penalties for violation of the Elevator Act to fines only, since all major elevator companies are facing
potential violations. In addition to these proceedings, thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea was also facing charges of
violations of certain provisions of the Framework Act on Construction Industry, relating to rules on
sub-contracting, for which it was recently fined €32,000.

In the event that thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea becomes subject to further fines or business suspensions, it must
be compliant with the restriction on subcontracting for a period five years following the imposition, in order to
avoid the revocation of its construction business license.

Due to settlements with the heirs of the deceased, there is no pending civil liability in connection with the
fatalities.

**_Audit of thyssenkrupp North America, Inc. by the State of Delaware_**

In 2011, the state of Delaware initiated an audit of thyssenkrupp North America, Inc., a Delaware corporation,
and its subsidiaries and related entities (collectively, “thyssenkrupp NA”) to determine thyssenkrupp NA’s
compliance with the Delaware Escheats laws, also known as abandoned and unclaimed property laws.

The thyssenkrupp NA audit involves an examination of the books and records of certain large entities within
thyssenkrupp NA (called proxy companies) covering the years 1996 to 2014 (which end date rolls forward every
year that the audit continues and is not completed).

Initial preliminary estimates of liability applicable to thyssenkrupp NA received from Delaware amount to USD
30 million. We have been able to negotiate a settlement agreement with the state of Delaware, which involves an
overall payment of US$7.9 million, of which US$7.2 million is required to be paid by thyssenkrupp Elevator in
connection with the audit, which concluded on December 11, 2019.

**Insurance**

We believe that our businesses have reasonable insurance protection, to the extent customary in the industry. We
are insured under global group policies held by thyssenkrupp AG, including third-party (product) liability,
property damage and business interruption, and directors and officers liability insurance. In addition, there are
local insurance policies to be obtained by us via the thyssenkrupp AG mandated insurance broker. Both, global
group insurance policies and local insurance policies remain to be mandated via the thyssenkrupp AG’s insurance
broker. We are currently in the process of establishing our own global group insurance policies, which would
come into effect on the Acquisition Closing Date, with support of a mandated insurance broker. For further
information on risks related to our insurance coverage, see “Our insurance coverage may not be sufficient and
_insurance premiums may increase.”_

**Compliance and Risk Management**

We control our business and operations with what we believe to be state-of-the-art compliance and risk
management systems. We established a standalone compliance and risk management system specific to
thyssenkrupp Elevator with effect from January 1, 2020. This built-upon and enhanced the existing compliance
program of the thyssenkrupp Group to specific needs of the elevator business. Our risk management system
operates Group-wide and is a fundamental part of our corporate governance system. We continuously seek to
reduce the likelihood and/or potential impact of the various risks to which we are exposed. The aim of our
compliance and risk management system is to enable us to observe all applicable legal regulations, including
those relating to anti-corruption, anti-money laundering, antitrust regulations and data protection on an ongoing
and sustainable basis.

**_Compliance_**

Our compliance program comprises the following three elements: “Inform and Advise,” “Identify,” and “Report
and Act” and focuses in particular on antitrust, anti-corruption, anti-money-laundering, export control and data
protection. It is closely interlinked with risk management and with our internal control system.

160


-----

Central components of the “Inform and Advise” pillar are antitrust law, anti-money laundering, export control
and corruption prevention training programs carried out by the compliance officers as well as compliance advice
given on business transactions and processes. In the training programs, employees are informed about
compliance requirements, risks, and possible sanctions. The requirements are based on law and Group-wide
policies and serve to implement international standards. We keep all our employees informed about compliance
measures and new developments through training, intranet and various forms of communication adapted to target
groups and content. We provide compliance support on important business transactions, for instance in
connection with major projects, acquisitions or the engagement of intermediaries. Our compliance officers also
advise the operating units on integrating compliance into their business processes.

The “Identify” pillar focuses on regularly reviewing critical business operations based on a risk-oriented,
structured audit process. Anti-money laundering screenings of high-risk payments are carried out when red flags
are raised. An additional element is the identification of compliance risks through our whistleblowing system.
Alongside the options of directly contacting a supervisor or the compliance department, this system provides
employees with a further channel for reporting possible infringements of laws or policies without revealing their
identity.

The third pillar, “Report and Act,” encompasses intensive compliance reporting in all three dimensions of our
organizational matrix. We investigate all reports of legal violations. Any violations identified are sanctioned as
necessary, regardless of the name and function of the person involved.

Substantive compliance responsibility in these areas remains with the competent corporate functions and
segments. This ensures that in all areas of the company compliance is understood in accordance with our mission
statement, an intensive exchange of knowledge takes place between the compliance function and those
responsible for content, and the resultant synergies in organization, processes and methods are utilized.

**_Risk Management_**

Our risk strategy is focused on securing our existence and increasing our sustainably. Our business success
requires opportunities to be recognized and associated risks to be identified and evaluated. Our risk strategy
dictates that business risks should be entered into consciously and responsibly and managed proactively by all
employees. Risks threatening our ability to continue as a going concern are to be avoided. The Group bases our
risk management approach on the “Governance, Risk and Compliance (GRC) Policy” (the “GRC Policy”)
applicable for all consolidated companies of the Group. In this policy, we define basic principles for corporate
governance and risk management and also describe the universally applicable risk policy principles in the Group
as a framework for meeting the requirements of proper, consistent and proactive risk management. The principles
serve as guidelines for professional and responsible risk management. The aims of risk management at the Group
are to increase risk awareness and establish a value-based risk culture at all corporate levels. Risks and
opportunities in the Group are therefore analyzed transparently and are systematically incorporated into business
decisions.

In the GRC Policy, the risk management system methodology is embedded in a “three lines of defense” model.
The first line of defense consists of functions that own and manage risks via management controls and internal
controls. The second line of defense consists of functions such as Controlling, Accounting and Risk, Compliance
and Legal, which oversee risks and help proactively manage them. Additionally, we have a department for our
Internal Control System (“ICS”) responsible for setting ICS strategy and ICS processes at our subsidiaries. The
goal of the ICS is to reduce operational risks, to ensure the reliability of financial reporting and to comply with
laws, policies and internal guidelines. Depending on a company’s size, a control testing or a control selfassessment is annually performed to ensure that controls are implemented and designed to mitigate the
underlying risks. Identified control deficiencies are assessed with regards to their impact and action plans
defined. The third line of defense consists of Corporate Function Internal Audit, which independently reviews the
appropriateness and efficiency of the process and systems implemented by the first two lines of defense. The
“three lines of defense” model is also supplemented by the work of our external financial statement auditors.

The design of various risk management instruments ensures that the sub-processes are integrated in a continuous
risk management loop and all risk managers are involved appropriately in the risk management process. Methods
and tools to identify, assess, control and report risks are implemented throughout the Group and are continually
improved. Our main focus in using risk management instruments is to assess possible deviations in the key
performance indicators such as adjusted EBIT and cash flow.

Standard reporting of estimated opportunities and risks occurs at monthly intervals and once yearly for budget
purposes. The opportunities and risks not included in the monthly updated estimations or in the budget are part of
standard business unit reporting.

161


-----

To record relevant event risks in a structured way in specific areas of responsibility, all Group companies
worldwide use a standardized IT risk management application to prepare risk maps biannually. The assessment
period used for the risk map goes beyond the period covered by the forecast and provides multiple-year
transparency on the local risk assessments. The regular reporting and updating of risks at local level also ensures
that risk awareness remains high throughout the Group. Risks already recognized in the form of balance sheet
provisions are also the subject of standardized analyses and risk reporting, ensuring systematic control of these
risks as well. Ad hoc risks are communicated immediately to the risk management officers and are also
documented via the established reporting channels.

Risks are also further evaluated by the Risk and Internal Control Committee on a regular basis. These
standardized risk management processes ensure that the Management Board and Supervisory Board are informed
promptly and in a structured way about our current risk situation. However, despite comprehensive risk analysis,
the occurrence of risks cannot be systematically ruled out. Risk transfer to insurers is currently handled centrally
by the insurance department of the thyssenkrupp Group and will be taken over by us on the Acquisition Closing
Date. Binding standards are in place for all Group companies to keep risk prevention at a sustainable and
appropriate level. Such standards are updated as required.

**Sustainability and Safety**

**_Sustainability_**

Sustainability is a core component of our corporate strategy. According to Neilsen’s Global Corporate
Sustainability Report, 2015, 66% of consumers are willing to spend more on a product from a sustainable
company. In our strategic sustainability management, we continuously work to identify the requirements of our
stakeholders and develop corresponding targets and measures to improve our performance. Aligned with this
approach on sustainability, at the Group, sustainability means investing in innovative mobility solutions that
tackle the challenges of urbanization while making cities and buildings smarter and the best places to live. It also
involves reducing our operational footprint, increasing our social contribution and ensuring our financial
strength.

We have a “Sustainability Committee,” consisting of members of our Management Board and heads of relevant
functions. This committee manages sustainability activities in the Group and decides on measures and on our
targets. The committee is supported by a Sustainability Council, which consists of sustainability managers of all
the business units and representatives of the relevant functions. The Sustainability Committee has set targets in
the areas of technology and innovations, environment, climate, energy, purchasing, and people. Our targets
include energy and environmental management, annual energy efficiency gains, sustainable adjusted research
and development intensity, a share of women in leadership positions, accident frequency rate and supplier
sustainability audits. Progress towards these targets is factored into variable compensation for our Management
Board and business area boards via a sustainability multiplier. For more information on our management, see
“Management.”

We aim to have our suppliers, along the entire chain, act responsibly and in line with environmental and social
standards based on principles of sustainability. To be able to work with us, suppliers must sign our “Supplier
Code of Conduct” or comply with equivalent standards. The Supplier Code of Conduct addresses possible risks
and negative impacts along the supply chain, including areas such as human rights, fair working conditions,
environmental protection, combating corruption and transparency into the origin of conflict minerals. Based on
standard risk criteria for specific countries and sectors, the business areas select certain suppliers each year in
order to carry out sustainability audits and evaluate compliance with our sustainability principles.

We seek to engage positively with the communities around our locations and to support local residents.
Accordingly, we are actively involved in various local projects, collaborations, multi-stakeholder initiatives and
associations. We promote enthusiasm for technology and innovation, education, and local engagement. To ensure
we maintain high compliance standards in all our work, we have implemented, among other things, a global
documentation and approval system for corporate citizenship activities.

**_Health and Safety_**

The health and safety of employees is of primary importance to us. We seek to reduce the number of workplace
accidents by employing exemplary practices, emphasizing concern for fellow employees, and eliminating unsafe
conditions and potentially dangerous activities. We actively identify safety weaknesses and risks to health in
order to discuss ways of making targeted improvements. We implement improvement ideas and monitors their
effect. We apply detailed regulations and precise controls, notably with respect to the protection of employees,

162


-----

suppliers, service providers, manufacturing processes, plants, research, product development, workflow and
transportation. There is an equal focus on the protection of the environment and the well-being of all who have
contact with our products.

Our goal is to reduce the frequency of workplace accidents and completely eliminate fatal accidents, which
unfortunately still occur. Fatalities increased from six in the year ended September 30, 2018 to ten in the year
ended September 30, 2019. We record and analyze each occupational incident in an effort to eliminate possible
hazard sources. Standardized and systematic procedures, as well as compliance with global regulations, help to
enhance safety. Our plants and processes are subject to continuous review and are kept up-to-date with
state-of-the-art technology. All of our facilities aim to satisfy government requirements for operators of industrial
plants and other facilities in the jurisdictions in which they operate. Because many raw materials, services,
technical goods and other supplies have to be sourced from third parties, we work together with all parties
concerned to ensure that deliveries comply with required specifications, standards and regulations.

We have implemented an integrated management system, defining global minimum standards and requirements
according to internationally recognized standards such as ISO 9001 (quality management), ISO 14001
(environmental management), ISO 50001 (energy management) and OHSAS 18001 (occupational health and
safety management) and ISO 45001 (occupational health and safety management).

**Information Technology**

Information Technology (“IT”) is an integral part of our operations, enabling process optimization, productivity
increases and digitalization. Our IT landscape covers the entire business value chain, from research and
development, engineering, manufacturing to New Installations, Services and Modernization. In addition, it
supports the functional roles of finance, human resources, quality, safety, purchasing etc. The key application
platforms include SAP (ERP), PTC Windchill, ConfigIT and VIEW (a proprietary solution for field sales and

These key applications have been designed as templates and are currently being rolled out globally based on

We are responsible for the entire infrastructure and application management of all local and global IT systems,
and regularly monitor and update these systems and processes to ensure reliability, compliance, business
continuity and performance. We are moving our application and infrastructure services to the cloud as we refresh
and consolidate to deliver efficient and secure IT operations throughout the service life cycle.

Our core IT governance is managed by global IT functional leaders with each of the business units supporting an
IT organization that is tightly aligned to globally executes the IT strategy and its corresponding templates.
Certain common services are currently provided by thyssenkrupp AG and, after the Acquisition Closing Date,

as prior to the Acquisition Closing Date. However, we will seek to migrate all provision of the IT Services to our

functions.

**REGULATION**

**Overview**

In all jurisdictions where we operate, our products and services are subject to laws, rules, regulations and
technical standards (collectively “laws”) at international, EU, national, state and municipal levels. In particular,
such laws include laws governing the design, manufacture, installation, operation and product safety of our
products and services, and are mainly outlined in applicable building laws, building codes, specific safety codes
for elevators and escalators and other product safety laws, as well as laws governing airport ground equipment
and airport buildings. These laws differ substantially from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. In addition, our business is
subject to environmental laws, product warranty and product liability laws, employee health and safety laws,
labor and employment protection laws, intellectual property laws, hazardous substances and chemicals laws,
export control laws, public procurement laws, competition and antitrust laws, tax laws, anti-money laundering
laws, sanction laws, anti-bribery laws, anti- terrorism laws, data protection laws and criminal and other laws. In
the area of environmental regulation, our operations are required to comply with laws and regulations relating to
air, water and noise pollution, greenhouse gas emissions, toxic and other chemicals and materials, waste
treatment and disposal methods, and the energy efficiency of production processes, among other things, in
various jurisdictions in which we operate. We are also subject to periodic monitoring by environmental
protection authorities in various jurisdictions.

For example, at the EU level the legal and regulatory environment in which we operate includes many EU
directives and regulations, which are either applied directly or otherwise implemented in the individual EU
member states through national legislation. By contrast, in the United States numerous federal laws apply at the
national level, while individual states and other more local jurisdictions have their own laws (e.g. building
codes). In addition, international agreements, including bilateral and multilateral agreements between countries
concerning customs duties or other regulations related to the import and export of products, apply directly or
indirectly to us.

The legal and regulatory requirements applicable to us are broad and diverse and may impose conflicting
obligations and limitations on us. The cost of compliance with legal and regulatory requirements may be
significant and we undertake significant efforts to stay up-to-date with all relevant requirements. The most
material laws and regulations applicable to our business operations, broken down by our key jurisdictions (the
EU, the United States and China, based on revenue as well as production output during the financial years
2016/2017 to 2018/2019), and by the general category of regulation, are described in further detail below.
References in this section to any legislation or regulation are deemed to refer to such legislation or regulation as
amended, supplemented or otherwise modified, and all further rules and regulations promulgated thereunder,
unless such context requires otherwise.

**Laws governing our products and services**

The laws most relevant to our products and services are mainly contained in the applicable building laws and
product safety laws. The following sets out the most relevant building, product liability and product safety laws
in the jurisdictions of our most important markets.

**_EU and Germany_**

_Product Safety Directive_

Directive 2001/95/EC of the EU Parliament and of the Council of December 3, 2001 (last amended by
Regulation (EC) No 596/2009 of the EU Parliament and of the Council of June 18, 2009) on general product
safety (the “Product Safety Directive”) applies to any product – including in the context of providing a service –
which is intended for consumers or likely, under reasonably foreseeable conditions, to be used by consumers
even if not intended for them, in the absence of specific provisions among the EU regulations governing the
safety of products concerned, or if sectorial legislation is insufficient. Under the Product Safety Directive,
producers and distributors must place on the market only products which comply with general safety
requirements. Therefore, manufacturers must provide consumers with the necessary information in order to
assess a product’s inherent threat, particularly when this is not inherently obvious, and take the necessary
measures to avoid such threats (for example, withdraw products from the market, inform consumers, recall
products which have already been supplied to consumers). Appointed national authorities must monitor the
compliance of products available on the market, ensure product safety legislation and rules are applied by
manufacturers and business chains and apply sanctions when necessary. For example, Regulation (EC) No
765/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of July 9, 2008 sets out the requirements for

164


-----

accreditation and market surveillance relating to the marketing of products, and its most prominent feature is the
“CE Marking” which can be used to attest the conformity of a product with the applicable requirements of the
relevant legislation.

In addition, the Product Safety Directive introduces an EU rapid alert system for dangerous non-food products.
Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2019/417 sets out guidelines for the management of the EU Rapid
Information System (“RAPEX”), an information system for the rapid exchange of information between the EU
member states and the EU Commission on measures and action taken in relation to products posing a serious risk
to the health and safety of consumers. In addition to RAPEX, the Commission has set up the “Product Safety
Business Alert Gateway,” enabling producers and distributors to report their dangerous products to the relevant
Member State authorities.

_Lifts Directive_

In light of the requirements for certain products and equipment, further directives have been adopted to
harmonize national legislation regarding health and safety requirements across the EU. Of particular importance
to us in this context is Directive 2014/33/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of February 26, 2014
(the “Lifts Directive”), regarding the harmonization of the laws of the Member States relating to lifts and safety
components for lifts (as defined in Annex III of the Lifts Directive). This Lifts Directive on the sale and putting
into service of lifts and safety components for lifts has two key objectives: (i) to allow lifts and their safety
components to be sold throughout the EU market; and (ii) to ensure a high level of safety for lift users and
maintenance staff. It generally applies to all lifts permanently serving buildings and constructions, intended for
the transport of persons and goods, and operating at a speed of more than 0.15 m/s. The Lifts Directive lays down
uniform rules on the sale and putting into service of lifts and safety components for lifts and defines the
responsibilities of manufacturers, importers, distributors, installers and authorized representatives in the context
of the sale of lifts and safety components for lifts. All lifts and safety components for sale in the EU must bear
the CE Marking (as described above) to demonstrate that they meet all essential safety requirements of EU
legislation. Before obtaining the CE Marking, the manufacturer must conduct a safety and conformity assessment
and establish technical documentation for its lifts and components. Lifts and safety components for lifts which
conform with harmonized standards or parts thereof, the references of which have been published in the Official
Journal of the European Union, shall be presumed to conform to the essential health and safety requirements set
out in Annex I of the Lifts Directive covered by those standards or parts thereof. “Harmonized standard,” as
defined in Article 2 No 1 lit. c of Regulation (EU) No 1025/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council
of October 25, 2012 on European standardization, means technical specifications, adopted by a recognized
standardization body, for repeated or continuous application, with which compliance is not compulsory, and
which is one of the following: (i) an “international standard” meaning a standard adopted by an international
standardization body; (ii) a “European standard” meaning a standard adopted by a European standardization
organization; (iii) a “harmonized standard” meaning a European standard adopted on the basis of a request made
by the Commission for the application of Union harmonization legislation; and (iv) a “national standard”
meaning a standard adopted by a national standardization body. Of particular importance here are the EN 81-20
and EN 81-50 safety rules for the construction and installation of lifts and EN 13015 specifying how maintenance
must be organized to keep lift safety up to the level required by the Lifts Directive.

_Machinery Directive_

The Lifts Directive does not apply to funicular railways, hoists, escalators, moving walks and low-speed
(< 0.15 m/s) home elevators. These are covered under Directive 2006/42/EC of the European Parliament and of
the Council of May 17, 2006 on machinery and amending Directive 95/16/EC (recast) (the “Machinery
Directive”). The Machinery Directive outlines both compulsory as well as voluntary standards, and only applies
to products when they are first placed on the EU market. This directive covers machinery, interchangeable
equipment, safety components, lifting accessories, chains, ropes and webbing, removable mechanical
transmission devices and partly completed machinery. This directive does not cover other types of machinery,
such as machinery used in fairgrounds, the nuclear industry, laboratories and mines or by the military or police.

_Product Liability Directive_

Council Directive 85/374/EEC of July 25, 1985, as amended by Directive 1999/34/EC of the EU Parliament and
of the Council of May 10, 1999 (the “Product Liability Directive”), applies to movables which have been
industrially produced, whether or not the movables have been subsequently incorporated into another movable or
into an immovable. It establishes the principle of strict liability in cases of damage deemed to be caused by a
defective product. Under a strict liability regime, the producer may be liable even without negligence or fault on

165


-----

its part. “Producer” means the manufacturer of a finished product, the producer of any raw material or the
manufacturer of a component part and any person who, by putting his or her name, trademark or other
distinguishing feature on the product, presents himself as its producer. Producers can be cleared of liability under
certain conditions, notably, if they prove that they did not put the product into circulation, the defect was due to
the compliance of the product with mandatory regulations issued by public authorities or the state of scientific or
technical knowledge at the time that the product was put into circulation could not detect the defect. The Product
Liability Directive applies to damage causing death or personal injuries and damage to private property. It sets
out a time limit of three years for the recovery of damages and forbids clauses limiting or excluding the liability
of the producer. The Product Liability Directive does not restrict compensation for non-material damage under
national legislation.

Within the chain of producers, we are theoretically entitled to seek compensation from our suppliers if the defect
giving rise to product liability stems from a component supplied by such supplier. However, clear responsibility
can be difficult to prove and, in order to maintain good relations to our suppliers, we are often required to refrain
from holding our suppliers accountable.

_Electromagnetic Compatibility Directive_

Directive 2014/30/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of February 26, 2014 on electromagnetic
compatibility (the “Electromagnetic Compatibility Directive”) aims to ensure that electrical and electronic
equipment complies with an adequate level of electromagnetic compatibility. It outlines uniform rules to ensure
protection against electromagnetic disturbance in order to guarantee the free movement of electrical and
electronic equipment within the EU’s internal market. The equipment covered by the Electromagnetic
Compatibility Directive includes both apparatus and fixed installations. It does not apply to: radio and
telecommunications terminal equipment; aircraft or equipment intended to be installed in aircraft; custom-built
evaluation kits for professional use at research and development facilities; and radio equipment used by radio
amateurs, unless the equipment is made available on the market for the general public.

_Regulation on Market Surveillance and Product Compliance_

On June 20, 2019, Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 on market surveillance and compliance of products (Market
Surveillance Regulation) was adopted by the European legislators. The Market Surveillance Regulation will
apply from 16 July 2021, and will lead to a tightening of conformity checks and additional powers for national
market surveillance authorities. The EU’s stated objective is to reinforce trust in the EU single market by
ensuring compliance with, and enforcement of product legislation in cooperation with customs authorities. The
powers of national market surveillance authorities will include at least (ii) the power to require economic
operators to provide relevant document (including access to embedded software, information on their supply
chain), (ii) the power to enter any premises, and (iii) the power to take samples. The measures implemented by
the Market Surveillance Regulation will particularly have impact on online sales; however, also the elevator
industry is also affected because elevators are also subject to harmonized EU legislation (i.e., Lifts Directive) and
are therefore covered by the Market Surveillance Regulation.

_Public Procurement Directive_

Since we regularly sell our products to public entities in the course of large infrastructure projects, we are also
subject to public procurement laws. Directive 2014/24/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of
February 26, 2014 on public procurement and repealing Directive 2004/18/EC (the “Public Procurement
Directive”) regulates how public contracts above certain threshold amounts can be awarded by or on behalf of
EU member states’ authorities. Within the meaning of the Public Procurement Directive, procurement is the
acquisition by means of a public contract of works, supplies or services by one or more contracting authorities
from economic operators chosen by those contracting authorities, whether or not the works, supplies or services
are intended for a public purpose. Procurement processes which are subject to the Public Procurement Directive
must comply with the requirements for a specific set of procedures as set out in the Public Procurement
Directive.

_German implementation measures and other material legislation_

In Germany, the Product Safety Directive has been implemented through the Product Safety Act
(Produktsicherheitsgesetz). Section 8 of the Product Safety Act provides for the possibility of issuing ordinances.
In this context, the Lifts Directive was implemented in the 12th ordinance to the Product Safety Act (12. VO zum
_Produktsicherheitsgesetz – Aufzugsverordnung, the “Elevator Ordinance”) and the Machinery Directive in the_

166


-----

ninth ordinance to the Product Safety Act (9. VO zum Produktsicherheitsgesetz, Maschinenverordnung, the
“Machine Ordinance”). Both are essentially aligned to the provisions of the corresponding directives. Section 5
para. 5 of the Elevator Ordinance obliges the installer of an elevator to take “corrective measures”
(Korrekturmaßnahmen), which can be interpreted as more than the warnings which may be sufficient in typical
product safety cases, therefore requiring the installer to provide a fully functional product even after the
expiration of any relevant warranty period, which could in turn result in significant costs for us.

In addition to European standards, technical standards such as DIN 15306 on passenger lifts in residential
buildings and DIN 15309 on passenger lifts in non-residential buildings continue to exist in Germany.

The Product Liability Directive has been implemented through the Product Liability Act
(Produkthaftungsgesetz). Furthermore, the German Civil Code (Bürgerliches _Gesetzbuch) obliges the_
manufacturer of a product to observe and put in place adequate safety precautions. Thereby, defective products
shall be prevented from causing personal injury or damage. In particular, the manufacturer must avoid faults
relating to the design and/or manufacture of the product. Furthermore, the manufacturer must instruct the users
on the intended use of the product. For products that are already on the market, the manufacturer must monitor
how its products are used and must inform the users about potential harmful uses which were not originally
anticipated. According to the legal definition, “manufacturer” is anyone who produces a product, including
suppliers and sub-suppliers. If the manufacturer fails to comply with its obligations, it shall be liable for the
damage incurred. While potential claimants must prove that a product is defective and that this defect caused
personal injury or damage, the manufacturer is obliged to evidentially prove that it has fulfilled its duties relating
to design, manufacture and monitoring of the products as well as regarding adequately informing the users.

The Electromagnetic Compatibility Directive is implemented in Germany via the law on electromagnetic
compatibility of equipment (Gesetz über die elektromagnetische Verträglichkeit von Betriebsmitteln).

In addition, there are regulations on lifts within the German building law (Bauordnungsrecht), specifically with
respect to fire protection regulations.

The Public Procurement Directive is implemented in Germany through several legal acts, in particular, Part IV of
the Act against Restraints of Competition (Gesetz gegen Wettbewerbesbeschränkungen), the Public Procurement
Ordinance (Vergabeverordnung), and the Regulations on Contract Awards for Public Works (Vergabe- und
_Vertragsordnung für Bauleistungen – Teil A, “VOB/A”) which also covers public procurement processes that are_
outside the scope of the Public Procurement Directive.

**_United States_**

_International building Code and regional adaptations_

Building laws in the United States are generally governed by the International Building Code (“IBC”), but most
individual states have made bespoke adoptions of the IBC and have implemented different variations, leading to
a highly fragmented building law landscape. Within the IBC and its local adaptations, there are also varying
provisions governing how our products may be used as part of a building.

_Safety standards from ASME and ANSI_

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers (“ASME”) and the American National Standards Institute
(“ANSI”) are both involved in setting the standards pertaining to how our products may be built and integrated
into an existing structure. The ASME 17.1 elevator and escalator safety code covers the design, construction,
operation, inspection, testing, maintenance, alteration, and repair of hoisting and lowering mechanisms (equipped
with a car or platform) when that hoisting mechanism is located in or adjacent to a structure. This includes
(among others): elevators, power-driven stairways and moving walks, escalators and moving walks, hoisting and
lowering mechanisms, dumbwaiters and cargo lifts. It does not, however, cover personnel hoists, which are
instead covered by ANSI A10.4. Similarly, material hoists are covered by ANSI A10.5 and stairway chairlifts are
covered by ASME A18.1.

_Maintenance standards from ASME and OSHA_

In California, the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (“OSHA”) and ASME work in conjunction to
upkeep maintenance requirements for elevators. In general, state governments monitor elevator certification and
inspections. Periodic maintenance is required on elevators, and certain maintenance, as well as records must be
maintained in order to be certified by the relevant state and local government authorities. ASME, as well as

167


-----

OSHA, requires that all operating components which can be hazardous to individuals must be inspected and
repaired immediately if problems are found. The safety equipment includes door operation, floor-to-floor travel,
acceleration and deceleration of the elevator and emergency and safety equipment.

_Product liability in the United States_

Under US product liability law, manufacturers, distributors, suppliers, retailers, and other parties who make
products available to the public can be held responsible for the injuries deemed to be caused by those products. If
a consumer, user or bystander is injured by a product that is defective or unreasonably dangerous, the
manufacturer or anyone else in the supply chain can be held responsible for that injury. Product liability lawsuits
brought by individual consumers or groups of consumers can become costly and lengthy. No uniform product
liability statute or common law exists in the United States. Each state defines product liability law under its own
standards. However, product liability claims are generally brought under the scope of strict product, tort
(negligence or fraud) and warranty claims. The diversity of product liability law in the United States and the
general availability of punitive damages, class actions and contingency fees create fertile ground for product
liability claims in the United States.

**_China_**

_Safety rules for the construction and installation of electric lifts (GB 7588-2003+XG1-2015)_

The safety rules for the construction and installation of electric lifts (GB 7588-2003+XG1-2015) were
implemented on July 1, 2016 and describe both compulsory and voluntary standards. These standards stipulate
minimum safety requirements which must be followed when manufacturing and installing passenger elevators,
sickbed elevators (for example, in hospitals) and cargo elevators in order to prevent accidents that may injure
passengers or damage cargo when elevators are operating.

_Construction law of the People’s Republic of China_

The Construction Law of the People’s Republic of China must be followed when engaging in construction
activities and in the exercise of supervision and administration over construction activities within the territory of
the People’s Republic of China. The construction activities referred to in this law mean construction of all types
of housing and the construction of their ancillary facilities, as well as the corresponding installation work of
wiring, piping and equipment. Therefore, the provisions of this law on construction works also apply to work
involving elevators, escalators or our other products.

_Law of the People’s Republic of China on bid invitation and bidding_

Certain construction projects to be undertaken within the territory of the People’s Republic of China, including
the surveying, design, construction and supervision of such projects, as well as the purchase of key equipment
and materials for such projects, are subject to bid invitation, which is regulated by the Law of the People’s
Republic of China on Bid Invitation and Bidding. Construction projects that require a formal bid invitation are:
(i) large infrastructure and public utility projects that concern public interests and security; (ii) projects invested
in wholly or partly by state-owned funds or financed by the state; and (iii) projects using loans or aid funds from
international organizations or governments of other countries. Tenders for the above types of elevator projects
are also subject to this law.

_Law of the People’s Republic of China on Product quality_

Anyone who manufactures or sells any product within the territory of the People’s Republic of China shall
comply with the Law of the People’s Republic of China on Product Quality. For the purpose of this regulation,
products are defined as products processed or manufactured for sale. Although the law does not apply to
construction projects, construction materials, structural components and fittings, and equipment that are used for
construction projects are within the scope of the legislation, therefore also covering our products.

_Special equipment safety law of the People’s Republic of China_

The Special Equipment Safety Law of the People’s Republic of China applies to elevators as they fall under the
law’s definition of special equipment. The law applies to the production (including the design, manufacture,
installation, modification and maintenance), operation, use, inspection, testing of and the supervision and
administration of elevators. Elevator recalls are also governed by this law.

168


-----

_Product liability in the People’s Republic of China_

Pursuant to the Product Quality Law of the People’s Republic of China (as promulgated on February 22, 1993,
implemented on September 1, 1993 and amended in 2000 and 2009), the Law of the People’s Republic of China
on the Protection of the Rights and Interests of Consumers (as promulgated on October 31, 1993 and amended on
October 25, 2013) and the Tort Law of the People’s Republic of China (as promulgated on December 26, 2009
and implemented on July 1, 2010), a producer shall be responsible for the quality of the products it has produced.
Where any harm is caused by a defective product, the victim may claim for compensation either from the
producers or sellers. If the liability lies on the producers and the compensation has been paid by the sellers, the
sellers have the right to recover their losses from the producers. If the liability lies on the sellers and the
compensation has been paid by the producers, the producers have the right to recover their losses from the
sellers.

**_ISO standards_**

The International Organization for Standardization (“ISO”) issues standards that are adhered to internationally.
For example, elevators, escalators and moving walks are governed by ISO 14798, power- operated lifting
platforms for persons with impaired mobility are governed by ISO 9386 and passenger boarding bridges are
governed by ISO 16004.

**Employee Health and Safety**

In all jurisdictions in which we operate, we must comply with applicable laws and regulations to protect
employees against occupational injuries. Under such laws and regulations, employers typically must establish
and maintain working conditions that effectively prevent danger to employees. In particular, employers must
comply with certain medical and hygiene standards, and meet certain health and safety requirements at work,
such as carrying out risk assessments as well as adopting measures for the safety of employees. This is based on,
for example, permissible maximum levels for noise in the workplace, regulations for the use of personal
protective equipment and requirements for ambient temperature, ventilation and lighting, as well as working time
and work break regulations.

**_EU_**

_Minimum Safety and Health Requirements Directive_

According to the Directive 2009/104/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of September 16, 2009,
concerning the minimum safety and health requirements for the use of work equipment by workers at work (the
“Minimum Safety and Health Requirements Directive”), employers must take every measure to ensure the safety
of work equipment made available to workers. In selecting the work equipment, employers must pay attention to
the specific working conditions which exist in the workplace with a view towards the safety and health of
workers. Where risks cannot be fully eliminated in the operation of the work equipment, employers must take
appropriate measures to minimize them. Where EU legislation governing work equipment exists, employers must
ensure that the equipment meets its requirements or, if no such requirements exist, then the equipment must meet
the requirements outlined in Annex I of the Minimum Safety and Health Requirements Directive. Where work
equipment is likely to involve a specific risk to worker health and safety, employers must ensure that access to it
is restricted only to those tasked with using that equipment. Employers must also ensure that only specially
qualified workers carry out repair, modification, maintenance or servicing work. Employers must ensure that
workers are appropriately trained, especially with regard to specific-risk equipment, and are made aware of any
risks which the use of equipment may entail.

In Germany, the “Ordinance on Industrial Safety and Health (Betriebssicherheitsverordnung)” implements the
Minimum Safety and Health Requirements Directive and is further refined by the “Technical rules for
operational safety” (Technische Regeln für Betriebssicherheit – TRBS). The “Act on the Implementation of
Occupational Health and Safety Measures to Improve the Safety and Health Protection of Employees at Work”
(Arbeitsschutzgesetz – ArbSchG) stipulates additional requirements to ensure the safety and health of employees.

**_United States_**

_Occupational Safety and Health Act 29 U.S.C. (1970)_

The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is a US labor law governing occupational health and safety in
the United States and is administered by OSHA, which is an agency of the United States Department of Labor
that covers most private sector employers and their employees within the United States, as well as individual

169


-----

states. Its primary goal is to ensure that employers provide employees with an environment free from recognized
hazards, such as exposure to toxic chemicals, excessive noise levels, mechanical dangers, heat or cold stress, or
unsanitary conditions. OSHA creates rules which are, together with all other rules created by federal regulatory
agencies, collected into a multi-part document called the Code of Federal Regulations (“CFR”). Individual states
also have established their own occupational health and safety standards, and these are in some cases more
stringent than those promulgated by OSHA. Under the “General Duty Clause” found at Section 5(a)(1) of the
Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, employers are required to provide their employees with a place of
employment that is “free from recognized hazards that are causing or are likely to cause death or serious physical
harm.” In addition, most relevant for us are the following standards:

**_OSHA 29 CFR 1910, General Industry Standards: These standards generally apply to employers and employees_**
engaged in general industry, and they cover a broad spectrum of activities, including the production of our
products and provision of our services.

**_OSHA 29 CFR 1926, Construction Standards: These standards apply to employers and employees in the_**
construction industry. The New Installations, the Modernizations and most repair work carried out by us is
governed by these standards.

**_OSHA 29 CFR 1904, Record Keeping Standards: These standards cover the accident and training record-_**
keeping requirements.

_Robotic Industries Association Safety Standards_

The Robotic Industries Association (“RIA”) issues the ANSI/RIA R15.06-2012 safety standard for robotic
equipment. This standard, which is an adoption of ISO 10218:2011 Parts 1 and 2, provides the industry with
guidance on the proper use of safety features embedded within robots, as well as how to safely integrate robots
into factories and work areas. OSHA relies on industry standards such as ANSI/RIA R15.06-2012, when
determining compliance with applicable safety regulations.

_National Fire Protection Association Standards_

OSHA’s electrical standards are based on the National Fire Protection Association (“NFPA”) standards NFPA
70, the National Electrical Code, any regionally adopted standards for the safe installation of electrical wiring
and equipment, and NFPA 70E, the Standard for Electrical Safety in the Workplace, which governs the
manufacturing of our products.

_Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (1976)_

The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (“RCRA”) gives the United States Environmental Protection
Agency, as well as individual states, the authority to control hazardous waste from cradle-to-grave. This includes
the generation, handling, transportation, treatment, storage, and disposal of hazardous waste. RCRA also sets
forth a framework for the management of non-hazardous solid wastes. RCRA also includes rules on how the
Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals (GHS) is applied in the United States,
which in turn also affects our products and services.

**_ISO 45001_**

ISO 45001 is the first international standard on occupational health and safety. It has been developed to improve
employee safety, reduce workplace risks and create better, safer working conditions. ISO 45001 was introduced
in 2018 and has a significant impact on how we organize our health and safety systems.

**Antitrust Law**

We must observe various antitrust laws and regulations applicable in the jurisdictions in which it operates. Of
particular relevance are: provisions on merger control, the prohibition of anti-competitive agreements, collusive
behavior, the prohibition of abuse of a dominant position and the receipt of advantages in violation of state aid
rules within the market. In general, such competition and antitrust laws and regulations are designed to preserve
free and open competition in the marketplace in an effort to enhance competitiveness and economic efficiency.
National and supranational competition and antitrust authorities may initiate investigations and proceedings for
alleged infringements of competition or antitrust laws, which may result in significant fines or other forms of
liability or impose certain limitations or conditions regarding acquisitions and certain business practices.

We have been involved in antitrust proceedings with European authorities and is still subject to certain related
third-party claims. For more information, see “Business—Legal Proceedings—Antitrust proceedings and private
_follow-on litigation.”_

170


-----

Within the EU, compliance with applicable European and national competition laws is monitored by the
European Commission and in some cases the national competition authorities (for instance, in Germany, the
Federal Cartel Office (Bundeskartellamt)). The EU’s antitrust rules are set out in articles 101 and 102 of the
Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (“TFEU”). Article 101(1) of the TFEU prohibits anticompetitive agreements to the extent they are not otherwise exempted by article 101(3) of the TFEU.

The assessment of whether the exemption criteria of article 101(3) of the TFEU are met must be made by us in a
“self-assessment.” This self-assessment of compliance of our agreements with dealers, suppliers or competitors
generally carries the risk that the European Commission, national competition authorities or national courts could
arrive at a different conclusion as to whether there is an infringement of the relevant competition law at issue.

**_Cross-border import and export of our Products_**

Most countries in which we conduct business have import and export control regulations. We manufacture and
handle products which are subject to export control and sanction regulations, as well as trade policy measures
such as tariffs. We are required to comply with sanctions restrictions imposed by multiple authorities, such as the
United Nations, the EU and the United States, in particular with respect to its commercial interactions with
parties in sanctioned countries. In addition, the EU’s, the United States’ and other applicable sanctions and
embargo laws and regulations vary in their application: they do not all apply to the same covered persons or
prescribe the same activities, and such sanctions and embargo laws and regulations may be amended or
strengthened over time.

**_Requirements in Member States of the EU_**

Within the EU’s internal market, the principle of free movement of goods applies. When importing and exporting
goods to non-EU countries, we have to comply with national and European foreign trade and customs
regulations, including applicable trade sanctions law. At the EU level, the relevant regulatory framework
concerning customs is the Union Customs Code (Regulation (EU) No 952/2013). For foreign trade regulations, a
number of EU level regulations and national laws are applicable, as further described further below.

We must also comply with EU compliance screening lists of specific persons and entities per Council
Regulations, including (EC) No 881/2002 and 2580/2001, and with anti-money laundering regulations, including
the Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive (EU) 2018/843. The EU has also imposed sanctions on certain
persons, entities and dual-use exports to Russia via Regulation (EU) No 692/2014 and Regulation (EU) No
833/2014. To ensure compliance with these laws and regulations, each Group company screens its transactions
and potential business partners and the export control team at thyssenkrupp AG conducts an additional postscreening of all debtors/creditors to detect any changes on sanctions lists.

**_Requirements under United States laws and regulations_**

In the United States, the US Customs and Border Protection agency, among others, regulates the import of goods
to and the export of goods from the United States. Imports are governed by a number of laws, including the
Tariff Act of 1930. The US Departments of Justice, Commerce, State and Treasury and other federal agencies
and authorities have a broad range of civil and criminal penalties they may seek to impose against corporations
and individuals for violations of economic sanctions laws, export controls laws, anti-money laundering laws and
other federal statutes and regulations, including those established by the US Department of Treasury’s Office of
Foreign Assets Control (“OFAC”). Various government agencies may seek to impose modifications to business
practices, including cessation of business activities in sanctioned countries or with sanctioned persons or entities
as well as modifications to compliance programs, which may increase compliance costs, and may subject us to
fines, penalties and other sanctions. A violation of these laws or regulations could adversely impact our business,
results of operations and financial condition.

Our current business in Russia and our former business in Iran, which still involves servicing and warranty
claims, are subject to the regulatory framework of US secondary sanctions. The United States have imposed
primary sanctions on certain Russian individuals, companies and sectors of the Russian economy. As a result of
the Countering America’s Adversaries Through Sanctions Act of 2017, non-US persons must comply with
certain secondary sanctions against Russia, even if such activities have no connection to the US. Among other
things, non-US persons may face penalties for knowingly facilitating significant transactions or significant
financial transactions for or on behalf of a party subject to the United States’ sanctions against Russia.

Moreover, on November 5, 2018, the US announced it would withdraw from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of
Action which had previously eased US sanctions on Iran under the authority of, among others, the Iran Sanctions

171


-----

Act, the Comprehensive Iran Sanctions, Accountability and Divestment Act of 2010, the National Defense
Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012, the Iran Threat Reduction and Syria Human Rights Act of 2012, the Iran
Freedom and Counter-Proliferation Act of 2012, and various Executive Orders. In broad terms, the US has
reimposed US extraterritorial sanctions measures against Iran in connection with activity related to Iran’s energy,
petrochemical, automotive, shipping, shipbuilding, port operating, and financial sectors. Persons engaged in such
activities involving Iran will face exposure to secondary sanctions or enforcement actions under US law.
Additionally, the US government has included certain Iranian persons and entities on the Specially Designated
Nationals And Blocked Persons List (“SDN List”) and other sanctions lists as administered by OFAC.

We have some business in Sudan, which is not prohibited under current US (or EU) sanctions. We have however
ceased any new business and are in the process of winding down any existing business in Sudan.

**Data Protection Laws**

Due to the increasingly digital nature of our offerings and its plan to further develop connectivity and
digitalization for its customers, regulations governing the protection of our various stakeholders’ personal data
could have a significant impact on our business.

**_EU and Germany_**

When processing personal data in the European Economic Area, we are subject to the General Data Protection
Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (“GDPR”) and the respective implementation legislation in the national laws of the
Member States, which is in Germany the Federal Data Protection Act (Bundesdatenschutzgesetz, “BDSG”). Both
the GDPR and BDSG have been applicable since May 25, 2018. The GDPR has significantly changed the legal
framework for data protection in the EU and triggered additional compliance efforts and costs for German
companies in general. The GDPR introduced substantial sanctions for non-compliance. A violation of obligations
under the GDPR may constitute an administrative offense, which can result in fines or investigative measures
imposed by the competent data protection authority, as well as civil liabilities or even criminal sanctions. We
have incurred and expects to continue to incur costs to implement various measures throughout its operations
(including appropriate training of employees, fulfillment of additional documentation duties, adjustments of
processes and monitoring by our data protection and compliance teams) as a result of the GDPR and the national
data protection laws. Furthermore, the GDPR generally requires us to inform the competent supervisory authority
of any breaches of personal data stored or processed by us within 72 hours of becoming aware of such breach.
Where the relevant breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of the affected data subjects,
we are also required to inform these data subjects of such breach without undue delay.

**_United States_**

We are subject to numerous Federal and State privacy laws in the US. These refer to general prohibitions of
unfair or deceiving practices, which includes the prohibition to handle personal data in an unexpected manner, as
well as to data protection in specific sectors. There are specific rules on cybersecurity and data breaches
notification requirements. Each state has developed their own data breach notification requirements. Data privacy
and protection laws are evolving in the U.S. and can vary significantly.

**_China_**

Regarding our activities in China, we are bound by Chinese data privacy law, which consists of numerous laws
and industry-specific regulations, complemented by standards. In addition, data privacy considerations can be
inferred from general principles of civil law including tort law. The legal landscape is complex and subject to
frequent changes. Therefore, uncertainty remains as to the specific application of Chinese data privacy law as
well as to the practical steps needed in order to achieve compliance. In December 2019, China’s authorities
announced new legislation on protection of personal data.

**_Supervisory Board committees_**

The Supervisory Board has the power to form committees in accordance with the law and decide the
composition, powers and procedures of such committees. Where permitted under law, decision-making powers
of the Supervisory Board may be conferred upon such committees. As of the date of this offering memorandum,
the Supervisory Board has formed the Executive Committee, the Mediation Committee and the Personnel
Committee, brief descriptions of which are set forth below.

_Executive committee_

The Executive Committee (Präsidium) advises and supports the chairperson and the vice chairperson of the
Supervisory Board and prepares the Supervisory Board meetings. The Executive Committee also has, among
others, the following responsibilities: (i) dealing with questions calling for possible immediate action by the
Management Board or potentially relating to confidential inside information; (ii) consulting on questions of
corporate governance and issuing recommendations in cases which require the Supervisory Board’s approval;
(iii) preparation of the Supervisory Board’s efficiency review; and (iv) decision-making in certain cases
transferred to the Executive Committee by the full Supervisory Board.

The Executive Committee consists of the chairperson of the Supervisory Board, the vice chairperson of the
Supervisory Board and two further members of the Supervisory Board – one elected at the proposal of the
employee representatives and one elected at the proposal of the shareholder’s representatives. The current
members of the Executive Committee who are expected to remain after consummation of the Acquisition are
Knut Kiesler (Vice-Chairman) and Susanne Herberger.

_Mediation Committee_

The Mediation Committee (Vermittlungsausschuss) pursuant to section 27 para. 3 German Co- Determination
Act (Mitbestimmungsgesetz) has the task of making proposals for the appointment and dismissal of members of
the Management Board in cases where section 31 paras. 3 and 5 German Co-Determination Act
(Mitbestimmungsgesetz) apply.

The Mediation Committee consists of the chairperson of the Supervisory Board, the vice chairperson of the
Supervisory Board and two further members of the Supervisory Board – one elected at the proposal of the
employee representatives and one elected at the proposal of the shareholder’s representatives. The current
members of the Mediation Committee who are expected to remain after consummation of the Acquisition are
Knut Giesler (Vice-Chairman) and Susanne Herberger.

_Personnel Committee_

The Personnel Committee (Personalausschuss) prepares the personnel decisions of the Supervisory Board and in
particular make proposals for the appointment and termination of the appointment of members of the
Management Board. It also makes, among other things, a proposal for the target share of women on the
Management Board and a deadline for achieving this target and submits to the Supervisory Board proposals for
resolution on the compensation of the individual member of the Management Board.

The Personnel Committee consists of the chairperson of the Supervisory Board, the vice chairperson of the
Supervisory Board and two further members of the Supervisory Board – one elected at the proposal of the
employee representatives and one elected at the proposal of the shareholder’s representatives. The current
members of the Personnel Committee who are expected to remain after consummation of the Acquisition are
Knut Giesler and Susanne Herberger.

**_Remuneration and other benefits of the members of the Management Board and the Supervisory Board_**

The Management Board of the Target received total remuneration of €6.0 million, €8.1 million and €3.7 million
in the years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively. Remuneration consisted of short-term
benefits, post-employment benefits, termination benefits and share-based compensation.

The Supervisory Board received total remuneration of €0.1 million in each of the years ended September 30,
2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively. Remuneration consisted of short-term benefits (inclusive of meeting
attendance fees).
