F-7


-----

**Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements**

**01 Basis of preparation**

**•** **General information**

On May 21, 2019, the Supervisory Board of thyssenkrupp Aktiengesellschaft, Duisburg and Essen, Germany
(hereafter “thyssenkrupp AG”) unanimously approved the Executive Board’s plans for a fundamental strategic
realignment of the group. As part of this new strategy, the Executive Board proposed an initial public offering
(hereafter “IPO”) of thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Business (hereafter “Elevator Technology Business”) to
the Supervisory Board. In addition to the IPO thyssenkrupp AG was also contemplating a full trade sale of the
Elevator Technology Business to potential interested parties.

On February 27, 2020, the Executive Board’s decision to sell its entire Elevator Technology Business to a
consortium led by Advent, Cinven and RAG foundation (hereafter “the transaction”) was approved by the
Supervisory Board of thyssenkrupp AG. The closing of this transaction is expected by the end of the current
fiscal year. thyssenkrupp AG will reinvest part of the purchase price in a stake in the Elevator Technology
Business.

The thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Group (hereafter “thyssenkrupp ET Group”)—which designs and
delivers passenger transportation solutions—has been separated from thyssenkrupp AG and its subsidiaries
(hereafter “thyssenkrupp Group”). In an initial preparatory step, the thyssenkrupp ET Group operating activities
that had previously not been operating as separate companies were transferred to separate legal entities. In a
second step, all companies making up the thyssenkrupp ET Group were transferred to wholly-owned subsidiaries
of thyssenkrupp AG, i.e. thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V., Roermond, Netherlands or to
thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations AG, Düsseldorf, Germany, which was previously named
thyssenkrupp Elevator AG until December 10, 2019. On June 2, 2020 thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and
Operations AG changed its legal form to thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovations and Operations GmbH (hereafter
“thyssenkrupp Elevator laO[1]”). In further steps, thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. and its
subsidiaries and the thyssenkrupp Elevator laO and its subsidiaries were then transferred at December 6, 2019
and at December 31, 2019, respectively, to a new company named thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH, Essen,
Germany (formerly thyssenkrupp Industrials GmbH, Essen, Germany, that was founded in June 2018 under the
name thyssenkrupp Carbon2Chem Management GmbH, Duisburg, Germany). As of December 31, 2019, both
companies are therefore 100%-subsidiaries of thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH, which is the parent
company of the thyssenkrupp ET Group. On January 16, 2020, name and legal form of the thyssenkrupp Elevator
Holding GmbH was changed to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG (hereafter “the Company[2]”).

The transferred Elevator Technology Business operations are comprised of legal entities as well as assets and
liabilities that have been transferred to the Company with effect from December 31, 2019, as part of the legal
reorganization that in accordance with IFRS 10.B97 “Consolidated Financial Statements” are deemed linked
transactions. This reorganization is a transaction under common control, since all transferred legal entities as well
as assets and liabilities are ultimately controlled by thyssenkrupp AG.

Up to and until December 31, 2019, the date of the completion of the legal reorganization, there was no
obligation for the Company to prepare consolidated financial statements for the thyssenkrupp ET Group because
the Elevator Technology Business was not a group of entities under control of a parent as defined by IFRS 10
“Consolidated Financial Statements” and has historically not prepared consolidated financial statements for
internal or external reporting purpose. Combined financial statements in accordance with International Financial
Reporting Standards (IFRS) as applicable in the European Union were prepared for the Elevator Technology
Business as of and for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017. The combined annual financial
statements are hereinafter referred to as the “Combined Financial Statements”. The Combined Financial
Statements of the Elevator Technology Business reflect the Elevator Technology Business as historically
included in the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG under application of the predecessor
accounting (book value) approach in accordance with established practice in accounting for business
combinations under common control under IFRS. These Combined Financial Statements are expected to be
published for the purpose of a bond offering in June 2020.

**•** **First-time adoption of International Financial Reporting Standards**

Since December 31, 2019, the date of the completion of the legal reorganization, the Elevator Technology
Business is a group of entities under the control of the Company as defined by IFRS 10 “Consolidated Financial
Statements.” Therefore, first-time consolidated financial statements as of September 30, 2020 have to be
prepared in accordance with the rules of IFRS 1 “First-Time adoption of International Financial Reporting
Standards”. The interim financial statements as of and for the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020 (the
**“Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements”) for the group of entities under the control of the**
Company are also prepared in accordance with IFRS 1.

The Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements presented here are based on uniform IFRS accounting
policies with an opening statement of financial position as of October 1, 2018. As consolidated financial
statements were previously not prepared for the thyssenkrupp ET Group, the reconciliations envisioned in
principle pursuant to IFRS 1 are not required.

For purposes of the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements the above noted transactions of the
legal reorganization have been accounted for as common control transactions by applying predecessor accounting
(book value) in accordance with recognized industry practice for business combinations under common control[3].
The Company’s interim consolidated financial statement include the results of the thyssenkrupp ET Group as of
and for the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020 as well as the comparatives results as if the transfer of the
business activities of the Elevator Technology Business into the Company had already taken place for all periods
presented. The financials of the Elevator Technology Business activities prior to the reorganization as of
December 31, 2019 are presented on a combined basis under the application of the same principles as applied in
the Combined Financial Statements.

IFRS accounting standards adopted by thyssenkrupp AG in the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020 for the first
time were incorporated in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements of the Company in
accordance with the respective date of first-time adoption of thyssenkrupp AG to reflect the book values as
historically included in the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG under application of the
predecessor accounting (book value) approach. Since thyssenkrupp AG applies IFRS 16 “Leases” using the
modified retrospective approach starting October 1, 2019 in its consolidated financial statements, IFRS 16 will
be applied at the same date using the same approach in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements
in accordance with the rules described above.

**•** **Information on the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements**

The Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements comprise interim consolidated statements of financial
position, interim consolidated statements of profit or loss, interim consolidated statements of comprehensive
income, interim consolidated statements of cash flows, interim consolidated statements of changes in equity and
selected notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the 1st half year ended
March 31, 2020 including the corresponding comparative information as of and for the 1st half year ended
March 31, 2019, and in addition for the comparative information as of September 30, 2019 and October1, 2018
for the interim consolidated statements of financial position.

The interim consolidated statement of profit or loss has been prepared using the cost-of-sales method. Assets and
liabilities are classified by maturity. They are classified as current if they mature within one year or within the
normal business cycle of the companies and operations included in the thyssenkrupp ET Group or are held for
sale. Inventories and trade accounts receivable and payable are generally presented as current. Deferred tax assets
and liabilities as well as pension provisions are generally presented as noncurrent.

The interim consolidated statement of changes in equity presents changes in capital stock, additional paid-in
capital, retained earnings as well as changes in other comprehensive income attributable to shareholders of
thyssenkrupp Elevator AG and the changes in equity to non-controlling interest in the respective reporting
period. Since the thyssenkrupp ET Group has a complex financial history and not constituted a group with a
parent entity for the comparative periods presented, no share capital is presented in the statements of changes in
equity for the comparative periods. The interim consolidated statements of cash flows is prepared using the
indirect method.

**Compliance with IFRS**

The following Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements of the Company were prepared in
accordance with IFRS as well as the related interpretations of the IFRS Interpretation Committee (“IFRIC”) as
they are to be applied in the EU at the end of the last reporting period presented. They also satisfy the
requirements for first-time consolidated financial statements in accordance with the rules of IFRS 1 and have
been prepared in a condensed form according to IAS 34 “Interim Financial Reporting” as endorsed by the EU.

In the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements of the Company, the predecessor accounting
approach has been applied in accordance with recognized industry practice for business combinations under
common control. The Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements of the Company reflect the Elevator
Technology companies and the operating activities assigned to the Elevator Technology Business as historically
included in the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG. In general, the Company applied the
same accounting policies and measurement principles in preparing the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial
Statements as were used in preparing the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG (using the
“extraction method”). This approach was adjusted with respect to transactions with remaining thyssenkrupp
Group companies and to ensure IFRS compliance. Transactions between the thyssenkrupp ET Group and the
remaining thyssenkrupp Group were recognized in accordance with IFRS and classified as related party
transactions as defined in IAS 24 “Related Party Disclosures”.

Reference is made where appropriate to the Combined Financial Statements in particular to the combination,
recognition and measurement principles.

For further information concerning the basis of preparation see also the Combined Financial Statements.

**Scope of consolidation**

In the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements, the direct and indirect subsidiaries of the Company
were fully consolidated in accordance with the principles of IFRS 10. In addition, joint ventures were accounted
for in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements using the equity method in accordance with
IAS 28 “Investments in Associates and Joint Ventures”.

For a full list of the companies and Elevator Technology Business operating activities included in the scope of
combination see the Combined Financial Statements. There have been no material changes in the scope of
consolidation in the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020.

**Treatment of costs for central services**

Until December 31, 2019, the thyssenkrupp ET Group has obtained controlling, accounting, human resources, IT
and infrastructure services from thyssenkrupp Group service companies, such as thyssenkrupp Regional Services
Germany GmbH, Essen, Germany.

**Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued)**

In addition, holding companies such as thyssenkrupp AG have provided various central services including
governance to the thyssenkrupp ET Group. These services were historically reported in the thyssenkrupp Group
and either were transferred to the thyssenkrupp ET Group as part of the legal reorganization or will be provided
as a service under transitional service agreements (hereafter “TSAs”) starting January 1, 2020. As of now, there
are TSAs for almost all central services (e.g. IT, HR, Legal) provided by the thyssenkrupp Group. Going
forward, it is planned to terminate these existing TSAs and to establish these central services at the thyssenkrupp
ET Group.

The respective income and costs for such services that were historically recharged to the thyssenkrupp ET Group,
have been included in the interim consolidated statement of profit or loss at their historical amounts. Where
income and costs for such services in the periods until December 31, 2019 were historically not recharged but
were essential to the operational business of the thyssenkrupp ET Group, such income and costs were either
directly attributed or, where this was not possible, allocated using appropriate allocation keys and are reflected in
the interim consolidated statements of profit or loss at their historical cost.

Furthermore, assets or liabilities relating to administrative services, service companies or the central activities of
the holding companies pertained to the thyssenkrupp ET Group were attributed in the Unaudited Interim
Consolidated Financial Statements based on the legal reorganization principle. Shared assets relating to such
holding companies that did not legally transfer to the thyssenkrupp ET Group were not included in the interim
consolidated statements of financial position of the Company. However, for such an appropriate usage charge
was reflected in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements in the reporting periods until
December 31, 2019. Shared assets relating to such holding companies that did legally transfer to the
thyssenkrupp ET Group, were included in the interim consolidated statements of financial position of the
Company. The usage by the remaining thyssenkrupp Group was accounted for by way of appropriate usage
income charges to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group in the reporting periods until December 31, 2019.
Administrative services or central activities will be continued after closing of the transaction by TSAs that have
been implemented January 01, 2020. Services as part of the TSAs might result in different cost charges compared
to the current allocation.

**thyssenkrupp brand**

In the periods up to September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business was using the thyssenkrupp brand
under an operating licensing model for which it incurred expenses recognized directly in profit or loss in other
expenses. As of September 30, 2019, as part of the proposed IPO, the Elevator Technology Business had entered
into a new license agreement with thyssenkrupp AG for the right to use the thyssenkrupp brand for certain
specified classes relevant for the Elevator Technology Business in exchange for a one-time fee and with no other
recurring expenses after September 30, 2019 (hereafter “new license agreement”). This license has been
recognized as an intangible asset with indefinite useful life in accordance with IAS 38 “Intangible Assets” as of
September 30, 2019. Historically recognized expenses for the use of the brand remain unchanged for the periods
up to September 30, 2019.

Based on the Executive Board’s decision as of February 27, 2020 to sell the entire thyssenkrupp ET Group the
above described new license agreement, entered into on September 30, 2019, was adjusted in March 2020 via an
addendum agreement, since the governance model in the new license agreement was only suitable with an IPO.
In substance, the terms and conditions of the addendum agreement lead to a limitation of the initially agreed
indefinite useful life.

The terms of the addendum agreement become effective subject to the condition precedent of all closing
conditions of the transaction being fulfilled and will result in the repayment of the initially agreed fully paid up
one-time fee in the amount of €1,080 million reduced by a fixed amount of €99 million for the use of the brand
starting October 1, 2019 until closing. In addition, a fixed amount of €74 million for the use of the brand for the
period of no longer than 18 months after closing was agreed. Both, the amount receivable and the amount
payable, are due immediately prior to closing. With the signing of the addendum agreement the intangible asset
for the right of use of the thyssenkrupp brand is classified as held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5.

**Capital structure**

The consolidated statement of changes in equity presents capital stock (of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG), additional
paid-in capital (of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG), retained earnings as well as cumulative other comprehensive
income and non-controlling interest for the interim reporting period ending March 31, 2020.

Since the thyssenkrupp ET Group has a complex financial history and did not constitute a consolidated group
with a parent entity for the reporting periods until December 31, 2019, no capital stock, additional paid-in capital
retained earnings are presented in the statement of changes in equity for the comparative period. For such periods
the equity of the thyssenkrupp ET Group consists of the invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group,
other components of equity and the invested equity attributable to non-controlling interest. Since the
thyssenkrupp ET Group had no share capital and reserves in its own right, any equity presented until
December 31, 2019 represents the parent’s net investment. Thus, the presentation of the equity for the reporting
periods until December 31, 2019 of the thyssenkrupp ET Group differs from the presentation of equity as
prescribed in IAS 1 “Presentation of Financial Statements”.

During the reporting period under consideration, the thyssenkrupp ET Group was mainly financed by the
remaining thyssenkrupp Group. The capital structure of the thyssenkrupp ET Group at the time of the closing of
the transaction will differ from the capital structure presented in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial
Statements.

**Future financing and liquidity planning**

Until closing of the transaction, thyssenkrupp ET Group is integrated into the cash pooling and cash management
systems of the thyssenkrupp Group. During the last months thyssenkrupp ET Group has implemented an
additional cash pooling and cash management system with the cash pool leader thyssenkrupp Elevator AG.

With Closing the settlement of all intercompany balances with thyssenkrupp Group is expected to result in a
slightly positive cash balance for thyssenkrupp ET Group. Additionally selected thyssenkrupp ET Group
companies, which were not integrated in the cash pooling and cash management systems of the thyssenkrupp
Group due to commercial or regulatory purposes, are expected to show positive cash balances at closing.

Against this background and under consideration of a sufficient free cash flow according to the latest planning
thyssenkrupp ET Group management expects to be able to fulfill all of its future payment obligations. In order to
additionally secure the financing of operating activities, thyssenkrupp ET Group plans to have access to a
Revolving Credit Facility in an amount of €800 million.

After closing the thyssenkrupp ET Group plans to have access to appropriate guarantee facilities, either under a
central Revolving Guarantee Facility or under additional bilateral agreements of thyssenkrupp ET Group
companies, fully satisfying the operative business requirements.

**Income taxes and deferred taxes**

Current and deferred income taxes are recognized in accordance with IAS 12 and IAS 34 in the Unaudited
Interim Consolidated Financial Statements. For the comparative period, income taxes were determined using the
separate tax return approach based on the assumption that the companies and operations of the Elevator
Technology Business constitute separate tax payers. This assumption implies that current and deferred taxes for
all companies (share deal companies) and operations (asset deal companies) within Elevator Technology
Business are calculated separately and that the recoverability of deferred tax assets is assessed on this basis.
Legal entities and business operating activities are treated for purposes of the separate tax return approach as a
tax group if such legal entities and business operations have historically been included in a tax group and as of
December 31, 2019 have operated under a new tax group or are still included within the historical tax group.

Deferred tax assets resulting from tax loss carryforwards are recognized in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated
Financial Statements to the extent that it is probable that they can be offset against positive results from the
respective thyssenkrupp ET Group companies or operations in the future. This is only applicable if the legal
entity is part of the thyssenkrupp ET Group and to the extent the legal entity has tax loss carryforwards legally
assessed.

the years in which they arose as contributions or withdrawals by the shareholders immediately settled in

**02 COVID-19**

Since January 2020, there is a progressive global spread of the COVID-19 pandemic resulting in various
actions—including lockdowns—that have been taken by governments all over the world in order to contain and
to control the virus. COVID-19 impacted the markets and facilities in multiple ways, depending on the local
exposure to the virus and the measures taken by local governments:

 - Our segments Asia Pacific (AP), Americas (AMS) and Europe/Africa (EA), which comprise our elevator
and escalator business, were affected to varying degrees. Nevertheless, the effect of the COVID-19 was felt
in all regions, leading to complete lockdowns in some regions and milder restrictions in others. In Asia
Pacific, temporary restrictions were mainly observed in China with recovery to almost normal operation in
March 2020. India was also affected by government restrictions with lockdowns of facilities. In the
Americas, some reductions observed in Brazil while production in the US remained mainly at normal levels,
with only temporary restrictions on construction sites and service operations. In Europe/Africa, most
impacted countries were Spain, France, Italy and Germany, with some site restrictions and temporary
reductions or lockdowns in productions facilities. In most countries production capacities in our core
factories have almost recovered to pre-pandemic levels.

 - The Access Solutions segment was affected in both business lines, Home Solutions and Airport Solutions.
Activities for Home Solutions have been operated at a lower level with partial temporary shut downs of

F-15


-----

**Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued)**

**02 COVID-19 (Continued)**

production facilities but are recovering constantly. The partial or complete shutdown of most airports has
led to a decrease of New Installation and Service operations due to postponements and suspensions of some
projects.

The COVID-19 pandemic is considered as a triggering event for an impairment test of goodwill per March 31,
2020. Before March 31, 2020, all groups of cash-generating units of the Elevator Technology Business showed
significant headroom. In addition, the key performance indicators of the operational planning of Elevator
Technology were tested for validity against the background of the COVID-19 pandemic and, in effect, the
recoverability of goodwill of the Elevator Technology Business was not classified as critical. The weighted
average cost of capital discount rate (WACC) for all but one cash-generating units of the Elevator Technology
Business decreased compared to September 30, 2019, mainly due to decreasing beta factors. The WACC is based
on a risk-free interest rate of 0.1% (September 30, 2019: 0.1%) and a market risk premium of 7.5%
(September 30, 2019: 6.75%). Furthermore, other intangible assets and property, plant and equipment were also
tested for impairment per March 31, 2020 which did not result in any impairment losses for the Elevator
Technology Business. Based on the uncertain progress of the COVID-19 pandemic, it cannot yet reasonably be
predicted to what extent the pandemic will affect the future financial position and results of operations of the
Elevator Technology Business. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic the accumulated ADJ EBIT of the
Elevator Technology Business is currently slightly below the budgeted expectations.

**03 Recently adopted accounting standards**

In fiscal year ending September 30, 2020 the thyssenkrupp ET Group adopted the following standard,
interpretation and amendments to already existing standards that, with the exemption of IFRS 16, do not have a
material impact on the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements.

**Adoption of IFRS 16**

In January 2016, the IASB published the new accounting standard IFRS 16 Leases. The new standard replaces
the previous classification of leases into operating and finance leases as a lessee and introduces a uniform
accounting model for the lessee. Under the previous standard (IAS 17), lease obligations for operating leases
were only to be disclosed in the notes. In accordance with IFRS 16, the rights and obligations resulting from
leases must be recognized as a right-of-use of the leased asset and a corresponding lease liability in the lessee’s
statement of financial position.

This resulted in the following recognition and measurement principles:

A contract constitutes a lease if the contract conveys the lessee

 - the right to control the use of an identified asset (the leased asset)

 - for a specific period

 - in exchange for a consideration.

Since October 1, 2019, the thyssenkrupp ET Group as a lessee recognizes in general for all leases within the
interim consolidated statement of financial position an asset for the right-of-use of the leased assets and a liability
for the lease payment commitments at present value. These are primarily rentals of property and buildings,
technical machinery and equipment as well as other equipment, factory and office equipment. The right-of-use
assets reported under property, plant and equipment are recognized at cost less accumulated depreciation and
impairment losses. Payments for non-lease components are not included in the determination of the lease
liability. The lease liabilities reported under financial liabilities reflect the present value of the outstanding lease
payments at the time the asset is made available for use. Lease payments are discounted at the interest rate
implicit in the lease if it can be readily determined. Otherwise, they are discounted at the lessee’s incremental
borrowing rate. The derivation of the interest rate is based on the assumption that an adequate amount of funds
will be raised over an adequate period of time in the amount of an asset comparable to the right-of-use asset,
taking into account the economic environment and comparable collateral.

The lease liabilities include the following lease payments:

 - Fixed payments, less lease incentives to be paid by the lessor;

F-16


-----

**Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued)**

**03 Recently adopted accounting standards (Continued)**

 - variable lease payments that are based on an index or an interest rate;

 - expected amounts to be payable by the lessee under residual value guarantees;

 - the exercise price of a purchase option, if the exercise is reasonably certain and

 - payment of penalties for the termination of the lease, if the lease term reflects the lessee exercising an option
to terminate the lease.

Right-of-use assets are measured at cost, which are comprised as follows:

 - Lease liability;

 - lease payments made at or before the commencement date less any lease incentives received;

 - initial direct costs; and

 - dismantling obligations.

Subsequent measurement of the right-of-use asset is performed at amortized cost. Right-of-use assets are
depreciated on a straight-line basis over the lease term, unless the useful life of the underlying asset is shorter. If
the lease agreement contains reasonably certain purchase options, the right of use is depreciated over the
economic life of the underlying asset.

In subsequent measurement, the lease liability is compounded, and the corresponding interest expense is
recognized in the financial result. The lease payments made reduce the carrying amount of the lease liability.

In accordance with the recognition exemptions, low-value leases of and short-term leases (less than twelve
months) are recognized in the statement of profit or loss. The thyssenkrupp ET Group has identified certain asset
classes (e.g. PCs, telephones, printers, copiers) which regularly contain leased assets of low value. Outside these
asset classes, only leased assets with a value of up to USD/€5,000 are classified as low-value leased assets.
Furthermore, the new regulations are not applied to leases of intangible assets. For contracts comprising a
non-lease component as well as a lease component, each lease component must be accounted for separately from
non-lease component as a lease. The lessee must allocate the contractually agreed-upon payment to the separate
lease components based on the relative standalone selling price of the lease component and the aggregated
standalone selling price of the non-lease components. In addition, intercompany leases will continue to be
presented in the segment report according to IFRS 8 as operating leases in accordance with IAS 17.

The term of the lease is determined based on the non-cancellable lease term. Especially real estate leases contain
extension and termination options. Such contractual conditions offer the greatest possible operational flexibility
to the thyssenkrupp ET Group. In determining the lease term, all facts and circumstances are considered that
provide an economic incentive to exercise renewal options or not to exercise termination options. Lease term
modifications from the exercise or non-exercise of such options are only considered in the lease term if they are
reasonably certain and are based on an event that is within the control of the lessee.

Use is made of the exemption option to apply IFRS 16 to all agreements that were previously identified as leases
by applying IAS 17 and IFRIC 4.

The thyssenkrupp ET Group has applied the modified retrospective approach in accordance with IFRS 16.C5(b).
In accordance with this approach the comparative prior-year figures do not have to be adjusted and the first-time
adoption effects are recognized in the retained earnings as of October 1, 2019.

The thyssenkrupp ET Group recognized new assets and liabilities for its operating leases at the date of transition
to IFRS 16. When applying the modified retrospective method, right-of-use assets were recognized at the initial
recognition date at the carrying amounts of the lease liabilities adjusted for deferred lease payments. The lease
liabilities were recognized at the present value of the lease payments outstanding at the date of first-time
application, discounted at the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate at the date of first-time application. The
thyssenkrupp ET Group made use of exemption options in the transition to IFRS 16 and treated leases with a
remaining term of up to twelve months as short-term leases, left initial direct costs unaffected in the initial
measurement of the right-of-use asset, and took current knowledge into account in determining the lease terms
for agreements with extension and/or termination options. No impairment test in accordance with IAS 36 was
carried out at the time of initial application. Instead, leases entered into immediately prior to October 1, 2019,

**04 Single asset held for sale**

Based on the Executive Board’s decision as of February 27, 2020 to sell the entire Elevator Technology Business
the new license agreement regarding the thyssenkrupp brand, entered into on September 30, 2019, was amended
in March 2020 via an addendum agreement, since the governance model in the new license agreement was only
suitable with an IPO. In substance, the terms and conditions of the addendum agreement lead to a limitation of
the initially agreed indefinite useful life.

The terms of the addendum agreement become effective subject to the condition precedent of all closing
conditions of the transaction being fulfilled and will result in the repayment of the initially agreed fully paid up
one-time fee in the amount of € 1,080 million reduced by a fixed amount of €99 million for the use of the brand
starting October 1, 2019 until closing. In addition, a fixed amount of €74 million for the use of the brand for the
period of no longer than 18 months after closing was agreed. Both, the amount receivable and the amount
payable, are due immediately prior to closing. With the signing of the addendum agreement the intangible asset
for the right of use of the thyssenkrupp brand is classified as held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5. Prior to the
aforementioned classification as held for sale an impairment loss on the thyssenkrupp brand amounting to
€99 million has been recognized.

**05 Acquisitions**

In the year ended September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business acquired the elevator business of
Nashville Machine Elevator Co., Inc. via asset deal effective May 31, 2019 and all shares of O´Keefe Elevator
Company, Inc. effective July 1, 2019. The purchase price allocation of Nashville Machine Elevator Co. has not
yet been finalized due to the pending identification of the acquired intangible assets. The purchase price
allocation of the O’Keefe Elevator Company has also not yet been finalized due to remaining clarification of
O’Keefe’s tax base. Compared to the presentation in the Combined Financial Statements for the fiscal year ended
September 30, 2019, there have only been some minor changes.

**Line item “Allocation of invested equity according to legal structure on Dec. 31, 2019”**

As of December 31, 2019, the legal reorganization was finalized and thus resulting in the necessity to present
equity based on the capital structure of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG instead of reporting invested equity. The main
effect shown in the line item “Allocation of invested equity according to legal structure on Dec. 31, 2019” is an
allocation of previously reported invested equity to capital stock, additional paid-in capital and retained earnings.
The amount of €4,522 million shown in additional paid in-capital and the amount of €500 million shown as
capital stock are mainly derived from a contribution in kind as well as a capital increase as part of the legal
reorganization. The capital increase amounts to €820 million and is shown in the additional paid-in-capital. The
shares in thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. in the amount of €4,202 million are contributed in
kind into thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding AG and are shown in capital stock in the amount of €500 million and in
additional paid-in-capital in the amount of €3,702 million.

**08 Other provisions**

The restructuring provisions included in other provisions decreased by €15 million to €67 million compared with
September 30, 2019. The additions in the amount of €14 million relate to the Europe/Africa and the Americas
business units.

In connection with the Elevator cartel, potentially injured parties have asserted claims for damages against
thyssenkrupp AG and companies of the thyssenkrupp Group in and out of court. Since September 30, 2019
further claims have been quantified in the ongoing course of the legal proceedings, which has not led to a change
in the risk assessment and recorded provisions. A majority of the proceedings have now been dealt with through
settlement, withdrawal or dismissal of the claims. Legal cases are still pending in Austria, Belgium and the
Netherlands. They are at different stages of proceedings. thyssenkrupp ET Group has recognized provisions for
the portion of the pending claims which, in its opinion, will probably result in cash outflows.

**10 Financial instruments**

The carrying amounts of trade accounts receivable, other current financial assets as well as cash and cash
equivalents equal their fair values.

Equity and debt instruments are in general measured at fair value, which is based to the extent available on
market prices as of the balance sheet date. When no quoted market prices in an active market are available,
equity and debt instruments are measured by discounting future cash flows based on current market interest rates
over the remaining term of the financial instruments.

The fair value of foreign currency forward transactions is determined on the basis of the middle spot exchange
rate applicable as of the interim balance sheet date, and taking account of forward premiums or discounts arising
for the respective remaining contract term compared to the contracted forward exchange rate. Common methods
for calculating option prices are used for foreign currency options. The fair value of an option is influenced not
only by the remaining term of an option, but also by other factors, such as current amount and volatility of the
underlying exchange or base rate.

The carrying amounts of trade accounts payable and other current liabilities equal their fair values. The fair value
of fixed rate liabilities equals the present value of expected cash flows. Discounting is based on interest rates
applicable as of the balance sheet date. The carrying amounts of floating rate liabilities equal their fair values.

(September 30, 2019: €2,773 million, October 1, 2018: €1,575 million) that was determined based on fair value
measurement attributable to Level 2.

The fair value hierarchy reflects the significance of the inputs used to determine fair values. Financial
instruments with fair value measurement based on quoted prices in active markets are disclosed in level 1. In
level 2 determination of fair values is based on observable inputs, e.g. foreign exchange rates. Level 3 comprises
financial instruments for which the fair value measurement is based on unobservable inputs.

In the reporting period there were no reclassifications between level 1, level 2 and level 3.

**Other services**

In addition to the contractual services specified above, the remaining thyssenkrupp Group provided services to
the thyssenkrupp ET Group through thyssenkrupp AG, service companies and regional holding companies. These
companies principally furnish central corporate services, such as tax and legal, IT services, corporate
communications, personnel-related services, accounting, controlling, financial services and treasury.

Until finalization of the legal reorganization such services have been reflected in form of corporate cost
allocations which amount to €16 million until December 31, 2019 (March 31, 2019: €30 million). Starting
January 1, 2020, the aforementioned services are provided as services under TSAs. As a result, no corporate cost
allocations have been recognized for periods after January 1, 2020.

For the 1st half year ended March 31, 2019, the allocation of the thyssenkrupp brand resulted in expenses of
€71 million. As of September 30, 2019 the Elevator Technology Business purchased the right to use the
thyssenkrupp brand for certain specified sectors relevant for the Elevator Technology Business for a purchase
price of €1,080 million. Based on the Executive Board’s decision to sell the entire Elevator Technology Business
the license agreement regarding the thyssenkrupp brand, entered into on September 30, 2019, was adjusted in
March 2020 via an addendum agreement. The terms of the addendum agreement become effective subject to the
condition precedent of all closing conditions of the transaction being fulfilled and will result in the repayment of
the initially agreed fully paid-up one-time fee in the amount of €1,080 million, reduced by a fixed amount of
€99 million for the use of the brand starting October 1, 2019 until closing. In addition, a fixed amount of
€74 million for the use of the brand for the period no longer than 18 months after closing was agreed.

**Financing**

During the reporting period, the thyssenkrupp ET Group was integrated into the cash pooling and cash
management systems of the thyssenkrupp Group. Financial receivables and liabilities due from/to the
thyssenkrupp Group are presented without netting in the Unaudited Consolidated Financial Statements. The
interest expenses and interest income generated in connection with the financing activities with thyssenkrupp AG
and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies in the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020 amounted to
€28 million (2019: €13 million) and €14 million (2019: €30 million), respectively.

**Leasing**

The thyssenkrupp ET Group has entered into leasing transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group. At the
end of the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020, these consisted in particular of real estate and vehicle lease
agreements with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group.

F-25


-----

**Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued)**

**11 Related Parties (Continued)**

The thyssenkrupp ET Group entered into agreements to purchase the leased multifunctional building in
Neuhausen and the test tower in Rottweil conditional on the execution of the proposed IPO. As per the share
purchase agreement (hereafter “SPA”) as of February 27, 2020, the fulfillment of the conditional IPO has lapsed,
however, the parties to the SPA agreed in principle to execute the purchase of the properties in the same or a
similar manner as intended under the proposed IPO. The amendments of the contracts have yet not been signed
and will become effective before closing of the transaction. The assumed purchase prices amounting to a total of
€74 million were paid upfront in September 2019. The purchase prices, that were formerly recognized as
financial assets in accordance with IAS 32 “Financial Instruments: Presentation” and are presented in the cash
flows from investing activities in accordance with IAS 7.16(e) “Statements of Cash Flows”, were effective
March 1, 2020 netted against the respective lease liability. According to IFRS 16.46(a) the carrying amount of
the right-of-use asset was decreased to reflect the lease modification. The gain was recognized in profit and loss.
With the proposed amendments of the contracts the legal ownership of the test tower in Rottweil as well as the
multifunctional building in Neuhausen will be transferred to the thyssenkrupp ET Group as part of the proposed
closing.

Furthermore the lease term of the leases of the thyssenkrupp ET Group headquarter located in Essen,
thyssenkrupp Allee 1, was reassessed according to IFRS 16.20 in conjunction with B41 with the signing of the
transaction on March 1, 2020 due to the sufficient certainty of a move of the headquarter location in the
beginning of next calendar year.

In total the lease modifications stated above resulted in an increase in the right-of-use assets of €11 million and a
decrease in the lease liability of €66 million. The gain resulting from the modification of the leased
multifunctional building in Neuhausen and the test tower in Rottweil recognized in profit and loss totaled to
€4 million.

**Guarantees/surety bonds**

The thyssenkrupp Group has provided €1,228 million guarantees/surety bonds in favour of the thyssenkrupp ET
Group as of March 31, 2020 (September 30, 2019: €1,287 million; October 1, 2018: €1,285 million). Thereof
€97 million corporate guarantees as of March 31, 2020 (September 30, 2019: €85 million; October 1, 2018: €101
million) and €1,131 million bank guarantees/surety bonds as of March 31, 2020 (September 30, 2019:
€1,202 million; October 1, 2018: €1,184 million).

**Transfers as part of the legal reorganization of the thyssenkrupp ET Group**

As part of the legal reorganization, several corporate restructurings were carried out. Any subsequent legal
transfers from thyssenkrupp AG to thyssenkrupp ET Group are recognized as an offset in equity that is for shares
being transferred as well as for assets or liabilities transferred, as contributions in kind.

The legal reorganization has been conducted via two legal intermediate holding entities, the thyssenkrupp
Elevator International Holding B.V., Roermond, Netherlands and thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and
Operations GmbH, Düsseldorf, Germany, which have both been transferred into the thyssenkrupp Elevator AG,
forming a linked transaction on December 31, 2019.

Whilst the transfer of the thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. into thyssenkrupp Elevator AG has
been conducted via a contribution in kind in exchange for new shares issued by thyssenkrupp Elevator AG to tk
Nederland Holding B.V., the transfer of thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations GmbH has been
conducted as an acquisition of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG with a corresponding purchase price in the amount of
€796 million. Prior to the transfer of thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. and the of thyssenkrupp
Elevator Innovation and Operations GmbH into thyssenkrupp Elevator AG both intermediate holding entities
were legally formed, respectively restructured.

**Notes to the Combined Financial Statements**

**01 Basis of preparation**

**•** **General information**

**Background**

On May 21, 2019, the Supervisory Board of thyssenkrupp Aktiengesellschaft, Duisburg and Essen, Germany
(hereafter “thyssenkrupp AG”) unanimously approved the Executive Board’s plans for a fundamental strategic
realignment of the group. As part of this new strategy, the Executive Board proposed an initial public offering
(hereafter “IPO”) of thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Business (hereafter “Elevator Technology Business”) to
the Supervisory Board. In addition to the IPO thyssenkrupp AG was also contemplating a full trade sale of the
Elevator Technology Business to potential interested parties.

On February 27, 2020, the Executive Board’s decision to sell its entire Elevator Technology Business to a
consortium led by Advent, Cinven and RAG foundation was approved by the Supervisory Board of thyssenkrupp
AG.

The Elevator Technology Business—which designs and delivers passenger transportation solutions—has been
separated from thyssenkrupp AG and its subsidiaries (hereafter “thyssenkrupp Group”). All companies making
up the Elevator Technology Business have been transferred to thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V.,
Roermond, Netherlands, or thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations AG, Düsseldorf, Germany, which
was previously named thyssenkrupp Elevator AG until December 10, 2019 (hereafter “thyssenkrupp Elevator
IaO2”[1]). In further steps, thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. and its subsidiaries and thyssenkrupp
Elevator laO and its subsidiaries were then transferred at December 6, 2019 and at December 31, 2019,
respectively, under a new company named thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH, Essen, Germany (formerly
thyssenkrupp Industrials GmbH, Essen, Germany, that was founded in June 2018 under the name thyssenkrupp
Carbon2Chem Management GmbH, Duisburg, Germany). As of December 31, 2019, both companies are
therefore 100%-subsidiaries of thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH, which is then the parent company of the
thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Group (hereafter “thyssenkrupp ET Group”). On January 16, 2020, name and
legal form of thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH was changed to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG (hereafter “the
Company”[2]).

All legal entities and the Elevator Technology Business operating activities that comprise the thyssenkrupp ET
Group have been transferred to thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. or thyssenkrupp Elevator laO,
or one of its direct or indirect subsidiaries as part of a restructuring under corporate law. Most of the German
legal entities have been transferred into thyssenkrupp laO. Most of the foreign legal entities have been transferred
into thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. All legal entities not forming part of the thyssenkrupp ET
Group have remained in the thyssenkrupp Group (hereafter “remaining thyssenkrupp Group”). Business
operating activities attributable to the Elevator Technology Business that have not been conducted in Elevator
Technology companies, have been transferred via asset deals into Elevator Technology Business legal entities.
Operating activities attributable to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group that have been conducted in Elevator
Technology companies have been transferred to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies.

Due to the significant restructuring in the context of the legal reorganization, there is no historical financial
information for the thyssenkrupp ET Group for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017 that
reflects the entire operating activities of the Elevator Technology Business. Prior to the legal reorganization the
Elevator Technology Business did not exist as a separate group from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2019,
although it was under the common control of thyssenkrupp AG over that period. Therefore, combined financial
statements were prepared for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, September 30, 2018 and September 30,
2017 (hereafter “Combined Financial Statements”). The Combined Financial Statements display a combined
presentation on book value carry-over basis of IFRS group financial information of the Elevator Technology
Business, as included in the historical thyssenkrupp AG consolidated financial statements for the respective
periods. The Elevator Technology Business is defined as the future legal structure comprised of the Company,
thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V., thyssenkrupp Elevator laO and their direct and indirect
subsidiaries but also includes all Elevator Technology Business operating activities that historically were not yet

1 Until December 10, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator IaO refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG. Starting on December 10, 2019, thyssenkrupp
Elevator IaO refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations AG.

2 Until January 16, 2020, the Company refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH. Starting on January 16, 2020, the Company refers
to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG.

**Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued)**

**01 Basis of preparation (Continued)**

part of these entities but, in the context of the legal reorganization, were transferred to the Company by
December 31, 2019. The operating activities attributed to the thyssenkrupp ET Group that were previously
conducted in the thyssenkrupp Group companies have been recorded at their historical amounts. This
combination of entities under common control is hence not displayed by applying the acquisition method in
accordance with IFRS 3, but by using the predecessor accounting method using book values as reported in the
historical thyssenkrupp AG consolidated financial statements as of September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017,
respectively. Further information on the scope and basis of preparation of the Combined Financial Statements is
presented in Note 02 and Note 03.

The Combined Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting
Standards, as endorsed by the EU (hereafter “IFRS”). The Combined Financial Statements comprise combined
statements of financial position, combined statements of profit or loss, combined statements of comprehensive
income, combined statements of cash flows, combined statements of changes in equity and notes to the
Combined Financial Statements for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017.

The Combined Financial Statements are presented in euros, with all amounts rounded to the nearest million
(million €) except when otherwise indicated; this may result in differences compared to the unrounded figures.

The Combined Financial Statements were prepared on May 29, 2020 by the Executive Board of the Company.

**Description of the Elevator Technology Business**

The employees of the Elevator Technology Business develop, manufacture, install, maintain and modernize:

 - Passenger and freight elevators;

 - Escalators and moving walks;

 - Passenger boarding bridges;

 - Stair and platform lifts.

The systems of the Elevator Technology Business transport people in many of the world’s buildings—from
major airports, train stations and shopping malls to large office towers and hotels. The Elevator Technology
Business also provides tailored service solutions.

The Elevator Technology Business has worldwide operations in a variety of legal entities as well as business
operating activities and was included in the consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG, mainly in the
reportable segment Elevator Technology.

**•** **Basis of preparation of the Combined Financial Statements**

**Compliance with IFRS**

The following Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business were prepared in accordance
with IFRS as well as the related interpretations of the IFRS Interpretation Committee (“IFRIC”) as they are to be
applied in the EU at the end of the last reporting period presented. As the IFRS do not provide guidelines for the
preparation of combined financial statements, IAS 8 “Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and
Errors” has been used for the preparation of the Combined Financial Statements. IAS 8.12 requires the
consideration of the most recent pronouncements of other standard-setting bodies, other financial reporting
requirements and recognized industry practices.

In the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business presented below, the predecessor
accounting approach has been applied in accordance with the recognized industry practices rules on business
combinations under common control. The Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business
reflect the Elevator Technology companies and the operating activities assigned to the Elevator Technology
Business as historically included in the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG. In general,
the Elevator Technology Business applied the same accounting policies and measurement principles in preparing
the Combined Financial Statements as were used in preparing the IFRS consolidated financial statements of
thyssenkrupp AG (using the “extraction method”). This approach was adjusted with respect to transactions with
the remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies and to ensure IFRS compliance. Transactions between the
Elevator Technology Business and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group were recognized in accordance with IFRS
and classified as related party transactions as defined in IAS 24 “Related Party Disclosures”.

F-42


-----

**Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued)**

**01 Basis of preparation (Continued)**

New IFRS accounting standards were applied in the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology
Business in fiscal years from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2019 in accordance with the same respective
dates of first-time adoption of thyssenkrupp AG.

Specifically, for IFRS 15 “Revenue from Contracts with Customers”, thyssenkrupp AG adopted the standard in
the fiscal year beginning on October 1, 2018, by applying the full retrospective approach to initial application.
Due to the financial statements of that fiscal year for the thyssenkrupp Group only presenting one comparative
period, the cumulative transition effects were included directly in retained earnings at the start of the comparative
period on October 1, 2017. In contrast, for the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology
Business, due to the additional comparative period from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2017 presented,
according to the full retrospective approach, IFRS 15 has been applied starting as of October 1, 2016 for the
Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business (i.e. the cumulative transition effects were
included directly in invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group at the start of the comparative period
on October 1, 2016).

The separate financial statements or reporting packages of the combined companies or operations, respectively,
were prepared as of the respective closing dates for the Combined Financial Statements. The periods for
recognizing adjusting events in the Combined Financial Statements are identical to the respective periods of the
IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG.

**Scope of combination**

Up to September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business was comprised of the Company as well as Elevator
Technology legal entities and business operating activities that were conducted in other direct and indirect
subsidiaries of thyssenkrupp AG. The legal transfer of the legal entities and the Elevator Technology Business
operating activities in the context of the reorganization under corporate law that comprise the thyssenkrupp ET
Group was not completed by September 30, 2019. As a result, financial statements of the Elevator Technology
Business as of and for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017 have been prepared on a
combined basis only.

The scope of combination for the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business for the
fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017 was determined on the principles of the legal
reorganization approach. This approach is based on the fact that the economic activities that form the new entity
were not managed as one division in the past, but the entities and operating activities included in the scope of
combination are legally bound together within a reorganization process. During the reporting periods of the
Combined Financial Statements, the assets and liabilities forming the reporting entity were under common
control of thyssenkrupp AG. The Combined Financial Statements have been prepared on the basis of the
extraction method from the historical consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG taking into account
the target structure of the reorganization.

The structure of the scope of combination of the Elevator Technology Business for these Combined Financial
Statements is comprised of the following:

 - The Company,

 - Legal entities that were fully dedicated to the Elevator Technology Business by virtue of their operations
and were part of the legal reorganization and were transferred to the Company by December 31, 2019,

 - Assets and liabilities as well as income and expenses of Elevator Technology Business operating activities
that were part of the legal reorganization and were transferred to the Company by December 31, 2019,

 - Joint ventures and other investments that were part of the legal reorganization and were transferred to the
Company by December 31, 2019.

If the above components were already legally transferred in the Elevator Technology Business during the
reported periods as of and for the years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017, these individual transfers are
already fully reflected within the equity for the respective period as of the dates of the respective individual
transfers. Businesses or individual assets or liabilities that qualify as an Elevator Technology Business operation,
that have transferred subsequently to September 30, 2019 to the Elevator Technology Business, are still included

in the scope of combination with effect from October 1, 2016, in accordance with the above and below

Businesses as defined in accordance with IFRS 3 “Business Combinations” in analogy for transactions under

were included with their respective assets and liabilities as well as income and expenses in the Combined

Businesses that were acquired from a third party during the reporting periods of the Combined Financial
Statements were included from the date at which the thyssenkrupp Group gained control. Companies and
operating activities that constitute a business and that were not controlled by Elevator Technology Business
companies after the legal reorganization had been finalized, were excluded from the scope of combination for all
periods.

Assets and liabilities that do not constitute a business in accordance with IFRS 3 that were acquired or disposed
of by entities that were part of the Elevator Technology Business during the reporting periods of the Combined
Financial Statements were included in or excluded from these financial statements as of the date of the
transaction. Leased assets which will be legally transferred from the thyssenkrupp Group to the thyssenkrupp ET
Group after the closing of the transaction, remained treated as leased assets in the Combined Financial

Operating activities that represent business operations that have been transferred as part of the legal
reorganization to an existing or newly formed Elevator Technology company but historically were part of a legal
entity that has remained in the remaining thyssenkrupp Group, were included in the scope of combination for all
periods presented. These transfers to existing or newly formed Elevator Technology companies have been part of
a “linked transaction”, according to IFRS 10.B97, that was closed as of December 31, 2019. For these Elevator
Technology Business operating activities, separate IFRS financial information were prepared and appropriately
included in the Combined Financial Statements. For the purposes of the Combined Financial Statements, income,
expenses, assets and liabilities were attributed and allocated to the relevant Elevator Technology Business
operating activities. Assets and liabilities as well as income and expenses were attributed directly or, where this
was not possible, indirectly with the help of appropriate allocation keys (for example on the basis of employee

Legal transfers to/from the Company or its direct and indirect subsidiaries during the reporting periods or after

Legal transfers to the Company or its direct and indirect subsidiaries during the reporting periods or after
September 30, 2019 but before or on December 31, 2019, that entirely relate to assets and liabilities or
obligations are referred to in the following as “asset deals” and the Elevator Technology Business operating
activities concerned as “asset deal companies”.

A full list of the companies and Elevator Technology Business operating activities included in the scope of
combination of the Combined Financial Statements is provided in Note 03 of the notes to the Combined
Financial Statements.

**Treatment of share deal companies in the Combined Financial Statements**

Separate financial statements or reporting packages were drawn up for share deal companies and are included in
the Combined Financial Statements. They also include liquidity and financial obligations as well as financial
assets or liabilities from central cash pooling agreements with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group along with the
respective interest income and expense. Any relevant income, expenses, assets and liabilities relating to business
activities initially reported in these entities but not forming part of the Elevator Technology Business were
excluded when preparing the separate financial statements or reporting packages for the Combined Financial
Statements.

**Treatment of asset deal companies in the Combined Financial Statements**

For purposes of the Combined Financial Statements, the relevant income, expenses, assets and liabilities of asset
deal companies were attributed to the Elevator Technology Business. Liquid assets, financial obligations and
financial assets or liabilities from cash pooling agreements with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group were not
attributed or allocated to the Elevator Technology Business because such assets or liabilities are not legally
attributable to the Elevator Technology Business, nor do legal claims or obligations exist towards the remaining
thyssenkrupp Group in these cases. Accordingly, no interest income or expense pertaining to such items was
reflected in the combined statements of profit or loss.

The Elevator Technology Business have obtained controlling, accounting, human resources, IT and infrastructure
services from thyssenkrupp Group service companies, such as thyssenkrupp Regional Services Germany GmbH,
Essen, Germany.

In addition, holding companies such as thyssenkrupp AG have provided various central services including
governance to the Elevator Technology Business. These services were historically reported within the business
area Corporate in the thyssenkrupp Group and will either be transferred to the Elevator Technology Business as
part of the legal reorganization or will be provided as a service under transitional service agreements subsequent
to the legal reorganization.

The respective income and costs for such services, that were historically recharged to the Elevator Technology
Business, have been included in the combined statement of profit or loss at their historical amounts. Where
income and costs for such services were historically not recharged but were essential to the operational business
of the Elevator Technology Business were either directly attributed or, where this was not possible, allocated
using appropriate allocation keys and are reflected in the Combined Financial Statements at their historical cost.

Furthermore, assets or liabilities relating to administrative services, service companies or the central activities of
the holding companies pertained to the Elevator Technology Business were attributed in the Combined Financial
Statements based on the legal reorganization principle. Shared assets relating to such holding companies that did
not legally transfer to the Elevator Technology Business were not included in the combined statements of
financial position of the Elevator Technology Business. However, for such an appropriate usage charge was
reflected in the Combined Financial Statements in the reporting periods. For shared assets relating to such
holding companies that did legally transfer to the Elevator Technology Business, were included in the combined
statements of financial position of the Elevator Technology Business. The usage by the remaining thyssenkrupp
Group was accounted for by way of appropriate usage income charges to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group in
the reporting periods.

**Presentation of the Combined Financial Statements as well as combination and consolidation principles**

The transfers of businesses between the Elevator Technology Business and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group
were qualified as transactions under common control. The Elevator Technology Business applied the predecessor
accounting approach in accordance with IDW RS HFA 2 by carrying forward the historical carrying amounts
recorded by the thyssenkrupp Group.

All income, expenses, assets and liabilities that are attributable to the economic operations of the Elevator
Technology Business and that are included in the legal reorganization process are reflected in the Combined
Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business.

For periods within the overall reporting period from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2019 there was no
requirement to prepare consolidated financial statements, since the Elevator Technology Business did not
constitute a legal group of entities in accordance with IFRS 10 “Consolidated Financial Statements”. As a result,
the companies or operating activities were combined. The carrying amounts of the investments and the respective
share of any parent company in the equity of its subsidiaries, which are both part of the Elevator Technology
Business were treated in accordance with the relevant IFRS requirements. Profit or loss transfers with the
remaining thyssenkrupp Group have been treated as contribution/withdrawal from/to the remaining thyssenkrupp
Group.

The Combined Financial Statements also include joint ventures accounted for using the equity method and other
investments held at historical cost. The carrying amounts of companies accounted for using the equity method

were adjusted annually by the percentage of any changes in their equity corresponding to the Elevator

Intercompany balances and transactions within the Elevator Technology Business along with all gains and losses
from transactions within the Elevator Technology Business were eliminated for purposes of the Combined

During the preparation of the Combined Financial Statements, deferred income tax effects on carve-out entries
were recognized as set out in more detail below.

**Combined statement of cash flows**

Operating transactions of the Elevator Technology Business with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group are reported
in the cash flows from operating activities. Financing transactions (in particular cash pooling) of the Elevator
Technology Business with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group are presented in the cash flows from financing
activities (for more details see Note 31).

The advance payments made for the test tower in Rottweil, Germany, and the multifunctional building in
Neuhausen, Germany, as well as the paid one-time fee for the thyssenkrupp brand are presented in the cash flows
from investing activities (for more details see Note 22), whereas any related proceeds from loans are presented in
the cash flows from financing activities.

The transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group also include cash inflows and outflows in connection
with control and profit or loss transfer agreements between the Elevator Technology Business companies and
remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies, capital contributions and transfers from reserves in connection with
the reorganization under corporate law as well as tax receivables, tax liabilities and deferred taxes presented as
contributions or withdrawals under the separate tax return approach (see the detailed explanation below).

Services recharged by the holding companies were also presented within operating cash flow in the same way as
tax charges and benefits under the separate tax return approach.

**Goodwill**

Historical goodwill arising on acquisitions within the thyssenkrupp Group was consistently allocated and
reported in the Cash Generating Units that are expected to benefit from the synergies of the acquisition. The
goodwill for the Combined Financial Statements was in turn assigned to the Elevator Technology Business on
the basis of the extraction method, i.e. where it was historically allocated. Therefore, only goodwill directly
related to the Elevator Technology Business is reflected in the Combined Financial Statements.

**thyssenkrupp brand**

In the periods up to September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business was using the thyssenkrupp brand
under an operating licensing model for which it incurred expenses recognized directly in profit or loss in other
expenses. As of September30, 2019, as part of the proposed IPO the Elevator Technology Business had entered
into a new license agreement with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group for the right to use the thyssenkrupp brand
for certain classified classes relevant for the Elevator Technology Business in exchange for a one-time fee and
with no other recurring expenses after September 30, 2019 (hereafter “new license agreement”). This license has
been recognized as an intangible asset with indefinite useful life in accordance with IAS 38 “Intangible Assets”
as of September 30, 2019. Historically recognized expenses for the use of the brand remain within the Combined
Financial Statements for the periods up to September 30, 2019.

Based on the Executive Board’s decision as of February 27, 2020 to sell the entire Elevator Technology Business
the above described new license agreement, entered into on September 30, 2019, was amended in March 2020
via an addendum agreement, since the governance model in the new license agreement was only suitable with an
IPO. In substance, the terms and conditions of the addendum agreement lead to a limitation of the initially agreed
indefinite useful life.

The terms of the addendum agreement become effective subject to the condition precedent of all closing
conditions of the transaction being fulfilled and will result in the repayment of the initially agreed fully paid up

one-time fee in the amount of €1,080 million reduced by a fixed amount of €99 million for the use of the brand

period of no longer than 18 months after closing was agreed. Both, the amount receivable and the amount
payable, are due immediately prior to closing. With the signing of the addendum agreement the intangible asset

effects of the addendum display a non-adjusting event after the reporting period presented (also refer to Note 32).

**Pensions and similar obligations**

The Combined Financial Statements include the pension obligations and plan assets directly attributable to the
Elevator Technology Business. The obligations and plan assets have been valued on the basis of expert actuarial
reports.

In the case of Elevator Technology companies (share deal companies), both active employees and retirees have
been included. In the case of operating activities to be transferred (asset deal companies), only active employees,
which have been assigned to the Elevator Technology Business in the relevant periods have been included.

The actual transfer of the employees and the associated actual transfer of their benefit entitlements may be
subject to local requirements or the consent of the employees and may, therefore, differ from the obligations
presented in the Combined Financial Statements. The transfer of the employees into Elevator Technology
companies have been completed by December 31, 2019. The associated pension obligations have been
determined on an individual basis.

Only plan assets that have been part of the Elevator Technology Business until the completion of the legal
reorganization have been included in the Combined Financial Statements.

The actuarial valuation was based on thyssenkrupp Group parameters and where necessary adjusted for Elevator
Technology Business specifics. Actuarial reports as of September 30, 2019, September 30, 2018, September 30,
2017 and October 1, 2016 under IAS 19 “Employee Benefits” were commissioned for material Elevator
Technology Business operating activities.

**Hedging**

The Elevator Technology Business uses derivative financial instruments, including foreign currency forward
contracts and foreign currency options to reduce its exposure to foreign currency risk. The Combined Financial
Statements include all hedges directly attributable to the Elevator Technology Business.

These derivatives are all entered into with counterparties within the thyssenkrupp Group. Of these derivatives,
some are designated as hedging instruments for hedge accounting purposes. All hedge documentation for this has
historically already been documented at a local level, i.e. where the hedged risk exists. As such, for the
Combined Financial Statements, all hedge accounting previously recorded can be maintained.

In the Combined Financial Statements any hedging relationships between the Elevator Technology Business and
the remaining thyssenkrupp Group will be presented and accounted for as with related parties (for more details
see Note 22).

**Share-based compensation**

Employees of the Elevator Technology Business participated in share-based compensation programs of the
thyssenkrupp Group. These are classified as cash-settled in line with the specific requirements for share-based
payment transactions among group entities. The expenses and obligations arising from share-based compensation
were historically recognized and reported in the financial statements of those companies which incurred the
personnel expenses and also settled the obligations for their employees. For more details see Note 13.

For the purposes of the Combined Financial Statements, this means that expenses were already correctly included
in the reporting financial statements of share deal companies and no changes to the classification of the programs
was necessary. For expenses and obligations related to employees that are part of the Elevator Technology
Business but that were not part of a share deal company, however, the costs and obligations were included in the
Combined Financial Statements with no changes to the classification so long as the contractual obligation to
settle the shared-based payment liability has been transferred to an Elevator Technology Business company as
part of the legal reorganization.
