**15 Provisions for employee benefits and other provisions (Continued)**

are non-current. Provisions of €259 million (2018: €220 million; 2017: €223 million) have a remaining term of
more than one year.

Provisions for employee compensation and benefit costs primarily represent employment anniversary bonuses
and obligations for the management incentive plans, while social plan and related costs pertaining to personnel
related structural measures are reflected in the provision for restructuring activities. Pension related obligations
for partial retirement agreements and early retirement programs, partly resulting from restructurings, are part of
the provision for pensions and similar obligations.

Product warranties and product defects represent the Elevator Technology Business’s responsibility for the
proper functioning of the goods sold (product warranty) as well as the obligation that arise from the use of the
products sold (product defect).

Provisions for other contractual costs represent pending losses from uncompleted contracts.

The provision for restructurings consists of provisions for employee termination benefits and exit costs which
have been established by operating divisions for costs incurred in connection with activities which do not
generate any future economic benefits for the Elevator Technology Business. Restructurings are being carried out
in all business units.

Other provisions include provisions for environmental obligations and other risks from individual items not
allocable to other positions.

The following items are included in provisions for litigation risks and other risks:

**Year ended Sept. 30, 2017**

In connection with the Elevator cartel, potentially injured parties asserted claims for damages against
thyssenkrupp AG and companies of the thyssenkrupp Group in and out of court. Some of the claims have not yet
been quantified. The legal proceedings are pending in Germany, Belgium, Austria and the Netherlands and are at
various stages; in some cases proceedings have already been mutually settled, claims have been withdrawn or
were dismissed. The Elevator Technology Business has set aside provisions for those pending claims which, in
its opinion, will probably lead to cash outflows.

Provisions include retentions on insured claims of four users of the Elevator Technology Business products in the
USA requesting individual damage payments for severe injuries and—in one case—fatality.

**Year ended Sept. 30, 2018**

In connection with the Elevator cartel, potentially injured parties asserted claims for damages against
thyssenkrupp AG and companies of the thyssenkrupp Group in and out of court. Some of the claims have not yet
been quantified. The legal proceedings are pending in Belgium, Austria and the Netherlands and are at various
stages; in some cases proceedings have already been mutually settled, claims have been withdrawn or were
dismissed. The Elevator Technology Business has set aside provisions for those pending claims which, in its
opinion, will probably lead to cash outflows.

Provisions include retentions on insured claims of four users of the Elevator Technology Business products in the
USA requesting individual damage payments for severe injuries and—in one case—fatality.

The Elevator Technology Business faces a law suit relating to the architectural planning and execution of new
headquarter building in the Middle East.

**Year ended Sept. 30, 2019**

In connection with the Elevator cartel, potentially injured parties asserted claims for damages against
thyssenkrupp AG and companies of the thyssenkrupp Group in and out of court. Some of the claims have not yet
been quantified. The legal proceedings are pending in Belgium, Austria and the Netherlands and are at various
stages; in some cases proceedings have already been mutually settled, claims have been withdrawn or were
dismissed. The Elevator Technology Business has set aside provisions for those pending claims which, in its
opinion, will probably lead to cash outflows.

Provisions include retentions on insured claims of two users of the Elevator Technology Business products in the
USA requesting individual damage payments for severe injuries.

The Elevator Technology Business has contingencies for the following material legal disputes:

**Year ended Sept. 30, 2017**

Creditors of a former owner of an acquired business in Brazil claim reversal of the acquisition in order to access
the acquired assets for satisfaction of claims against the former owner.

A Chinese customer sues the Elevator Technology Business for delays in elevator installation and claims damage
payments for increased construction cost.

South Korean employees claim adjustment of calculations of ordinary wages.

**Year ended Sept. 30, 2018**

Creditors of a former owner of an acquired business in Brazil claim reversal of the acquisition in order to access
the acquired assets for satisfaction of claims against the former owner.

**Year ended Sept. 30, 2019**

Creditors of a former owner of an acquired business in Brazil claim reversal of the acquisition in order to access
the acquired assets for satisfaction of claims against the former owner.

The Elevator Technology Business is in dispute with a French customer over liquidated damages relating to
defective products and delays.

In addition further legal and arbitration actions and official investigations and proceedings have been filed
against Elevator Technology companies or may be initiated or filed in the future. Disputes in connection with the
acquisition or disposal of companies or company units may lead to partial repayment of the purchase price or to
the payment of damages or to tax charges. Furthermore, damage claims may be payable to contractual partners,
customers, consortium partners and subcontractors under performance contracts. Predicting the progress and
results of lawsuits involves considerable difficulties and uncertainties. This means that lawsuits, official
investigations and proceedings as well as claims not disclosed separately could also individually or together with
other legal disputes, official investigations and proceedings as well as claims have a negative and also potentially
major future impact on the Elevator Technology Business’s net assets, financial position and results of operations
of the Elevator Technology Business. However, at present the Elevator Technology Business does not expect
pending lawsuits, official investigations and proceedings as well as claims not explained separately in this section
to have a major negative impact on the Elevator Technology Business’s net assets, financial position and results
of operations.

measured at fair value, the fair value equals the carrying amount less impairment losses recognized in other
comprehensive income.

Equity and debt instruments are in general measured at fair value, which is based to the extent available on
market prices as of the balance sheet date. When no quoted market prices in an active market are available,
equity and debt instruments are measured by discounting future cash flows based on current market interest rates
over the remaining term of the financial instruments.

The fair value of foreign currency forward transactions is determined on the basis of the middle spot exchange
rate applicable as of the balance sheet date, and taking account of forward premiums or discounts arising for the
respective remaining contract term compared to the contracted forward exchange rate. Common methods for
calculating option prices are used for foreign currency options. The fair value of an option is influenced not only
by the remaining term of an option, but also by other factors, such as current amount and volatility of the
underlying exchange or base rate.

The carrying amounts of trade accounts receivable and other current liabilities equal their fair values due to the
short remaining terms. The fair value of fixed rate long-term financial liabilities equals the present value of

The fair value hierarchy reflects the significance of the inputs used to determine fair values. Financial
instruments with fair value measurement based on quoted prices in active markets are disclosed in level 1. In
level 2 determination of fair values is based on observable inputs, e.g. foreign exchange rates. Level 3 comprises
financial instruments for which the fair value measurement is based on unobservable inputs using recognized
valuation models.

In the reporting year there were no reclassifications between level 1 and level 2.

**Derivatives that do not qualify for hedge accounting**

If a hedging relationship does not meet the requirements for hedge accounting in accordance with the conditions
under IFRS 9 (previous years: IAS 39) or hedge accounting is economically not reasonable, the derivative
financial instrument is recognized as a derivative that does not qualify for hedge accounting. The resulting
impact on profit or loss is shown in the table on net gains and losses from financial instruments by measurement
categories. This item also includes embedded derivatives. They exist in the Elevator Technology Business in the
way that regular supply and service transactions with suppliers and customers abroad are not concluded in the
functional currency (local currency) of either contracting parties.

**Financial risks**

Being a global business, the Elevator Technology Business is exposed to financial risks in the form of credit risks
(default risk), liquidity risks and market risks (foreign currency and interest rate risks) during the course of
ordinary activities. The aim of risk management is to limit the risks arising from operating activities and
associated financing requirements by applying selected derivate and non-derivative hedging instruments. Within
the framework of risk management, financial risks and credit risks must be avoided as far as possible,
compensated by a risk portfolio, passed on to third parties or limited (principle of risk aversion).

**Credit risk**

Credit risk (default risk) is the risk of the Elevator Technology Business incurring financial losses due to the
non-fulfillment or partial fulfillment of existing debt obligations. Credit risk management is governed by
corporate guidelines. Companies and business operating activities of the Elevator Technology Business are
required to implement credit risk management in accordance with these guidelines.

In order to minimize default risks (credit risks) from the use of financial instruments, such transactions are only
concluded with counterparties that meet our internal minimum requirements of the Elevator Technology
Business. Predominantly, the Elevator Technology Business concludes its financial instruments currently and in
the future with thyssenkrupp AG. Therefore, thyssenkrupp AG represents the main counterparty subject to credit
risk.

The Elevator Technology Business generally secures default risks with suitable advance and progress payments.
Only in seldom cases, in case that a credit risk analysis provides a higher default risk, letters of credit and
payment guarantees from banks, insurance companies and management companies are requested. In order to
minimize default risks from operating activities, the corporate guidelines provide for the assessment of default
risk based on the risk profile of the business partner using suitable internal and, where available, external
information, such as ratings and credit reports, and the estimation of a financial risk exposure of the respective
business transaction from the Elevator Technology Business perspective. The Elevator Technology Business
takes a credit decision for each business transaction with each business partner using the aforementioned
approach. Taking into account the individual characteristics of its customer structures and business models, the
Elevator Technology Business lays down clear process rules for determining which measures are to be taken in
the event of payment default in order to mitigate the maximum default risk as far as possible.

Transactions whose value exceeds specified materiality thresholds, especially in the area of major sales contracts,
also require prior approval at the different management levels inside the Elevator Technology Business. Among
other things, the amount and hedging of default risks are assessed.

**Maturity analysis**

Liquidity risk is the risk that the Elevator Technology Business is unable to meet its existing or future obligations
due to insufficient availability of cash or cash equivalents.

**Sensitivity analysis**

Market risk is the risk that fair values or future cash flows of non-derivative or derivative financial instruments
will fluctuate due to changes in risk factors. Among market risks relevant to the Elevator Technology Business
are foreign currency and interest rate risks. Associated with these risks are fluctuations in income, equity and
cash flow.

The following analyses and amounts determined by means of sensitivity analyses represent hypothetical, futureoriented data that can differ from actual outcomes because of unforeseeable developments in financial markets.
Moreover, non-financial or non-quantifiable risks, such as business risks, are not considered here.

F-107


-----

**Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued)**

**21 Financial instruments (Continued)**

**Foreign currency risk exposure—Foreign currency hedging is used to fix prices on the basis of hedging rates as**
protection against any unfavorable exchange rate fluctuations in the future. Hedging periods are generally based
on the maturities of underlying transactions. Foreign currency derivative contracts usually have maturities of
twelve months or less, but can also be up to six years in single exceptional cases.

The US dollar is the only relevant risk variable for sensitivity analyses under IFRS 7, as the vast majority of
foreign currency cash flows occurs in US dollars. As hedging transactions are generally used to hedge underlying
transactions, opposite effects in underlying and hedging transactions are almost entirely offset over the total
period. Thus, the currency risk exposure described here results from hedging relationships with off-balance sheet
underlying transactions, i.e. hedges of firm commitments and forecasted sales. Based on our analysis, the US
dollar exposure as of September 30, 2019 was as follows:

If the euro had been 10% stronger against the US dollar as of September 30, 2019, the hedge reserve in equity
and fair value of hedging transactions would have been €0 million (2018: €1 million; 2017: €2 million) higher
and earnings resulting from the measurement as of the balance sheet date €2 million (2018: €2 million; 2017: €2
million) higher. If the euro had been 10% weaker against the US dollar as of September 30, 2019, the hedge
reserve in equity and fair value of hedging transactions would have been €0 million (2018: €1 million; 2017: €3
million) lower and earnings resulting from the measurement as of the balance sheet date €3 million (2018:
€2 million; 2017: €4 million) lower.

**Interest rate risk—Interest rate instruments can result in cash flow risks, opportunity effects, as well as interest**
rate risks affecting the statement of financial position and earnings. Refinancing and variable-rate financial
instruments are subject to cash flow risk which expresses the uncertainty of future interest payments. Cash flow
risk is measured by means of cash flow sensitivity. Opportunity effects arise from non-derivatives, as these are
measured at amortized cost rather than fair value, in contrast to interest derivatives. This difference, the so-called
opportunity effect, affects neither the statement of financial position nor the statement of profit or loss.
Opportunity effects and interest rate risks affecting the statement of financial position and earnings are
determined by calculating fair value sensitivity analyses and changes.

As of September 30, 2019, a +100 /(20) basis point parallel shift in yield curves is assumed for all currencies in
interest analyses. The parallel downward shift is limited to (20) basis points to account for continued low interest
rates with in part negative interest rates. Negative interest rates are included in the current analysis. The analysis
results in the opportunities (positive values) and risks (negative values) shown in the following table:

**Other services**

In addition to the contractual services specified above, the remaining thyssenkrupp Group provided services to
the Elevator Technology Business through thyssenkrupp AG, service companies, and regional holding
companies. These companies principally furnish central corporate services, such as tax and legal, IT services,
corporate communications, personnel-related services, accounting, controlling, financial services and treasury.

The cost of such services provided by the remaining thyssenkrupp Group to the Elevator Technology Business
totaled €66 million in the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019 (2018: €71 million; 2017: €98 million).

Furthermore the allocation of the thyssenkrupp brand resulted in expenses of €142 million in the fiscal year
ended September 30, 2019 (2018: €139 million; 2017: €114 million). Effective September 30, 2019 the Elevator
Technology Business purchased the right to use the thyssenkrupp brand for certain classified sectors relevant for
the Elevator Technology Business for a purchase price of €1,080 million.

**Financing**

During the reporting periods, the Elevator Technology Business was integrated into the cash pooling and cash
management systems of the thyssenkrupp Group. Financial receivables and liabilities from/due to the
thyssenkrupp Group are presented without netting in the combined financial statements. The interest expenses
and interest income generated in connection with the financing activities with thyssenkrupp AG and the
remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies in fiscal year ended September 30, 2019 amounted to €26 million
(2018: €29 million; 2017: €45 million) and €57 million (2018: €55 million; 2017: €72 million), respectively.

**Leasing**

The Elevator Technology Business has entered into leasing transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group.
At the end of fiscal year 2018/2019, these consisted in particular of operating lease agreements and the finance
lease of the test tower in Rottweil with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group with respect to real estate.

The Elevator Technology Business entered into agreements to purchase the leased multifunctional building in
Neuhausen and the test tower in Rottweil conditional on the execution of the proposed IPO. As per the share
purchase agreement (hereafter “SPA”) as of February 27, 2020, the fulfillment of the conditional IPO has lapsed,
however, the parties to the SPA agreed in principle to execute the purchase of the properties in the same or a
similar manner as intended under the proposed IPO. The amendments of the contracts have yet not been signed
and will become effective before closing of the transaction. The assumed purchase prices amounting to a total of
€74 million were paid upfront in September 2019. Due to the uncertainty of the execution of the proposed IPO
and the economic substance of the payment, the purchase prices were recognized as financial assets in
accordance to IAS 32 “Financial Instruments: Presentation” and are presented in the cash flows from investing
activities in accordance with IAS 7.16(e) “Statements of Cash Flows”. With the proposed amendments of the
contracts the legal ownership of the test tower in Rottweil as well as the multifunctional building in Neuhausen
would be transferred to the thyssenkrupp ET Group as part of the proposed closing.

**Guarantees/surety bonds**

The thyssenkrupp Group has provided €1,287 million guarantees/surety bonds in favour of the Elevator
Technology Business as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €1,285 million; 2017: €1,195 million). Thereof
€85 million corporate guarantees as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €101 million; 2017: €100 million) and
€1,202 million bank guarantees/surety bonds as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €1,184 million; 2017: €1,095
million).

**23 Segment reporting**

The Elevator Technology Business offers global urban passenger transportation systems throughout the entire
lifecycle. The business units are in line with the internal organizational and reporting structure and represent the
segments in accordance with IFRS 8.

**Europe/Africa**

The business unit comprises the manufacturing, new installation, modernization and maintenance of elevators,
escalators and walkways for countries in Europe and Africa.

**Americas**

The business unit comprises the manufacturing, new installation, modernization and maintenance of elevators,
escalators and walkways for countries in North and South America.

**Asia/Pacific**

The business unit comprises the manufacturing, new installation, modernization and maintenance of elevators,
escalators and walkways for countries in the Middle East, Asia, Australia and New Zealand.

These three reportable segments mainly comprise the elevator and escalator business (excluding mobility home
solutions).

**Access Solutions**

The business unit manages globally customized mobility home solutions, i.e., the manufacturing, installation and
maintenance of stairlifts, home elevators and platform lifts as well as Passenger Boarding Bridges primarily for
the access to airplanes.

Additionally Corporate Elevator provides certain functions and services to the operating businesses of the
Elevator Technology Business, e.g., Financing, R&D, Providing IP, Recruiting, etc.

**Reconciliation**

Reconciliation comprises the consolidation as well as effects resulting from allocations of thyssenkrupp AG.
Consolidation essentially contains the elimination of intercompany profits in inventories and the reversal of

intercompany interest income. The allocations of thyssenkrupp AG include corporate costs and non-operational
effects that were historically recorded on parent company level and previously not allocated or charged to the
Elevator Technology Business.

The accounting principles for the segments are the same as those described for the Elevator Technology Business
in the summary of significant accounting principles.

Elevator Technology Business’s key earnings performance indicator is adjusted EBIT (Earnings Before Interest
and Taxes). Adjusted EBIT is calculated according to economic criteria and is independent from IFRS rules. It
provides information on the profitability of a unit and contains all elements of the income statement relating to
operating performance. This also includes items of financial income/expense that can be characterized as
operational, including income and expense from investments where there is a long-term intention to hold the
assets. It is adjusted for special items, i.e. excluding disposal losses/gains from M&A, restructuring expenses,
impairment losses/impairment reversals and other non-operating expenses and income. It is more suitable for
comparing operating performance over several periods.

Operating net working capital is the key indicator for measuring liquidity and solvency in operating activities. It
is primarily comprised of inventories, trade accounts receivable, trade accounts payable and net advance
payments.

**32 Subsequent events (Continued)**

**Other relevant events**

 - In connection with the elevator cartel, potentially injured parties have asserted claims for damages against
thyssenkrupp AG and companies of the thyssenkrupp Group in and out of court. Since September 30, 2019
further claims have been quantified in the ongoing course of the legal proceedings, which has not led to a
change in the risk assessment and recorded provisions. A majority of the proceedings have now been dealt
with through settlement, withdrawal or dismissal of the claims. Legal cases are still pending in Austria,
Belgium and the Netherlands. They are at different stages of proceedings. thyssenkrupp has recognized
provisions for the portion of the pending claims which thyssenkrupp believes will probably result in cash
outflows.

 - The Company received €820 million from thyssenkrupp Nederland Holding B.V. as capital contribution on
December 18, 2019.

 - As of January 16, 2020, the thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH changed its legal form into a German
stock corporation and has been renamed to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG. The control and profit or loss transfer
agreements (Beherrschungs- und Gewinnabführungsverträge) between the thyssenkrupp ET Group and
thyssenkrupp AG as well as other thyssenkrupp Group companies have been terminated on December 31,
2019.

 - As of February 11, 2020, thyssenkrupp Industrials Finance Germany GmbH, Essen, Germany has been
transferred to the thyssenkrupp ET Group and as of February 18, 2020 has been merged into the Company.

 - In 2011 the state of Delaware initiated an audit of certain entities within the scope of combination to
determine their compliance with the Delaware Escheats laws, also known as abandoned and unclaimed
property laws. A provision in connection with this matter was recognized for certain legal entities within the
scope of combination. As a result of the current negotiations with the state of Delaware the related provision
was reduced by a double digit € million amount after balance sheet date. This revaluation of the provision
displays a non-adjusting event after the reporting period presented.

 - Since January 2020, there is a progressive global spread of the COVID-19 pandemic resulting in various
actions – including lockdowns – that have been taken by governments all over the world in order to contain
and to control the virus. COVID-19 impacted the markets and facilities in multiple ways, depending on the
local exposure to the virus and the measures taken by local governments:

The elevator and escalator business (segments Europe/Africa, Americas and Asia/Pacific) was affected to
varying degrees. Nevertheless, the effect of the COVID-19 was felt in all regions, leading to complete
lockdowns in some regions and milder restrictions in others. Although production came to a temporary
standstill in some countries, most of the production facilities are currently operating and in the process of
recovering. In most countries production capacities in our core factories have almost recovered to
pre-pandemic levels.

The Access Solutions business (segment Access Solutions) was affected in both business lines, Home
Solutions and Airport Solutions. Activities for Home Solutions have been operated at a lower level with
partial temporary shut downs of production facilities but are recovering constantly. The partial or complete
shutdown of most airports has led to a decrease of New Installation and Service operations due to
postponements and suspensions of some projects.

The COVID-19 pandemic is considered as a triggering event for an impairment test of goodwill per
March 31, 2020. Therefore, the operational planning of Elevator Technology was tested for validity against
the background of the COVID-19 pandemic and, in effect, the recoverability of goodwill of the Elevator
Technology Business was not classified as critical. Furthermore, other intangible assets and property, plant
and equipment were also tested for impairment per March 31, 2020 which did not result in any impairment
losses for the Elevator Technology Business. Based on the uncertain progress of the COVID-19 pandemic, it
cannot yet reasonably be predicted to what extent the pandemic will affect the future financial position and
results of operations of the Elevator Technology Business. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic the
accumulated ADJ EBIT of the Elevator Technology Business is currently slightly below the budgeted
expectations.

**Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued)**

**32 Subsequent events (Continued)**

 - Based on the Executive Board’s decision as of February 27, 2020 to sell the entire Elevator Technology
Business the new license agreement regarding the thyssenkrupp brand, entered into on September 30, 2019,
was amended in March 2020 via an addendum agreement, since the governance model in the new license
agreement was only suitable with an IPO. In substance, the terms and conditions of the addendum
agreement lead to a limitation of the initially agreed indefinite useful life.

The terms of the addendum agreement become effective subject to the condition precedent of all closing
conditions of the transaction being fulfilled and will result in the repayment of the initially agreed fully paid
up one-time fee in the amount of €1,080 million reduced by a fixed amount of €99 million for the use of the
brand starting October 1, 2019 until closing. In addition a fixed amount of €74 million for the use of the
brand for the period of no longer than 18 months after closing was agreed. Both, the amount receivable and
the amount payable, are due immediately prior to closing. With the signing of the addendum agreement the
intangible asset for the right of use of the thyssenkrupp brand will be classified as held for sale in
accordance with IFRS 5.

 - On February 27, 2020, the Executive Board’s decision to sell its entire Elevator Technology Business to a
consortium of Advent, Cinven and the RAG foundation was approved by the Supervisory Board of
thyssenkrupp AG. The purchase price (assuming closing of the transaction at June 30, 2020) is €17.2 billion.
The purchase agreement has been signed in February 2020. The closing of the transaction is subject to
merger control approvals, although thyssenkrupp continues to expect no concerns from the responsible
authorities. Even under the circumstances of the COVID-19 pandemic, the closing of the transaction is
expected by the end of the current fiscal year. Thyssenkrupp AG will reinvest part of the purchase price
(€1.25 billion) in a stake in the Elevator Technology Business.

 - During the 1st half ended March 31, 2020, the Elevator Technology Business reported restructuring costs
amounting to €14 million in the business units Europe/Africa and Americas.

**INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT**

To thyssenkrupp Elevator AG, Essen

**Qualified Opinion**

We have audited the combined financial statements which comprise the combined statements of financial
position as at 30 September 2019, 2018 and 2017, and the combined statements of profit or loss, combined
statements of comprehensive income, combined statements of cash flows and combined statements of changes in
equity for the years then ended, and notes to the combined financial statements, including a summary of
significant accounting policies (together the “Combined Financial Statements”), for the business set out in
note Note 01 Basis of preparation to the Combined Financial Statements (the “Elevator Technology Business”).

In our opinion, except for the possible effects of the matter described in the “Basis for qualified opinion” section
of our report, the accompanying Combined Financial Statements give a true and fair view of the financial
position of the Elevator Technology Business as at 30 September 2019, 2018 and 2017, and of its financial
performance and its cash flows for the years then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting
Standards, as adopted by the European Union (“EU-IFRS”).

**Basis for qualified opinion**

The Elevator Technology Business includes among others certain entities located in Latin America comprising
the Operating Unit Spanish Latin America which are outlined in Note 01 Basis of preparation to the Combined
Financial Statements. These entities represent about 1.9 %, 1.6 % and 1.9 % of total sales, about 2.2 %, 2.5 %
and 1.9 % of total assets and about -5.0 %, 0.7 % and 0.8 % of total net income of the Elevator Technology
Business as of and for the years ended 30 September 2019, 2018 and 2017 respectively. Due to issues regarding
the local bookkeeping and financial reporting processes which led to qualified, adverse or disclaimer of opinions
on the financial information of these entities in several instances as at 30 September 2018 and 2017 and for the
years then ended we were not able to obtain sufficient information and evidence required to assess the existence,
completeness, valuation and cut-off of the assets and liabilities as well as the income and expense of these
subsidiaries. As a result, we were unable to determine whether any adjustments were necessary in respect of
these amounts included in the Combined Financial Statements as at 30 September 2018 and 2017 and for the
years ended 30 September 2018 and 2017. Additionally, since we were unable to determine whether the
combined statement of financial position as at 30 September 2018 give a true and fair view of the financial
position, we were consequently unable to determine whether adjustments might have been necessary in respect of
the profit for the year ended 30 September 2019 in the combined statements of profit and loss, comprehensive
income and changes in equity as well as in respect of the net cash flows reported in the combined statement of
cash flows for the year ended 30 September 2019.

We conducted our audit in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (ISAs). Our responsibilities
under those standards are further described in the “Auditor’s responsibilities for the audit of the Combined
Financial Statements” section of our report. We are independent of the entities included in the Elevator
Technology Business in accordance with the ethical requirements that are relevant to our audit of the Combined
Financial Statements in Germany, and we have fulfilled our other ethical responsibilities in accordance with
these requirements. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide
a basis for our qualified opinion.

**Emphasis of matter—Basis of accounting**

We draw attention to the fact that, as described in note Note 01 Basis of preparation to the Combined Financial
Statements, the Elevator Technology Business included in the Combined Financial Statements has not operated
as a separate stand-alone group of entities. These Combined Financial Statements are, therefore, not necessarily
indicative of results that would have occurred if the Elevator Technology Business had operated as a separate
stand-alone group of entities during the years presented or of future results of the Elevator Technology Business.
Our opinion is not modified in respect of this matter.

**Responsibilities of management and those charged with governance for the Combined Financial**
**Statements**

Management is responsible for the preparation of Combined Financial Statements that give a true and fair view in
accordance with EU-IFRS, and for such internal control as management determines is necessary to enable the
preparation of Combined Financial Statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.

F-127


-----

In preparing the Combined Financial Statements, management is responsible for assessing the ability of the
Elevator Technology Business to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going
concern and using the going concern basis of accounting unless management either intends to liquidate the
Elevator Technology Business or to cease operations, or has no realistic alternative but to do so.

Those charged with governance are responsible for overseeing the financial reporting process of the Elevator
Technology Business.

**Auditor’s responsibilities for the audit of the Combined Financial Statements**

Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the Combined Financial Statements as a whole
are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that includes
our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in
accordance with ISAs will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from
fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected
to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these Combined Financial Statements.

As part of an audit in accordance with ISAs, we exercise professional judgment and maintain professional
scepticism throughout the audit. We also:

 - Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the Combined Financial Statements, whether due to
fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtain audit evidence that
is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. The risk of not detecting a material
misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve
collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control.

 - Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are
appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the
Elevator Technology Business’ internal control.

 - Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and
related disclosures made by management.

 - Conclude on the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based
on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may
cast significant doubt on the ability of the Elevator Technology Business to continue as a going concern. If
we conclude that a material uncertainty exists, we are required to draw attention in our auditor’s report to
the related disclosures in the Combined Financial Statements or, if such disclosures are inadequate, to
modify our opinion. Our conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of our auditor’s
report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Elevator Technology Business to cease to
continue as a going concern.

 - Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the Combined Financial Statements, including the
disclosures, and whether the Combined Financial Statements represent the underlying transactions and
events in a manner that achieves fair presentation.

 - Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or business
activities within the Elevator Technology Business to express an opinion on the Combined Financial
Statements. We are responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the audit. We remain
solely responsible for our audit opinion.

We communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and
timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control that we
identify during our audit.
